When it comes to film festivals, Tribeca isn't enough for Robert De Niro. As Dave Itzkoff relates on our sister blog ArtsBeat, Mr. De Niro, a co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, will serve as president of the jury for the 64th annual Cannes Film Festival, which will be May 11-22.
City Room Fraunces Tavern is back in business. -Nick Fox

On a side street in Long Island City, Queens, young people in artful dishabille ducked through the doorway of a factory marked Alfred Mainzer Inc. Greeting Cards on Wednesday night. Inside, they headed down a rabbit hole of sorts - a hallway with a beamed ceiling so low you had to stoop - into a very odd world.

Yes, Robert De Niro is already a co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, but do you want to be the one to tell him he can't be involved in more than one cinematic gala at a time? The organizers of the Cannes Film Festival clearly didn't mind Mr. De Niro's other affiliation, announcing on Thursday that he will serve as the president of the jury for its coming 64th annual run, which will be May 11-22. Mr. De Niro, the quintessential New York actor whose films run the gamut from "Mean Streets" to "Little Fockers," served as the president of the Cannes jury twice in the 1980s, and starred in two films that won the festival's Palme d'or prize: Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," in 1976, and Roland Joffe's "Mission," in 1986.

Some of the most compelling first-person accounts of family caregiving I've ever read come from the "Narrative Matters'' section of the policy journal Health Affairs. Often these stories are written by medical professionals who have found all of their training and expertise useless when faced with responsibility for a parent or spouse. What they thought they knew they didn't, and what they did know got lost in the emotional upheaval of caring for a loved one rather than a patient.

I see that various people, including Ryan Avent, are going on about how Texas is a great success story of this recession despite an unemployment rate about the same as New York's. I think what's going on is a misunderstanding of the difference between trends and cycles.

After all the attention generated by his list of top movies of 2010, Quentin Tarantino is now sheepishly admitting he forgot one: "Somewhere," directed by his friend (and ex) Sofia Coppola, which received the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival under his watch as president of the jury. The folks at Vulture contacted Mr. Tarantino to ask him about the omission. "I'm a little embarrassed by it, actually," he told them, explaining that he did not include the films from Venice in his considerations because "the world knows how I feel about those films already." Mr. Tarantino was also surprised by how much attention his list generated. "If I'd known it was going to get out, I'd have put it in my top 10," he said.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

Though he started out in advertising in Manhattan, Eric Monkaba has always had a bit of wanderlust. While vacationing in Morocco a few years back, Monkaba shared a taxi in the High Atlas Mountains with a few British tour managers who opened his eyes to a different career path. Soon enough he was leading tours through the deserts of Egypt, Jordan and Morocco. After studying Arabic at the University of Damascus and a stint working with street children in Yemen, he started Backpacker Concierge, a personalized travel consultancy specializing in responsible tourism in the Middle East, mainly in Egypt and Jordan.

More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad O'Connor, the New York Times "Really?" columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

Once a year, Hong Kong's largest, longest-lived artist's colony throws an open day in Fo Tan, an industrial neighborhood near suburban Sha Tin. This year marks the 10th anniversary of the event, the Fotanian Open Studios, on Jan. 8, 9, 15 and 16. The Wah Luen Industrial Center (15-21 Wong Chuk Yeung Street) is the epicenter, with other studios in neighboring warehouse buildings. A map designed to guide visitors through the show is available.

Larry Fink, born in 1941, started taking photographs as an adolescent. His work has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, among others, and he was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1976. His books include "Social Graces" (1984, reissued 2001), "Boxing" (1997), "Runway" (2000) and "The Vanities: Hollywood Parties 2000-2009," which will be published this year by Schirmer/Mosel. He is a professor of photography at Bard College. This conversation, with Adriana Teresa, the co-founder of FotoVisura and the publisher of Visura Magazine, has been edited and condensed.

A new edition of "Huckleberry Finn" removes the 219 uses of the word "nigger" in the novel and replaces them with "slave." The professor who proposed the idea said he did it because he was hesitant to pronounce the word when he was teaching the book, and because he wanted an edition "not for scholars, but for younger people and general readers." What do you think about tinkering with a literary classic like this? Have you studied "Huck" in school? How did your teacher handle the language?

More than five weeks after his musical, ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' began preview performances on Broadway, U2's lead singer, Bono, saw the show for the first time on Tuesday night, gauging audience reaction while assessing for himself what is and isn't working in the $65 million spectacle. Bono and the Edge, U2's lead guitarist, were the original creative forces when the ''Spider-Man'' project began nine years ago, and they wrote the music and lyrics for the show, their Broadway debut. The U2 mates recently returned from a string of concerts in New Zealand and Australia; the Edge, who lives in New York and had already seen ''Spider-Man,'' joined Bono for the performance on Tuesday at the Foxwoods Theater, according to two people involved in the production.

6:24 p.m. | Updated Barbra Streisand has met with Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurents to discuss starring as Rose, the mother of all stage mamas, in a film version of their 1959 musical ''Gypsy,'' the two men said in telephone interviews on Wednesday. Mr. Laurents, who wrote the book for ''Gypsy'' and directed its 2008 revival on Broadway starring Patti LuPone, said that Warner Brothers and Joel Silver were attached as producers, but that no director had been chosen. Contrary to a report in The New York Post on Wednesday, Mr. Laurents said that Ms. Streisand would not direct the film; she once wanted to, he said, ''but playing Rose is enough to make her happy.'' Ms. Streisand, who won an Academy Award for best actress in 1968 for the film musical ''Funny Girl,'' has been interested in doing ''Gypsy'' for many years, Mr. Laurents said, ''but now things are serious and a movie is truly in the works.'' He said that he had suggested Tom Hanks to play the role of Herbie, Rose's love interest and the talent manager of her two daughters, Baby June and Louise. ''Barbra loved the idea,'' Mr. Laurents said.

ANDEREGG--Karen. The Lauder Family and Clinique Mourn the Death of Karen Anderegg, Friend and Former President of Clinique. The Lauder family and Clinique send their heartfelt condolences upon the passing of Karen Anderegg, friend and former President of Clinique. Karen died on December 27, 2010 at her winter home at Smoke Tree Ranch, Palm Springs, California at the age of 70. Her husband William D. Rutherford and her step-son Dr. Mel Rutherford were by her side. Karen had a talent for words, a talent for people, and a talent for style. Karen was already a well-known figure in the magazine industry with editorial careers at Vogue, and Mademoiselle and had just launched the first U.S. edition of Elle, when we tapped her to be the President of Clinique in 1987. During the five years she spent leading Clinique, she was known among her colleagues for her creative vision and her brilliance. A strong mentor and a tireless advocate for women, Karen was generous with her advice and her encouragement to young women leaders. Karen was one of the most valuable members of our management team. She moved to Portland, Oregon in 1991 to be with her husband. Although Karen was deeply missed at Clinique, we were glad to see her share her passions for women's issues and art in her new community. She served on the Boards of Directors of the Oregon Symphony, Oregon Entrepreneurs Forum, The Coast Airlines, Bizstrata, and Athena Medical. At the time of her death, she was a member of the Board of Ethics Point and ODS Health Plans. She also served on the Business Advisory Board of Portland State University. Karen is survived by her daughter Margit Anderegg and grandchildren Augie and Axel of New York City; her sister Kathryn Miller of Woodland, Washington; nephew F. Jackson Lewis and family of Portland, Oregon; her husband William D. Rutherford and his children, Dr. Mel Rutherford of Dundas, Canada, and Wayne Rutherford of Dakar, Senegal. She will be missed by her many friends at The Estee Lauder Companies. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Providence Portland Medical Foundation, 4805 NE Glisan, Portland, Oregon 97213, or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, or to the charity of your choice.

WEEKEND An article on Friday about cultural offerings that some critics, reporters and editors for The Times are looking forward to in 2011, including the Off Broadway show ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' erroneously credited a distinction to Rick Elice, who adapted a novel by Ridley Pearson and Dave Barry for the show. While he was nominated for the Tony Award for best book for ''Jersey Boys,'' he did not win.

OPENINGS QUEEN OF E.VIL, a label best known for its graphic T-shirts, including its horoscope series ($80) and colorful cashmere sweaters ($250), has opened its first boutique, Bond 666. The NoHo store will have art installations in the soaring 18-foot-high space. The brand was started by Aimee David in 1999 and has done collaborations with Max Mara and with Casio in Tokyo on e.vil Baby G-shock watches; 666 Broadway, (212) 777-7066; queenofevil.com. ... DAVID LERNER, who makes stylish leggings and workout clothing, has opened a temporary store at 1435 Lexington Avenue, (212) 996-6474; dlcollection.com. Mr. Lerner, 27, started his namesake line in 2008 with leggings ($176 with cargo pockets) and has since added form-fitting dresses and tops to the line; they are sold at Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman ($60 to $200). The temporary store will be open until at least May. ... RICKY'S NYC has turned a temporary shop in Flatbush into its second permanent location in Brooklyn at 478 Bergen Street, (718) 622-0063; rickysnyc.com.

US Airways Flight 1549 may make it to North Carolina after all. The plane, which splash-landed in the Hudson River two years ago next week, may soon be bound for the Carolinas Aviation Museum in Charlotte, the museum's president said on Wednesday. But it would have to travel there on the back of a truck because it no longer has its engines or its wings or tail.

An article on Dec. 23 about obsessively orderly people entertaining for the holidays misstated the job of one such person, Jeff Bell, at KCBS radio. He is a news anchor, not a D.J. The article also misidentified the city where the station is located. It is in San Francisco, not in Los Angeles.

Carnegie Hall announced on Tuesday that it would celebrate its 120th anniversary on April 12 with a gala event to be hosted by James Taylor, along with a sizeable lineup of celebrity guests, including Bette Midler, Sting, Steve Martin and Barbara Cook. The event, to highlight ''many of the extraordinary musical and cultural events that have taken place on the Hall's legendary stages over the past 12 decades,'' as the institution described it, will also feature members of the Tanglewood Festival Chorus. Proceeds will benefit Carnegie Hall's artistic and educational programs. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The struggling Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington has hired an outside consultant, Lord Cultural Resources, to help it chart a path toward financial health, Artinfo.com reported. The museum also plans to lease an adjacent parking lot, on which it once intended to expand, for roughly $1 million a year to a local developer to build an office tower. The Corcoran expects to run a $3 million deficit this fiscal year on a budget of approximately $24 million. It also has $4 million of bank debt, and an endowment of only $23 million. In an interview with Artinfo.com, the museum's director and president, Fred Bollerer, called the museum's operations ''unsustainable.'' He said that Lord would, among other things, help the Corcoran figure out the best relationship between the art gallery and the more fiscally stable Corcoran College of Art + Design.

WEISS--Stephen Mark, 71, of Rockaway Township, NJ, died unexpectedly at his home on January 3, 2011. Devoted husband of 41 years to the late Sharon Weiss; beloved father of David Weiss (Allison) and Danielle Loevy (Jon); cherished and proud Poppy to Rebecca and Jocelyn Weiss, Carter, Ethan and Oliver Loevy; caring brother to Joan Daly; and devoted brother-in-law to Andrea and Ira Leventhal. His warmth, love, thoughtfulness, kindness, intelligence, and humor will be deeply missed. Words cannot express the extent of our sadness for this sudden and irreplaceable loss. Services at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman in Livingston, NJ, at 10am on Thursday, January 6, 2011.

GIBLER--Zach. With sorrow we join the mourners of Zach Gibler. Though we had only recently met I felt as if I had connected with a lifelong friend. His passion, brilliance, humility, strength of character and goodness were always evident. Condolences to Mary and Rachel. May Zach's memory be a comfort to his family and all those upon whose life he had such an impact. Leon Wagner

BERLISS--Arthur D.,Jr. died peacefully on December 31, 2010 at age 96. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne; his son, Henry; his grandsons, Jeremy and Jeffrey, and his sister, Marian. His love for and devotion to Suzanne were extraordinary. Arthur graduated from The Fieldston School in 1932 and from Yale in 1936. When he was accepted by Harvard Law School but not by Yale Law School, he decided not to become a lawyer. He served in the US Navy with distinction in World War II. He earned a Silver Star in 1943 at age 29 due to his bravery at the time of the invasion of Sicily. He was in command of a ship close to the shore the night before the invasion that had been ordered to signal the location of the landing beach to the invading forces. He had a successful business career in the printing business that resulted in the sale by him and his partner of the Allen Hollander Company to Litton Industries when Arthur was in his mid-50's. In conjunction with Admiral Gene La Roque and other patriotic people, Arthur helped start and enlist substantial support for the Center for Defense Information in Washington, DC. Arthur loved golf and he served as a Board Member and President of Quaker Ridge Golf Club. He traveled extensively throughout his life. In 1975 he and all his family mourned the death of his daughter, Elizabeth. His grandsons, Jeremy and Jeffrey, born in 1976 and 1980 respectively, were always a great source of joy for Arthur and Suzanne. Arthur was buried on January 2, 2011 between his mother, Marie, and his daughter, Elizabeth. A memorial service will be scheduled. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to Doctors Without Borders, or such other charity that people who knew and loved Arthur choose.

The smartphone is already the Swiss Army knife of the digital age, replacing the need for alarm clocks, GPS units and even digital cameras with the flick of a finger. At the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, iHealth Labs, a start-up in Mountain View, Calif., has unveiled the iHealth Blood Pressure Dock, an attachment for iOS devices that can measure and record heart rate and blood pressure.

HUNT--Douglass, of Chapel Hill, NC on January 1 at the age of 86. Beloved husband of Mary Jane. Devoted father of Havilah, Douglass III, Amanda, and Arthur. Loved grandfather. Memorial Service Saturday, January 8, 2011 at 1pm at the Chapel of the Cross, Chapel Hill.

ROBINSON--Phyllis K. The One Club and its board of directors mourn the loss of Phyllis K. Robinson (1921-2010) who passed away at home in Manhattan, December 31. Mrs. Robinson was elected to the Copywriters Hall of Fame in 1968, now named the Creative Hall of Fame. She was the first copy chief at the newly formed advertising agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach and her work with Bill Bernbach and Bob Gage changed the face of advertising. Phyllis was articulate, intelligent and charming. She chaired many dinners at the Creative Hall of Fame and lent both grace and prestige to the evenings. She played a major role in the documentary Art & Copy, a history of creative ideas in advertising. We extend our deepest sympathy to her daughter Nancy Thompson, her nieces, Margery Cantor, Ann Jacobson, Linda Robinson and nephew, Jeffrey Robinson, her many friends, including Linda Hacker and all those friends and colleagues who knew her and loved her. Mary Warlick Chief Executive Officer The One Club

HOROWITZ--Barbara Silver. On January 5, 2011. Daughter of the late Ruth and Jonas Silver. Beloved wife of Gedale B. Horowitz. Devoted mother of Ruth (Michael Nachman) and Seth (Linda). Loving grandmother of Jared and Elliot. Private family service.

LONDON (AP) -- The first study to link a childhood vaccine to autism was based on doctored information about the children involved, according to a new report on the widely discredited research. The conclusions of the 1998 paper by Dr. Andrew Wakefield and his colleagues were renounced by 10 of its 13 authors and later retracted by the medical journal The Lancet, where it was published. Still, the suggestion that the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine was connected to autism rattled parents worldwide; immunization rates for the MMR shot have never fully recovered.

HOLD THE PARTY In the last three weeks, three Web darlings -- Twitter, Groupon and Facebook -- have racked up $1.2 billion in financing. While the flood of new capital is certainly a reason for celebration, it's also prudent to remember that a $100 million-plus venture capital round does not ensure against failure. For every Facebook there's an Amp'd Mobile -- a company that went out of business just one year after raising $150 million in a single round. EVELYN M. RUSLI
Two weeks ago, Standard & Poor's put out a news release warning that it was poised to lower its ratings on almost 1,200 complex mortgage securities. So what? Isn't that dog-bites-man at this point?

O'HARE--Edward John, passed away at home on January 1, 2011. He was born in NYC in 1937 and moved to Atlanta in 1987. He married Katharine Cavanagh in 1961 and they have four children and four grandchildren. After attending Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, NY, Ed served in the US Army and achieved the rank of staff sergeant. Upon his return from Korea, he graduated from Saint John's University and worked in advertising at Foote, Cone & Belding and then Ogilvy & Mather. He spent many years at American Express in NYC before joining American Security Group/Assurant, where he retired as CEO in 2000. Ed loved to play golf and was a member of the Cherokee Town & Country Club. He also enjoyed birdwatching, cooking, hockey, puzzles, Scrabble and family vacations at the ocean. He was an active supporter of the Holy Spirit Preparatory School in Atlanta. He is missed by his family: his wife Katharine; children: Cartha, Jennifer, Edward Marcus (Liza) and Matthew; and grandchildren Kate, Edward Patrick, Andrew and Dylan. His large extended family includes siblings Edward Heiner (Joan), Eleanor Carr (Frank), John O'Hare (Linda) and Lorraine Moran (Dennis). He was pre-deceased by sister Rosemary Heiner. The family will welcome friends at Patterson's Funeral Home (Arlington location at 173 Allen Road, Sandy Springs; 404-851-9900) on Wednesday, January 5th from 5pm-8pm. The funeral mass will be at the Holy Spirit Catholic Church at 4465 Northside Drive, Atlanta on Thursday January 6th at 10:30am. Donations may be sent to Holy Spirit Preparatory School.

LAS VEGAS -- Virtually instantaneous traffic updates come to TomTom's line of GPS devices with the launch of its Go 2505 M LIVE model. The $349 product, which will be available by mid-2011, uses both satellite and GPRS radio signals to update traffic conditions every two minutes, compared with every 15 minutes for the company's other models. The Go 2505 also features other live services that are available free for the first year, including local search, updated local fuel prices and weather. Standard spoken commands can summon directions to the nearest fast-food joint or gas station. ''The data is twice as accurate as Navteq,'' said Tom Murray, a TomTom senior vice president for marketing.

BLECKER--Joan, (nee Reiss) died peacefully on January 4, 2011 at age 83, after a long, courageous battle with breast cancer, surrounded by her family. She was loved dearly and will be greatly missed. She is survived by her brother Albert, her daughters Irene and Linda, their families, and her four grandchildren; Carol, Allison, Brandon, and Jamie. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Seymour. The funeral will be held at 2pm on January 6, 2011 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society.

LinkedIn, the popular social networking site built around professional relationships, plans to go public this year and has hired banks to advise it on the process, people with direct knowledge of the matter said on Wednesday. LinkedIn chose Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Merrill Lynch and JPMorgan Chase as three advisers, following a round of pitches held in early November, said one of these people, who requested anonymity because the process is confidential.

HIESTAND--Dale. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Dale Hiestand PhD '63, professor emeritus in the Finance and Economics division of Columbia Business School. In a career spanning three decades (196495), Professor Hiestand's scholarship contributed to the body of knowledge in human resources and employment, nonprofit management, and the relationships among business, government, and society. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Hiestand family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School
A J. Crew store in Manhattan.8:17 p.m. | Updated More than a month after agreeing to sell itself to two leveraged buyout firms for $3 billion, J. Crew may have found potential new suitors.

Sony is back at the Consumer Electronics Show with a new OLED screen. But don't plan on hanging this one on the wall; it measures three-and-a-half inches. OLED has been a once-and-future technology for a half-dozen years now, and unless some flat-panel maker shows up in Las Vegas with a surprise this year -- Mitsubishi, perhaps? -- the technology, at least at the consumer level, remains in CE limbo. So far, except for Sony's 11-inch, $2,500 TV, OLED has only been applied to small-screen uses, such as mobile devices, a Walkman and a few cameras.

7:46 p.m. | Updated After news broke of the investment by Goldman Sachs in the social networking site Facebook, a harsh spotlight was cast on a nearly 50-year-old law that limits the number of shareholders in a private company.

ENGLE--Elizabeth Marion of New York, NY, and previously of Edinburgh, Scotland died on New Year's Day at the age of 80. Wife of the late Joe R. Engle; mother of Graham Barr and Kristen Lasky; grandmother of Maya and Iain Barr. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 8 at 5pm at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

HAUG--Dorothy. The Stanley Isaacs Neighborhood Center gratefully acknowledges the tremendous legacy of community spirit and generosity of Dorothy Haug. We send heartfelt condolences to Gretchen and Lewis Stone and the entire family. Lee Wareham, President Wanda Wooten, Executive Director

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - After some three decades spent on N.F.L. sidelines - almost exclusively with special teams - the Jets assistant Mike Westhoff still experiences the occasional first. On Saturday, he will confront the league's new playoff overtime rule. On Wednesday, Westhoff called the rule ''basically really simple.'' But he also saw the strategy involved. He said he would address the team on Thursday and would go over the basics: that the first team to receive the ball cannot win simply by kicking a field goal, as it could in the regular season; that a touchdown would still win the game on the first possession; that should each team kick one field goal, the format reverts to sudden death.

ALBANY - The chaos-plagued State Senate faced fresh tumult on Wednesday as four Democrats announced they would split from their party's leadership and start their own, independent caucus. The move does not change the balance of power in the Senate, which the Republicans captured in November and now hold with a razor-thin, two-seat majority, 32 to 30.

Apple's iPad controls the high end of the nascent tablet market, but Vizio seems to have its eyes on the lower end. On Monday, Vizio, which made its name selling televisions, announced that it would begin selling an Android tablet with an 8-inch screen, a front-facing camera, HD video capability, and the ability to connect to HD televisions. It also announced that it would begin selling smartphones. The new devices will be on display at this week's International Consumer Electronics Show, where many companies are planning to introduce their own tablets.

BREITLING is known for its precision watches, but the timing for its first store was a little off, opening just after last month's blizzard. The 3,400-square-foot store has some 900 watch models on display, along with aviation-theme murals by the artist Kevin T. Kelly. ''The prices are from the sublime to the ridiculous,'' said Marie Bodman, the president of Breitling USA. Watches range from $2,000 to $225,000, though most are between $5,000 and $10,000; 5 East 57th Street; (855) 999-1884, breitling.com.

THE accessories designer Rebecca Minkoff has introduced a men's collection for spring 2011. The Ben Minkoff collection is an homage to Rebecca's grandfather, who flew as a combat fighter pilot in World War II. The line has touches of nostalgia, military and modern. Each piece is hand-crafted. The Nicky Messenger Bag ($495) is at Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and their respective Web sites. Also at Cockpit USA, a supplier of military apparel in Lower Manhattan; benminkoff.com.

After months of staff turmoil including a new owner, editor and chief executive and scores of lower-level departures, the management ranks at Newsweek are beginning to stabilize. The magazine has named a new publisher, Ray Chelstowski, a former publisher of Rolling Stone and Entertainment Weekly. Mr. Chelstowski will assume responsibility for both Newsweek and The Daily Beast, a sign that the two organizations are moving closer toward completing a merger of their business operations.

FRONT PAGE An article on Tuesday about ambivalence toward Tolstoy in Russia referred incorrectly to the cast of ''The Last Station,'' a movie about Tolstoy for which a Russian producer said he was unable to obtain government support. While several cast members are British, some are not -- including Christopher Plummer, a Canadian who plays Tolstoy. A picture caption with the continuation of the article misidentified the site shown. It was Tolstoy's house in Moscow, not his estate about 125 miles from Moscow.

The Shortcuts column on Dec. 18, about using and maintaining nonstick cookware, referred incorrectly to the contents of Baker's Joy, a coating spray for bakeware. Like PAM and other cooking sprays, it contains soy lecithin; it is not the case that soy lecithin is absent from Baker's Joy.

Four questions for Nicole Fischelis (above), Macy's fashion director: What's your best-selling item now? Shine and sequins are major. Anything metallic, from silver to gold. (Some examples: Calvin Klein gold sequined tees, $59, or black sequined shift by Alfani, $89.)

The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who spent much of last year recovering from esophageal cancer and a back ailment, will miss three concerts in Japan at the end of the month because of surgery to ease pain in his lower back. Doctors will perform an endoscopic procedure on Mr. Ozawa, 75, Agence France-Presse reported, which will force him to miss performances with the Mito Chamber Orchestra in late January. Associates of Mr. Ozawa said he wanted to get through the surgery as soon as possible before returning to Carnegie Hall in April for the hall's JapanNYC festival, which he is directing. Mr. Ozawa is scheduled to conduct his youth orchestra, the Seiji Ozawa Ongaku-juku, at Carnegie.

If some restaurants are cursed with bad locations, maybe others are cursed with bad labor relations. Two years after a federal judge awarded $4.6 million to delivery workers at the Saigon Grill, a Manhattan noodle house, to compensate for their severe exploitation, the restaurant's new owners face a fresh round of claims of worker discrimination and intimidation. A restaurant workers' union filed a complaint with federal authorities last month accusing the new owners of harassing and firing workers who protested age discrimination and expressed support for joining a union. Bei Lin and Qiao Lin, brothers who now own the restaurant , threatened the employees, manipulated work schedules to decrease their tips, and fired many who objected, according to the complaint filed with the National Labor Relations Board by the 318 Restaurant Workers Union.

Qualcomm's $3.1 billion deal to acquire the chip maker Atheros Communications is a long-term play on the increasingly wired nature of consumers' lives. The deal, formally announced on Wednesday, is the largest takeover yet by Qualcomm, a leading wireless technology company. It also comes on the heels of Intel's $1.4 billion purchase in August of Infineon's wireless chip business, which competes with Atheros.

MATTHEW MARKS GALLERY has opened a temporary poster shop that carries original works of art, rare books and signed catalogs. Most items are under $100 and nothing is over $5,000. A poster designed and signed by Gary Hume in conjunction with a 1997 gallery show is $100. A Cy Twombly book of photographs is $20. The shop, on the second floor above the gallery, has comfortable chairs to browse other works, including those by Jasper Johns, Nan Golden, Charles Ray, Mike Kelly and Andreas Gursky. It is slated to be open at least through January; 526 West 22nd Street; (212) 243-0200, matthewmarks.com.

LEFF--Alan H.,on January 5, 2011. Beloved husband of Charlotte (Lewine). Devoted father of Michael, Daniel and Richard. Dear father-in-law of Michelle, Pamela, Sharon, Bernice and Phillip. Proud grandfather of Kristen, Stephen, Brian, Jamison, Jonathan, Elizabeth, Caitlyn and Courtney. Survived by loving in-laws, cousins and many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, LLC 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone, NY. Visiting, Thursday 2-5pm and 7-10pm. Religious Service: Friday, 9:30am, Rabbi Ackerman. Funeral: 10am. Interment: Hungarian Union Field Cemetery

How easy it is to look upon the modern superstars as men who care less about the game than the wealth and celebrity it brings them. I give you two names that utterly belie that image: Ricardo Kaká and Xavi Hernández.

Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the Kennedy Center, who doubles as an arts management guru, is taking his show on the road next month - to Africa. Over a week, he will give arts management seminars in five cities: Lagos, Nigeria; Kampala, Uganda; Nairobi, Kenya; Zanzibar, Tanzania; and Harare, Zimbabwe. The one-day sessions will be hosted by local arts leaders who have taken part in the Kennedy Center's Summer International Fellowship program for arts managers. Mr. Kaiser said in an interview that 300 people had signed up to attend the seminar in Lagos, 150 each in Nairobi and Harare, and sizable groups in the other cities, as well.
WILLS-ABRAHAMS--Patricia, beloved wife, mother, sister and grandma passed away at home January 2, 2011 after a courageous battle with cancer. She will be deeply missed by all her family and friends.

An article last Thursday about 110 subjects that New Yorkers were talking about in 2010 misspelled the given name of a model in a Calvin Klein underwear ad. He is Kellan Lutz, not Kellen. The article also referred incorrectly to the Columbia student whose valedictory speech contained plagiarized material. He was the valedictorian for the School of General Studies, not for the entire university.

BUTLER--Marian, died December 26, 2010, she was 94. Born in Binghamton, NY, Marian was the daughter of Charles and Ethel (nee) White Blakeslee. She graduated Vassar College with a Bachelor of Arts Degree and was a member of the Vassar Golf Team. During WWII, in Washington D.C., she volunteered as an ambulance driver for the Red Cross. Her husband, Arthur Leon Butler was on active duty in the European Theater and married Marian after the war. She inherited the Cambridge Business School, Inc. from her husband after his death in 1967. She later added the ESL (English as a second Language) Division. Visitation on Thursday from 2-8pm will be at Frank E. Campbell, at 81st and Madison. Interment Friday at Woodlawn Cemetery. That there will be a memorial service at Carnegie East House at 1844 Second Ave. on Saturday, February 5 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, you may send a donation in her name to the Lighthouse International, 111 E. 59 St., New York, NY 10022.

HOROWITZ--Barbara Silver. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Barbara Silver Horowitz, wife of Gedale Horowitz, a trustee and past chairman of Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Mrs. Horowitz was an associate trustee since 2002. She also served as a board member of the Jewish Museum and Jewish Theological Seminary. The Horowitz's dedication to and support of the health system has enabled North Shore-LIJ to improve the lives of countless residents in the communities we serve. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, daughter Ruth Horowitz and son-in-law Michael Nachman, son Seth Horowitz and daughter-in-law Linda, and grandchildren Jared and Elliot. Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO Richard D. Goldstein, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

FISHER--Janet Cane. The Board, Musicians, and Staff of the New York Philharmonic mourn the passing, on December 28, 2010, of our friend and Patron, whose family has meant so much to the Orchestra and to its home, Avery Fisher Hall. We offer our condolences to her children, Barbara, Nancy, Chip, and family.

BAER--Fernand B. Jr. October 10, 1935-December 28, 2010. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. Our hearts are shattered. Our cherished Tony was a gentleman, scholar, and the most devoted friend anyone could have. He gave without hesitation in ways that cannot be measured. No matter what, he was ever curious, vibrant, full of humor and eager to embrace life at its fullest. No matter what, he was compassionate, generous, and a lifesaver and buoy to any friend in need. No matter what, he never complained. Instead, he strode forth, with a smile on his face, ready to do good and bring joy. For Tony, every day was an opportunity to learn something new to add to his already impressive and vast store of knowledge. His was the gift of truly listening and selfless caring for others. A virtual one-man Google, one's inbox never stayed empty if he knew you needed to know whatever it was. How lucky were we to have him in our family. How painfully silent it is now that he is gone. We pray that he is at peace. He will forever be missed. All our Love, Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie

SMIRLOCK--Lillian, 90, formerly of Westbury, NY, on January 3rd. Veteran, homemaker, administrator, force of nature. Adored spouse of the late Lawrence Smirlock. Beloved and esteemed mother, grandmother, sister and in-law. Calling hours Friday 7-9pm at Donohue-Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY. Funeral service at the funeral home Saturday 10am. Interment at Pinelawn Memorial Park. Contributions in her name can be made to the Blinded Veterans Association. www.donohue-cecare.com.

POPPER--Lilly, of Riverdale and Yonkers, NY, died peacefully at 94, December 26, 2010. Widow of George Popper, sister of Walter Strauss and Anna Klingsberg, aunt of Deborah Diamond, Dinah Bodkin and David Klingsberg. Born August 17, 1916 in Vienna, Austria. Studied horticulture in the UK; reached America as a refugee in 1940. Worked in the Strauss family greenhouse business and as an independent supplier in the Flower District. Married in 1969 and shared active retirement with her husband, invigorated by a love of mountain hiking. She will be fondly remembered by the Strauss-Klingsberg and Popper families, and by the families of Edith Harnik and Jack Wolff, among many others.

BUSINESS DAY The Deal Professor column on the DealBook page on Wednesday, about deal makers who excelled in 2010, referred incorrectly to Morgan Stanley's role as an adviser in the buyout of Burger King. It advised Burger King -- not the buyer, 3G Capital.

STEVENSON--Charles P. of Hobe Sound, Florida, passed away on Christmas Day at his home on Jupiter Island. Mr. Stevenson was 92 years old and a native of Buffalo, New York where he was President of the Eastman Machine Company until his retirement. He was a graduate of Yale University in 1941 and then went on to serve 22 months during the war in the South Pacific and later was stationed in Washington DC. After the war, he served on the boards of many hospitals, schools, the Niagara Falls Bridge Commission, and was on the World Trade Commission to Russia. He loved the game of golf and served on the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association. Mr. Stevenson's first wife, Mary Louise Lord, died in 1991. They had five children; Wade, Charles Jr., Louise Zimmerman, Robert, and Roy and also 21 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In 1993, he married Barbara Franklin Rogers, and together, they have lived at their home on Jupiter Island for the past 17 years. A Memorial Service will be held January 22, at 5:00pm followed by a reception at the Jupiter Island Club.
DePINNA--George Leo. Daddy, you left this earth 11 years ago, but I feel your presence with me always. Miss your sense of humor and the sound of your voice. All my love, N.M.I
The On Location column on Dec. 23, about Michel Pastore's houseboat on the Nile, misstated the monthly rent that he paid for a Nile houseboat in 1970. It was $93, not $8.

PAHLAVI--HIH Prince Ali Reza. Armao and Company mourns the sudden loss of our esteemed Vice Chairman and Counselor, His Imperial Highness Prince Ali Reza Pahlavi of Iran. Born in Tehran in 1966, He obtained a B.A. from Princeton University in 1984, a Masters Degree from Columbia in 1992 and attended Harvard University in pursuit of a Ph.D. in Ancient Iranian studies. Prince Ali Reza was an intelligent, sensitive, loyal, fearless and dedicated to His Family and friends. His counsel, wisdom and sense of humor will be profoundly missed and always cherished. Although He left Iran at the time of the Islamic uprising in 1979, His heart and soul were forever with His country and countrymen.

ANDERSON--Robert David, age 81, of North Palm Beach, FL, passed away on January 3rd, as a result of complications from MSA, a rare neurological disease. The son of Herbert and Laurette Anderson, Bob was born in Elizabeth, NJ, raised in Westfield, NJ, and lived in New York City before moving to Rumson, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Barbara, their children; Karen Ouellette and her husband Stephen Ouellette of Rockport, MA, Libby Anderson and her husband Robert Watson of Westhampton, MA, and Dean Anderson and his wife Dana Walner Anderson of Chicago, IL, and seven grandchildren; Emma and Jamey Ouellette, Dillon and Kyle Watson, and Isabelle, Tatum, and Chase Anderson. He is also survived by a sister, Jean Augustine of Pennington, NJ, and several nieces and nephews. Mr. Anderson received a post graduate degree from Hotchkiss School, graduated from Hamilton College, and received his MBA from the University of Michigan Business School. He began his career on Wall Street with Kidder Peabody, and in1956 joined Distributors Group, Inc., a mutual fund management company, as Vice President of Sales Management and a Director of the Company. He continued a lifelong interest in the mutual fund industry, co-founding Bull & Bear Group in 1974, which managed several funds and a discount brokerage firm. He remained Vice Chairman and Director of the company, now known as Winmill & Co. A former member of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Mr. Anderson served on a number of committees, including the District Business Conduct, Investment Company, and District 12 Committees. He was a past member of the Board of Governors of the Mutual Fund No Load Association and the Mutual Fund Education Alliance. Mr. Anderson was also a former President of the University of Michigan Club of NY, and managed their Scholarship Fund for over 25 years. Mr. Anderson was a member of the Rumson Country Club, Rumson, NJ, Seabright Beach Club, Seabright, NJ, Lost Tree Club, N. Palm Beach, FL, Tower Hill Presbyterian Church, Red Bank, NJ, and First Presbyterian Church, N. Palm Beach, FL. An avid golfer, he was Club Champion of the Rumson Country Club in 1972, enjoyed paddle tennis in the winter and was a tough competitor in both Bridge and Backgammon. He was a devoted and loving husband, father, and grandfather, a loyal friend and trusted advisor to many. His joy of life, wonderful sense of humor and generous love of family and friends will be deeply missed by all. Services will be held at the Lost Tree Chapel on Saturday, January 8th at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to the Mayo Clinic Department of Neurology, 200 1st St. SW, Rochester, MN 55905. The family is planning a memorial service to be held in Rumson, NJ this summer.

Before Goldman Sachs bought a stake in Facebook and started offering shares to wealthy clients, a powerful investment group within the firm turned down the chance to buy a piece of the social networking behemoth, according to several people briefed on the internal discussions. Goldman Sachs Capital Partners - a group that manages and invests for pensions, sovereign wealth funds and other prominent clients - was given the initial opportunity to invest $450 million in Facebook, said the people, who were not authorized to speak publicly on the matter.

Ab Simon, who as the longtime chairman of the Seagram Chateau & Estate Wines Company was a commanding figure in the American wine trade and a leading importer of fine Bordeaux to the United States, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88. The cause was complications of heart disease, his wife, Francine, said.

The record industry's traditional post-holiday doldrums were reflected in this week's Billboard album chart as sales of Christmas-related CDs dropped sharply and even nonholiday fare experienced a decline. Taylor Swift's ''Speak Now'' continued as No. 1, for the third week in a row, but its sales fell 72 percent, to 77,000, from the previous week. Sales of the records that had been holding down the No. 2 and 3 slots leading into Christmas, ''The Gift'' by Susan Boyle and the ''Glee'' cast's ''Christmas Album,'' plunged more than 90 percent, dropping both of those CDs out of the Top 10. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: PETER SELLERSThroughout his career Sellers (1925-80) maintained that he had no personality and that, like an empty pitcher, he was merely waiting to be filled by his latest character. Or, as Bette Davis once put it, ''He isn't an actor, he's a chameleon.'' This 25-film tribute, Thursdays in January, starts with Sellers's international breakthrough, ''I'm All Right Jack'' (1959), a working-class comedy in which he plays a Marxist ideologue and union leader adorned with a Hitler mustache. In ''Heavens Above!'' (1963), at 10, he stars as a prison chaplain turned small-town vicar whose tendency to speak the truth shocks his conservative parishioners. In ''Two-Way Stretch'' (1960), at 12:15 a.m., he plays a pampered convict plotting to commit the perfect crime while still behind bars. ''The Ladykillers'' (1955), at 2, features Sellers (back row center above) as part of an outlaw gang that rents rooms in the home of an eccentric, elderly widow (Katie Johnson, front row center) while planning a major heist. And in ''Your Past Is Showing'' (1957), at 3:45, Sellers portrays one of several bumbling blackmail victims who join forces to do in their tormentor. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY A mass shooting at a college sends the Seattle Grace doctors, their own wounds still mending, into action. In ''Private Practice,'' at 10, Addison (Kate Walsh) asks Dr. Rodriguez (Cristian de la Fuente) to help save her mother's partner. Meanwhile Pete (Tim Daly) and Amelia (Caterina Scorsone) run into complications when a patient's wife and his mistress can't agree on his course of treatment. Eric Stoltz is the director.

Vivian Maier, evidently one of America's more insightful street photographers, has at last been discovered. The release of every fresh image on the Web causes a sensation among the growing legion of her admirers. (Frankly, Lens is late to the table.) Ms. Maier's streetscapes manage simultaneously to capture a redolent sense of place and the paradoxical moments that give the city its jazz, while elevating and dignifying the people in her frames - vulnerable, noble, defeated, proud, fragile, tender and often quite funny. Harry Callahan is just one of the masters with whom Ms. Maier is already being compared.

The Academy Awards aren't all celebrity glitz and glam: the Bagger spent all day hanging out at an outer-borough elementary school, and it was still part of the Oscar beat. (Stay tuned to find out why.) Also today, the Academy announced the winners of its technical awards, which appear as a blip on the telecast but get to enjoy what is probably a pretty fun ceremony, usually hosted by a pretty young actress (Jessica Alba is totally scientific, right?). The honorees at the nerd Oscars will include Dr. Mark Sagar, for "influential facial motion retargeting solutions," a.k.a. a way to transform motion-capture into a stable of animated characters; Mark Noel and John Frazier, for creating a winch system that allows cars, planes and other large props to be flown on wires; and Eric Tabellion and Arnauld Lamorlette, for "the creation of a computer graphics bounce lighting methodology that is practical at feature film scale," as seen in "Shrek 2" and described in their paper "An Approximate Global Illumination System for Computer Generated Films." What if the Bagger covered these Oscars instead? The mind boggles.

Let's not indulge in any equivocation: Mayor Rudy Giuliani's 2008 presidential campaign was a flop. Mr. Giuliani then dropped out of the race and endorsed John McCain.

On the third-season premiere of "Jersey Shore" on Thursday night, it was Deena Cortese, the newest addition to the beach house, who spent the episode repeatedly declaring herself a "blast in a glass." But on Friday it was MTV that had cause to celebrate: it said the premiere had been watched by 8.45 million viewers, making it MTV's highest-rated series broadcast to date. The Season 3 debut episode, in which Nicole Polizzi (alias Snooki), Mike Sorrentino (aka the Situation) and their catchphrase-coining pals returned to their abode in Seaside Heights, N.J., saw a ratings increase of 63 percent over the Season 2 premiere in July (when the orange-skinned cast traveled to Miami) and 36 percent over that season's finale in October. The overall viewership for the latest "Jersey Shore" premiere at 10 p.m. even exceeded broadcast networks like ABC (which drew 7.8 million viewers for a "Private Practice" repeat) and NBC (which attracted just over two million for reruns of "The Office").

During the health care debate, I wrote a series of posts defending the filibuster - you can find them here, here, and here, with a much later follow-up here - and arguing for the virtues of a supermajority hurdle for controversial, big-ticket legislation. I stand by all of those arguments, but I also agree with Daniel Foster that the filibuster reform proposal the Senate Democrats are putting forward looks pretty reasonable.  Essentially, for the filibuster to work as I'd like it to work, it needs to be available as a check on temporary majorities without becoming a routine tactic for obstruction, which is how it's increasingly employed. Ultimately, restoring this balance requires more collegiality, comity, and good manners: There's no rule you can change that explicitly limits the filibuster to particularly sweeping and controversial pieces of legislation. (I mean, no reasonable rule, since I suppose you could imagine a provision stating that "60 votes shall only be required for cloture when Gallup shows that a majority of Americans oppose the legislation in question," or something similarly implausible.) But the revisions the Democrats are contemplating - which would limit the filibuster to substantive measures (no filibustering motions to proceed) and require actual speechifying from filibustering senators - would at least make the filibuster feel more extraordinary than it does today. And that seems like a step in the right direction.

Clutch performance in professional basketball has its own distinct mythology. The meaning of every action - each shot, foregone shot, pass and foregone pass - is dissected and analyzed to a ludicrous degree, primarily in an effort to better understand the stuff of which N.B.A. players are made. Does a certain star have "nerves of steel" or a "killer instinct?" Are they soft? Weak-minded? Descriptions such as these are thrown around disguised as absolutes, even though clutch play is often hopelessly tainted by perception bias. All it takes is one big shot to create a legend. Once a player establishes a reputation as a clutch scorer, it typically follows him to his grave, regardless of what that pesky legitimate evidence indicates.

Were you already jealous of Lena Dunham, the 24-year-old wunderkind writer, director and star of the sleeper-hit comedy "Tiny Furniture"? Prepare to grow even greener with envy: on Friday HBO announced that it had ordered a full season of a new comedy series that Ms. Dunham created and will star in for that cable channel. HBO said in a news release that the series, called "Girls," will offer "a comic look at the assorted humiliations and rare triumphs of a group of girls in their early 20s," with a cast that will also feature Jemima Kirke (of "Tiny Furniture"), Allison Williams ("American Dreams"), Adam Driver (of the HBO movie "You Don't Know Jack") and Zosia Mamet ("Mad Men"). Lest she be labeled an underachiever, Ms. Dunham also wrote and directed the show's pilot episode, and the series will be produced by Jenni Konner and Judd Apatow (who's keeping plenty busy himself these days). A premiere date for "Girls" wasn't immediately announced.
This post is part of a occasional series profiling Web sites and blogs made in New York. Have a profile suggestion? E-mail NewYorkOnline@nytimes.com.

The fashion world's favorite new parlor game is over. Condé Nast France president Xavier Romatet has confirmed that Alt, the French Vogue fashion director, has been tapped to replace Carine Roitfeld as editor in chief of the magazine. The April issue will be her first on top of the masthead.

In the course of reporting this weekend's Your Money column, I traveled to Champlain College in Burlington, Vt., to learn more about what it refers to as its "financial sophistication" program. As far as I know, Champlain is the only college in the country right now to make completion of financial literacy seminars a requirement for all undergraduates. (If you know of others, please let me know in the comments below.)
A selection of photographs from the New York region in the past week.

Dance on television is hitting the festival circuit. The Vail International Dance Festival, announcing its program for this summer, said on Friday that Super Cr3w would appear on its closing program Aug. 13, an evening devoted to small screen dancing. The group is a past winner of the MTV dance competition series, "America's Best Dance Crews."

Six years ago a small Texas publisher released an obscure book written by a father-son research team. The work, based on a series of studies conducted in rural China and Taiwan, challenged the conventional wisdom about health and nutrition by espousing the benefits of a plant-based diet.
Once again, a number of automakers will skip the Detroit auto show, which opens to the press on Monday and to the public on Jan. 15.

In the lull before the media frenzy that will no doubt strike again next week, when Julian Assange returns to court in London to continue his fight against extradition to Sweden, his British publisher is trying to drum up interest in his book, which is due out in April.

Generations of high school sweethearts have stayed together into college, but the connection tended to unravel by Thanksgiving. That's no longer the case, Abigail Sullivan Moore writes in an article in Education Life. Now, thanks to technology, particularly Skype, campus-to-campus relationships go on, and on, and on. Breaking up is hard to do. Should you?
Update, 2:34 p.m. | A 72-year-old woman died early Friday after a fire swept through the second floor of a tenement building on Manhattan's Lower East Side, the authorities said.
It seems that no part of Brooklyn can be left untouched by its ever-striving culinary scene, even its microorganisms.

Just FYI: since this morning, I've approved about 320 comments, and rejected I think 10 -- 9 for obscene language, one because it was an advertisement for cheap shoes, or something. No opinions were censored; to be honest, supportive comments are a bit more likely than hostile comments to contain unacceptable language.

The women who faced down middle age in the 1970s responded by running away from home. "They got jobs, got their consciousness raised or got divorced," writes Judith Warner in this weekend's New York Times Magazine.

6:17 p.m. | Updated LONDON - It might seem a curious marriage of author and subject. But the British writer Monica Ali's coming novel tells the story of a fictional princess based on Diana, Princess of Wales, and imagines what might have happened had Diana not been killed in a car accident in Paris in 1997.

Automakers are among the most adventurous marketers when it comes to trying to reach consumers through new media. That is being underlined by a pair of initiatives for the Mini line of cars sold by BMW.

Top financial trade groups are lobbying regulators to soften new rules that would crack down on fraud and manipulation in the $600 trillion derivatives industry, regulatory disclosure records show - a debate that seems to center on semantics.

In the latest edition of Education Life, The Times's quarterly supplement, to be published this weekend, Trip Gabriel wonders why the personal essay is so important to admissions officers. The essay is viewed as the one place where a student's own voice can be heard. In his story, "The Almighty Essay," Mr. Gabriel writes:

The effort that goes into dressing a prize-winning red-carpet clotheshorse often feels greater than what one can properly say about the ugly dress or indeed a second-rate event. This week's People's Choice Awards illustrated the problem. After deploying references to Adderall, Xanax, "Pride and Prejudice" and fancy pillowcases to describe the awfulness of the clothes, Amy Odell of New York magazine's The Cut blog received a lecture from readers about her misuse of Jane Austen. There are no milkmaids in "Pride and Prejudice," she was told, certainly no "slovenly milkmaids." Ms. Odell might wish she had just said cow.

Trying to get your preschooler into kindergarten at a popular public school across the street? Wondering whether you will have priority over a former neighbor who moved to a different borough but who already has a child there?

The actress Leslie Mann is lucky to have almost a whole year to figure out what to get her husband, the comedy director Judd Apatow, for the 2011 holiday season, because she'll need the time to top Mr. Apatow's latest gift to her: another movie role. Ms. Mann, who has been featured in all of her husband's films including "The 40-Year-Old Virgin" and "Funny People," is set to reunite with Paul Rudd to reprise the semi-happily married couple they portrayed in Mr. Apatow's 2007 hit "Knocked Up." Variety reported that the as-yet untitled film, to be written and directed by Mr. Apatow, would be a follow-up of sorts to "Knocked Up" - in which Ms. Mann played the sister of Katherine Heigl's newly pregnant character, and Mr. Rudd, another Apatow regular, played Ms. Mann's mushroom-ingesting, fantasy-baseball-obsessed spouse - though not necessarily a direct sequel or prequel to that comedy.

In this week's Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad asks Dr. Jeffrey Kullgren, an internist at the University of Pennsylvania who researches consumer-driven health care, for advice on how to negotiate with a doctor or other medical provider. "Your physician may be just as uncomfortable with these conversations as you are," he said. "That's because -- and I can tell you firsthand -- doctors are simply not trained for this. I was trained to give the very best care for my patients, regardless of cost."

What makes great music great? There are lots of ways to answer. Here's a playful approach: make a list of the Top 10 composers in history. A gimmick? Sure, but one worth using if you have to defend your choices. What goes into a decision to put certain composers on such a list or to keep them off? Should influence matter, or just the works themselves? What about popularity? Are there any objective criteria?

This week, we've been asking you to identify locations included in our Where to Go 2011 issue, which will be online later today. Many readers correctly guessed the last three: the first, posted on Facebook, was Miami; the second Salonika, Greece; and the third Reykjavik, Iceland.

Grant money for dance is flowing through the Joyce Theater. The Joyce said on Friday that it would allot $625,000 toward helping 10 choreographers - and possibly more - work on projects. Six will be given partners from the world of theater - directors or dramaturges - to help them "embrace new methods of creating work by introducing them to the theater model in which projects go through multiple workshops," the Joyce said. The Rockefeller Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund and Andrew W. Mellon Foundation are giving the grants.
In the first video of his series, The Times's chief classical music critic, Anthony Tommasini, explains the importance of Bach and his influence on classical music to come.

Hash Week continues: Stay At Stove Dad has a guest post from Steve Flax, a journalist who got a job at Harvest, in Cambridge, Mass., based on the strength of his roast beef hash. The secret, he said, was raiding the walk-in refrigerator and commandeering four leftover prime rib roasts. "I owed it all to using such great leftovers rather than to any special skill as a chef," he writes. At the bottom of the post, there's a talk-through recipe; Julia Child is mixed up in the tale somewhere, too.
The House race forecasts issued by Stu Rothenberg and his team on the eve of last November's elections performed extremely well.
We're watching the white flakes come down, and so is the Bloomberg administration.

The United States added 103,000 jobs on net in December, the Labor Department said today. While growth is better than shrinking, of course, the number was substantially lower than what economists had been expecting.

When Harvey Weinstein promises, he delivers (usually). Just a few weeks ago, he announced to the Bagger that everyone associated with "The King's Speech" would turn up for promotional duties eventually; this at a screening with Eve Best and Jennifer Ehle, who worked just a few days on the film between them but were charming to talk to about it nonetheless. Up next on the hype machine: Guy Pearce, who plays Edward VIII, whose abdication to marry Wallis Simpson forced his stuttering brother, George (Colin Firth), to step up to the royal mic more than he would've liked. Mr. Pearce lives in Australia but had been flown to Los Angeles by HBO to do some work for its upcoming mini-series "Mildred Pierce," and of course the Weinstein Company took advantage of his presence in an American time zone. He spoke by phone with the Bagger for far longer than the 15 minutes a publicist allotted, about why David, as Edward was known to his family, never wanted to be king and how his brother, known as Bertie, resented him forever because of it. There was also some talk about sex, Nazis, and the Queen mum.
Eventually. Of course, if you don't read it you'll eventually die, too.

Larry McKaughan, head of the vintage clothing company Heller's Café, has garnered a cultlike following among heritage-obsessed shoppers on the hunt for authentic, turn-of-the-century clothing. So when J. Crew approached him to collaborate on a capsule collection, he jumped at the chance.
Greg Bishop, in Indianapolis for the Jets' wild-card matchup with the Colts on Saturday, answered your questions on Friday afternoon.
A tie-up between the British mall owner Capital Shopping Centers and the American developer Simon Property is looking dimmer.

For several years, the professor and his wife, who has Parkinson's disease, managed in their house in Cambridge, Mass. But two years ago, finding living on their own too difficult, they moved together into an assisted living facility.
President Obama will name Gene Sperling today to replace Larry Summers as director of the National Economic Council, White House officials said.

JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley said on Friday that they had each won approval from Chinese regulators to form joint ventures in the country, potentially giving them a bigger role in China's booming securities business.

The giant snowstorm in December rekindled the irritation that is felt by many homeowners in the New York area, who after spending hours digging their cars out of six-foot-high snowbanks and driving to pick up groceries, return home to find a strange car parked in that just-cleared curb space. This is, perhaps, a minor inconvenience compared with the plight of residents whose cars get snowed in and stay snowed in for days after a storm, but it is nonetheless frustrating on an interpersonal level.
The president hailed William M. Daley first, describing him as a "man of rare effectiveness," one who "embodies the values of hard work and fair play."
Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. He's also a Giants fan who watches a lot of tape.

Last June, we published a case study that explored whether the natural soap maker True Body Products should add a scented offering. Janice Shade, True Body's chief executive, feared that adding the line might alienate existing customers who are adamantly opposed to scented soaps, sometimes because of allergies. But the suggestion to add the scented soaps came from Ms. Shade's North Atlantic region Whole Foods buyer, and Ms. Shade knew that a line extension would give her company the larger shelf presence it needed to increase sales, which were about $45,000 in 2009.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. -- For Jets left guard Matt Slauson, the less then glamorous life of new fatherhood should be here: picking up  baby food at the store on his way home, 2 a.m. feedings and plenty of diaper purchases and changes. Sprinkle in some playoff football, and Slauson ought to be yawning his way through practice and film study. Instead, he looks bright and fresh despite the birth of Montgomery James a week ago.

Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck announced on Thursday that he would return to Stanford to complete his degree in architectural design. He was all but guaranteed to be the No. 1 pick in the draft. And no team needs a quarterback more than the Carolina Panthers, who happen to have the No. 1 selection.

Joe Namath has had some experience beating the Colts in a big game. In this video, he talks about disrupting Peyton Manning, with blitzes and disguised coverages, and bothering his receivers, by jamming them at the line.

Mahalaxmi Racecourse isn't just home to the most lucrative races in all of India. The racetrack -- established under British colonial rule in 1883 -- is also a pastoral oasis near the heart of this teeming city. The green swath on display from inside the whitewashed grandstand induces a welcome sense of languor, one that is periodically interrupted when the horses approach the starting gate before a race.

The psychology community is engaged in a debate over the appropriateness of publishing studies that appear to show evidence for extrasensory perception in a scholarly journal. Do you think it's possible to scientifically study what is by definition extraordinary? And, do you believe in ESP and clairvoyance?

There are thousands and thousands of arrests in New York City in any given year -- and occasionally those taken into custody slip their shackles and flee. Sometimes they stay free long enough for the episodes to become embarrassing black eyes for the New York Police Department. But sometimes, the moments of freedom are so fleeting that the news media never learn of them. That does not mean there are not lessons to be learned, however. And here is a big one: Do not leave the keys to the cell where the prisoners can get them.

GLOVER--Erika Domenica Leopoldina, age 79, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, died on November 16, 2010, of heart failure and kidney failure at Nevis. Erika Glover was along with her late husband William a Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which they founded in 1964. She was born in the former Yugoslavia in 1931, left for Germany in 1954, and came to the United States, to Kentucky, in 1957. She settled in New York, where she worked for CBS and The New Yorker, marrying William Glover in 1962. She was a woman of courage, enthusiasm, and joy, a bonne vivante who loved her family very much. She is survived by daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu; a brother Luka, sister-in-law Vera, nephew Boris in Croatia; and cousins Marijan and Gregory in Toronto. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, www.doctorswithout borders.org

Holiday Train Show (through Sunday) This will be the last weekend to enjoy the sight, sound and smell of the Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden before it is packed away until the holidays of 2011. The TWA Flight Center at Kennedy International Airport, above, complete with a model of the Concorde, was a new addition to this season's display -- the 19th -- of more than 140 New York City landmarks made of twigs, pine cones, nuts, cinnamon sticks and other natural materials. The flight center joins veterans like the original Yankee Stadium and the Statue of Liberty and more recent sites, like the original Penn Station (2009) and the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History (2008). Also making its debut this season was a Thomas the Tank Engine train set. A crew of 20 took about 10 days to assemble the display's quarter-mile of track and lush backdrop; by Monday, it will be a memory of Christmas past. Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Bronx River Parkway, Exit 7W, Fordham Road, Bedford Park, the Bronx, (718) 817-8700, nybg.org; $20; $18 for students and 65+; $10 for children 2 to 12; free for under 2; parking, $12. (Anne Mancuso)

WASHINGTON -- He is a top executive at JPMorgan Chase, where he is paid as much as $5 million a year and supervises the Washington lobbying efforts for the nation's second largest bank. William M. Daley also serves on the board of directors at Boeing, the giant defense contractor, and Abbott Labs, the global drug company, which has billions of dollars at stake in health care reform. And now, Mr. Daley, a long-time Illinois political operative, will hold one of the most powerful jobs in Washington: chief of staff in the White House, where he will help decide who gets access to the Oval Office and what the president's Capitol Hill agenda should be.

On a side street in Long Island City, Queens, young people in artful dishabille ducked through the doorway of a factory marked Alfred Mainzer Inc. Greeting Cards on Wednesday night. Inside, they headed down a rabbit hole of sorts -- a hallway with a beamed ceiling so low they had to stoop -- into a very odd world. They were at the Flux Factory, an artists' collective, to learn about passions and obsessions at an event called Expert Oddities, where a group of artists across a variety of disciplines lectured on oddball subjects upon which they had fixated.

TRAGER--Judge David G. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of an extraordinary and beloved colleague, teacher, trustee, former dean and great friend. The son of Solomon and Clara Trager, who emigrated from Vienna to the United States at the end of World War I, David was raised in Mount Vernon, NY, and was a graduate of Columbia University and Harvard Law School. As a young lawyer, David trained under the great trial lawyer, Emile Zola Berman, and then served successively as law clerk to New York State Court of Appeals Judge Kenneth Keating and Chief Judge Stanley Fuld. He then began a career that combined law school teaching and public service. From 1970 to 1972, he served as Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and Chief of the Appeals Division. In 1972, he joined the faculty of Brooklyn Law School, with which he was associated until his death. In 1974, was appointed United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York by President Richard Nixon. When David took office, he pledged to hire only "the most qualified lawyers that can be attracted," selected solely on the basis of their ability, and he increased the hiring of women and minority assistants. He was the first U.S. Attorney in the country to create part-time positions for Assistant U.S. Attorneys. He also pledged to conduct business "in a completely independent and nonpolitical fashion," and to "enforce the laws vigorously against all who violate them." He kept that pledge, a fact recognized by President Jimmy Carter who continued him in office. In 1978, he returned to Brooklyn Law School, where he taught Constitutional Law and Conflict of Laws and, in 1983, was appointed Dean of the Law School. During his tenure as Dean, the School made great progress in virtually every area. He was instrumental in attracting nationally renowned and promising new scholars and made the School a magnet for visiting professors from around the world. Under his leadership, the School embarked on what was at the time the most ambitious capital expansion program in its history, including construction of an architecturally acclaimed addition to the School's main building and the purchase of the School's first residence halls. David was a formidable multi-tasker; while serving as Dean, he also served as Chair of the State Commission of Investigation, as a member of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, as President of the Federal Bar Council, and as Chairman of Mayor Koch's Committee on the Judiciary. In 1993, he was appointed United States District Judge for the Eastern District of New York, and continued his affiliation with Brooklyn Law School as a member of the Board of Trustees and as an Adjunct Professor. His role in raising the School to new heights was indispensable and his mark on Brooklyn Law School is indelible. We extend our deepest sympathy to David's wife, Roberta Weisbrod, their children, Mara (Isaac Koyfman), Josiah, and Naomi, grandchildren Nathaniel and Hannah, his brother, Arthur, and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick Chairman of the Board Joan G. Wexler President Michael A. Gerber Interim Dean

Ellen Weiss, the senior vice president for news at NPR whose quick firing of the senior news analyst Juan Williams last October ignited a political and public relations firestorm, resigned Thursday at the end of an internal investigation into the dismissal. Vivian Schiller, the president and chief executive of NPR, was denied her 2010 bonus by the NPR board, which said it was concerned over her role in the firing. The board expressed confidence, however, in her leadership in the future.

Yes, Robert De Niro is already a co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, but do you want to be the one to tell him he can't be involved in more than one cinematic gala at a time? The organizers of the Cannes Film Festival clearly didn't mind Mr. De Niro's other affiliation, announcing on Thursday that he will serve as the president of the jury for its coming 64th annual run, which will be May 11-22. Mr. De Niro, the quintessential New York actor whose films run the gamut from ''Mean Streets'' to ''Little Fockers,'' served as the president of the Cannes jury twice in the 1980s, and starred in two films that won the festival's Palme d'or prize: Martin Scorsese's ''Taxi Driver,'' in 1976, and Roland Joffe's ''Mission,'' in 1986. In a remarkably long statement for the notably laconic actor, Mr. De Niro said, ''The Cannes Film Festival is a rare opportunity for me as it is one of the oldest and one of the best in the world.'' He added that because of his involvement in the Tribeca Film Festival and its spinoff the Doha Tribeca Film Festival in Qatar, ''I have an increased appreciation for the jury, who serve, undertaking an important role in choosing films that are represented in the world of film at its highest level, and these types of festivals help connect the international film community and have a lasting cultural impact.''

Deep inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the $600 billion man is fast at work. In a spare, government-issue office in Lower Manhattan, behind a bank of cubicles and a scruffy copy machine, Josh Frost and a band of market specialists are making the Fed's ultimate Wall Street trade. They are buying hundreds of billions of dollars of United States Treasury securities on the open market in a controversial attempt to keep interest rates low and, in the process, revive the economy.

HIRSCH--Genevieve. On January 5, 2011, we lost Genevieve (nee Baucheron), 84 years old, a very special person loved by all who knew her for her unique spirit, her expertise in art and cuisine, and her singular blend of warmth and wisdom, learned during her incredible life on two continents. After the sad loss of her beloved husband, Joseph, almost thirty years ago, she rebuilt her life with the support of her family and a small group of close friends. She was a loving mother to her son, Ric and his wife, Karen, a doting grandmother to their children, Matthew, Andrew and Chloe, and a devoted stepmother to Joseph's sons, Chuck and Paul and his wife, Jane, and their children, Gina and Eric. Her loss leaves us all deeply saddened but nurturing loving memories of this extraordinary person and the life she so richly lived. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, those wishing to honor Gen's memory consider making donations to the American Diabetes Association, either through their website or directly to the Association at P.O. Box 11454, Alexandria, VA 22312.

Unlike its struggling rival Borders, Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest book chain, said on Thursday that it finished the holiday season with stronger sales than expected, reporting its highest comparable store sales increase since 1997. That increase was 9.7 percent over the same nine-week period the year before, while overall store sales increased 8.2 percent, to $1.1 billion. The company attributed the gains partly to interest in its e-reading devices, especially the Nook Color, which was introduced last fall.

Investors, still reeling from one disaster, are betting on the likelihood of another. Amid the volatility in the markets, wealthy individuals and big institutions are flocking to hedge funds that buy so-called catastrophe bonds and other investments tied to the probability of Gulf Coast hurricanes, Japanese earthquakes, large snowfalls in Canada and other natural disasters.

WASHINGTON -- The White House has ordered the Pentagon to squeeze almost all growth from its spending over the next five years, which will require eventually shrinking the Army and Marine Corps and seeking controversial increases in the fees paid by for retired, working-age veterans for their health insurance, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday. The reductions of up to 47,000 troops from the Army and Marine Corps forces -- roughly 6 percent shrinkage -- would be the first since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, reversing the trend ever since. They will be made easier by the withdrawal under way from Iraq, and will only begin in 2015 -- just as Afghan forces are to take over the security mission there according to agreements with NATO.
