HOROWITZ--Barbara. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the loss of Barbara Silver Horowitz, JTS trustee since 1999 and member of the board's Committee on The Jewish Museum. Ms. Horowitz was also a former member of the Advisory Board of JTS's William Davidson Graduate School of Jewish Education. Throughout her distinguished service, her thoughtful counsel was guided by her strong commitment to traditional Jewish values, and she was a determined advocate for JTS, around the board table and in the Jewish world. Loving wife of Gedale Horowitz, mother of Ruth Ellen and Seth Robert, and grandmother of Jared Isaac and Elliot, Ms. Horowitz was a dedicated philanthropist and champion of education, health care, and the arts. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

Facebook says that it will begin reporting its financial results by April 2012, setting the stage for a likely public stock offering, according to a document sent by Goldman Sachs to potential investors. As investor interest builds in private shares of Facebook, stoked by news of Goldman Sachs's deal with the social networking giant, the Securities and Exchange Commission is stepping up its inquiry into the trading of shares in hot private Internet companies. The S.E.C. has contacted Goldman about its private Facebook offering, according to the offering document, which calls the inquiry preliminary.

Colin Quinn knows his history well enough to star in a one-man Broadway show on the subject, but not well enough to know that January is when a production is supposed to quietly close up shop, not extend for another month. Nonetheless, the producers of ''Colin Quinn Long Story Short,'' in which Mr. Quinn recaps the 2,000-year trajectory of civilization in about 75 minutes, announced on Thursday that the show will again extend its run at the Helen Hayes Theater through March 5. This will likely be the final extension for the show, which also represents Jerry Seinfeld's debut as a Broadway director, as ''Rock of Ages'' is slated to move to the Helen Hayes that month.

An article on Thursday about a call for tax reform by the Internal Revenue Service's taxpayer advocate misstated, in some editions, the annual amount of write-offs, deductions and loopholes known as ''tax expenditures.'' It is $1.1 trillion, not billion.

Breast cancer patients in some states may soon lose Medicare coverage for the expensive drug Avastin, after the Food and Drug Administration's decision to revoke the drug's approval for that disease. Palmetto, one of the companies that determine Medicare coverage for different regions, said in a notice posted on its Web site that it would no longer pay for use of Avastin to treat breast cancer starting Jan. 29.

Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum who was accused by the Italian government of trafficking in looted artifacts, is now speaking out in her defense after never getting the chance to do so at her trial in Rome. The case against Ms. True, which dragged on for more than five years, ended abruptly in October after a court ruled that the statute of limitations on the crimes she was accused of had expired. Many witnesses testified for the prosecution, which argued that Ms. True knowingly bought ancient artifacts of dubious provenance for the collection of the Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

Lustig, Judith Schwartz, Co-Presidents; Simon Klarfeld, Executive Director

DIGLIO--Jeffrey. The Board and Staff of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved Board member Jeff Diglio. Jeff helped shape every program at God's Love and his impact will forever be immeasurable. Jeff taught us about the struggles of living with HIV/AIDS. He fought so valiantly, many times over the years, to regain his health, each time inspiring us. Jeff's dignity, kindness and loving care of others are hallmarks of a life well lived. We have lost a true hero and great friend. Everyone at God's Love mourns Jeff's passing. We send our heartfelt condolences to his parents, Marie and Stanley, and his partner Frederick Gonzalez. We will miss Jeff deeply and remember him forever.

After his flight from Cincinnati landed on Nov. 2, FrontPoint hedge fund manager Steven Czech turned on his BlackBerry and watched as his phone ''lit up like a Christmas tree'' with the devastating news that a colleague had been linked to a federal insider trading case. The development threatened to derail his nine-month effort to introduce a new fund. Mr. Czech had recently signed a fourth major investor.

BERLISS--Arthur, Jr. Quaker Ridge Golf Club remembers with admiration, Arthur Berliss, Jr., a member for over seven decades, who personified exceptionally high character and a keen interest in our community. Past president from 1972 to 1974, he will always be a part of Quaker Ridge heritage. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family in their time of sorrow. Quaker Ridge Golf Club Alan Howard, President

TRAGER--Judge David G. The members of the Federal Bar Council extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Roberta, and children, Mara, Josiah and Naomi and the rest of his family on the passing of the Honorable David G. Trager, who served with distinction as a United States District Judge for the Eastern District of New York. Judge Trager was President of the Federal Bar Council from 1986 to 1987, and in 2006 was awarded the Council's Emory Buckner Medal for outstanding public service. An active, valued and respected member of the Bench and Bar, Judge Trager will be missed by all of us. Frank H. Wohl, President, Federal Bar Council.
COHN--Mitzi. Dear Mom, Happy Birthday, a day does not pass that I wish I could speak to you. Love and miss you, Diane.

The philanthropists Edythe and Eli Broad unveiled plans on Thursday in Los Angeles for the museum that will be named after them and house their substantial collection of contemporary art. The three-story museum - to be designed by the firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro and called the Broad Art Foundation - will be near the Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Museum of Contemporary Art. It will feature almost an acre of column-free gallery space and a lecture hall for up to 200 people within its 120,000 square feet, and it will be wrapped with what the architects describe as a porous honeycomb ''veil,'' visible through a top-floor, sky-lit gallery.

NEW HIRE Elizabeth Warren, who is setting up the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, announced her latest significant hire: Holly Petraeus, left, the wife of Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan. Mrs. Petraeus will direct the Office of Servicemember Affairs, a division in the bureau that will be responsible for protecting military families from financial swindles. BEN PROTESS POSSIBLE BREAKUP Sara Lee is leaning toward splitting itself into its meats and coffee businesses after rejecting a takeover bid by JBS of Brazil, people briefed on the matter said.

Anthony S. Seminerio, a correction officer who served 30 years as a state lawmaker from southwest Queens before pleading guilty in 2009 to influence peddling, died on Thursday at a federal prison hospital, less than a year into his six-year sentence. He was 75. A federal prisons spokesman said Mr. Seminerio died at the Butner Federal Correctional Complex in Butner, N.C. The cause of death was not immediately available.

ALGUS--Dr. Seymour, 87, died January 5, 2011. Dr. Algus received his D.D.S. from University of Penn and studied periodontology at Columbia where he later taught. For 50 years he practiced periodontics in Brooklyn. While in the Coast Guard he developed a love for fishing and the outdoors. He was open, warm, and generous with a great sense of humor. Dr. Algus is survived by his devoted wife Myrna, daughter Jane, son Mitchell, his wife Dyanne, their children Amanda and Benjamin, great grandchild Alexis, fond uncle of Michael, Karen and Howard and their families, and many others who loved him.

SAUNDERS--Muriel Lewis April 17, 1917 to January 1, 2011. Daughter, wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister and aunt, Muriel Saunders left this world as she came into it, with a smile and passion to live each day to its fullest; she was an inspiration to many. Born and raised in the Bronx, she married the love of her life Ira Saunders in 1940. She worked for an accounting firm in Manhattan, and after the birth of her two daughters Barbra and Margi, she moved her family to Hewlett, New York where she was a devoted wife and mother. Muriel and Ira lived in Hewlett until 1979, when they moved to Delray Beach, Florida where they lived side by side until Ira's death in 1989. After the passing of Ira, Muriel continued to live life to the fullest as a golfer, avid card player, tennis enthusiast, world traveler and grandmother of four. Muriel had recently moved to Atlanta Georgia to be closer to her family and her newly born great grandchildren. Muriel passed away on January 1st, 2011 after having her last dance on New Year's Eve. She leaves behind many saddened by the loss: her sister Elaine Katz, her two daughters Barbra and Margi, their husbands Stephen and Peter, her grandchildren Joanna and boyfriend Shannon, Jennifer and fiance Heath, Brian and wife Christine and two great grandchildren Allison and Justin, and Neil and fiance Monica. Always a lady, she was a woman full of life and grace, and will be greatly missed by all.
ANASTASIO--Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Anastasio, associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1972 until retiring on June 1, 2006.

HOROWITZ--Barbara. The staff and trustees of the New Museum mourn the loss of Barbara Silver Horowitz, a true friend and dedicated supporter of the Museum with her husband Gedale, and daughter Ruth, a New Museum trustee. We remember Barbara's generosity, her love of art and fond travels together and extend our profound sympathy to Gedale, Ruth, son-in-law Michael, son Seth and daughter-in-law Linda.

An article on Wednesday about the assassination of Salman Taseer, an outspoken secular politician in Pakistan, misstated the decade in which he was imprisoned by the military dictator Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq for his opposition to the rise of religious parties and the extremism they spread. It was the 1980s, not the 1970s.

Members of Congress read the United States Constitution aloud on the floor of the House of Representatives on Thursday. It was an apparent first, and a reflected the influence of the Tea Party movement, which has celebrated the founding document. Despite the framers' stated intentions in the preamble to the Constitution, there is little ''domestic tranquility'' when it comes to interpreting what the document means. Following is sample of some of the clauses most revered, and disputed, by advocates on either side of the political spectrum. An annotated guide is available at nytimes.com/politics. KATE ZERNIKE Article I, Section 8

MUMBAI, India -- The fortunes of private equity firms took a big hit during the financial crisis, but Henry R. Kravis, the buyout mogul, says he is not ready for a ''tombstone'' -- not for his industry or for himself. Mr. Kravis, speaking to reporters in Mumbai on Thursday, said business was on the upswing again after two ''terrible'' years during which it was hard to raise money for funds and acquisitions. But the global economy and financial markets started improving last year and should gain speed in 2011, he said.

BRUCHEY--Stuart W.,93, passed away peacefully on December 20, 2010 of pneumonia in Austin, TX. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor, to whom he was married for 54 years; his sons, Andrew and Samuel: his daughters-in-law Aleksandra and Lisa; and four cherished grandchildren: Luka, Sofia, Ana, and Sammy. Born in Washington, D.C. to Nellie and Walter Bruchey, he graduated from McDonogh School in Pikesville, MD and received his AB and Ph.D. in history from John Hopkins University. He went on to a distinguished teaching career culminating in the Allan Nevins Professorship at Columbia University. After retirement he continued teaching as the Libra professor at the University of Maine at Orono, ME. He is also the author of numerous scholarly books and articles. He loved teaching and writing and was devoted to his students. We will miss his warmth, lively wit and his steadfast commitment to hard work, honesty and doing the right thing. We will hold him in our hearts forever.

STOUT--Nancy Tucker, died peacefully on Tuesday, January 4th. Wife of the late State Senator Richard R. Stout; beloved mother of Richard, Jr., Penny Strakhov, Betsy Foehl, Tucky Poque, Susan Stout and Nancy Taylor; cherished grandmother of ten grandchildren, Nachmans, Foehls, Pogues and Taylors and great-grandmother to seven and one-half great-grandchildren. Visitation on Friday, January 7th, 4pm-7pm at Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank. Funeral on Saturday, January 8th, 11am at St. George's by the River Church, 7 Lincoln Ave., Rumson.

TRAGER--Hon. David G. The Trustees, Physicians and Staff of The Brooklyn Hospital Center mourn the passing of longtime Trustee and friend, The Honorable David G. Trager. His leadership and dedication to the Hospital have been a model to us all, and we will miss him dearly. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Roberta, and to their entire family. Carlos P. Naudon, Chairman Jonathan Weld, Immediate Past Chairman Richard B. Becker, President

GIBLER--Zach. With sorrow we join the mourners of Zach Gibler. Though we had only recently met I felt as if I had connected with a lifelong friend. His passion, brilliance, humility, strength of character and goodness were always evident. Condolences to Mary and Rachel. May Zach's memory be a comfort to his family and all those upon whose life he had such an impact. Leon Wagner

My Sunday column looks at the rise of China, through the prism of the new women's world chess champion, Hou Yifan. She's a 16-year-old schoolgirl, and an astonishing phenomenon. Until now, there has only been one woman to crack the top 100 in chess rankings, and that's Judit Polgar, by far the most impressive player in the history of women's chess. Polgar, from an amazing chess-playing Hungarian family, peaked at no. 8 in the world and most recently was ranked 49. But Polgar is 34 and is unlikely to surge to the top of the rankings, while Hou Yifan is young enough that she could end up in the top few players worldwide over the next 10 or 15 years. (While Hou Yifan is the women's chess champion, she still has a lower ranking than Polgar, who does not compete in women's tournaments. Here's the piece by my Times colleague and chess columnist Dylan McClain about Hou's triumph.)

"The Social Network" picked up some awards-season momentum on Saturday, when the National Society of Film Critics named it best picture and handed out awards to David Fincher (best director), Jesse Eisenberg (best actor) and Aaron Sorkin (best screenplay). "Inside Job" nabbed the best nonfiction film award, while "Carlos," even though it's not eligible for an Oscar, was named best foreign language film. The best actress award went to "Vincere's" Giovanna Mezzogiorno, while Geoffrey Rush ("The King's Speech") and Olivia Williams ("The Ghost Writer") were named best supporting actor and actress, respectively.

For someone who doesn't actually live in Washington, Susan Axelrod has a pretty inside track to the White House. She is, after all, married to David Axelrod, who has been one of the president's closest advisers since before he even declared his run. The Caucus recently caught up with Ms. Axelrod, a founding member of CURE (Citizens United for Research in Epilepsy) at Commissary, a neighborhood coffee shop a few blocks away from the apartment her husband rents - at least through early February, when he moves back to their home in Chicago. She scanned the menu for cholesterol-healthy options and weighed in on everything from the ups and downs of life in the White House, what it will be like to have her husband back at home, how they met, what she misses about Chicago when she's not there, and her work.

SmartyPig customers received a disappointing note when they logged into their accounts this week: the online savings bank cut its interest rate -- the second rate cut in less than four months -- to 1.35 percent from 1.75 percent. So the Pig is no longer the star of the high-yield savings scene that it once was. Now, it's largely on par with other high-yield online savings accounts (Can we still call them that?) at institutions like American Express and Sallie Mae (which is still much better than most big brick-and-mortar banks).

A picture caption last Saturday with the college basketball roundup misidentified the Connecticut player shown taking a shot during the Huskies' victory over South Florida. He is Kemba Walker, not Roscoe Smith.

A cover article this weekend about choosing the Top 10 classical composers misstates, at one point, the length of time that opera had existed as of 1750, when Bach died. As the article correctly conveys in other references, opera had been around for roughly 150 years then, not ''a half-century.''

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Friday for an article about members of Congress who are choosing to sleep in their offices referred incorrectly to Representative Jason Chaffetz, Republican of Utah, who was shown setting up a cot. As the article correctly noted, Mr. Chaffetz came to Congress in 2008; he is not a freshman.

BADELL--Angeles, MD. Achieved her final peace at her home in Rye, NY on January 7, 2011. Dr. Badell was born in Barcelona, Spain in 1929, and her Catalan heritage and pride infused her life's achievements both personal and professional. She was the only female graduate in the class of 1952 of the Facultad de Medicina in Barcelona. Married in 1953, her young family made the journey to the United States in 1955. With pride, she became a United States citizen on April 20, 1964. Dr. Badell completed her residency in the new field of Rehabilitation with the support of Dr. Howard A. Rusk. As a leader in the study of physical medicine and pediatric rehabilitation, Dr. Badell's career spanned more than 50 years including roles as Director of the Children's Unit at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, NY and Director of Rehabilitation at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Westbury, NY. She pioneered the use of a combined therapy approach for children, integrating physical, speech and occupational therapies along with educational, emotional and family support. She also published extensively and is still considered an expert in the overall treatment of spina bifida. Dr. Badell's personal passion was being a mother and continually nurturing her own and her daughters' relationship with a beautiful, loving and multi-talented family miles away in Spain. Her legacy to her daughters and grandchildren is passed on through her values which speak to being a good person that honors family, enjoys the accomplishments that come with hard work, seeks an excellent education and has the courage to overcome obstacles. She is survived by her daughters and their husbands: Angie (Douglas Robertson), Carmen (John Thain), and Maria (Michael Paddack); and her treasured grandchildren are blessed with many memories of their "Yaya" and "Grandma": Alexander (Tracy), Nicole, Victoria and Zachary Thain; Anna Fleming and Eliza Claire Paddack, along with an extended family in and around Barcelona, Spain. It was Dr. Badell's wish that she also be known for her ongoing esteem and support of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus. Services will be held at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY on Tuesday January 11, at 11am.
KRISTOF BLOG Readers are invited to send questions about Sudan to Nicholas D. Kristof and former President Jimmy Carter. nytimes.com/ontheground

The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday named James R. Doty, a white-collar criminal defense attorney and former general counsel at the agency, the nation's top accounting regulator. The S.E.C. appointed Mr. Doty chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, an independent panel created by Congress in the wake of scandals at Enron and Worldcom. Before that, the industry policed itself. The board inspects accounting firms, writes rules and fines violators.

An article on Friday about a legal dispute between American sunken treasure hunters and the government of Spain, in which the treasure hunters are using some of the confidential diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks, referred incorrectly to the release of those cables. WikiLeaks has 251,287 cables and has released all of them to several news organizations; it has not released all of them publicly. (According to the State Department, about 2,700 of the cables have been made public to date.) The error also appeared on Dec. 4 in an article about the cables and in an Inside The Times capsule summary for that article.

The Seahawks are the worst team ever to reach the playoffs in an established league that doesn't award postseason berths like participation trophies. Their first-round hopes rest with their legendary home-field advantage (bolstered by crowd noise and jet lag) and the Saints' knack for tripping over weak opponents (see Cardinals and Browns). SEAHAWKS ON OFFENSE If Matt Hasselbeck was the family sedan, he would be donated to charity for a tax write-off rather than traded in at this point. Hasselbeck is a consummate pro who has had an outstanding career, but he could snap like a piece of balsa wood at any time. The rest of the offense was built from post-consumer recyclables, cast-offs from bad teams like Mike Williams (Lions), Marshawn Lynch (Bills) and Michael Robinson (Niners). The hardest hitter in the N.F.L. is not Ray Lewis or Troy Polamalu; it's central tendency. The Saints' defense recorded 26 interceptions and 9 return touchdowns last year, but those outliers regressed to 9 interceptions and 2 turnovers this season. The Saints' real turnover potential lies somewhere between the two extremes.

JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley said on Friday that they had each won approval from Chinese regulators to form joint ventures in the country, potentially giving them a bigger role in China's booming securities business. The two firms are the latest global banks to win the right to team up with local players to underwrite stock and bond offerings in China. Eventually, the joint ventures will be able to sell stocks to Chinese citizens and institutions.

A regional Medicare contractor that was planning to stop paying for use of the drug Avastin to treat breast cancer has reversed course. The contractor, Palmetto GBA, which determines Medicare coverage for certain states, said it would continue to pay for Avastin while the drug's manufacturer, Genentech, appealed a decision by the Food and Drug Administration to revoke the drug's approval as a treatment for breast cancer.

Grant money for dance is flowing through the Joyce Theater. The Joyce said on Friday that it would allot $625,000 toward helping 10 choreographers - and possibly more - work on projects. Six will be given partners from the world of theater - directors or dramaturges - to help them ''embrace new methods of creating work by introducing them to the theater model in which projects go through multiple workshops,'' the Joyce said. The Rockefeller Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund and Andrew W. Mellon Foundation are giving the grants. The dance-theater pairs are Monica Bill Barnes and Pam MacKinnon, Alexandra Beller and Katherine Profeta, Nora Chipaumire and Doris Mirescu, Doug Elkins and Anne Kauffman, Mark Lonergan and Kirsten Bowen, and Gesel Mason and Morgan Jenness. Four other choreographers, Wally Cardona, Jessica Lang, Pam Tanowitz and Kate Weare, are being given space, staff workers, advice and $25,000 to create new works.

GREENBERG--Josiah. Dean David M. Schizer and the entire Columbia Law School community deeply mourn the loss of its distinguished graduate, Josiah Greenberg '81. Josiah is the son of our esteemed colleague and former Dean of Columbia College, Professor Jack Greenberg '48, and stepson of Deborah Greenberg '57, founding director of the Law School's AIDS Law Clinic. Josiah was a founding partner of Greenberg & Oser LLP. He was widely recognized for his skill with sophisticated and complex commercial and personal legal transactions. Josiah was admitted to practice in several of the nation's top courts, including the U.S. Supreme Court. During this difficult time, all of us extend our deepest condolences to the Greenberg family.

When Daniel Kitson was about 9, he told his teacher that he was thinking of killing himself. At some point over the next few decades, he forgot this had ever happened, until just over a week ago when his mother reminded him. Asked in an interview if he really was suicidal or if it was just a plea for attention, he said with a merry chuckle, ''I have no idea.'' It's the kind of odd, intriguing story that Mr. Kitson specializes in: disturbing, willfully open-ended and its content incongruously matched with its tone. In his acclaimed shows Mr. Kitson, a 33-year-old British comic with a bushy beard and a stutter, explores questions about loss and love and the pursuit of meaning that are too complicated to answer completely.

On the third-season premiere of ''Jersey Shore'' on Thursday night, it was Deena Cortese, the newest addition to the beach house, who spent the episode repeatedly declaring herself a ''blast in a glass.'' But on Friday it was MTV that had cause to celebrate: it said the premiere had been watched by 8.45 million viewers, making it MTV's highest-rated series broadcast to date. The Season 3 debut episode, in which Nicole Polizzi (alias Snooki), Mike Sorrentino (aka the Situation) and their catchphrase-coining pals returned to their abode in Seaside Heights, N.J., saw a ratings increase of 63 percent over the Season 2 premiere in July (when the orange-skinned cast traveled to Miami) and 36 percent over that season's finale in October. The overall viewership for the latest ''Jersey Shore'' premiere at 10 p.m. even exceeded broadcast networks like ABC (which drew 7.8 million viewers for a ''Private Practice'' repeat) and NBC (which attracted just over two million for reruns of ''The Office''). ''At the end of the day they haven't changed,'' Chris Linn, MTV's executive vice president of programming and head of production, said in a telephone interview. ''They're still true to who they are. They're the same characters that we fell in love with in the first season. I think we all have the same worry that the success of the show and their notoriety would somehow change them into something less enjoyable, and that just hasn't happened.''

On Feb. 8 Donald H. Rumsfeld's long-awaited memoir, ''Known and Unknown,'' will go on sale, full of recollections from Mr. Rumsfeld's long and often contentious time in public service. Then there is the alternate version: ''Donald,'' a novel published by McSweeney's, which promises ''America's former Secretary of Defense like we have never known him before.''

Beloved husband of Ann, father of Nicholas and Kate, grandfather of Emily, David, and Vanessa, uncle of Miye Schakne. Scientist, researcher. scholar and teacher at Columbia University; a lover of music and the buildings in which it was performed, he did honor to this devotion in his work and in his life.

Warm, funny and intuitive, she befriended her colleagues and engaged everyone she met. Mom never hesitated to speak her mind or follow her dreams. We were proud of her and will miss her. Nancy

Were you already jealous of Lena Dunham, the 24-year-old wunderkind writer, director and star of the sleeper-hit comedy ''Tiny Furniture''? Prepare to grow even greener with envy: on Friday HBO announced that it had ordered a full season of a new comedy series that Ms. Dunham created and will star in for that cable channel. HBO said in a news release that the series, called ''Girls,'' will offer ''a comic look at the assorted humiliations and rare triumphs of a group of girls in their early 20s,'' with a cast that will also feature Jemima Kirke (of ''Tiny Furniture''), Allison Williams (''American Dreams''), Adam Driver (of the HBO movie ''You Don't Know Jack'') and Zosia Mamet (''Mad Men''). Lest she be labeled an underachiever, Ms. Dunham also wrote and directed the show's pilot episode, and the series will be produced by Jenni Konner and Judd Apatow (who's keeping plenty busy himself these days). A premiere date for ''Girls'' wasn't immediately announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FRIEDMAN--B. H. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sadness the passing of longtime Trustee, writer, advisor, and dear friend, B. H. Friedman. He will always be remembered for his love of art, language and books. Bob wrote the biography of the Museum's founder Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney and numerous works on artists including an early biography on Jackson Pollock. His passion for the Whitney and American Art led to his appointment to the Whitney Board of Trustees in 1961, as one of the original non-family Trustees. B. H. lent his intellect and wisdom to the shaping of the institution for four decades serving as Chairman of the Whitney's first Building Committee and overseeing the planning and construction of our iconic Marcel Breuer Building. During his outstanding leadership of the Acquisitions Committee, the Museum's collection was enhanced by so many of the New York School of artists he befriended. When elected an Honorary Trustee in 1978, it was said that B.H. "brought a dimension to our thinking, an insight, which is rare and precious.' This depth and his legacy will remain an indelible part of the Whitney. His presence will be sorely missed. Our most sincere and heartfelt sympathies to his daughter Daisy, his son Jackson, daughter-in-law Petra, and his grandchildren Oskar and Linea. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

An obituary on Friday about Margot Stevenson, a Broadway actress who also appeared in films and on the radio, misspelled the surname of the actress who originated the part of Margot Lane on the radio show ''The Shadow,'' which Ms. Stevenson later played. She was Agnes Moorehead, not Moorhead.

HILLYER--Raphael. The Juilliard School is saddened by the death of Raphael Hillyer, a former faculty member and a founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet. With grace, intelligence, and artistry Raphael Hillyer created a distinguished career as a superb violist and successful pedagogue. His contributions to the Juilliard tradition of excellence will be eternally appreciated by us all. Joseph W. Polisi, President

LONDON -- It might seem like a curious marriage of author and subject. But the British writer Monica Ali's forthcoming novel tells the story of a fictional princess based on Diana, Princess of Wales, and imagines what might have happened had Diana not been killed in a car accident in Paris in 1997. The book, ''Untold Story,'' is to be published by Scribner in the United States in June (it comes out in Britain in March), and arises from Ms. Ali's longtime ''what if?'' musings about Diana, who was 36, divorced and struggling to find her new, post-royal place in the world when she died.

An article on Tuesday about a pardon that outgoing Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California gave to Esteban Nuñez, the son of a former speaker of the State Assembly, misidentified the person who had written a letter on Mr. Nuñez's behalf. It was Bob White, who was chief of staff for former Gov. Pete Wilson; the letter was not written by Mr. Wilson.

ANDEREGG--Karen. My other mother, for 41 years. Beloved by me, my husband, and my children. She cried when she showed me this poem, because it described the life that she felt so lucky to have: We met at the end of the party / When most of the drinks were dead / And all the glasses dirty: / "Have this that's left," you said. / We walked through the last of summer, / When shadows reached long and blue / Across days that were growing shorter: / You said: "There's autumn too." / Always for you what's finished / Is nothing, and what survives / Cancels the failed, the famished, / As if we had fresh lives / From that night on, and just living / Could make me unaware / Of June, and the guests arriving, / And I not there. -Philip Larkin Karen, we love you and we will miss you forever. Margit, Peter, Axel & Augie
GOLD--Beatrice. Jan 8, 1994 Memories of you Mother are always in our hearts. Your loving Daughter and family.

Jets at ColtsSaturday, 8 p.m.Line: Colts by 21/2 The Jets did not fall easily to the Colts in last year's A.F.C. Championship game, holding a 4-point lead midway through the third quarter before falling to a 17-point finishing kick by Peyton Manning. The 30-17 defeat announced the Jets as the N.F.L.'s Next Big Thing, and just in case you missed the announcement, the team spent seven months tweeting it, texting it and shouting it through bullhorns on street corners.

PAPE--Michael V. passed away on January 5, 2011 at his residence in Scarsdale. He was 95 years old. Mr. Pape was born August 12, 1915 in Greenpoint Brooklyn to Joseph and Rose Pontone Pape. Mr. Pape was the president of Ace Gear Industries Inc. and member of the Scarsdale American Legion. He was a veteran of the United States Army. Mr. Pape is survived by two sons Dr. Lawrence G. One way my husband and I save a little money is to use the shampoo, conditioner and other products we've collected from hotel stays. During the depths of the recession, when we stayed at an apartment rental, we stocked up on the hair products the owners had left for us to use. Still, I couldn't help wondering whether we were being frugal or we were stealing.

A federal judge in New York has dismissed a lawsuit against J.K. Rowling, the author of the ''Harry Potter'' series, clearing Ms. Rowling of an accusation that she borrowed plotlines from a book by another British author, Adrian Jacobs. The lawsuit was brought by the estate of Mr. Jacobs and concerns his 1987 book, ''The Adventures of Willy the Wizard.'' Mr. Jacobs's estate said that Ms. Rowling had copied from the book for ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,'' the fourth in her series. Ms. Rowling said that she had never heard of Mr. Jacobs's book until the plagiarism charge was made.

HOROWITZ--Barbara. Dean David M. Schizer and the entire Columbia Law School community are greatly saddened by the loss of Barbara Silver Horowitz, who was, along with her husband, Gedale B. Horowitz '55, a devoted champion of the Law School and Columbia University. Throughout her life, Barbara had an unstinting devotion to educational excellence. She was intimately connected to the alumni affairs of Barnard College from the time she graduated in 1955, and generously endowed a chair for the director of education at Barnard and established its Centennial Scholars program. For many years Barbara and Dale have also extended their counsel, generosity, and friendship to the Law School, where Dale has served on the Steering Committee for the Board of Visitors, and his class reunion committee. Last year, they received Columbia University Alumni Medals for Distinguished Service from the Columbia Alumni Association. Barbara was an inspiration to many for conveying her passion for Columbia with both humility and grace. Our hearts and deepest sympathies go out to Dale, son Seth '89, daughter Ruth Horowitz Nachman, and their families.

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: ROAD TO MOROCCOBing Crosby portrays Jeff Peters, and Bob Hope is Turkey Jackson, con artists marooned in the Arabian desert after a shipwreck, in this 1942 musical, directed by David Butler. In need of cash, Jeff sells Turkey into slavery, but then decides to rescue his friend after his conscience gets the best of him -- only to discover that Turkey is now the romantic consort of the beautiful Princess Shalmar (Dorothy Lamour, above, with Hope, left, and Crosby). But Turkey has competition in the evil sheik Mullay Kasim (Anthony Quinn). Meanwhile, a court astrologer sees doom in Jeff and Turkey's future. In introducing the film, Robert Osborne and Alec Baldwin explain why ''Road to Morocco'' -- the third, and most popular, of the ''Road'' pictures starring Crosby, Hope and Lamour -- is must-see viewing. The evening continues on a royal theme with ''The Prince and the Showgirl'' (1957), with Marilyn Monroe as an American starlet in London who causes an international stir when she falls for a titled European (Laurence Olivier, who also directed), at 9:30; ''The Swan'' (1956), starring Grace Kelly as a noblewoman who falls for her brother's tutor (Louis Jourdan) on the eve of her marriage to a prince (Alec Guinness), at 11:30; ''Mrs. Brown'' (1997), about the scandalous friendship between Queen Victoria (Judi Dench) and John Brown (Billy Connolly), her personal servant, at 1:30 a.m.; and ''The Student Prince'' (1954), with Edmund Purdom as a prince who falls in love with a barmaid (Ann Blyth) during his last fling before assuming the crown, at 3:30. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY On the one-year anniversary of the earthquake in Haiti, Kim Lawton returns to the country to examine what religious agencies are doing to help survivors. Also, Saul Gonzalez reports on the Seamen's Church Institute, the largest service organization for mariners in the United States.

On Sunday, this storm-tossed city will reach an impressive municipal milestone: the 17th consecutive day, stretching back to the bureaucratic observance of Christmas on Dec. 24, that alternate-side parking rules are suspended. That is a long time for the streets to go uncleaned. Perhaps you're wondering if your car will start. Maybe you think it's some sort of record. (Sadly, we did.)

Take that, Ohio State. Almost a week after Texas Christian University beat Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl, the team's supporters are apparently still gloating. Twenty electronic billboards appeared in and around Columbus on Friday with a message directed at Ohio State.

DINSMORE--Edwin J. 91, of Phillipsburg, NJ, Laguna Niguel, CA and formerly of Forest Hills Gardens, NY went to his eternal life on December 15, 2010 from his New Jersey home with his loving family at his bedside. Husband of Josephine for 54 years; father to six children, Dr. Robert, Kathleen (Dubia), Brian, Patricia (Jennings), Dr. Stephen and Dr. Barbara (Burke)and devoted grandfather to 12 wonderful grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Ed graduated from St. John's University and served proudly in WWII as a US Coast Guard Lieutenant seeing action in the European and Pacific Theaters. Ed was a CPA working both for Continental Baking Company & ITT. He was known for his love of family, New York Times crosswords, scrabble games and a Master's bridge player actively playing in California, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania bridge clubs. Ed's brother-in-law, Msgr. James B. Reynolds offered a Mass of Resurrection at St. Patrick's Church in Belvidere, NJ, December 18th at 12 noon to celebrate his blessed life.

To review or not to review? Or rather, when to review? That is a question lately debated in reference to ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' the exhaustively discussed, exhaustingly delayed new musical that began previews in late November and has postponed its opening date three times. When the opening was pushed back from Jan. 11 to Feb. 7, a couple of critics decided to toss aside Broadway decorum and file reports after attending a preview performance.

An operatic version of ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' national tours by the Abbey Theater and the Druid Theater Company and an Irish film series curated by Gabriel Byrne at the Museum of Modern Art are among the highlights of a year-long Irish arts series in the United States that will be funded by the Irish government, press representatives for the series said on Thursday. The full program, called Imagine Ireland, will feature some 400 events in 40 states and will be supported by a $5.3 million investment from Ireland. It is expected to be announced on Friday morning at a presentation hosted by Mr. Byrne, the ''In Treatment'' star and Irish cultural ambassador, and Christine C. In the corner of our dining room, there's an old half-round cabinet on wheels. It has a handsomely decorated front-panel that swings around on a lazy susan to reveal a collection of whiskey glasses and decanters on the other side. It's what's sometimes called a hide-a-bar, though we use it now mainly as a place to charge our cellphones. We keep it prominently displayed because we like it. But it also oddly embodies the split life of my mother-in-law, from whom we inherited it. And it has lately shaped the course of my own life both as a writer and a son-in-law.

As a lifelong resident of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Gary Atlas would always enjoy seeing the robust old Russians marching up the beach, dripping and content after a frigid dip in the wintry ocean. So in September 2007, while unemployed and tending to his mother, Enid, who was dying of emphysema, Mr. Atlas sought relief from depression by running on the beach and swimming in the ocean every day.

WHO will be making it big in 2011? Clare Grafik, senior curator of the Photographers' Gallery in London, puts her money on Maurizio Anzeri, an Italian artist based in London whose work incorporates drawing, sculpture, photography, even hair. Using vintage studio portraits found in flea markets, Mr. Anzeri responds to each (unidentified) sitter with a unique configuration of colored thread stitched into the surface of the photograph. ''Rather than a gesture of annihilation,'' Ms. Grafik said, ''these patterns, often formed over the faces of the subjects, seem to augment their sitters' identities. What results are unique and intimate artworks that take the power of the anonymous photograph into the realm of a poetic personal vision.'' ELIAS REDSTONE

TOWNIES The courtroom is one of those quintessential New York situations where people are just cobbled together, trying to make sense of it all. Like an apartment building, it is a self-contained world, conforming to its own logic. The court attorneys, often former prosecutors who now counsel 200 or so people a day, shuffle in and out, jotting down the bare bones of people's sagas and stories, sifting through gripes and vituperations, offering advice on the fly. As in any court, the attorneys know the predilections of the judges: some don't like cyclists; another has a thing against dogs. One judge, a court officer told me, used to charge higher fines for people caught drinking imported beer than for those drinking domestic ones.-- ELIZABETH DWOSKIN, excerpt from ''Summoned by the Court Jester FIXES Brazil is employing a version of an idea now in use in some 40 countries,one already successful on an enormous scale. This is likely the most important government antipoverty program the world has ever seen. It is worth looking at how it works, and why it has been able to help so many people. The program fights poverty in two ways. One is straightforward: it gives money to the poor. This works. And no, the money tends not to be stolen or diverted to the better-off. The idea's other purpose -- to give children more education and better health -- is longer term and harder to measure. But measured it is.-- TINA ROSENBERG, excerpt from ''To Beat Back Poverty, Pay the Poor'' For more, nytimes.com/opinionator

A picture caption on Page 6 this weekend with an article about the comic actor Brian Bedford misidentifies the actress playing opposite him in the latest Broadway revival of ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' She is Charlotte Parry (as Cecily Cardew), not Sara Topham, who plays Gwendolyn in the production.

FRIEDMAN--B. H. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sadness the passing of longtime Trustee, writer, advisor, and dear friend, B. H. Friedman. He will always be remembered for his love of art, language and books. Bob wrote the biography of the Museum's founder Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney and numerous works on artists including an early biography on Jackson Pollock. His passion for the Whitney and American Art led to his appointment to the Whitney Board of Trustees in 1961, as one of the original non-family Trustees. B. H. lent his intellect and wisdom to the shaping of the institution for four decades serving as Chairman of the Whitney's first Building Committee and overseeing the planning and construction of our iconic Marcel Breuer Building. During his outstanding leadership of the Acquisitions Committee, the Museum's collection was enhanced by so many of the New York School of artists he befriended. When elected an Honorary Trustee in 1978, it was said that B.H. "brought a dimension to our thinking, an insight, which is rare and precious.' This depth and his legacy will remain an indelible part of the Whitney. His presence will be sorely missed. Our most sincere and heartfelt sympathies to his daughter Daisy, his son Jackson, daughter-in-law Petra, and his grandchildren Oskar and Linea. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

RAPPAPORT--Stanley. The partners and staff of Rochlin Greenblatt Gallo LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend Stanley Rappaport. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Beatrice, children Danny and Ronda and his daughter-in-law Evelyn, his grandchildren and his family. Stanley was kind, considerate and devoted to his family and his friends. He was an excellent businessman who enriched the lives of all who were fortunate to know him. He will be missed and always remembered for his kindness and generosity. To know Stanley is to love him. Robert E. Rochlin

An obituary last Sunday about the author Ruth Park misstated the name of the protagonist of a series of radio plays and books she wrote for children. He is the Muddle-Headed Wombat, not the Muddle-Headed Mongoose.

RHODES--Russell, L. Noted advertising executive and author died of natural causes on December 29, 2010, in New York City where he resided for over 35 years. Mr. Rhodes, the younger son of Mary and Edgar Rhodes, was born on October 27, 1931 in Derby, Connecticut. He graduated from Loomis School and Yale University and earned an MBA from Harvard Business School. After business school, Mr. Rhodes joined Procter and Gamble in Cincinnati in its marketing department before embarking on a career in the advertising agency world. He spent a decade in England and France with the Norman, Craig & Kummel agency and Ogilvy & Mather. He subsequently moved to New York with Ogilvy & Mather where he held senior positions on such accounts as American Express, Avon and Cotton Inc. During this period he found time to write five novels of the spy/ thriller genre, among which were "The Herod Conspiracy" and "The Styx Complex." After twenty years with Ogilvy & Mather, Mr. Rhodes retired and spent his retirement traveling and enjoying life with his legion of friends. Mr. Rhodes is survived by his brother Edward, of Albuquerque, New Mexico, numerous family members and seven godchildren in the United States and the United Kingdom. He was an accomplished, erudite man of great wit, charm and spirit. He will be greatly missed. A memorial service, date to be announced, will be held. Martinis will be served.

GLOVER--Erika Domenica Leopoldina, age 79, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, died on November 16, 2010, of heart failure and kidney failure at Nevis. Erika Glover was along with her late husband William a Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which they founded in 1964. She was born in the former Yugoslavia in 1931, left for Germany in 1954, and came to the United States, to Kentucky, in 1957. She settled in New York, where she worked for CBS and The New Yorker, marrying William Glover in 1962. She was a woman of courage, enthusiasm, and joy, a bonne vivante who loved her family very much. She is survived by daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu; a brother Luka, sister-in-law Vera, nephew Boris in Croatia; and cousins Marijan and Gregory in Toronto. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, www.doctorswithout borders.org

A cover article this weekend about choosing the Top 10 classical composers misstates, at one point, the length of time that opera had existed as of 1750, when Bach died. As the article correctly conveys in other references, opera had been around for roughly 150 years then, not ''a half-century.''

Our deepest love goes out to Jane, Elizabeth, Kathryn, Ben and Olivia, and rest assured that you will forever be in our hearts. The Balkan, Drazan, Finkelstein, Goldstein and Mendelsohn Families

Russia's remarkable gold medal at the world junior championships in Buffalo this week - three straight comeback victories, including five unanswered third-period goals to beat Canada, 5-3, before more than 18,000 fans at HSBC Arena in the tournament final Wednesday - again put the lie to all the stereotypes that are trotted out at international hockey events. Stereotypes like the notion that Canadians are hard-working players who more than make up for lack of talent with big hearts and an indomitable will to win. Or that the Russians supposedly have endless talent but are petulant, enigmatic and undependable when it matters.

IT was the airport in Lviv, of all things, that first charmed me. Regional airports across the former Soviet Union tend to be a dreary lot, with all the appeal of a 24-hour bus station. But the one in Lviv, the largest city in western Ukraine, had wood paneling and ornate columns and the feel of a grand old railway station in a 1950s film. I was there last winter to cover the Ukrainian presidential elections, tromping through the snow to watch the candidates on the stump and to pester voters for their opinions. But I soon discovered that this city on the edge of the Soviet empire, at a crossroads of Europe, was a cobblestoned find. The unexpected beauty of the airport terminal was a hint of what Lviv offered -- winding streets that reflected the influences of centuries of overlapping cultures.

HIRSCH--Genevieve. On January 5, 2011, we lost Genevieve (nee Baucheron), 84 years old, a very special person loved by all who knew her for her unique spirit, her expertise in art and cuisine, and her singular blend of warmth and wisdom, learned during her incredible life on two continents. After the sad loss of her beloved husband, Joseph, almost thirty years ago, she rebuilt her life with the support of her family and a small group of close friends. She was a loving mother to her son, Ric and his wife, Karen, a doting grandmother to their children, Matthew, Andrew and Chloe, and a devoted stepmother to Joseph's sons, Chuck and Paul and his wife, Jane, and their children, Gina and Eric. Her loss leaves us all deeply saddened but nurturing loving memories of this extraordinary person and the life she so richly lived. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, those wishing to honor Gen's memory consider making donations to the American Diabetes Association, either through their website or directly to the Association at P.O. Box 11454, Alexandria, VA 22312.

A map on Nov. 28 with an article about joint naval exercises by the United States and South Korea in the East China Sea erroneously included one area as part of China's self-proclaimed 200-mile exclusive economic zone, which China had warned the joint naval exercise participants to avoid. The zone does not include the area east of the Korean peninsula. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the map was published; this correction was delayed because editors failed to follow through on the complaint.

LEACH--Joe C. Joe C. Leach, originally of Brownwood, Texas, passed away on December 28, 2010. Joe came from humble beginnings in Brownwood, where his academic drive and basketball skills eventually earned him a full scholarship at Howard Payne University. After graduating, Joe gave back to his beloved home state as both a basketball coach and biology teacher. In the early 70s, his natural abilities in business carried him first to Dallas and later to Sydney, Australia, where he discovered the first designer denim: "JAG" jeans. He then opened the first ever jeans-only store in Beverly Hills, CA. After making his mark on the fashion world, Joe changed courses and went to work in finance for his mentor, Alan Greenberg, at the Los Angeles office of Bear Stearns. It was there that Joe's trademark tenacity, honesty and humility earned him the trust of those around him and allowed him to cultivate a thriving business and build precious friendships, both of which he lovingly nurtured for over thirty years. In addition to being a successful businessman and entrepreneur, Joe was a genuine bon vivant. Friends were always greeted with a warmhearted smile and notoriously good humor. In his free time, Joe loved to play golf and was an avid sports aficionado. Throughout his life, Joe remained proud of his modest roots and returned to Texas as often as he could. Joe is survived by his loving wife, Heyson Leach, and sons Skip Morelock Leach of Dallas and Scott Leach of Los Angeles. Predeceasing him were his parents Carl and Juanita Leach and brother Ronald Leach. Joe's favorite quote, "Life is not about learning to survive the storm, but rather learning how to dance in the rain..." We are all blessed to have danced with him. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: The Vintage Club Employees Scholarship Fund 42-600 Cook Street, Suite 201B Palm Desert, CA 92211 Telephone: (760)674-9080 Fax: (760) 674-8121

NELSON--Dr. Irving, a warm and caring pediatrician for thousands of children in Westchester County for over 60 years, passed away peacefully at his home in Ardsley, NY on December 27, 2010. He was 95 years old. Dr. Nelson had a long, illustrious career as a pediatrician. Following graduation from New York University in 1935 and Long Island College of Medicine in 1939, he joined the US Air Force and was stationed in Italy. He served as a Flight Surgeon from 1941-1946 and was a highly decorated Lt. Colonel. He completed his pediatrics training at Cumberland Hospital, where he was Chief Pediatric Resident in 1947. Dr. Nelson was director of Pediatrics at White Plains Hospital from 1957 to 1971, and was Attending Pediatrician at Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla and St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was elected Chairman of the Pediatrics Section of the Westchester Academy of Medicine in 1962 and 1963. Dr. Nelson proudly volunteered for several community organizations. He participated in the Westchester County Department of Health Well Baby Clinics in Tuckahoe and White Plains, volunteered for many years as the Physician for the Town of Greenville Volunteer Fire Department, and was the pediatrician for Hartsdale Public Schools. Dr. Nelson was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 10, 1915, and was older brother to Howard and Ruth. He is survived by his beloved wife Gloria, his devoted children Francine (Murray) and Mitchell (Leslie), and five adoring grandchildren Kate, Jeffrey, Josh, Scott, and Tommy. Private funeral services were held on Friday December 31, 2010. Donations may be made to White Plains Hospital, Pediatrics Department, 41 East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10061 (or online at www.wphospital.org)

SPAMER--Otto G. passed away peacefully New Years' Day, January 1, 2011, with his wife and son at his bedside. A devoted husband of 41 years to his wife, Dr. Carmel N. Donovan. Loving father to son Donovan and his wife Kristan. Very proud and adoring grandfather of Logan Otto Spamer. He attended Fordham Preparatory School and University and received a Masters in Hospital Administration from George Washington University. He was also a Captain in the United States Air Force. As a former hospital director Otto G. Spamer, along with four Radiologists founded Lenox Hill Radiology and Medical Imaging Associates, PC, a private Radiology practice on the Upper Eastside of Manhattan. Here he was devoted to providing quality, compassionate and efficient care. Otto cared and looked after all. He was an avid reader and thinker, and he loved to pass along his knowledge to others. Otto will be remembered as an irreplaceable teacher, and his generosity will never be forgotten. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and staff members. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 15th at 3 pm at Christ United Methodist Church, 520 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations may be sent to: In honor of Dr. Michael Zervos's care of Otto G. Spamer Stephen B. Colvin Professorship Fund NYU Langone Medical Center Office of Development One Park Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10016.

In theory, the more minutes a team's most productive player can play per game, the better. The Golden State Warriors seem to be embracing that spirit wholeheartedly with their use of shooting guard Monta Ellis. Leading the N.B.A. in minutes a game at 40.9 entering Saturday, Ellis is second on the team with a 20.17 player efficiency rating, according to ESPN. His minutes are actually down from 41.4 a game last season, which also led the league.

OF all the lo-fi carryalls about to hit stores, the cheekiest may well be the Together Bag from Thursday Friday, a screen-printed tote resembling the iconic Hermès Birkin. Roni Brunn and Olena Sholomytska, the pair behind Thursday Friday, were looking to create a bag that could be used for everything, including the groceries, when inspiration hit. ''We realized that we were using an extra bag to supplement our 'real' bags,'' Ms. Sholomytska said. ''So we ended up with a surreal design that references luxury but is ultimately an anti-status status symbol.'' It's $35 at thufri.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

TOBIAS-DAVIS--Judy. We are deeply saddened by the loss of Judy Tobias Davis, a board member for more than 25 years who made her mark at Goddard Riverside Community Center. An advocate and a fervent champion for our programs and for families, she was a true leader who inspired her colleagues with her compassion, savvy and style. We will remember her as a consummate host for our Meet-the-Author Dinners and a unique visionary who elevated our Musical Evenings series to new heights. Our thoughts are with her family. Goddard Riverside Community Center.

8 P.M. (13, 49) ELSA'S LEGACY: THE BORN FREE STORY In 1960 Joy Adamson published ''Born Free,'' the story of an orphaned lion cub in Kenya named Elsa, left, and her eventual release back into the wild after being taught by Ms. Adamson and her husband, George, to survive on her own. The book sold millions of copies and in 1966 was made into an Academy Award-winning film -- in the process changing public perceptions by treating animals as individuals. The reality behind the movie was far less romantic. This 50th-anniversary special, presented by ''Nature,'' uses George Adamson's journal entries, home movies and conversations with several of the couple's confidants to examine their roles as pioneering conservationists and their controversial views about wildlife. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURRepresentative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, and Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, debate federal spending.

Q. Which constitutional amendment decrees when Congress should assemble, and what date does it specify? A. That would be the 20th Amendment, which states that new terms begin Jan. 3, ''unless they shall by law appoint a different day.'' The 112th Congress chose Jan. 5.

GUGGENHEIMER--Charles S. died peacefully, January 7, 2011 at age 77 after a short illness. He was born in New York, September 13, 1933. Charles attended Collegiate School, and graduated from Deerfield Academy, Yale College, and after serving in the army, from Columbia Law School. For many years he was a partner of the law firm of Guggenheimer & Untermyer. He was a strong supporter of Yale University. He served as an officer, and for many years was a Member of the Council of the Yale Club of New York City. He was former Chairman of the House, University and Admission Committees of the Yale Club and was presently a member of the Marketing and Membership Committee. He is survived by his brother Randolph, Jr. (Jane), and nephews Randolph III (Elizabeth), Steven (Julia), and niece Lynn (Jonathan). He is also survived by six great-nieces and one great-nephew. Funeral service private. The family will receive at Frank E. Campbells, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Sunday, January 10, 2011 and Monday, January 11, 2011 from 5 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Yale University, c/o Yale Club Scholars, The Yale Club of New York, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York 10017, Attention: Rachel Cooke.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Emily Bosk and Ethan Schoolman referred incorrectly to the bridegroom's mother. She is Maureen Sugarman Schoolman -- not Maureen Sugarman, which is her maiden name.

A dining review in some editions last Sunday about Udupi Bhavan, a South Indian vegetarian restaurant in Middletown, Conn., translated the word ''bhavan'' incorrectly. It means house or dwelling place, not tavern.

THE NEWS The new Republican majority in the House of Representatives adopted legislative rules intended to ease the way for its agenda of spending and tax cuts and a repeal of the health care overhaul. BEHIND THE NEWS In the name of deficit reduction, the rules require every dollar of new spending to be offset by cutting a dollar somewhere else -- but do not require the same for tax cuts, which also swell the deficit. Meanwhile, Democrats in the Senate pushed to curtail blocking tactics like filibusters that Republicans have used to bedevil them.

An article last Sunday about the Museum of Modern Art and how it has become a more inviting place misstated the cost of its new building, which opened in 2004. It was $425 million, not ''more than $800 million.'' (The museum carried out an $858 million capital campaign to pay for the building and other projects.)

REPURPOSING Irys Kornbluth (right), a senior in product design, made this gown for Stanford's Sustainable Fashion Show. She found her materials at a free store -- a communal closet on campus. ''The irregularity and ambiguity of a scrap can be a source of interest in the design if it's given a chance and not thrown away,'' she says.

A report in the Slap Shot hockey column on Dec. 26 misidentified the captain of the Dallas Stars who was praised for providing inspiration by playing with a badly broken nose. He is Brenden Morrow -- not Brad Richards, a teammate. And because of that error, a quotation by Dallas Coach Marc Crawford was erroneously applied to Richards. Crawford was referring to Morrow when he said: ''He's uncomfortable, we're uncomfortable for him just watching him, but that's leadership. You can't help but be somewhat motivated when you see your captain come out and play the way that he does.'' And a picture with the article was published in error. Although the caption gave Morrow's statistics, the photograph was of Richards.

At the Consumer Electronics Show on Tuesday, General Motors announced that it would offer its OnStar safety and connectivity system to owners of non-G.M. cars. Packaged within a rearview mirror, the OnStar aftermarket system will initially be available through Best Buy for $299, not including installation and a fee for the service. G.M. said installation is expected to cost from $75 to $100, and service plans begin at $18.95 per month, or $199 per year.

BELL--Sam, U.S. District Judge for the Northern District of Ohio, Inactive Status, died December 23, 2010, in Akron, Ohio. The only child of Marie Williams Bell and Samuel H. Bell was born in Rochester, NY, on a snowy New Year's Eve in 1925. A short time later the family moved to Akron, Ohio. Intelligent and evenhanded in his approach, Judge Bell treated those with whom he dealt with fairness and respect. And he listened, intently. Watching his mind work was like watching the twinkling facets of a turning crystal. His wit, his love of sports and Notre Dame, and his capacity for understanding humanity enhanced his intellectualism. He served on every level of the judiciary except the U.S. Supreme Court. When sitting as a trial judge, he always stood up when the jury entered his courtroom; not the reverse. "A gift" was the way he described his time as a federal judge. Though he took senior status to preserve a temporary judgeship for Akron and inactive status in 1998, the law continued to live for him. He team-taught with his wife, a lawyer and legal writing teacher, and others, a pre-law seminar at The College of Wooster, culminating in the Bell Lectureship in Law at The College of Wooster. He helped to found the Scanlon Inn of Court. Considered a Constitutionalist, he was an avid reader of history and visited many Civil War battlefields to study the logistics involved. Time spent outdoors with his wife Jennie, whether flyfishing, bicycling or walking local trails was relished by both. Preceded in death by his parents and his first wife, Joyce Shaw Bell, the mother of his sons, he is survived by his wife Jennie McCall Bell of Silver Lake, Ohio; sons Henry W. and wife and Steven D.; six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He shall be greatly missed by the Steven H. Mault family of Portsmouth, Ohio. Services have been held. Memorials may be made to the Bell Lectureship at the College of Wooster or to the Humane Society of Greater Akron, Ohio, or of your choice. His Quiet Strength was Magnificent. May God bless Sam Bell in Heaven as his presence blessed so many of us on Earth.

Martha Plumb's heart broke, and she feared the worst as she set pen to paper to inquire about her husband. ''I sent my dear husband forth to battle with a pure motive, as all true patriot women aught to,'' she wrote. GOULD--Doris (nee Blankstein), of Great Neck, NY. Died unexpectedly on January 5, 2011, after a superheroic battle with metastatic cancer, at a spry 93 years of age. Devoted and beloved "one and only" of 55 years and 333 days to Jacques; dear mother of Melissa and Roger. She lived life on her own terms until the very end. OLLSTEIN--Dr. Ronald Neil, a physician who was a pioneer in modern plastic surgery for burn victims, died on December 30, 2010, in Newark, Delaware. He was 76. The cause was cancer after a courageous nine-year effort to survive and live life to the fullest. Dr. Ollstein was born April 14, 1934 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Miriam Middleman Ollstein and Philip Ollstein. He was a graduate of Cornell University Medical College and trained in general and plastic surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was named Chief of the Burn Section, Department of Surgery, Harlem Hospital Center, where he created the city's first modern dedicated Burn Center. He was a founding member of the American Burn Association, Chairman of the Information Council on Fabric Flammability, and served on the National Advisory Committee for the Flammable Fabrics Act. His early work became a classic in establishing the nation's flammability safety standards for clothing. In 1968, Dr. Ollstein was appointed to the Department of Surgery, Plastic and Hand Surgery Section at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York. In 1973 he served as Chief until his retirement in 1996. He was a member of the surgical faculties of the New York Medical College, New York University School of Medicine and the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He chaired the Ethics Committee of the American Association of Plastic Surgeons, was elected President of the Jerome P. Webster Society of Plastic Surgery and served on the Board of Directors of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. In 2001, Dr. Ollstein received the St. Vincent dePaul Distinguished Physician Award from St. Vincent's Hospital and in 2006 he authored the book on St. Vincent's Hospital's modern history, entitled "Mission, Matrix & Money." Dr. Ollstein was a patriot, historian and collector. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Louise A. Restak, and a son, Bruce Ollstein. He is pre-deceased by two sons: Mark and David Ollstein. The family suggests a contribution in his memory to: The New Castle Historical Society; The Mt. Vernon Ladies Association of the Union, Mt. Vernon, Virginia; and The American Jewish Historical Society, New York City.

The San Antonio Spurs may have the best record in the N.B.A. and the Miami Heat may receive most of the buzz, but the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers are still running out one of the most efficient lineups in basketball, according to plus/minus rating. The five-player combination of Kobe Bryant, Lamar Odom, Ron Artest, Pau Gasol and Derek Fisher has scored 151 more points than it has allowed in 604 minutes together through Friday, which easily surpasses the Dallas Mavericks' top group at 111.

The ''New York World'' article in some editions last Sunday, featuring excerpts from the ethnic press, included two errors from The Jewish Week about labor problems at the Flaum Appetizing Corporation. That figure represents back pay they would have earned had they had not been fired; it does not include unpaid overtime, which is the subject of a separate legal action.

BARGAIN hunters will need to be craftier when booking a trip if they want to get the best prices this year. It's no secret that airfares are up and added fees for everything from checked bags to exit-row seats are pushing the cost of flying higher. On top of that, hotel bargains are expected to be harder to come by as business travelers begin to return, diminishing the need for hotels to discount rooms in major cities. But that doesn't mean a year in front of your television. There are still plenty of ways to cut costs. Here are 11 strategies -- and some useful Web sites -- to help you save on travel this year.

Shoppers in the market for used cars should brace themselves before heading to dealerships. With drivers holding onto their cars longer, used-car dealers are finding they have to pay more for good vehicles at auction. Consequently, consumers are paying more for them at dealerships and used-car lots -- sometimes significantly more than they did a just couple of years ago.

THE Jan. 14 release of ''The Green Hornet'' gives occasion to recall that the first roadgoing 200-mile-per-hour car was a 1937 Lincoln-Zephyr. Black Beauty, the automotive star of the cliff-hanging ''Green Hornet'' movie serial of the 1940s, scorched Mulholland Drive in Los Angeles as the car of the series' masked hero. Its speed, of course, was pure cinematic fantasy. But surpassing 200 m.p.h. in a production car eventually became a reality. The 1987 Ferrari F40 cracked that barrier, and since then, Jaguar, Lamborghini, McLaren, Porsche, Bugatti and others have followed.

Roberto Alomar and Bert Blyleven were selected for baseball's Hall of Fame this afternoon, becoming the 234th and 235th players so honored. Others were left on the sidelines, however. Jeff Bagwell, the Astros slugger who according to baseball-reference.com's Wins Above Replacement statistic was among the 50 best hitters of all-time, received just 42 percent of the vote. The multidimensional shortstop Barry Larkin, who made 12 All-Star teams, and won 9 Silver Sluggers and 3 Gold Gloves, was also left out, although he was named on 62 percent of the ballots, up from 52 percent a year ago.
Film Stephen Holden

BADELL--Angeles, MD. Achieved her final peace at her home in Rye, NY on January 7, 2011. Dr. Badell was born in Barcelona, Spain in 1929, and her Catalan heritage and pride infused her life's achievements both personal and professional. She was the only female graduate in the class of 1952 of the Facultad de Medicina in Barcelona. Married in 1953, her young family made the journey to the United States in 1955. With pride, she became a United States citizen on April 20, 1964. Dr. Badell completed her residency in the new field of Rehabilitation with the support of Dr. Howard A. Rusk. As a leader in the study of physical medicine and pediatric rehabilitation, Dr. Badell's career spanned more than 50 years including roles as Director of the Children's Unit at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, NY and Director of Rehabilitation at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Westbury, NY. She pioneered the use of a combined therapy approach for children, integrating physical, speech and occupational therapies along with educational, emotional and family support. She also published extensively and is still considered an expert in the overall treatment of spina bifida. Dr. Badell's personal passion was being a mother and continually nurturing her own and her daughters' relationship with a beautiful, loving and multi-talented family miles away in Spain. Her legacy to her daughters and grandchildren is passed on through her values which speak to being a good person that honors family, enjoys the accomplishments that come with hard work, seeks an excellent education and has the courage to overcome obstacles. She is survived by her daughters and their husbands: Angie (Douglas Robertson), Carmen (John Thain), and Maria (Michael Paddack); and her treasured grandchildren are blessed with many memories of their "Yaya" and "Grandma": Alexander (Tracy), Nicole, Victoria and Zachary Thain; Anna Fleming and Eliza Claire Paddack, along with an extended family in and around Barcelona, Spain. It was Dr. Badell's wish that she also be known for her ongoing esteem and support of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus. Services will be held at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY on Tuesday January 11, at 11am.

Neuberger Legacy Fund, 735 Anderson Hill Rd. Purchase, NY 10577-1400. The Neuberger Family.

The giant snowstorm in December rekindled the irritation that is felt by many homeowners in the New York area, who after spending hours digging their cars out of six-foot-high snowbanks and driving to pick up groceries, return home to find a strange car parked in that just-cleared curb space. This is, perhaps, a minor inconvenience compared with the plight of residents whose cars get snowed in and stay snowed in for days after a storm, but it is nonetheless frustrating on an interpersonal level. My neighbors and I are all in the same snowed-in predicament - dig we must, drive we must. So at some point, all of us have to shovel out. Surely space usurpers know the toil and trouble and exertion necessary to create a car-length chasm in the mini-mountain of snow outside their front doors because they had to dig out their own cars? Now they have to use another's space?

Packers at EaglesSunday, 4:30 p.m.Line: Eagles by 21/2 Blame the Packers. With 7:42 to play in the second quarter of the season opener, Clay Matthews sacked the jittery quarterback-of-the-future Kevin Kolb, causing the concussion that eventually knocked Kolb out of the game. Enter Michael Vick, and soon President Obama is talking about second chances, Tom Coughlin is screaming at Matt Dodge and the supposedly rebuilding Eagles are streaking to the division title. If Matthews was just a little less tenacious, the Eagles would be 7-9 and Vick would be just another backup of dubious provenance hoping for a fresh start in Arizona or San Francisco.

THERE is something subversively appealing about the Italian art of desecration -- the use, or some would say, misuse of historic places and cultural treasures. So much of Italy is ancient, magnificent, priceless and also serviceable. When I was Rome bureau chief in the late '90s, I visited the Palazzo Farnese, a Renaissance palace designed by Antonio da Sangallo the Younger and Michelangelo. It was a busy place. It's the French embassy, and in the ambassador's office, junior diplomats smoked and fetched faxes underneath giant frescoes by Francesco Salviati and Taddeo Zuccari.

CHLUSKI--John J. John J. Chluski, former Senior Vice President of ITT, died on January 3, 2011 after a long illness, in Boca Raton, FL. He was an instrumental part of the significant industrial growth of ITT Europe during the time of the legendary Harold Geneen and subsequently assisted Geneens successor, Rand Araskog, in the merger and subsequent sale of ITT Telecommunications to Alcatel of France. Fluent in four languages, he ran ITT's automotive and industrial companies throughout Europe. Mr. Chluski had quite a life before ITT. He was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1923 and educated in Poland, France and the UK. At the outbreak of WWII, he was captured by the Soviet army in 1939 and spent several months in a prison camp near Kieve, Ukraine. On his release he made his way by train and bicycle across Europe to North Africa where he survived in Algiers until Allied forces liberated the area in 1942. He volunteered to fight the Axis forces with the Americans and was subsequently selected and trained by the OSS as a paratrooper where he performed several drops behind enemy lines. After military service in WWII, he received a degree in economics at the City of London Polytechnic. He joined Harry Ferguson Ltd. in the UK as a shipping clerk in 1948. By 1968 and after working for the company in the UK, France and Canada, he became CEO of Massey Ferguson's North American operations based in Des Moines, Iowa. He joined ITT Corporation of New York, NY in 1972 and was placed in charge of their new automotive group based in Brussels, Belgium. Subsequently he was also given responsibilities of their Industrial Products and Electronic businesses, totaling over 50 companies and thousands of employees. In 1981, he was appointed Senior VP Executive Representative of the Chairman and CEO. In 1986 he was key negotiator for the sale of ITT's world telecommunications business to GCE (Alcatel). He retired as an employee at the age of 65 from ITT in 1986, but continued as an advisor to the Chairman and CEO of ITT until 1994. He was also appointed as Advisor to Chairman of Marceau Investissements based in Paris, France from 1988-2002. During this time, he also served as Chairman of the Advisory Board of Alexander Proudfoot Company worldwide from 1988-1995 and for IMT Consulting of Las Vegas, NV from 1996-2001. Most recently he served as an advisor to Goodmark USA of Boca Raton, Mr. Chluski is survived by his wife Dorene, son John, daughter-in-law Melissa and his granddaughter, Chloe, all of Boca Raton, FL. A memorial service will take place on Thursday, January 13 at St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church in Boca Raton at 11:00am.

Alex Ovechkin's drop-off in goal scoring this season has inspired criticism, but listen to Washington Coach Bruce Boudreau, speaking after the Capitals' Winter Classic victory over the Penguins on Jan. 1.
