If you've watched the HBO stuff, every time we score, he's the first guy on the ice cheering and he's happy for the team.''

I soldier on, solely to help this place out.

In 1971, Earl Monroe was traded to the Knicks from the Baltimore Bullets, now the Washington Wizards. A flashy ball handler known as the Pearl, he joined Walt Frazier to form one of the most talented backcourts in N.B.A. history. They helped lead the Knicks to the championship in 1973. Monroe, whose No. 15 jersey was retired by the team in 1986, was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1990. He was also named to the N.B.A.'s 50th-anniversary team in 1996. Monroe, Junior Bridgeman and George Gervin were honored recently for their service to the National Basketball Retired Players Association and the N.Y.U. Langone Medical Center at a benefit for the hospital's Center for the Study and Treatment of Pain.Q.How do you spend your time now?A.I have a multimedia company called Reverse Spin Entertainment that is involved with music, film and sports. I'm also a health advocate for Emblem Health and Merck.Q.How did you become involved with music?A.I've always been a music guy. My father used to sing and dance with Bessie Smith. I've been a fan of gospel, blues, R&B and pop. I love great voices, big hooks, melodies and lyrics that say something.Q.Do you have a favorite artist you've worked with?A.In 1983, I launched my first label, Pretty Pearl Records, with a guy from my alma mater in Winston Salem, N.C., by the name of Curtis Hairston. He was a phenomenal talent, and we had hit records in the U.S. and Europe. Unfortunately, at age 34, Curtis passed away.Q.What is your latest project?A.With my new label, Reverse Spin Entertainment, or R.S.E., I'm contemplating a tribute record to celebrate Curtis's legacy. R.S.E. also owns other masters and has an extensive publishing catalog which we endeavor to find opportunities for. With new signings, we're looking for talent outside of the mainstream and assisting them in building their careers.Q.Any thoughts about Solomon Burke, a friend of your family's, who died in October?A.Solomon Burke was a great talent and a fantastic singer. A member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, he transcended generations of fans from his R&B days of songs like ''Everybody Needs Somebody to Love,'' to songs the younger folks were able to experience, like ''Crazy.'' He performed, acted and was a country music pioneer. When I was growing up in Philly, my cousin Margie used to bring him by the house. I thought he was a cousin of mine. I use to charge the kids in the neighborhood 10 cents just to come in the dining room to look at him. We have lost a giant, but we are blessed by the wonderful legacy he left behind.Q.What players do you enjoy watching now?A.I enjoy watching Kobe Bryant, LeBron James, Kevin Durant, Chris Paul and a few other players in the league. Most of the players I've mentioned are guards. They not only are great players, but they are leaders and set a good example for the youth. Q.How has the game changed since you were in the league?A.The game is faster up and down the court, and there are not as many back-to-the-basket big men. With the advent of so many underclassmen coming into the league, there is not the same continuity of play from experienced veterans and basketball I.Q.Q.What do you think about the officiating in today's game?A.The officiating is a little different in that with the pace of the game itself; referees have to be as much in shape as the players. Still I feel as when I played, I hate the refs. But over all, they do a good job.Q.What do you think about the new rule calling for technicals for overt gestures, like punching the air in anger, even if they are not directed at a referee?A.I think it's good for the game. You don't show up the refs, and it eliminates some of the heated exchanges that occur, not only between the players and refs, but also helps to keep the crowd in check. Especially my friend Spike Lee.

RYAN--Richard Nelson, Jr.,64, of Easthampton, NY died December 28, 2010. Born January 14, 1946 in New York City. He was the son of Richard Nelson Ryan and Hope Bacon Ryan Klenk, both deceased. He grew up in NYC and Wainscott, NY. He attended Buckley School, Aiken Prep and Winchendon School. He entered the Army in 1966 and upon return worked on Wall Street. He was a well known resident of Easthampton for 35 plus years. A true and beloved brother and friend, quietly generous he gave to many and all always without recognition. He is survived by his sister Hope Ryan Garrett of Seattle, WA, his niece Hope Farnell Belles of Tiburon, CA and his nephew Richard Ryan Plum of Southampton, NY. He was predeceased by his sister Alix Ryan Plum. At his request there will be no funeral service. A gathering in his honor will be held in the spring. Date and time to be announced. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons (ARF), PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975 or to the Easthampton Volunteer Ambulance Association, 1 Cedar St., Easthampton, NY 11937.

Most of the destroyed buildings haven't beenrebuilt, and more than 800,000 people still live in tentcities. To make matters worse, an ongoing choleraoutbreak has infected more than 150,000 and killedmore than 3,400.

ANDEREGG--Karen. My other mother, for 41 years. Beloved by me, my husband, and my children. She cried when she showed me this poem, because it described the life that she felt so lucky to have: We met at the end of the party / When most of the drinks were dead / And all the glasses dirty: / "Have this that's left," you said. / We walked through the last of summer, / When shadows reached long and blue / Across days that were growing shorter: / You said: "There's autumn too." / Always for you what's finished / Is nothing, and what survives / Cancels the failed, the famished, / As if we had fresh lives / From that night on, and just living / Could make me unaware / Of June, and the guests arriving, / And I not there. -Philip Larkin Karen, we love you and we will miss you forever. Margit, Peter, Axel & Augie
Art Carol Vogel

A listing of critics' top 2010 car picks last Sunday imprecisely attributed the design of the Aston Martin Rapide. Although Ian Callum, Aston Martin's former design director, is credited with the design of the DB9 coupe on which the Rapide sedan is based, the company says its current design director, Marek Reichman, is responsible for bringing the Rapide to production.

THE effort that goes into dressing a prize-winning red carpet clotheshorse often feels greater than what one can properly say about the ugly dress or indeed a second-rate event. Last week's People's Choice Awards illustrated the problem. After deploying references to Adderall, Xanax, ''Pride and Prejudice'' and fancy pillowcases to describe the awfulness of the clothes, Amy Odell of New York magazine's Cut blog received a lecture from readers about her misuse of Jane Austen. There are no milkmaids in ''Pride and Prejudice,'' she was told, certainly no ''slovenly milkmaids.'' Ms. Odell might wish she had just said cow.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

Here's a reader comment on Jon Pareles's column about the new simplicity in pop music. ''They say the hardest ice cream to make is a truly great vanilla, because the recipe's simplicity shows any flaws in the ingredients or the maker's skill. I think the same is true with pop or rock music. Pop, unlike opera or classical, is a simple medium, basically three chords with a sung melody on top. The genius is in how you assemble them. Even a mature band working with full creative powers can still write beautifully simple music, such as U2's 'I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For,' from the album 'Joshua Tree.' That's pop at it's best. After all, we hum the melody, not the trills and fills.''

DINSMORE--Edwin J. 91, of Phillipsburg, NJ, Laguna Niguel, CA and formerly of Forest Hills Gardens, NY went to his eternal life on December 15, 2010 from his New Jersey home with his loving family at his bedside. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Ed graduated from St. John's University and served proudly in WWII as a US Coast Guard Lieutenant seeing action in the European and Pacific Theaters. Ed was a CPA working both for Continental Baking Company & ITT. He was known for his love of family, New York Times crosswords, scrabble games and a Master's bridge player actively playing in California, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania bridge clubs. Ed's brother-in-law, Msgr. James B. Reynolds offered a Mass of Resurrection at St. Patrick's Church in Belvidere, NJ, December 18th at 12 noon to celebrate his blessed life.

SOME young designers just have that golden touch. And when it comes to Melanie Kamsler and Tamila Purvis, the duo behind the aptly named Australian label ManiaMania, we mean that literally. Fans like Devendra Banhart, Erin Wasson and Alexandra Richards are, well, mad for their bohemian jewels with a rock 'n' roll edge. ''Seeing our pieces on people is still a pretty big deal,'' Ms. Purvis said. The model Abbey Lee Kershaw recently appeared in the brand's spring 2011 campaign (at right), which has such signature looks as a metal vagabond cuff that has the whittled texture of wood, and a bronze ring with amazonite. ''Our jewelry is known for being unique,'' Ms. Purvis said, ''and people have said they feel powerful wearing it.'' CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Conventional wisdom holds that the best picture Oscar nearly always goes to the best director winner. And Oscarologist wisdom holds that the Academy's best director is nearly always the same as the Directors Guild of America's choice; the two prizes haven't matched up only six times in 62 years. So when the D.G.A. announced its nominees on Monday, the following people were probably doubly celebrating: Darren Aronofsky, for "Black Swan;" Tom Hooper, for "The King's Speech;" Christopher Nolan for "Inception;" David Fincher for "The Social Network" and David O. Russell for "The Fighter."

On many issues relevant to charting a smooth human journey in this century, arguments are often framed between camps seeking to promote and spread "sustainable" behaviors and those pushing to advance and/or disseminate "better" technologies. Dennis Freedman, the former creative director of W, has a new job: creative director of Barneys New York. As part of the continuing changes made by Mark Lee, the retailer's new chief executive, Mr. Freedman will be responsible for overall creative direction of the store, including its photographic and video images, window displays, visual merchandising and store design. He will be free to engage outside window dressers and other collaborators to create Barneys' windows, a humorous stage developed by Simon Doonan. He starts next week. Mr. Freedman, who spent 20 years at W, helped shape the look and influence of the magazine through his close contacts with photographers like Bruce Weber, Steven Klein, Juergen Teller and Philip-Lorca diCorcia. He left the magazine last year.

Gary's surrealist picture above is a depiction, in the spirit of Salvador Dali, of the ancient hand game of morra. Today we'll explore various versions of this game, such as odd-even morra and guessing morra. The basic game is played in a manner similar to the well-known "rock-paper-scissors." Two players face each other, initially concealing their hands. One of them says "One, two, three, shoot!" and then both players display a number of fingers from some preset range. The number of points or dollars at stake in each round is equal to the number of fingers displayed. In odd-even morra, one of the players ("Odd") wins the stakes for the round if the total number of fingers displayed is odd. On the other hand (!), the other player ("Even") wins the stakes if the total number of fingers is even.

"The Social Network" may have continued its sweep of professional opionators on Saturday when it earned the top prize (and more) from the National Society of Film Critics, but there were some surprises among the winners. The group, consisting of 61 writers from publications like Time, The Village Voice and The New Yorker, gave the best supporting actress award to Olivia Williams for her role as a political wife in Roman Polanski's "The Ghost Writer." She creamed her competition, getting substantially more votes than Amy Adams and Melissa Leo for "The Fighter" or Jacki Weaver for "Animal Kingdom." "The Ghost Writer" also placed in the screenplay and director category, which may mean that it has a better-than-a-dark-horse chance at the Oscars (a dappled horse?). The society does reveal its final tally, an unusual openness in the world of trophy-giving. For a closer look at what their numbers mean, check out The Hollywood Reporter's take. As Tim Appelo notes there, if Ms. Williams does win an Oscar, she will have to hand it over to Mr. Polanski - as she promised she would - because he's got a pretty clear vision for his performers. "He acts the scene for you," she said. "And if you don't copy what he does, he goes, 'No! Like this,' -- pause, movement, intonation, the works. So the prize for any performance really does go to Roman."

If most television networks can have talk shows featuring celebrities, why not YouTube? The ''Partners Project,'' which started last month, is being positioned as the talk show of YouTube, featuring contributors who have drawn online audiences of millions. Among the first guests were an aspiring actress, Justine Ezarik, who created ''iJustine'' to share videos about her life; and Dane Boedigheimer, who started ''The Annoying Orange,'' an animated series about talking fruit.

Andrew H. Green was 15 years old, traveling alone from his family's home in Worcester, Mass., when he got his first taste of the city that he would come to so profoundly define. In Connecticut, he wrote his father in 1835, ''we changed stages and found in our stage nearly a whole cheese with a half a dozen sheets of gingerbread which we break and throw to the poor as we passed along.'' Not long after, he asked his father to send him a pair of calfskin boots ''for they cost an enormous price here.'' He later reported that his brother's cap was stolen from the store in which young Andrew worked from 7 a.m. to 8:30 p.m., said it was lonesome there, but confidently added: ''I know how to keep books well.''

Billie Joe Armstrong plays many roles in ''American Idiot,'' and that's before he even takes the stage at the St. James Theater. Mr. Armstrong, the 38-year-old Green Day front man and guitarist and a co-writer of that Broadway musical adapted from his band's hit album of the same title, rejoined the show on Jan. 1 to resume the role of St. Jimmy, the pugnacious, drug-pushing alter ego of the protagonist, Johnny (portrayed by John Gallagher Jr.). (Charles Isherwood's review of Mr. Armstrong in ''American Idiot'' appears in Monday's New York Times.) But in the final minutes before showtime on Friday night, Mr. Armstrong took on other parts - from a nervous neophyte gingerly reviewing his notes from Michael Mayer, the musical's director and co-writer, to an extroverted jester prancing around the stage in a female co-star's sequined dress.

GRABAR--Oleg, died on Saturday, January 8, 2011 at his home in Princeton, New Jersey. He was 81 years old and is survived by Terry, his wife of 59 years, his son Nicolas, daughter-in-law Jennifer Sage and grandchildren Henry, Olivia and Margaret. He will also be remembered by his beloved family in France, his many friends in Princeton, Cambridge and elsewhere, and an immense circle of colleagues, students, correspondents and readers throughout the world. A funeral service will be held at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street in Princeton at 10:30am on Tuesday, January 11, 2011. Oleg Grabar was a distinguished scholar of Islamic art and architecture and a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey (1990 1998), Harvard University (1969 1990) and the University of Michigan (1954 1969). Born in Strasbourg in 1929, he studied at the University of Paris, Harvard University (A.B. 1950) and Princeton University (Ph.D. 1955) and became a U.S. citizen in 1960. Professor Grabar was a prolific and inexhaustible scholar, teacher and author. He wrote more than 30 books in English and French, which have been translated into many languages, and more than 100 articles. The Formation of Islamic Art, first published in 1978, and the two-volume Pelican history of Islamic art and architecture are standards in the field, as are his monographs on the Dome of the Rock, the Alhambra and the Great Mosque of Isfahan. He was a mentor to several generations of scholars of Islamic art, an organizer of colloquia, scholarly organizations, journals and prizes, and the recipient of numerous honors. Most recently in November 2010, his life's work was recognized by the Chairman's Award from the Aga Khan Award for Architecture. Oleg Grabar's days were animated by a spirit of curiosity, energy and wonder, and by his gifts of enthusiasm and generosity towards his students, colleagues, friends and family.

DuPontagreed Sunday evening to buy Danisco, a Danish specialty food ingredients maker, for $5.8 billion in cash, marking the biggest deal by the chemical company in years. The deal also represents an effort by DuPont to expand the company's offerings in more specialized areas like biofuels and food enzymes.

8:25 P.M. (Sundance) THE DARJEELING LIMITED (2007) In this film, Wes Anderson's fifth feature, three semi-estranged brothers -- above from left, Francis (Owen Wilson), Peter (Adrien Brody) and Jack (Jason Schwartzman) -- travel by rail across India in what has been devised by Francis as a bonding experience so that the siblings can be ''brothers like we used to be'' and ''say yes to everything.'' But mostly Francis wants Peter and Jack to say yes to him. Among Mr. Anderson's inspirations: ''The River,'' Jean Renoir's film about Indian village life, and music from the films of Satyajit Ray. Anjelica Huston, Natalie Portman, Irrfan Khan and Bill Murray round out the ensemble cast. ''This shaggy-dog road trip,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''is unstintingly fussy, vain and self-regarding. But it is also a treasure: an odd, flawed, but nonetheless beautifully handmade object as apt to win affection as to provoke annoyance. You might say that it has sentimental value.'' 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR Brad Womack and one bachelorette go on a fantasy date to the Hollywood Bowl, where they're serenaded by the band Train. The evening is then sealed with a kiss. In ''Castle,'' at 10, Castle (Nathan Fillion) and Beckett (Stana Katic) investigate the death of a magic-shop owner who was found in Houdini's water-torture tank.

KELLY--Michael T.,WWII Veteran and NYPD Sergeant, South Plainfield, NJ, died on Friday January 7, 2011 at Haven Hospice located within JFK Medical Center in Edison, NJ. Born moments before midnight on December 31, 1925 in the Hell's Kitchen section of New York City, Mike lived a life that left a wake of love, respect and fun. After graduating eighth grade from Holy Cross School, he attended Cardinal Hayes High School until his Sophomore year, when he decided to leave school in order to enlist in the U.S. Navy to fight for his country during WWII. After returning from the war, Mike worked as an electrician and attended night school. He entered the New York Police Academy in 1957, served in the South Bronx and Manhattan before retiring in 1981 as a Sergeant of the 110th Precinct in Jackson Heights, Queens. Mike married Mary Creaven on September 29th, 1962. They spent the majority of their 48 years of loving marriage in Bellerose Terrace, where they raised five children: Terry, Michael, Marybeth, Cathy, and Brian. He is also survived by ten grandchildren. This page cannot express how much Mike was loved every day of his life. Friends may call Tuesday, 2-5 pm and 7-9:30 pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave, Floral Park, NY. Funeral mass Wednesday, 9:15 am at Our Lady of Victory RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

What is a duck - or more specifically, the Aflac duck - to do on Monday night when the Oregon Ducks play the Auburn Tigers in the Bowl Championship Series title game? The marketing gurus at the insurance company Aflac posed that tongue-in-cheek question on the duck's Facebook page on Dec. 28. As the company's ubiquitous mascot, the duck presumably should side with Oregon. Then again, Aflac's headquarters in Columbus, Ga., are about 30 minutes from Auburn, Ala., and the Tigers are a favorite of many of the company's 4,000 employees there.

SWEIG--Morton Arthur, born in New York on February 13, 1915 died peacefully at home in New York on January 8, 2011. Morton was a successful and proud businessman who knew and understood the value of hard work. He was a pioneer in the building maintenance industry and a legend to those who knew him. He is survived by his wife Helen Koslow Sweig, daughter Jeannie Kligman (Gerald) of Palm Beach, FL, son Michael (Jo Ann) of Chicago, IL, grandfather to Gary (Karen) Kligman of Bloomfield Hills, MI, Wendy Kligman of Rye Brook, NY, three great-grandchildren Jacob, Amelia and Sara, step-father of Dale and Max Burger, Sally and Robert Koslow, and Vicki and Dan Kriser. He was preceded in death by his wife of greater than 50 years Charlotte (Phillips) Sweig who passed away in 1995. Morty will be sorely missed. Funeral services to be held on Monday January 10 at 11am at Temple Emanuel on Fifth Avenue and 65th street.

Probably the best thing about last week's dreary annual summary of home entertainment revenue from the Digital Entertainment Group is that the numbers weren't adjusted for inflation. That made the six-year tumble in cumulative spending on DVDs and other forms of home entertainment look only about half as bad as it really was. In the peak year of 2004, according to the group, which is an industrywide consortium of technology and entertainment companies, consumers spent about $21.8 billion to rent and buy DVDs, Blu-ray discs, digital downloads and other forms of home entertainment.

GUGGENHEIMER--Charles S. died peacefully, January 7, 2011 at age 77 after a short illness. He was born in New York, September 13, 1933. Charles attended Collegiate School, and graduated from Deerfield Academy, Yale College, and after serving in the army, from Columbia Law School. For many years he was a partner of the law firm of Guggenheimer & Untermyer. He was a strong supporter of Yale University. He served as an officer, and for many years was a Member of the Council of the Yale Club of New York City. He was former Chairman of the House, University and Admission Committees of the Yale Club and was presently a member of the Marketing and Membership Committee. He is survived by his brother Randolph, Jr. (Jane), and nephews Randolph III (Elizabeth), Steven (Julia), and niece Lynn (Jonathan). He is also survived by six great-nieces and one great-nephew. Funeral service private. The family will receive at Frank E. Campbells, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Sunday, January 10, 2011 and Monday, January 11, 2011 from 5 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Yale University, c/o Yale Club Scholars, The Yale Club of New York, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York 10017, Attention: Rachel Cooke.

If there has been a parallel between No. 1 Auburn (13-0) and No. 2 Oregon (12-0) this season, it has been their blistering pace. Each employs shotgun, no-huddle systems that put up dizzying numbers, and each flummoxes and wears down opponents. Many are predicting a high-scoring Bowl Championship Series title game Monday night in Glendale, Ariz., but the chances appear less likely. The defenses will be accustomed to the opposition's pace after a season of facing a similar system in practice and more than a month of preparations, making it unlikely the combined score will reach the 50s.

Auburn University flags, emblematic nowadays of the football team's quest for a national title, are flapping from front porches and car antennas across Alabama. Maybe even on the moon. A set of 10 small blue-and-orange flags accompanied the Auburn graduate Thomas Mattingly, known as T.K., on Apollo 16 nearly 40 years ago. In the wake of the shootings in Tucson on Saturday, the number of Americans who say gun control laws should be made stricter has increased since last spring, but nearly 6 in 10 Americans think stricter laws would have had little effect on preventing the violence which claimed the lives of six people and injured fourteen others, according to a CBS News poll.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - When can you have more than 100 percent of something? In the original version of the film The Producers (a movie that I have pretty much committed to memory because that's how much I love it), Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder cook up a scheme to sell investment rights to their dubious Broadway production to a slew of unsuspecting older women. By the end of the film, they haven't really learned their lesson, and we leave them selling more than 100 percent of the rights to everyone in their prison, including the warden.

On Thursday, March 7, 1850, the Senate's all-time greatest orator delivered the most controversial speech of his life. Daniel Webster's voice "rang out like a trumpet ... with a roll of thunder in it," the historian Robert Remini has written; it was "powered by a massive chest that sent it hurtling great distances." The "Godlike Daniel" mesmerized audiences with his "large, deep-socketed black eyes ... [that] glowed like coals in a furnace."
A 19-year-old Andruw Jones made Yankee Stadium his stage on Oct. 20, 1996, when his two majestic homers in Game 1 of the World Series lifted him into the baseball public's consciousness.

I had never heard of Kistler at the time, but one of my companions told me the story of how these two young men, Steve Kistler and Mark Bixler, had started a winery and, virtually by themselves, were making chardonnays that were rivaling white Burgundies.

I love the N.F.L., and especially the playoffs. Every game is an elimination game, and every game starts at a reasonable hour on the East Coast. Of the 11 N.F.L. postseason games every year, only two begin after 8 p.m. Baseball playoff games tend to start later, and of the last 43 postseason series, stretching back to the 2004 World Series, only five have produced a winner-take-all game.

The nation's largest cupcake chain, Crumbs Bake Shop, has merged with an investment company and will go public. DealBook speaks to its founders about their plans for a nationwide expansion.

As first reported by DealBook's Peter Lattman this week, the nation's largest cupcake chain, Crumbs Bake Shop, will go public through a $66 million dollar merger with an investment company, the 57th Street General Acquisition Corporation. We spoke to Crumbs' founders, Jason and Mia Bauer, about their plans to expand the chain to 200 stores nationwide by 2014.

The parks department wants to get better food into parks all over the city, Eater reports. The department is putting out a request on Wednesday for proposals from food vendors serving "top quality food'' with "menus that are inventive and interesting ... and that incorporate ethnically diverse and/or healthy food choices.'' Food trucks, or in some cases food carts, would be able to set up in more than 50 locations in all boroughs. Here are the details of what they're looking for and a list of the parks where the vendors can be located.

As I have noted before on DealBook, derivative contracts have a broad exception to the normal rules of bankruptcy, often called a safe harbor. Derivatives are not subject to the automatic stay, collateral collected on the eve of bankruptcy cannot be attacked as a preference, and derivative contracts are not subject to a debtor's ability to assume or reject contracts unless the nondebtor counterparty consents.

Several weeks before its doors were scheduled for shuttering, Max Fish has been granted a reprieve. Monday afternoon, a lease extension was finalized giving the venerable Lower East Side bar another year at its Ludlow Street location. The extension, which maintains the terms of the current lease, is the result of an agreement between Arwen Properties and the bar's owner, Ullie Rimkus. The lease now ends Jan. 31, 2012.

The '80s hair-band musical "Rock of Ages," which closed on Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, will offer an unusual way to get discounted tickets when it resumes performances at the Helen Hayes Theater on March 24, producers announced on Monday.

The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Alber Elbaz opened his pre-fall show with an observation: more women, he says, are wearing evening clothes during the day. The collection that followed might very well be the stuff of self-fulfilling prophecy. An ivory silk floor-length skirt, for example, took on the ease of trousers when paired with a thick ribbed sweater. But the best looks swung the other way, too. Here, a blouse and tweed skirt - daytime staples - are gussied up with bronze Lurex and a dollop of fur. (The wolf is optional.)

"Detroit," a new play about American dissipation with some deliciously tart roles, set in the adjacent backyards of two recovering addicts and their anxious middle-class neighbors, will be produced on Broadway in early fall of 2011 under the direction of Austin Pendleton, the producers announced on Tuesday. No casting was announced for the five-character play, which will mark the Broadway debut of the playwright Lisa D'Amour, a well-known downtown writer and artist. The Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago produced "Detroit" last fall, which included Laurie Metcalf ("November" on Broadway, "Roseanne" on ABC) as the middle-class wife. The lead producers will be Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Debbie Bisno, in association with Steppenwolf; Mr. Richards and Mr. Frankel previously teamed with Steppenwolf for its transfers of "August: Osage County" and "Superior Donuts" to Broadway. Performance dates and a theater will be announced later.

This week's restaurant review: Ciano, on East 22nd Street, in the space that Diner's Journal readers may remember as Beppe. Shea Gallante, who used to man the stoves at Cru (now it's Lotus of Siam - would you try to keep track, please!), is the chef, partnered with Stratis Morfogen, the nightclub impresario. John Slover, who also worked at Cru, is the wine director. They've made a lovely restaurant, less obviously stuffy and ambitious than Cru, but great fun for that.

Best snark about the euro crisis yet from Satyajit Das, who suggests that European leaders, as part of their educational mission, are giving us geography lessons. First they told us that Ireland wasn't Greece; then they told us that Portugal wasn't Ireland; now they're telling us that Spain isn't Greece, Ireland, or Portugal; soon the Belgians will be improving our spelling, telling us that there's no B in PIGS.

Coco Chanel once dismissed Paco Rabanne as the "steelworker of fashion," for his use of metal in his stubbornly futuristic designs. Rabanne, who is responsible for some acidic put-downs of his own, certainly lived up to the moniker with his ubiquitous chain mail dresses of the 1960s. Less known, however, is his 69 bag from a collection of that year. Celebrating the designer's enduring vision of fashion, Comme des Garçons has teamed up with Paco Rabanne to release nine variations on the bag, including versions in clear, acrylic Perspex, pink metallic suede, and black rubber. This is one chain mail you'll be happy to receive.

The American Society of Cinematographers announced its nominees late on Monday, and it was a nice mix of veterans and newcomers - although still all the films you would expect. Matthew Libatique ("Black Swan"), Wally Pfister ("Inception"), Danny Cohen ("The King's Speech"), Jeff Cronenweth ("The Social Network") and Roger Deakins ("True Grit") got the nod. Mr. Deakins is the old hand of the group, having been nominated nine times and won twice, for "The Shawshank Redemption" in 1995 and "The Man Who Wasn't There" in 2002. Mr. Deakins will also receive a lifetime achievement award. Mr. Pfister has been recognized before, and Mr. Cohen, Mr. Cronenweth and Mr. Libatique are all first-timers.

The top energy official at the United States Chamber of Commerce, the powerful lobbying group, urges lawmakers to focus on expanding fossil fuel energy production, not "high-cost energy sources" like wind and solar. Bush, says in an interview. "It may be lovely to think about a world without fossil fuels, but that simply is not America's energy reality." [The Hill]

To help shake off those winter doldrums Jacob's Pillow has announced the lineup for its annual summer dance festival in Becket, Mass. A world premiere by Jane Comfort, anniversary celebrations of the Trisha Brown Dance Company and the Mark Morris Dance Group, as well as the American debuts of two companies, 3e Étage, comprising dancers from the Paris Opera Ballet, and DanzAbierta, a contemporary troupe from Cuba, are among the highlights of the festival. It will run from June 18 through Aug. 28 and include related events like an Annie Leibovitz dance photography exhibition.

I trembled when I felt the suction of the sterile brace over my right eyeball. The brightly lighted operation room faded to black as the blood ceased to flow. My left eye, still functioning for the time being, followed the surgeon with a paranoia I had not felt in months. My Army-sponsored Lasik eye surgery was supposed to be a relatively simple procedure. The surgeon would cut a flap into my cornea, imprint the prescription on its inner surface, and finally replace the flap with a few steroid drops. I'd jump up, throw on some sunglasses, and would probably see 20/20 in a few days. But this wasn't what I signed up for.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

If you've ever wondered why some women have skin that glows, it may be time to invest in the services of Christine Chin. A facialist's facialist if ever there was one, Chin has figured out how to buff, squeeze and laser even the most recalcitrant skin into its best showing. She's not been called "Mean Christine" for no reason: her facials are rigorous rather than soothing and may include the meticulous (and time-consuming) lancing of what she affectionately refers to as "doughnuts" - those sebaceous bumps under the skin that give it a regrettably bumpy appearance but are rarely bothered with by more massage-happy hands. Chin's knowledge and expertise don't come cheap and her Orchard Street salon isn't cozy or even spacious, but she's worth the trek. And now there's another reason to seek her out, even if you've never tried her services: Chin has come out with a new line - the Christine Chin Celebrity collection - that reinforces her beliefs. The result of four years of closely supervised work with a Swiss lab, the products include Nano Gold, a new type of gold particle, as well as active plant cells from Sequoia, Blue Lotus and Argan. They range in price from $48 for the superb cleanser and toner to $120 for the debris-busting gommage. For the complete list of available products for sale online, go to christinechin.com.

Lots of good comments on this post. But I think there's a bit of an intellectual trap lurking here. As I pointed out, the typical conservative line about equality of opportunity, not results, really implies the need for a radical restructuring of our society, which doesn't offer anything remotely resembling equal opportunity. At this point, however, there's a tendency to think about what that restructuring would involve -- and because it's basically impossible, to throw up one's hands.

There really is nothing new under the sun. On Thursday, "The Master of the Blue Jeans" opens at Didier Aaron in New York. Originally organized by Gerlinde Gruber, a curator at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, for Galerie Canesso in Paris, the exhibition includes seven late-17th-century Italian paintings that show poor people dressed in denim fabric, which was made then in Genoa and known by the French name for that city, Gênes. The paintings, which had once been attributed to artists like Velázquez and de la Tour, are now thought to be the work of a single, unknown artist. The catalog even has a brief essay by that 20th-century master of stonewash, François Girbaud. For more information, go to didieraaron.com.

Like all dutiful new arrivals on these shores, Josephine the baboon was equipped to record her visit in July 1957. She was on her way from Mombasa, Kenya, to the St. Louis Zoo, via the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn, where the freighter Lombok landed with bustards, dik-diks, elephants, giraffes, hippopotamuses, rhinoceroses, secretary birds, tortoises and zebras. The full tale - and 17 pictures from the archives - are on the Lens blog.

Everything felt very proper - chin up, crusts off -- at the lunch for "The King's Speech" on Monday, held at a private club in Manhattan that resembled an English manor house, complete with a bust of Churchill and an actual Churchill, Edwina Sandys, granddaughter of that British prime minister, who said she'd seen the movie three times. Tina Brown and Harry Evans were also there, along with Trudie Styler, Geoffrey Fletcher (the Oscar-winning screenwriter of "Precious") and a sizable contingent of people who talked about literature, opera, and, one presumes, fox hunting or tea (or kinky sex). Also present, though less proper: Harvey Weinstein, who suggested a shot to the Bagger's illustrious producer, Jeremy Beiler, whispering, "Close-up!" as our pal focused his camera. (Anyone who wondered whether Mr. Weinstein's filmmakers get final cut might have an answer now.)

I started out as a retailer. As time passed, I realized and struggled with the fact that I was also a manufacturer. Eventually, I expanded into being a distributor, a direct-sales organization and now a Web marketer. The first three evolutions were slow and painful, but I figured them out. This latest twist, becoming a Web marketer, is different. This time, it is not just about people and problems. It's about understanding the realities of a whole new world.

8:46 p.m. | Updated Duke Energy, a big power company based in North Carolina, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire a rival, Progress Energy, in an all-stock deal valued at $13.7 billion, creating the nation's largest utility company. The combined company would have $22.7 billion in annual revenue and more than seven million customers in North Carolina, South Carolina, Florida, Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio.

NATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about costs associated with health care legislation and its proposed repeal described incorrectly an analysis by the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office. It said its costs estimates -- such as its recent assessment that a repeal would increase the deficit by about $230 billion over 10 years -- have a roughly equal chance of turning out to be too high or two low. The budget office did not say that the health care law is equally likely to save the government money or to cost more.

CLARKE--Roger Scarlett of Collinsville, Connecticut died peacefully on Saturday January 8, 2011 of kidney cancer. Born in Yorkshire, England in 1936, he studied architecture at Liverpool University and in Munich, Germany. He worked in the New York offices of Skidmore, Owings, & Merrill and Edward Larrabee Barnes before establishing a practice in Connecticut which specialized in historic preservation. Roger will be remembered for his dry sense of humor and his uncommon vision, reflected in his remarkable sketches and architecture. He is survived by his wife Marjorie, his children Alison Clarke and Justin Clarke, his sister Heather Wheat, and his grandchildren Claudia, Scarlett and Ian. A celebration of his life is planned for spring 2011. Memorial donations may be made to the Maxwell Shepherd Memorial Arts Fund, Inc. c/o the Collinsville Savings Society or the CT Trust for Historic Preservation.

RYAN--John T.,age 92 of Bethel, CT formerly of Woodside, NY, died January 6, 2011. He was the husband of the late Veronica (Miller) Ryan. Mr. Ryan was born in New York City, the son of the late John A. and Clara M. (McGough) Ryan. Mr. Ryan attended Saint Paul The Apostle Catholic School, Power Memorial Academy and in 1941, he graduated from Fordham University. He served in the United States Coast Guard during WWII. Mr. Ryan worked in the circulation department of the New York Times for 45 years, retiring in 1991. Visitation will be on Friday, January 14, 2011 from 10am to 12 noon, in the Bethel Funeral Home, 215 Greenwood Ave., Bethel, CT, with a service to follow in the Bethel United Methodist Church, Bethel, CT. Information and online condolences at: HullFuneralService.com

THE ARTS A critic's notebook on Monday about the 2011 New York Winter Jazzfest, using information from a festival official, misstated the number of people who attended. There were about 1,400 on Friday night, not 1,000, and about 2,600 on Saturday night. A picture caption with the notebook referred incorrectly to the band that Butch Morris was shown conducting at Le Poisson Rouge. It is J D Allen's VisionFugitive; the band is not Mr. Morris's. Another picture caption with the notebook misidentified the bass player shown at the left in the Charles Gayle Trio at Kenny's Castaways. He is Christopher Dean Sullivan -- not Larry Roland, who had been scheduled to play.

FRIEDMAN--Debbie. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School mourns the untimely passing of the very talented Debbie Friedman, a close friend of our school community. Debbie's music has been an integral part of the school culture. She wrote a special song for our school, "Ki Mitzion", which is sung every year at our Chumash ceremony. She will be greatly missed as a musician and a friend. We send our deepest condolences to her family and close friends. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Barry N. Winograd, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

GUGGENHEIMER--Charles. The members and staff of The Yale Club of New York City mourn the passing of beloved member Charles S. Guggenheimer '55. Charlie served for many years on the Yale Club's Council and numerous committees. Amongst his many contributions, the most important was Charlie's role as an ambassador for the Yale Club to generations of young Yale graduates and our bridge to the University itself. His most lasting contribution was his tireless work on the Yale Club Scholars Fund. Under his leadership, the fund grew to provide assistance to 45 undergraduates, adding 12 new incoming freshmen to the program each year. These Scholars represent a legacy for the Club and a testament to Charlie's dedication. To honor Charlie's legacy the Club will be renaming the fund the Charles S. Guggenheimer '55 Scholars Fund. The Yale Club extends its deepest sympathies to Charlie's family. Charlie will be remembered for his wisdom, kindness, and commitment to all things Yale. He will be greatly missed.

The Tricycle Theater will present two special performances of ''The Great Game: Afghanistan,'' its seven-hour marathon of short plays about Afghanistan's history of foreign occupations, for the Pentagon on Feb. 10 and 11, the theater announced. The performances will take place at the Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington for an audience of military and government officials, service members, veterans and their families. Ben Brantley, in a positive review of the production last month for The New York Times, said that after watching the seven-hour cycle, audience members ''can be forgiven for thinking of Afghanistan as something Samuel Beckett, in a really down mood, might have come up with.''

WINGATE--David Aaron David Aaron Wingate, born Aaron David Winograd on January 6, 1921, died on January 9 following a long illness, shortly after his 90th birthday. He was the beloved husband of Shoshanna; elder brother of the Honorable Eliyahu Winograd of Tel Aviv; father of Batsheva Wingate Ostrow and Ealan Wingate; father-in-law of Ronald Ostrow and Melinda Wingate; grandfather of Amanda Wingate and of Alonna Ostrow Ostad, Sharone Ostrow Gilbert, and Jonathan Ostrow, and their spouses Michael Ostad, Richard Gilbert, and Rose Ostrow; great-grandfather of Hannah, Alexandra, and Ari Ostad; Benjamin, Emma, Zachary, and Sam Gilbert; and Julian Ostrow. He also leaves a loving extended family in Israel, where he was born. He lived in Old Westbury, NY and Palm Beach, Florida. He was a strong and devoted head of his family, who adored and revered him and will remember him forever. From a young age, he was driven by curiosity. Aaron/ David became a successful business man first in Palestine, then in the newly formed Israel, where he was a fifth generation Israeli, and then in his adopted New York community. He was the CEO of Hi-Shear Industries (an NYSE-registered institution). He and his wife supported many Jewish institutions, including the Jewish Theological Seminary, North Shore Long Island Jewish Hospital, the UJA, the Solomon Schechter School, and Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, where they endowed the David and Shoshanna Wingate Center. He was a powerful presence in many lives. His own life was shaped by the love of an extraordinary and wonderful woman, Shoshanna. All who knew them admired the deep love they held for each other and their amazing partnership throughout their sixty-seven years together. David and his adored Shoshanna forged a life built on hard work, sacrifice, commitment to family and a dedication to the welfare of the Jewish Community. They shared a great love of the arts and a circle of devoted friends. He will be remembered always by all those his life touched, and by all those who knew him for his delighted and welcoming smile. May his name be forever a blessing. May his name always be included among the names of the righteous. Services are at 11:30am on Tuesday, January 11 at Temple Beth Sholom, Rosyln Heights, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in David Wingate's honor to a Jewish charity of your choice.

COQUILLETTE--Robert M.,retired W.R. Grace executive and community service volunteer, died December 22, 2010 at a Boston area hospital. He was 92. He attended Harvard College as a Conant fellow, and received his B.S. degree Magna Cum Laude in Chemistry in 1939. After serving in the Navy in the Pacific during WWII, he joined the Dewey & Almy Chemical Company which became part of W.R. Grace in 1955. In 1962, Mr. Coquillette became president of the Ohio Rubber Co. Division of the Eagle-Picher Company of which he was a vice president and director. In 1965, he rejoined Grace in New York City holding various positions including corporate executive vice president and head of the Corporate Administration Group and sector executive of Grace's food-service businesses. From 1981 until his retirement in 1983, he was a member of Grace's Corporate Executive Office and of the Executive Committee. Following retirement, Mr. Coquillette resided in Mattapoisett, Massachusetts, where he was a trustee of The Old Dartmouth Historical Society, The Mattapoisett Historical Society, The Mattapoisett Land Trust and The Tri-County Music Association. He was a member of the American Chemical Society, the Harvard Club of New York City, the New York Yacht Club, the Mattapoisett Yacht Club, the Mattapoisett Casino and the Chemical Management & Resources Association of which he was recipient of the 1977 Award for Executive Excellence. He was a member of the Permanent Class Committee of the Harvard College Class of 1939. Mr. Coquillette was married for 66 years to Dagmar Bistrup, now deceased. They are survived by two married sons, seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. He will be much missed. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 19 at 2:00pm at the Mattapoisett Congregational Church, Mattapoisett, Massachusetts. The family suggests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Dagmar Coquillette Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Mattapoisett Congregational Church, P.O. Box 284, Mattapoisett, MA 02739. For on-line guestbook please visit www.saundersdwyer.com.

Especially loved wife of the late Sol Chick Chaikin, former President of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, cherished mother of Robert and Marilyn, Eric and Stacey, David and Wendy and Karen; adored grandmother of Reed, Gregg, Shari, Kyle, Allison, Nikki, Lee, Wendy, Shana, Grady, Seth, Agata, Zachary, Kim and Rebecca; and beloved great-grandmother of thirteen; passed away January 9, 2011 quietly at home. She devoted her life to family, friends and numerous community causes, retired BOCES teacher for children who were visually handicapped or blind and/or learning disabled; translated books into braille for the blind, was formerly a member of the Board of Overseers at the Heller School for Social Policy and Management, Brandeis University and former Chair, Institute for Child, Youth and Family Policy at the Heller School; recipient of the Association of Children with Learning Disabilities Humanitarian Award, Nassau Chapter; who after her husband's death chronicled the beginning of their life-long love affair, penning her memoir, "To My Memory Sing" and poetry books titled, "The Perfect Starfish" and "Polished Stones." DAVIDOFF LOWERED EXPECTATIONS Nielsen Holdings, the television ratings and consumer measurement company, is tempering expectations ahead of its initial public offering. According to an amended version of its prospectus, filed on Monday, Nielsen expects to price its shares at $20 to $22. At the midpoint of that range, Nielsen will raise $1.5 billion -- a significant step down from its previous estimate late last year of $2 billion. Under the terms of the deal, underwriters also have the option to buy an additional 10.7 million shares. And if that option is fully exercised, Nielsen will increase its total fund-raising to about $1.7 billion. EVELYN M. RUSLI

(13, 49) DEADLIEST EARTHQUAKES In an evening of programming devoted to Haiti on the eve of the one-year anniversary of the earthquake that killed more than 200,000 in the capital, Port-au-Prince, this ''Nova'' episode follows a team of American geologists as they enter the country in the earthquake's immediate aftermath to help determine what caused it, as well as the risks of a new one. A month later ''Nova'' also tags along as the geologists travel to Chile, where a quake 100 times more powerful generated a tsunami -- and where new data could help prevent future disasters. ''Battle for Haiti,'' a ''Frontline'' episode that examines gang leaders' efforts to reassert control in the ravaged capital, will be broadcast at 9 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 49; ''Children of Haiti,'' an ''Independent Lens'' installment that follows three teenage boys over three years, will be shown at 10 on Channel 13 and at 11 on Channel 49. 10 A.M. Taylor Swift's "Speak Now" is at No. 1 for the sixth week on the Billboard album chart this week. But the weekly sales figures have earned it what Billboard.com calls the "dubious honor" of having the lowest sales - 52,000 copies - for a No. 1 album since Nielsen SoundScan began keeping track in 1991. The previous low was set by the "Dreamgirls" soundtrack on the Jan., 27, 2007, chart, with slightly more than 60,000 albums sold. Back to 2011: Nicki Minaj's "Pink Friday" climbed to No. 2 with 39,000, and Bruno Mars moved up a spot to No. 3 with "Doo-Wops & Hooligans," which sold 38,000. Daft Punk's "Tron: Legacy" soundtrack is fourth with sales of 34,000, and Eminem's "Recovery" slipped three notches to No. 5, with sales of 33,000.

I'm with Calculated Risk here: it says something about the sheer desperation of the European situation that Portugal's ability to sell 10-year bonds at an interest rate of "only" 6.7 percent is considered a success. If you think about the debt dynamics here -- the burden of growing interest payments on an economy that is likely to face years of grinding debt deflation -- an interest rate that high is little short of ruinous. But it is, indeed, not as bad as people were expecting last week; hence, success.

Stevie Wonder, Elton John, Gladys Knight and Dionne Warwick will reunite for a live performance on Feb. 9 of the song "That's What Friends Are For" at amfAR's New York Gala benefit at Cipriani Wall Street, the foundation has announced. The song, which was a No. 1 single in 1986, was originally written by Carole Bayer Sager and Burt Bacharach and was released by Arista as a benefit single for amfAR, the Foundation for AIDS Research. It raised $3 million for the foundation, after Ms. Warwick gathered the writers and artists, who offered to donate their portion of profits from the recording. Clive Davis, the president of Arista, also agreed to donate all profits. In addition to the special performance next month, amfAR will honor former President Bill Clinton; Diane von Furstenberg; and two of the foundation's co-founders, Dr. Mathilde Krim and Elizabeth Taylor.

The Turkish jeweler Sevan Bicakci was motivated by both myth and hard reality when making this one-of-a-kind pair of sterling, 24-karat gold and diamond earrings. At once a representation of Poseidon's magnificent chariot horses and a tribute to Turkey's Mount Ida, which figures prominently in Greek mythology as the site from which the gods watched the Trojan War, the sparkly steeds are also a protest against modern-day mining on the resources-rich site. "I know this sounds odd coming from a jeweler," Bicakci says, "but the natural treasure of Ida is much more valuable than gold." The earrings are $16,860 at Barneys New York.

If you are any sort of gardener at all, you know that this is the time of year, when hoar frost is on the twig, that held the greatest charm for Beverley Nichols. The most amusing garden writer of all times, Nichols (1898-1985), who specialized in winter flowers, regularly crescendoed to the point where he could literally have you laughing out loud. Here he is fatally associating cyclamens, those "vulgar, obvious plants" whose seeds failed to grow for him after 10 weeks in pots, with "tiresome women who live in flats with electric stoves and indigestion and a Pekingese snoring in the scullery."

Though the striking and dangerous craft of fire-breathing has made something of a comeback in the last few years, it's still a fringe activity. In Paris several years ago, the police shooed practitioners out of Paris's parks, due to safety concerns. The fire breathers, along with flame jugglers and dancers, began meeting at a more out-of-the-way spot long favored by skateboarders: the vast (and treeless) courtyard of the Palais de Tokyo, an imposing, neo-Classical modern art museum built for the 1937 World's Fair. Their Saturday night gatherings have become a fixture of Paris's underground life and even spawned an annual party that offers anyone, if only for a night, a view into this glowing world. This year's edition, the seventh, is on Jan. 22.

The TV Sports column on Thursday, about viewership of college football bowl games as they migrate from broadcast television to cable, misidentified the bowl last year in which Iowa defeated Georgia Tech 24-14. It was the Orange Bowl, not the Sugar Bowl.

WEEKEND The Tipsy Diaries column on Friday about favorite cocktails from 2010, including the Seven Spice Sour served at Má Pêche in Manhattan, using information from the beverage director there, Colin Alevras, misidentified the creator of that drink. He is Don Lee, who used to work at the restaurant; Mr. Alevras did not create the drink.

Pavia Rosati, 40, lost her sense of smell after suffering head trauma four years ago. ''I'm someone who would describe my whole life through smells, which is why it took me a long time to accept that I might have to live like that forever. I miss the everyday smells you take for granted.'' Rain falling on the sidewalk on Second Avenue. Hermès's Un Jardin sur le Nil -- ''the last perfume I'll ever wear because it's the last one I loved.'' Onions sautéing in olive oil. Rosemary simmering in chick peas. Rib-eye charring on a barbecue. ''Above all I miss the smell of the air on a busy street on a crisp fall day.'' But no, even more, scents that are nameless: the smell of her skin, of her husband's neck, of her parents' house. ''If I get my sense of smell back, I'm going to do everything exactly the same. I'll just inhale a little more slowly and deeply.'' This series presents multiple-exposure portraits of perceptions of the city described by New Yorkers missing one or more senses. Earlier in the series: nytimes.com/lens.

The Charles Schwab Corporation agreed on Tuesday to pay $119 million to settle federal and state lawsuits in which regulators accused the company of misleading investors in a bond mutual fund that contained risky mortgage-backed securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission also filed civil complaints against two senior Schwab executives who oversaw the fund. Those lawsuits continue despite the settlement by the company.

8 P.M. (TCM) HAPPY 101ST BIRTHDAY, LUISE RAINER Reared in Düsseldorf, Germany, and Vienna -- during a childhood she described as ''one of starvation, poverty and revolution'' -- Ms. Rainer distinguished herself on the Berlin stage in Max Reinhardt's company before heading in 1935 to Hollywood, where some imagined she might become the next Greta Garbo. Under contract to MGM, she had achieved fame by 1937 as the first back-to-back Oscar recipient in acting. ''Nothing worse could have happened to me,'' she said later of her subsequent inability to meet audience expectations in a succession of insignificant roles. After a failed marriage to the playwright Clifford Odets, she left MGM after only three and a half years and eight pictures, returning to film briefly in 1943 in ''Hostages'' for Paramount. Happily remarried to the British publisher Robert Knittel from 1945 until his death in 1989, Ms. Rainer appeared sporadically in television and onstage in London, where she lives, before making her 11-minute movie comeback at 86 in ''The Gambler'' (1997) as the wealthy grandmother of a family on the brink of ruin. This four-film tribute is introduced by ''Luise Rainer: Live From the TCM Film Festival'' (2011), featuring her April 2010 interview with Robert Osborne. ''The Good Earth'' (1937), Victor Fleming's adaptation of the Pearl Buck classic about Chinese farmers battling the elements, starring Ms. Rainer in her Oscar-winning role as the kitchen slave O-Lan, follows at 8:30. In ''The Great Ziegfeld'' (1936), at 11:30, Robert Z. Leonard's lavish biography of the starmaker Flo Ziegfeld (William Powell), she plays the French singer Anna Held, for which she earned her first Oscar. In ''The Great Waltz'' (1938), at 2:45 a.m., a film loosely based on the life of the composer Johann Strauss II (Fernand Gravet), she appears as the fictitious Poldi Vogelhuber, Strauss's wife. The night ends with ''Dramatic School'' (1938), at 4:30, with Ms. Rainer (above, proposing a toast), appearing alongside Lana Turner and Paulette Goddard, as a young actress struggling to find fame on the stage and success in her marriage to a titled Frenchman (Alan Marshal). 7:55 P.M. (Sundance) L'AUBERGE ESPAGNOLE (2002) Xavier Rousseau, an uptight Parisian student played by Romain Duris, moves into a communal apartment in Barcelona and soon learns the international language of love and friendship in this comedy from Cédric Klapisch. Audrey Tatou is Xavier's worried girlfriend. In ''Bob Le Flambeur'' (1956), the first entry in a double bill by Jean Pierre Melville, starting at 10, Roger Duchesne stars as Bob Montagné, a pompadoured middle-aged gambler who stakes everything on a daring plan to rob a casino. In ''Le Doulos'' (1962), at 11:45, a young Jean-Paul Belmondo, dressed in trench coat and fedora, stars as Silien, a stylishly sinister Parisian hood hired by a recent parolee (Serge Reggiani) for a safe-cracking job.

An obituary on Tuesday about Debbie Friedman, a singer and songwriter who married traditional Jewish texts to contemporary melodies, gave an incorrect birth date from a family spokesman. She was born on Feb. 23, 1951, not on Feb. 8.

Michael White and Chris Cannon have officially dissolved their high-flying, high-end restaurant partnership, following two months of silence after blog items and unceasing speculation in the food world fueled the rumors of a breakup. The Altamarea Group, the SoHo-based umbrella company for the restaurateurs' businesses, announced Monday in a three-paragraph statement that Mr. White and Ahmass Fakahany, the company's chief executive, ''have ended their partnership'' with Mr. Cannon, resulting in a division of their fast-growing empire. The former partners operated seven restaurants - Marea, Alto, Convivio, Osteria Morini and Ai Fiori in Manhattan, as well as Due Mari and Due Terre, both in New Jersey. The statement said that Mr. Cannon would continue to own and operate the Northern Italian-accented Alto and the Southern Italian-inflected Convivio, and would soon name new chefs for them. That's because Gordon Finn, the chef de cuisine of Alto, and Matt Adler, the chef de cuisine of Convivio, will be leaving the restaurants for Mr. White. ''They will stay until we can find replacements for them,'' Mr. Cannon said. Mr. White and Mr. Fakahany, both of whom declined comment, will continue to own and operate Marea, Osteria Morini and Ai Fiori, as well as Due Terre and Due Mari in New Jersey. According to the statement, ''all future ventures under the Altamarea Group name will be operated by the partnership of Fakahany and White,'' including the company's ''first international project due to open in late spring 2011 on the Hong Kong harbor.'' In prior interviews, Mr. Cannon, Mr. White and Mr. Fakahany said they had planned to collaborate in ventures in other American cities and Asia, and were to have explored the opening of casual takeout restaurants. No financial details of the breakup were disclosed. Rumors of the breakup were first reported in November on Eater. It took months to make the announcement due to ''the complicated situation with a lot of restaurants involved - untangling them,'' Mr. Cannon said.He declined comment on the reasons for the breakup, or on Mr. Fakahany, but said that ''I very much enjoyed working with Michael, and I will look upon the time with him very fondly.''

SIMMONS--Desmond L.,of Smoke Rise, NJ on December 21 of natural causes. Beloved father of Barbara S. Wainscott by his late wife Marjorie, devoted and loving husband of his widow Jeanne Budde. A kind and honourable man of great integrity, he is greatly missed.

To help shake off those winter doldrums Jacob's Pillow has announced the lineup for its annual summer dance festival in Becket, Mass. A world premiere by Jane Comfort, anniversary celebrations of the Trisha Brown Dance Company and the Mark Morris Dance Group, as well as the American debuts of two companies, 3e Etage, comprising dancers from the Paris Opera Ballet, and DanzAbierta, a contemporary troupe from Cuba, are among the highlights of the festival. It will run from June 18 through Aug. 28 and include related events like an Annie Leibovitz dance photography exhibition. On opening night a gala performance will feature a world premiere created by the Houston Ballet artistic director, Stanton Welch. Others appearing at the festival include Keigwin & Company, Ballet du Grand Theatre de Geneve, Jonah Bokaer and David Dorfman Dance. The festival will continue its ''Under 35'' reduced-price ticket program for younger people and community Dance Day, with free performances and workshops on July 10. Visit jacobspillow.org for more details.

LOSS--Edith. A former magazine executive, died suddenly December 25 in Doylestown, PA. She was 82. Ms. Loss spent 36 years at Conde Nast Publications, first at Charm and later at Mademoiselle where she was merchandising director. At the time of her retirement in 1991, she was executive editor in charge of merchandising for Bride's where she managed the magazine's relations with leading department stores across the country and served as liaison between editorial and advertising. Ms. Loss was an inspiring mentor to countless young women and was active in the Fashion Group International where she volunteered as archival liaison. She is survived by her husband of over 43 years, Robert Sukup, sister Margaret Jones, of Lakeland, FL, four nieces and one nephew. A native New Yorker, Ms. Loss and her husband divided time between Manhattan and Bucks County, PA, where they restored an 18th century stone farmhouse. They moved there full-time in 2008. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

4:20 p.m. | Updated The dancers union has moved to block efforts by New York City Ballet to establish a smaller touring ensemble, saying it violates their labor contract. The union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said that City Ballet was required to ask its permission if it wanted to tour with anything less than the entire company. City Ballet failed to ask permission, the guild said. ''Until it secures A.G.M.A.'s consent, N.Y.C.B. may not conduct any tours which engage less than the entire company,'' the union said, adding that it mailed notice of its complaint to the company on Monday. Because the announcement came during ''difficult contract negotiations,'' it violated the principle of good-faith bargaining, the guild said, prompting the union to file an unfair labor practice charge against the company.

Hobbit fans can breathe a sigh of relief. Ian McKellen has agreed to reprise his role as Gandalf in Peter Jackson's two-picture adaptation of J.R.R. Tolkien's novel ''The Hobbit.'' Mr. McKellen portrayed Gandalf, the tall (especially when compared with a Hobbit) wizard in the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, and garnered an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor in the first of the three films, ''The Fellowship of the Ring.'' The adventures in Middle Earth begin with ''The Hobbit,'' which is scheduled to start shooting in New Zealand next month. Mr. Jackson was eager to sign up the same actors from the trilogy and has so far been successful. Andy Serkis has agreed to return as Gollum, Elijah Wood will play Frodo, and Cate Blanchett will appear as Galadriel. Mr. Jackson is hoping that Orlando Bloom will also agree to return to play the elf Legolas.

RINALDI--Frank R.,of Manhattan, died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, January 9, 2011, age 83. He was born in Mt. Vernon, NY, May 19, 1927, son of the late Frank and Fulvia Rinaldi of Mt. Vernon, NY. He was predeceased by his wife, Jean; son, Stephen; brothers, Dick and Joseph. He is survived by his son, Kirk (Mandi) of Londonderry, NH and long-time companion, Marilyn Wragg. He graduated from Harvard University in 1947, Harvard Law School, 1950 and was an active alumnus. Retiring from a longtime legal practice at the BNY Financial Corp., Bank of New York in 2000, he pursued his love of the cultural life of Manhattan and the Philharmonic, tutoring foreign students in English and traveling with Mrs. Wragg. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (New York City) Friday, 2-5 and 7-9pm with funeral service starting at 7:30pm. GUGGENHEIMER--Charles. The members and staff of The Yale Club of New York City mourn the passing of beloved member Charles S. Guggenheimer '55. Charlie served for many years on the Yale Club's Council and numerous committees. Amongst his many contributions, the most important was Charlie's role as an ambassador for the Yale Club to generations of young Yale graduates and our bridge to the University itself. His most lasting contribution was his tireless work on the Yale Club Scholars Fund. Under his leadership, the fund grew to provide assistance to 45 undergraduates, adding 12 new incoming freshmen to the program each year. These Scholars represent a legacy for the Club and a testament to Charlie's dedication. To honor Charlie's legacy the Club will be renaming the fund the Charles S. Guggenheimer '55 Scholars Fund. The Yale Club extends its deepest sympathies to Charlie's family. Charlie will be remembered for his wisdom, kindness, and commitment to all things Yale. He will be greatly missed.

''Detroit,'' a new play about American dissipation with some deliciously tart roles, set in the adjacent backyards of two recovering addicts and their anxious middle-class neighbors, will be produced on Broadway in early fall of 2011 under the direction of Austin Pendleton, the producers announced on Tuesday. No casting was announced for the five-character play, which will mark the Broadway debut of the playwright Lisa D'Amour, a well-known downtown writer and artist. Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company produced ''Detroit'' last fall, which included Laurie Metcalf (''November'' on Broadway, ''Roseanne'' on ABC) as the middle-class wife. The lead producers will be Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel, and Debbie Bisno, in association with Steppenwolf; Mr. Richards and Mr. Frankel previously teamed with Steppenwolf for its transfers of ''August: Osage County'' and ''Superior Donuts'' to Broadway. Performance dates and a theater will be announced later. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FRIEDMAN--Harvey L.,68, of White Plains, NY passed away on January 10, 2011 and is survived by his loving wife, Arlene three sons, David, Drew and Noah, devoted daughter-in-law, Lesley and grandchildren, Andrea and Max. Also, caring brother and sister-in-law, Ken and Nadine Sharf. A well respected real estate attorney, former partner at Kramer, Levin, et.al. and personal attorney for Dennis Mehiel at 4M Corporation. His caring of others, witty sense of humor, and love of family and friends, defined him. He bravely battled Alzheimer's Disease for nine long years. CRANE--William Murphy, Sr. JD, born in Woodlawn, New York on July 19, 1920, resident of Harwichport, Massachusetts, formerly of Yonkers, New York, died at his home on January 11, 2011 at the age of 90. William, known by his friends and family as Murph, was beloved husband to the late Dorothea Anne Kelsh of Bronxville, New York and is survived by his children William Murphy Crane, Jr., Dorothea Kelly, Thomas Crane and his wife Susan, and Marguerite McCormack and her husband Robert and his beloved grandchildren Kimberly, Stephen, Irina, Noelle, William Robert, Paige, Yana, Erin, Liza, William and Promyse. Following Murph's graduation from Manhattan College in 1942, he served in the United States Army Air Force. Murph attended Fordham School of Law where he earned the degree of Doctor of Juris Prudence. Murph pursued a career in banking at Citibank where he served until his retirement in 1979. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's church, Bronxville on Friday January 14 at 10 am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

CHAIKIN--Rosalind B. Especially loved wife of the late Sol Chick Chaikin, former President of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, cherished mother of Robert and Marilyn, Eric and Stacey, David and Wendy and Karen; adored grandmother of Reed, Gregg, Shari, Kyle, Allison, Nikki, Lee, Wendy, Shana, Grady, Seth, Agata, Zachary, Kim and Rebecca; and beloved great-grandmother of thirteen; passed away January 9, 2011 quietly at home. She devoted her life to family, friends and numerous community causes, retired BOCES teacher for children who were visually handicapped or blind and/or learning disabled; translated books into braille for the blind, was formerly a member of the Board of Overseers at the Heller School for Social Policy and Management, Brandeis University and former Chair, Institute for Child, Youth and Family Policy at the Heller School; recipient of the Association of Children with Learning Disabilities Humanitarian Award, Nassau Chapter; who after her husband's death chronicled the beginning of their life-long love affair, penning her memoir, "To My Memory Sing" and poetry books titled, "The Perfect Starfish" and "Polished Stones." A gorgeous, graceful, intelligent lady full of love and life will be seriously missed by family, friends and all who knew her. The Chaikin Family

The Tuck Rule has lost a supporter, and not just anybody. Mike Pereira was the N.F.L.'s vice president for officiating from 2004-9, and spent the five seasons before that as the league's director of officiating. He joined Fox Sports this season as a rules analyst. It's in that capacity that he revisited a rule that has puzzled many fans (and infuriated some) for a decade. On Sunday, Chiefs quarterback Matt Cassel was tackled by the Ravens' Lardarius Webb while pulling the ball back to his body. The ruling was a fumble, and the Ravens recovered. After a challenge and review, the call was reversed to an incomplete pass. The call turned out not to matter -- the Ravens won easily, 30-7. But a Tuck ruling meant everything in 2002, when the Raiders recovered the ball but had to give it back to the Patriots in a snowy playoff game. At the time, Pereira defended the call, saying, ''Any time you're tucking the ball back toward your body, it's an incomplete pass'' and ''I may agree that Brady was not trying to throw the ball'' but ''he never controlled it long enough to consider him a runner.''

OURLICHT--Laurie E.,age 57, succumbed to multiple myeloma December 24, 2010. She earned her undergraduate degree from SUNY at Fredonia and a Masters in Fine Arts from Temple University. She was an accomplished artist with her work appearing in many shows and collections over her too short life. We mourn our beloved mother, daughter, and sister, sister in law, aunt, cousin and friend. She leaves behind her son Samuel; father Boris; brother David; sister- in -law Marybeth; nephew David; niece Christine. She fought the good fight and we will all miss you Laurie. Love, Your Family & Friends

The conclusion of the historian David Brion Davis's most recent book, "Inhuman Bondage," traces the significance of the United States Civil War in the ending of slavery elsewhere. It implicitly poses the question: What if the Confederacy had won recognition from Britain in 1862 and had survived the war? Our rather frightening answer is that the three great centers of slavery in the Americas, the United States South, Cuba and Brazil - plus the smaller plantation economy of Dutch Suriname - would not have abolished slavery when they did.

Sometime early this year, New York City's taxi and limousine commission will announce the winner of its "Taxi of Tomorrow" competition. Or it won't. The project was begun in 2007, and in December 2009 a "request for proposals" went out to automotive manufacturers and designers. The bar wasn't set all that high: the Taxi of Tomorrow was meant to be "safe, fuel-efficient, accessible, durable, and comfortable." A look at the three finalists announced in November 2010 confirms they are perhaps all of those things. They are also, well, dull. Boxy. Lacking in imagination. (Not that New York's current cab, the Ford Crown Victoria, was one to inspire much.)

Mandy Coon nabbed one of this year's Ecco Domani fashion awards for her structural, dark, moody and much buzzed-about designs, but her talents don't stop there. She occasionally moonlights as a D.J. and a model, and it turns out she is also something of a film buff. Her newest side project is called the Fashion in Film-Designer Inspiration movie night. First up for the private event is Ingmar Bergman's beautifully confusing psychological thriller "Persona." The film stars Liv Ullmann as Elisabeth, a successful actress who becomes suddenly mute, and Bibi Andersson as Alma, a young nurse who is supposed to care for Elisabeth but falls into an even more twisted and fragile mental state than her patient. The film's costumes are more straightforward than the plot - black turtlenecks, a great pleather trench, a monochromatic suit. It's not hard to see why Coon would be drawn to it.

The gourmet coffee and thriving food cart cultures of Portland, Ore., are hardly starving for attention, but the city is also quietly home to Kornblatt's Delicatessen, one of the truly great New York delis outside the five boroughs.Located in the Northwest 23rd shopping district, this displaced ode to New York deli counter culture strives for authenticity (Nova lox, pickles and meats imported from New York City), and yet it can't help but reflect the differences between Manhattan and Portland. For starters, there are four local beers on tap, including Deschutes Black Butte Porter and Cascade I.P.A., as well as a spacious, relaxed dining room and a vegetarian Reuben option, both unheard of at, say, Katz's or Eisenberg's in New York. There's even locally made organic chicken basil sausage on the brunch menu.

As we are reminded not just this week but every day in the news, violence remains a major public health issue in the United States. Homicide remains the 15th leading cause of death over all and the leading cause of death among African-American males age 15 to 34.

I don't have much to add to the litany of praise that the president's memorial service performance has earned, deservedly, from his political opponents. The peculiar atmosphere of the event notwithstanding, the speech was everything it needed to be: A moving eulogy for the dead, a sober, religiously-inflected reflection on the mystery of iniquity, and an explicit rebuke to partisan readings of this tragedy - which will close the book, one hopes, on a week's worth of inappropriate and increasingly implausible attempts to portray Jared Lee Loughner as a Tea Partier in spirit. Everything Obama did right during his presidential campaign he did right last night: It may not have been the best speech of his life, but it was the best speech of his presidency.

More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science?
