The Museum of Modern Art has acquired the David Wojnarowicz video that was removed from a show at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington after drawing criticism from a religious organization and some congressional Republicans. The museum acquired both the original 13-minute version of the video, titled "A Fire in My Belly," and a separate 7-minute excerpt made by the artist; the two are now being shown in a loop as part of a display of contemporary art from the museum's collection that will remain up until May 9.

Carrying small digital video cameras on patrols and other military missions covered by The New York Times over the years, I have amassed a few bricks worth of footage of the Afghan war - shuras and firefights, long walks and short dashes, helicopter flights and convoys, the routines of fire base life and an accidental visual inventory of the Afghan countryside. I often keep the video camera on as a notebook, absorbing sights and sounds that I might refer to later when I write. It aids with accuracy. Many times I also find that the camera has soaked up dialogue or recorded visual details that that I didn't hear or see in real time. It's a priceless tool, even if it adds to the work after each assignment, when the footage must be downloaded, labeled and archived.

Lesley Manville had no idea what the National Board of Review was when she learned she had won its best actress award for her work in Mike Leigh's "Another Year." She confided this to the Bagger, and to the roomful of attendees, at the National Board of Review's gala on Tuesday night. Though she is a veteran actress and a veteran of Mr. Leigh's films -- it is her sixth collaboration with the maverick British director, who famously drafts no scripts or characters before he begins working on his films - it is her first time at the awards slog. She's a quick study, though. (She has to be: Mr. Leigh's films are all improvised.)

COFFEY--Jeremiah P.,96, died peacefully on January 11, 2011, at the end of a long, full life. Son of immigrants Doonane and Gortnaskehy, County Tipperary, he was born in Brooklyn, NY, attended Our Lady of Perpetual Help elementary school and Regis High School, rose to the rank of Captain at the New York Fire Department and then went on to become the business manager of the Long Island Catholic Newspaper at its founding. Married for sixty years to Josephine Campbell Coffey, he is the father of Josephine, Jeremiah, Patrick, James, Catherine, Justin, Moira, Helen and Jane. He is the grandfather of Matthew, Erin, John, Owen, Caroline, Elena, Aedan, Julia, Sarah, Gregory, Jenny and Josephine. He is the great-grandfather of Amaris, Olive and Ava. He is survived by his sister Nance and his brother Patrick. "Pray for me as I will for thee, that we may merrily meet in heaven". Reposing, Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Ave., Friday 2-4, 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, Saturday 10am, St Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment, St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. mackenmortuary.com

O'BRIEN--Thomas E.,of Fort Pierce, Florida, formerly of Larchmont, died January 9th after a long illness. The only child of the late Mary and Peter O'Brien of Mahanoy City, Pennsylvania, Tom was born March 21, 1927 in Ashland, Pennsylvania. He was a graduate of the US Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, NY (class of 1944 - the last of the wartime cadets), Georgetown University Schools of Foreign Service and Law, and was a Commander in the US Naval Reserve Retired, having served in the Korean conflict. Tom had been an attorney in private practice in Manhattan, New Rochelle, Larchmont, Mamaroneck and Queens. Among his favorite work was serving as the attorney for two USMMA-sponsored 12-Metre America's Cup Syndicates - Courageous and America II. Tom is survived by his daughters, Margaret Attwood O'Brien of Salisbury, CT and Catherine O'Brien Yaffa, her husband Richard and their two children Jessica Gould Yaffa and Douglas Charles Yaffa of Harrison, NY and by his former wife Patricia Gould O'Brien (Patty) of Larchmont, NY. Burial at sea in Florida was private. Memorial Service 11am Saturday January 22 at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont NY.

An article on Dec. 30 about household injuries to children gave an outdated title for a doctor at Children's Hospital Los Angeles who spoke about the most common causes of such injuries. Dr. Alan Nager is the director of the division of emergency and transport medicine; he is no longer acting head of the division of emergency medicine.

The 41-story former Deutsche Bank building opposite the World Trade Center site is now the one-story former Deutsche Bank building. Within a month, it should be down to zero; the last and largest of the 9/11 structural remnants to be cleared away, almost a full decade after it was seriously damaged in the attack and six years after the first of many promised completion dates.

Randy Gardner, a lanky Portland-transplant living in Tucson, had stopped by Gabrielle Giffords' political event on Saturday after dropping some bills off at the post office. He ducked for cover once the shooting started, but when he heard ''pop, pop, pop'' and the same screams that many survivors from the massacre have described, he found it more than terrifying. He found it uncomfortably familiar.

8:15 P.M. (Sundance) SUMMER HOURS (2008) Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche play Frédéric and Adrienne, siblings who must decide what to do with their mother's charming country house and cherished art collection after her death. He wants to keep everything as is for the enjoyment of the next generation. She and another brother (Jérémie Renier, above left with Ms. Binoche and Mr. Berling) want to sell the house and most of its contents, donating the best paintings and furnishings to the Musée d'Orsay. ''That, in a nutshell, is the dramatic arc of this extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this movie from Olivier Assayas, which, Mr. Scott said, is about ''the curious alchemy that transforms certain objects into art.'' The film, ''as calm and quiet as its title, is in some ways his most coherent and complex exploration of the current shape of the world,'' Mr. Scott added. ''Don't be fooled by the apparent modesty of its ambitions. Sometimes a small, homely object -- a teapot, a writing desk, a sketchbook, a movie about such things -- turns out to be a masterpiece.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: PETER SELLERSTurner Classic Movies continues its tribute to the chameleonic Sellers, starting with ''Only Two Can Play'' (1962), in which he portrays a Welsh librarian who, fed up with his boring, married existence, tries to consummate an affair with a beautiful woman (Mai Zetterling). In ''The Millionairess'' (1960), at 10, he plays an ascetic Indian doctor pursued by the world's richest woman (Sophia Loren). In ''I Love You, Alice B. Toklas'' (1968), at 11:45, Sellers is a henpecked Los Angeles lawyer who escapes into the world of hippies and free love; in ''What's New Pussycat?'' (1965), at 1:30 a.m., he's a psychiatrist to a fashion editor (Peter O'Toole) who can't stop beautiful women from pursuing him. And in ''After the Fox'' (1966), at 3:30, Sellers plays a notorious con man who poses as a film director to smuggle $3 million in gold bullion into Italy.

An article and a chart in the special Education Life section on Sunday about revisions to the Advanced Placement program referred incorrectly to score trends on A.P. exams since 1997. The scores given were means, not medians. An accompanying article about a change in the scoring of A.P. exams so that points are no longer deducted for a wrong answer misstated the amount deducted for a wrong answer on the SAT, which is not changing. A wrong answer on the SAT costs 0.25 of a point, not 0.75.

Portugal won some breathing room Wednesday with a better-than-expected bond auction that fueled a rise in global stock markets and led the government to reaffirm its stance against accepting a bailout. WINGATE--David Aaron David Aaron Wingate, born Aaron David Winograd on January 6, 1921, died on January 9 following a long illness, shortly after his 90th birthday. He was the beloved husband of Shoshanna; elder brother of the Honorable Eliyahu Winograd of Tel Aviv; father of Batsheva Wingate Ostrow and Ealan Wingate; father-in-law of Ronald Ostrow and Melinda Wingate; grandfather of Amanda Wingate and of Alonna Ostrow Ostad, Sharone Ostrow Gilbert, and Jonathan Ostrow, and their spouses Michael Ostad, Richard Gilbert, and Rose Ostrow; great-grandfather of Hannah, Alexandra, and Ari Ostad; Benjamin, Emma, Zachary, and Sam Gilbert; and Julian Ostrow. He also leaves a loving extended family in Israel, where he was born. He lived in Old Westbury, NY and Palm Beach, Florida. He was a strong and devoted head of his family, who adored and revered him and will remember him forever. From a young age, he was driven by curiosity. Aaron/ David became a successful business man first in Palestine, then in the newly formed Israel, where he was a fifth generation Israeli, and then in his adopted New York community. He was the CEO of Hi-Shear Industries (an NYSE-registered institution). He and his wife supported many Jewish institutions, including the Jewish Theological Seminary, North Shore Long Island Jewish Hospital, the UJA, the Solomon Schechter School, and Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, where they endowed the David and Shoshanna Wingate Center. He was a powerful presence in many lives. His own life was shaped by the love of an extraordinary and wonderful woman, Shoshanna. All who knew them admired the deep love they held for each other and their amazing partnership throughout their sixty-seven years together. David and his adored Shoshanna forged a life built on hard work, sacrifice, commitment to family and a dedication to the welfare of the Jewish Community. They shared a great love of the arts and a circle of devoted friends. He will be remembered always by all those his life touched, and by all those who knew him for his delighted and welcoming smile. May his name be forever a blessing. May his name always be included among the names of the righteous. Services are at 11:30am on Tuesday, January 11 at Temple Beth Sholom, Rosyln Heights, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in David Wingate's honor to a Jewish charity of your choice.

An article on Tuesday about long-time political tensions in the Eighth Congressional District of Arizona, represented by Gabrielle Giffords, referred incorrectly to the National Republican Congressional Committee's financial support for Jesse Kelly, a Republican candidate with Tea Party backing who opposed Ms. Giffords in last year's election. The N.R.C.C. provided money to help pay for an advertisement for Mr. Kelly's campaign; it is not the case that Mr. Kelly did not receive financial support from the committee.

Lorenzo Romar, coach of the Washington men's basketball team, acknowledged Tuesday that one of his players was being investigated by the police in Seattle after an accusation of sexual assault by a 16-year-old girl. The police have not identified the player and have not filed charges. Romar addressed the investigation with reporters at his regular weekly news conference, but said he could not provide any specifics. Romar said the university was taking the investigation seriously but that he would take no action until getting further information from the police. The allegation, which was first reported by KIRO-TV in Seattle, came from a girl who told the police that the player raped her after they met at an apartment Saturday night. The two had met on Facebook, according to the police report, and agreed to meet that night.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- Inside Thompson-Boling Arena, Jason Shay, an assistant with the Tennessee men's basketball team, looked down at his standardized letter jacket with the orange ''T'' embroidered on the front. It might not be orange enough, he thought, for his recruiting adventure over the next five and a half months. ''They have to know I'm there,'' he said of recruits and their coaches and parents. ''I have an orange sweat suit at home. Maybe I can wear that. That's the one thing about our colors; you know we're in the building. We stand out.''

Chip Kelly, Oregon's football coach, found inspiration in his friend and fellow New England native Micky Ward, a former junior-welterweight champion. Early in the season, he showed his team film of Ward in the ring. Ward also met with the players, most recently on Monday night, before the Ducks' 22-19 loss to Auburn in the national championship game in Glendale, Ariz. ''I guess my speech didn't do too good,'' Ward said, laughing. ''But I think the players got a lot out of my message to them, which was basically to give it all you have, especially in the last round. Don't hold anything back. It's the way I fought my entire career.'' Until the release of the hit movie ''The Fighter,'' Ward was best known for his three brutal bouts with Arturo Gatti in 2002 and 2003. Ward said that Mark Wahlberg, who was nominated for a Golden Globe for his performance in the film, ''did a great job playing me because he truly captured how loyal I was to everyone around me.''

At the Consumer Electronics Show, products ran from the sublime to the ridiculous, to the really ridiculous. Take Hannspree, which has built its business making components for other TV companies, but makes its own TVs as well. Several of its lines have a distinctly whimsical bent. For instance, what hoops fan wouldn't want a 55-inch TV embedded in a 74 inch basketball? It's man-cave ready with full HD, an LCD screen and four HDMI inputs. If you aren't a basketball fan, there is also a giant football TV, a huge soccer ball TV, and oddly, an oversized apple. Even if you order now you won't get your football shaped TV in time for the Super Bowl, however. The 55-inch models are built to order at a price of $9,000 each - not including shipping - and take about three months from order to delivery.

MILLY has a playful new children's line, the Milly Minis collection. The designer Michelle Smith (below, with daughter Sophia) said translating the vibrant prints and feminine style was easy, except for one thing: ''It was tough getting a 4-year-old fit model to stay still and not wiggle.'' The line will range from $150 to $195 for dresses and $225 to $245 for coats. Ms. Smith is also adding a ladylike structured handbag line, priced from $250 to $525. The entire collection will be available at the Milly flagship store opening this spring on Madison Avenue. The bags and the children's line are available this month at Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue and Millyny.com.

LONDON -- Marta Vieira da Silva is unrivaled at what she does, but a person of no fixed abode, with no certain future. She has scored goals galore in Brazil, Sweden and the United States. On Monday, FIFA once again acknowledged her as overwhelmingly the best female player on earth, for the fifth year in a row.

MCCARTEN--Louis A. Louis A.,Lieutenant Colonel, "Andy", of Fall River, MA died January 10, 2011. He retired from the military in 1976 with over 30 years in the Army and Army Reserves. He was the husband of the late Dorothy "Gloria" (Kearns) McCarten to whom he had been married for over 49 years. Born in New York, he was the son of the late Charles and Madeline (Cuvillier) McCarten. He was a 1947 graduate of Yale University, New Haven, CT, attended Harvard Law School, Cambridge, MA and received his M.B.A. in accounting from New York University. He was a financial executive for many years, retiring in 1984, after working for various companies, including Reeves Soundcraft, Nautec and Celanese in New York, Industrial National Bank in Rhode Island, Credit Card Services Corp of Alexandria, VA, Max Factor in Hollywood, CA and Computers International in Los Angeles. He was a member of the University Club, of Providence, RI and former member of the Rhode Island Country Club. He was an avid reader, loved to ski and was a connoisseur of fine wines. He is survived by one daughter, Dorothy Gloria McCarten of Norwalk, CT; three sons Louis McCarten II of Glendale, CA, Charles R. McCarten of Warren, RI and Christopher McCarten and his wife Mary Jo of Fall River, MA; and three grandchildren, Samuel, Nicholas and Alexis. His funeral will be held on Friday, January 14, 2011 at 8am from the Waring-Sullivan Home Of Memorial Tribute at Cherry Place 178 Winter St., Fall River, followed by his funeral mass at 9am in Holy name Church 709 Hanover St., Fall River. Visiting hours will be Thursday from 5 to 8pm. Burial will be St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronyx, NY. For tributes and directions visit: www.waring-sullivan.com

Over the next two weeks Anthony Tommasini is exploring the qualities that make a classical composer great, maybe even the best of all time. Watch videos and vote for your own top 10 here and read previous posts here and share your thoughts in the comments field. Mr. Tommasini's final list will be posted on Jan. 21. The 19th century will pose the toughest calls in our whimsical attempt to identify the top 10 classical composers of all time. Think of Chopin, Schumann, Berlioz, Liszt, Brahms, Tchaikovsky. And what about Verdi and Wagner? So let me deal with the 20th century first, see how many slots might still be left, and work backward.

GEISMAR--Anne, born May 1, 1909 died in New York on January 10, 2011 after a brief illness. Anne, widow of well-known literary critic and historian Maxwell Geismar, was herself an author and editor, having published "Resilient Radical" at age 96. A lifelong resident of Harrison, NY, she is survived by her daughter Katie and son-in-law Larry Seiden; daughter Elizabeth Geismar; brother Robert Rosenberg, and was preceded in death by her son Peter. She was a daughter of James and Bessie Rosenberg of Scarsdale, NY. She will always be loved and remembered by her family, including three devoted grandchildren and six great-grandchildren for her tenacity and zeal.

Over the next two weeks, executives at the market researcher Nielsen will traverse the United States and Europe to sell big investors on its $1.5 billion offering, putting it on track to become the first major company backed by private equity to go public this year. The stakes are high, not only for the company's owners, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Carlyle Group and the Blackstone Group, but also for the rest of the buyout world.

CARPENTER--Edward N. (Tim), of Lawrence, New York, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 12th, at the age of 91. Tim graduated from The Buckley School, Brooks School and Yale University in 1942. He married Kitty Eaton and served in the Pacific as a U.S. Marine in World War II, including the battle of Iwo Jima. After the war he returned to lead the brokerage firm of Jessup and Lamont. In 1960 he retired from the world of finance to work full time as a playwright and lyricist. His wife, Kitty, died in 1971 after 29 years of marriage. In 1973 he married Margaret Owen Van Rensselaer. He is survived by his beloved wife Margaret and his devoted children Katherine Carpenter McCallum, Carolyn Carpenter Wright, Jake Burton Carpenter, Richard Owen Carpenter, Stephen Owen Carpenter, Posie Owen Carpenter and Margaret Carpenter Jones. His son, George Whitney Carpenter, USMC, was killed in Vietnam in 1967. Tim is also survived by twenty grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His family, friends and community will never forget his extraordinary principles, kindness and strength as a leader. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity St. John's Church in Hewlett, Long Island on Saturday, January 15th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the George W. Carpenter Scholarship Fund at the Brooks School, North Andover, MA 01845, or to St. John's Episcopal Hospital, 327 Beach 19th Street, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

Archie Andrews, the perpetual teenager from Riverdale, is taking another step into the future. Beginning in April, Archie Comics will offer digital versions of its comics on the same day that the print editions arrive on newsstands. The company will be starting with six monthly titles: Archie, Archie & Friends, Betty, Veronica, Betty and Veronica, and Jughead. ''We have a very exciting little business here,'' said Jon Goldwater, the co-chief executive of Archie Comics. ''We have to keep figuring out ways of pushing it forward.''DC and Marvel Comics have experimented with ''day-and-date'' releases, in which the digital version of a comic book is available at the same time as the print version, but they have largely been one-offs.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the renovation of the Grand Hyatt hotel in Manhattan described incorrectly plans for the hotel's Commodore Grill, which is currently closed. It will reopen as a banquet and meeting facility, not as a public restaurant. The article also referred incorrectly to a Hyatt representative. The employee, Farley Kern, is a woman.

Taylor Swift's ''Speak Now'' is at No. 1 for the sixth week on the Billboard album chart this week. But the weekly sales figures have earned it what Billboard.com calls the ''dubious honor'' of having the lowest sales - 52,000 copies - for a No. 1 album since Nielsen SoundScan began keeping track in 1991. The previous low was set by the ''Dreamgirls'' soundtrack on the Jan., 27, 2007, chart, with slightly more than 60,000 albums sold. Back to 2011: Nicki Minaj's ''Pink Friday'' climbed to No. 2 with 39,000, and Bruno Mars moved up a spot to No. 3 with ''Doo-Wops & Hooligans,'' which sold 38,000. Daft Punk's ''Tron: Legacy'' soundtrack is fourth with sales of 34,000, and Eminem's ''Recovery'' slipped three notches to No. 5, with sales of 33,000. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The New York City Fire Department should work closely with Broadway theater owners, producers, and employees to develop new preparedness and training standards for emergencies like the attempted car bombing last May in Times Square, according to a report [pdf] of the New York State Assembly's subcommittee on workplace safety, chaired by Queens Assemblyman Rory Lancman. The May 1 attempted bombing revealed that theater employees were unfamiliar with ''what to do in case of an emergency as well as the unique problems that a theater workplace poses in the event of a fire or evacuation,'' according to the report, which was released on Wednesday and drew on interviews with members of seven theatrical unions including Actors' Equity and the stagehands' Local 1.''Taking the May 1, 2010, car bomb as an example,'' the report stated, ''theater employees expressed how unprepared they were in dealing with the situation. They were given misinformation, and they were directed to exit through portals they did not even know existed, indicating their lack of knowledge of the building they work in and exit routes. In the event of another attack, the same issues would arise.''

The N.B.A.'s latest marketing foray not only lacks the charm of previous endeavors, but actually borders on creepy in its attempt at capturing the surreal. At the risk of oversimplifying, it doesn't seem to have much of a point. We, the viewing audience, dive into Kevin Durant's past to watch an apparent time traveler pretend to inform Durant of his eventual N.B.A. fate. In the lack of real purpose, we're left to focus solely on the commercial's aesthetic, which is as bizarre as it is false.It's silly to ask how we -- along with our mystery traveler -- are transported to Rockville, Maryland circa 2005. After all, beyond a typical suspension of disbelief that accompanies the commercial medium, television ads are typically constructed in a serialized manner. In Television Culture, media scholar John Fiske described the serialized form as "an infinitely extended middle," and in a sense, that's where these spots take (and leave) us. The year 2005 isn't a beginning in any sense for Durant, and we're not privileged to see the process by which our traveler makes his way into Durant's past. There's also no real attempt at ending or closure, marking the images we see as some sort of enduring middleness, a journey which we join in progress. If nothing else, such a structure reinforces that this tale we're witnessing is hardly our own.

I wonder periodically if there is some sort of mom-blog jinx. I was already an avid reader of blogs even before I was asked to create Motherlode, and now scrolling through several dozen of them each day is my professional routine. When you read so many you can't help noticing that very bad things have happened to a striking number of their authors. Some of this, of course, is because the Internet is now the place to turn when parents are struggling. That would explain many of the blogs that were started after -- after a father was paralyzed, or a mother died in childbirth or a husband drowned.But what strikes me is the number of times that tragedy found a blogger who just happened to be blogging. Stephanie Nielsen wrote mostly about life as the mother of four children until she and her husband were nearly killed, and Stephanie was horrifyingly burned, in a plane crash. Heather Armstrong was writing about work when she was blindsided by postpartum depression and blogged her way through a psychiatric hospitalization. The comic Daphne Brogdon's blog was about her blended family, until she lost her life savings to Bernie Madoff.

There were a lot of great comments -- too many, unfortunately, for me to be able to single them all out or otherwise address them here. Though I'm going to dedicate this post to selectively recapping the comments and seeing what perspective we can wring out of them, it won't be my last word on the subject. And some of the comments I neglect here will influence future posts.

ROBINSON--Phyllis K.: Part of the team that opened Doyle Dane Bernbach, loving wife and mother, a gifted writer and mentor, Phyllis was more than "The Original Mad Woman." Friend and beacon, she had an amazing ability to cut directly to the chase, almost always with a bit of well-timed humor. Phyllis' work was unfailingly fresh, capturing social change and feelings that were still only in the air in work such as "It lets me be me" for Clairol. A force in advertising's creative revolution, Phyllis was an unabashed champion of creative freedom and room to breathe. She was a gifted Copy Chief, the first female in that role, and we will miss you dearly. Your friends at DDB

WASHINGTON -- Julian Assange, the flamboyant founder of WikiLeaks, is living on a supporter's 600-acre estate outside London, where he has negotiated $1.7 million in book deals and regularly issues defiant statements about the antisecrecy group's plans. Meanwhile, the young soldier accused of leaking the secret documents that brought WikiLeaks and Mr. Assange to fame and notoriety is locked in a tiny cell at the Quantico Marine Corps Base in Virginia. The soldier, Pfc. Bradley Manning, who turned 23 last month in the military prison, is accused of the biggest leak of classified documents in American history. He awaits trial on charges that could put him in prison for 52 years, according to the Army.

Services entrusted to R.Stutzmann & Son, New Hyde Park, NY. (516) 352-3434.

On Oct. 2, 1954, before almost 80,000 fans at Cleveland Stadium, the Indians' Dale Mitchell popped out against Johnny Antonelli to give the New York Giants their fifth World Series championship. There is no footage of Willie Mays and friends hoisting the commissioner's trophy in triumph. Back then, there was no such thing. Baseball did not present its champion with the familiar ring of flags until 1967, and the Giants did not earn it until last November, more than a half-century after they moved to San Francisco. Next week, they will take the trophy to their ancestral home with a public visit to New York.

An article on Thursday about the perjury trial of a Cuban exile, Luis Posada Carriles, referred incompletely to the years that he worked for the Central Intelligence Agency. Besides working for the C.I.A. in Miami between 1965 and 1967, he was also a ''paid asset'' of the agency in Venezuela from 1968 to 1976, according to declassified documents and a unclassified summary of his career in the court record.

Despite at least three major film projects in the works, the Academy Award nominee Carey Mulligan (''An Education'') is finding time to return to the New York stage. Ms. Mulligan is set to star in the United States premiere of ''Through A Glass Darkly,'' a stage adaptation of the 1961 film by Ingmar Bergman about a mentally ill young woman who, while on a tense vacation with her family, grapples with a tenuous hold on reality and with otherworldly voices, one of which may be God's. The Atlantic Theater Company production will be directed by David Leveaux, a five-time nominee for Tony Awards for best director; he will move to this play after mounting the Broadway revival of Tom Stoppard's ''Arcadia'' this spring. The adaptation of the Bergman work, by Jenny Worton, was produced at the Almeida Theater in London last summer.

A Manhattan lawyer who has filed a series of antifeminist lawsuits in recent years -- with little success -- has suffered his latest defeat: the United States Supreme Court refused to hear what he calls his ''ladies' night lawsuit.'' In 2007, the lawyer, Roy Den Hollander, filed a class-action suit against Manhattan nightclubs like Copacabana, China Club, Lotus and Sol, claiming that they discriminated against men by offering free or reduced admission to women on ''ladies' nights.'' Mr. Den Hollander contended that these offers violated the 14th Amendment's guarantee of equal protection under the law.

Around midnight, upstairs in a small club on Avenue of the Americas, the pitch-black dance floor resounded with the rapid stomps and warbling, high-energy cries of the dabke, an Arab folk dance performed at weddings and other celebrations. When the strobe lights flashed, they revealed a sea of raised hands. A man in the crowd removed his kaffiyeh, the traditional headdress worn by some Arab and Kurdish men, and whipped it around in the air.

DORFF--Richard. Died January 12, age 82. Beloved husband of Joan, loving dad of Daniel, Janet and husband Tony, devoted grandpa of Julia, Michael, David and Allison. Service at Riverside, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, Friday 2:30pm. Donations-- St. Francis Hospital Foundation, Development Office, 100 Pt. Washington Blvd, Roslyn 11576.

CARPENTER--Edward N. (Tim), of Lawrence, New York, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 12th, at the age of 91. Tim graduated from The Buckley School, Brooks School and Yale University in 1942. He married Kitty Eaton and served in the Pacific as a U.S. Marine in World War II, including the battle of Iwo Jima. After the war he returned to lead the brokerage firm of Jessup and Lamont. In 1960 he retired from the world of finance to work full time as a playwright and lyricist. His wife, Kitty, died in 1971 after 29 years of marriage. In 1973 he married Margaret Owen Van Rensselaer. He is survived by his beloved wife Margaret and his devoted children Katherine Carpenter McCallum, Carolyn Carpenter Wright, Jake Burton Carpenter, Richard Owen Carpenter, Stephen Owen Carpenter, Posie Owen Carpenter and Margaret Carpenter Jones. His son, George Whitney Carpenter, USMC, was killed in Vietnam in 1967. Tim is also survived by twenty grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His family, friends and community will never forget his extraordinary principles, kindness and strength as a leader. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity St. John's Church in Hewlett, Long Island on Saturday, January 15th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the George W. Carpenter Scholarship Fund at the Brooks School, North Andover, MA 01845, or to St. John's Episcopal Hospital, 327 Beach 19th Street, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

WHITING--Margaret. With deep sadness, The Johnny Mercer Foundation joins legions of fans around the world in mourning the passing of legendary singer Margaret Whiting. The world remembers her as the embodiment of the American Songbook. We on the Board remember her as the President of the Johnny Mercer Foundation, the person chosen by Ginger Mercer to expand Johnny's legacy through educating and mentoring vocal aspirants and celebrating Johnny as America's lyric laureate. Margaret created an enduring cultural legacy not only through her own music but also through her dedication to insuring a permanent record of Johnny's achievements. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. John D. Marshall, Chairman The Johnny Mercer Foundation

The Museum of Modern Art has acquired the David Wojnarowicz video that was removed from a show at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington after drawing criticism from a religious organization and some congressional Republicans. The museum acquired both the original 13-minute version of the video, titled ''A Fire in My Belly,'' and a separate 7-minute excerpt made by the artist; the two are now being shown in a loop as part of a display of contemporary art from the museum's collection that will remain up until May 9. Mr. Wojnarowicz, who died of AIDS in 1992, made the video in the late 1980s in response to the AIDS crisis. It was included in a show at the National Portrait Gallery, a Smithsonian museum, examining gay themes in American portraiture but was removed after it was attacked by Bill Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, and several Republican congressmen who objected to an image in the video of ants crawling on a crucifix.

He was very special to us all. Shelly spent his last seven years with his partner and angel, Olga Paz, who with her four children, gave Shelly so much joy and love for the last years of his life. Shelly lived a challenging and beautiful life. He was a real "Broadway Guy" who loved his home and family, dogs and birds and most especially riding his horse thru the New Jersey countryside. Funeral services will be held 11am on Friday at the A. S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 N Main Street, Cranbury.

The schools superintendent in Waterbury, Conn., is seeking to shut down a production of one of August Wilson's great dramas, ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' because some of the teenage actors would have to utter the word ''nigger'' as called for in the script, according to a report in the city's Republican-American newspaper. The Waterbury Board of Education is expected to take up the matter at a meeting on Tuesday. According to the newspaper, the superintendent, David Snead, said this week that educators should not do anything that might encourage people to use the word. ''The use of the N-word is something all civil rights leaders around the country want us to stop using,'' said Mr. Snead, who is black.

When Duane Reade opened a new store a few months ago in Brooklyn, it faced opposition from residents loyal to a local pharmacy. So it decided to include something in the store that the neighborhood did not have: a bar that specializes in beer. One corner of the Duane Reade store on Bedford Avenue in the Williamsburg neighborhood has Fire Island Lighthouse Ale and eight other beers on tap, with growlers -- refillable glass bottles -- lining the walls. Uniformed clerks-cum-beer-experts fill the growlers and conduct tastings only -- sorry, no pints served. Behind a bar, a large walk-in refrigerator stocks common national brands as well as local, craft and imported beers. ''We knew we would have a little bit of a battle to try to bring Duane Reade into this community, because they really don't like a chain store,'' said Paul Tiberio, senior vice president for merchandising and marketing at the company.

8:58 p.m. | Updated There was a dramatic avian emergency in Midtown on Thursday afternoon, and City Room did not have to go far to report it: a juvenile red-tailed hawk smashed into the five-story glass atrium at The New York Times Building, fell to a fourth-floor landing, then fell again to the courtyard four stories below. A rescue was required. Crowds gathered at the newsroom windows. The bird lay motionless most of the time, but occasionally twitched its head or flapped its wings. NYC Audubon urged getting the bird into a box until a falconer arrived so that it did not try to fly again and reinjure itself, but building-services workers were initially leery. ''He's got some sharp talons,'' a supervisor said. ''I'm not going to put my guys at risk.''

The Metropolitan Opera will now be more wheelchair accessible. The opera company on Thursday settled a civil rights lawsuit in Manhattan federal court that had been brought against the Met for failure to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act. The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York announced that it had filed, and simultaneously settled, the lawsuit against the Met. Under the settlement, in the form of a consent decree, the Met has agreed to install additional wheelchair seating, raised letter or Braille signs and accessible drinking fountains, renovate its restrooms and concession stands and eliminate barriers to accessibility in its elevators.

Verge, the folks who organize satellite fairs for emerging artists in places like Miami Beach, are starting what they say is the first-ever Brooklyn art fair. Called Art Brooklyn, it will be timed to coincide with the Armory Show and will take place in multiple locations throughout the DUMBO neighborhood March 3-6. The aim of the fair is to promote Brooklyn as a cultural hub that will attract artists and collectors from around the world. As a way of luring young artists and galleries, prices for space at the fair are particularly cheap. A 200-square-foot exhibition space, for example, will only cost $1,950, and artists' project spaces are inexpensive too, costing those who are accepted a fee of $500 for 100 square feet of space at 111 Front Street. There will also be a juried exhibition, and there is an open call for artists practicing in every medium. (And Verge is not limiting it to just Brooklyn artists.) Finalists selected from a panel of arts professionals will be given space to show one work from their application at a special section of the fair.

SPLITTING UP The Marathon Oil Corporation, led by Clarence P. Cazalot Jr., left, the president and chief executive, announced plans on Thursday to spin off its downstream business, creating two independent companies. The first, which will keep the Marathon Oil Corporation name, will focus on exploration and production, while the second, the Marathon Petroleum Corporation, will deal with refining, marketing and pipeline transportation. When the deal is complete, Marathon Petroleum will be the fifth-largest refiner in the United States.

O'BRIEN--Thomas E.,of Fort Pierce, Florida, formerly of Larchmont, died January 9th after a long illness. The only child of the late Mary and Peter O'Brien of Mahanoy City, Pennsylvania, Tom was born March 21, 1927 in Ashland, Pennsylvania. He was a graduate of the US Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, NY (class of 1944 - the last of the wartime cadets), Georgetown University Schools of Foreign Service and Law, and was a Commander in the US Naval Reserve Retired, having served in the Korean conflict. Tom had been an attorney in private practice in Manhattan, New Rochelle, Larchmont, Mamaroneck and Queens. Among his favorite work was serving as the attorney for two USMMA-sponsored 12-Metre America's Cup Syndicates - Courageous and America II. Tom is survived by his daughters, Margaret Attwood O'Brien of Salisbury, CT and Catherine O'Brien Yaffa, her husband Richard and their two children Jessica Gould Yaffa and Douglas Charles Yaffa of Harrison, NY and by his former wife Patricia Gould O'Brien (Patty) of Larchmont, NY. Burial at sea in Florida was private. Memorial Service 11am Saturday January 22 at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont NY.

9 P.M. (VH1) 16TH ANNUAL CRITICS' CHOICE MOVIE AWARDS The Broadcast Film Critics Association will bestow its honors at this ceremony broadcast live from the Hollywood Palladium. The show will feature appearances by Jon Hamm, Julianne Moore, Josh Brolin, Jesse Eisenberg, Sofía Vergara, Kevin Spacey, Emma Stone and former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California. Maroon 5 is the house band. Emily Blunt and Jimmy Kimmel will present Matt Damon (above) with the fourth Joel Siegel Award, which is named for the longtime ''Good Morning America'' film critic who died in 2007. Quentin Tarantino will receive the inaugural Critics' Choice Music+Film Award, presented by Tim Roth and created to recognize a filmmaker who heightens storytelling through the effective use of music. The show will also offer a preview of ''Single Ladies,'' a comedic drama starring Stacey Dash, LisaRaye McCoy and Charity Shea that explores what women want in a relationship. Tim Kash and La La Vazquez will report from the red carpet starting at 8 p.m. on VH1 and MTV. 8 P.M. (CBS) MEDIUM A desperate man seeks the help of Allison (Patricia Arquette) in finding his wife. Meanwhile she and Joe (Jake Weber) become concerned when Marie (Miranda Carabello) is overcome with anxiety during a spelling test. Miguel Sandoval, who plays District Attorney Devalos, directed the episode. In ''CSI: NY'' at 9, Mac (Gary Sinise) butts heads with the chief of Barcelona's crime lab after a Spanish club promoter is found dead.

Martin Luther King's Birthday (Sunday and Monday) This year, the 25th in which the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been commemorated as a federal holiday, New Yorkers can participate in a variety of activities to celebrate his life and civic involvement -- like his March 1968 visit, above, to Corona, Queens, where he met with clergy members and residents. A concert and a discussion with Roy Innis, national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, and others will take place on Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Sponsored by the radio station WNYC, it is free, but reservations are required: rsvp@wnyc.org. Also in Brooklyn, a free tribute with commentary by the writer Walter Mosley; performances by the a cappella group the Persuasions and others; and a film screening is planned on Monday at 10:30 a.m. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene; (718) 636-4100, bam.org. ''Celebrate the Dream,'' another free event sponsored annually by the JCC in Manhattan, will feature music, dance and spoken word on Monday at 6:30 p.m. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street; (646) 505-5708, jccmanhattan.org. And for those who want to follow the example of Dr. King, who would have turned 82 on Saturday, by serving the needs of others, suggested volunteer activities and locations are available at the Web site mlkday.gov. (Anne Mancuso)

An obituary last Friday about the Brooklyn federal judge David G. Trager referred incorrectly to his history as a mayoral adviser on judicial appointments. He was chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Judicial Appointments from 1982 to 1989, under Edward I. Koch. He did not serve on a similar panel under Mayor David N. Dinkins.

My Sunday column is about China's education system -- and it's a challenging topic. You see, Americans (me included) tend to be quite admiring, and Shanghai's success in the PISA tests would seem to ratify that. But the Chinese education system does have one important group of detractors: the Chinese themselves. As I noted in the column, so many Chinese whom I respect are deeply critical of their school system as too regimented and stifling, even though they do acknowledge that the Confucian reverence for education is deeply embedded and very positive.

While we're looking at Reagan-era data, a thought for those who believe that the strength of a currency is a measure of the strength of a nation's economy: did the U.S. economy surge during Reagan's first term, then decline in his second?

From my point of view, the current slump is just about what we should have expected given that we had a nasty financial crisis and continue to have a lot of over-leveraged players in the system. Ken Rogoff once said that the United States is having a "garden-variety severe financial crisis" -- indeed, anyone who read Reinhart and Rogoff on the aftermath of crises more or less expected a prolonged period of weak employment. And I've been warning about a protracted liquidity trap, in which even a zero interest rate policy (ZIRP) isn't enough to raise demand sufficiently, for more than a decade.

Joseph Gagnon is worried. Mr. Gagnon, a former Federal Reserve economist now at the Peterson Institute, contends in a new paper that the world's financial imbalances -- such as China's trade surplus and the United States' trade deficit -- will probably return to record levels in coming years. He argues that the imbalances have narrowed recently only because of the recession (which, for example, has reduced American demand for Chinese exports).

Carmelo Anthony, whom the Knicks are considering acquiring in a trade, is sometimes thought of as a selfish player. Indeed, he is the center of the Denver Nuggets' offense: when he is on the court for them, about 30 percent of their possessions end in Anthony shooting, going to the foul line, or committing a turnover. Nor is Anthony much of a passer: over his career, he's accumulated 3.1 assists per 36 minutes played, considerably less than that of other high-volume scorers like Kobe Bryant (4.6 assists per 36 minutes) or LeBron James (6.2).

Eva Gabrielsson, the longtime partner of the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, says in a new memoir that she wants to secure the rights to complete Mr. Larsson's fourth novel in the ''Millennium'' series, which he was writing when he died suddenly in 2004. According to Agence France-Presse, which obtained a copy of the memoir, scheduled for publication in France, Norway and Sweden next week, Ms. Gabrielsson says that she and Mr. Larsson ''often wrote together.'' ''It is not my intention to recount here the plot of the fourth volume,'' she writes in the memoir. ''On the other hand, I want to say that Lisbeth little by little frees herself from her ghosts and her enemies.''

With its cascading delays and cast injuries, the troubled birth of ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' on Broadway has attracted a great deal of attention. Thus inspired, City Room paged through yellowed clippings to bring you some other notable theatrical misfires through Broadway history. Model T! (1914) Plagued by repeated Equity work stoppages - something producer Henry Ford never encountered back in Detroit - the musical drama about the creation of the nation's first assembly-line automobile was delayed in previews first when the stage collapsed under the weight of an entire factory floor and again when one car rolled past its wheel chucks in the slanted orchestra pit, crippling a stagehand. On opening night, the synchronized starting of 300 two-stroke engines unleashed a cloud of smoke that hospitalized half the audience. Ford, cursing New York theatergoers as a bunch of ''sissy Communards,'' caravaned the show back to Detroit, where it enjoyed a 90-year run.

CARPENTER--Edward N. (Tim), of Lawrence, New York, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 12th, at the age of 91. Tim graduated from The Buckley School, Brooks School and Yale University in 1942. He married Kitty Eaton and served in the Pacific as a U.S. Marine in World War II, including the battle of Iwo Jima. After the war he returned to lead the brokerage firm of Jessup and Lamont. In 1960 he retired from the world of finance to work full time as a playwright and lyricist. His wife, Kitty, died in 1971 after 29 years of marriage. In 1973 he married Margaret Owen Van Rensselaer. He is survived by his beloved wife Margaret and his devoted children Katherine Carpenter McCallum, Carolyn Carpenter Wright, Jake Burton Carpenter, Richard Owen Carpenter, Stephen Owen Carpenter, Posie Owen Carpenter and Margaret Carpenter Jones. His son, George Whitney Carpenter, USMC, was killed in Vietnam in 1967. Tim is also survived by twenty grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His family, friends and community will never forget his extraordinary principles, kindness and strength as a leader. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity St. John's Church in Hewlett, Long Island on Saturday, January 15th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the George W. Carpenter Scholarship Fund at the Brooks School, North Andover, MA 01845, or to St. John's Episcopal Hospital, 327 Beach 19th Street, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

Imagine that your employer sent you a letter just before Christmas informing you that it failed to withhold the proper amount of income to cover your 2010 tax bill, and would begin deducting that extra amount from your paycheck right after New Year's. That's what happened to 61 employees with same-sex partners at Yale University, in New Haven, Conn., which made an inadvertent payroll error that will mean thousands of dollars in extra taxes withdrawn from paychecks of many of these workers this year.

The Academy award-winning actress Sissy Spacek plans to tell the stories of her life in a new memoir, scheduled for publication in 2012. The tentatively titled ''Barefoot Stories,'' to be published by Hyperion, is a string of tales about Ms. Spacek's childhood in the South and her rise to fame as the star of films including ''Coal Miner's Daughter'' and ''Carrie.'' Ms. Spacek, who grew up in Texas and currently lives in rural Virginia, said in a statement: ''I'm thrilled to be writing this book. I just wish I had studied harder in English class.''

LOS ANGELES- Selling tickets to the afterparties is nothing. In a suit filed in Superior court in Los Angeles on Thursday, a former publicist for the Golden Globes alleges that the organization's members engaged in payola, accepting money and gifts from studios in exchange for nominating their films; sold red carpet space and media access at a profit; and received payment from studios to lobby their fellow Hollywood Foreign Press voters towards (or against) movies. The publicist, Michael Russell, who had worked with the association for 17 years, asked for $2 million in damages and lost wages, reported TheWrap.com. ''These actions perpetrate a fraud on the public, to which HFPA holds itself out as a charitable organization dedicated to recognizing excellence in film,'' the lawsuit read, according to the blog. The organization - whose president, Philip Berk, was also named in the suit, did not respond to a request for comment from The Wrap. As a publicist, Mr. Russell's job ''involved defending the HFPA from the very claims he now cites in his own lawsuit,'' Brent Lang writes in the blog. ''Many investigative stories over the years have singled out the organization for practices that might call into question its non-profit status; the organization has responded over the years by tightening its rules, but has not responded to criticisms that the organization is a closely-held clique that is almost impossible to join.''

GOLDSTEIN--Maynard, 2 December 1913-12 January 2011. On October 16, 2010, Maynard Goldstein--the last surviving veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade who fought at Jarama--spoke at a benefit event for the Archives of the Vets. He spoke passionately, bringing to life the streets of New York in the 1930's, the streets out of which he came and out of which came the seven other New Yorkers who crossed the Pyrenees with him, putting their lives on the line as they and three thousand other Americans tried to stop the spread of fascism. He spoke without hesitation. He spoke about the continued need to confront the forces of reaction. He spoke without notes. And he held the audience spellbound. Some one and one half months later he celebrated his 97th birthday. Happily? Not quite. Sadly? Not really. But he wasn't pleased with his increasing frailty and he missed Kate, his wife of sixty-eight years, no less an activist than he, who had died three years earlier. Having loving and appreciating friends and family did little to make up for her loss. And so did he go into and through his tenth decade, with all the losses inseparable from a long life, but pleased that his activism didn't stop with Spain. After all, his was the only unionized advertising agency in the City, something he insisted upon, something he brought to pass. His mind never faltered. No surprise then that he played bridge up to the last week of his life. A gathering to memorialize this most remarkable man will be held at his apartment in Manhattan, 300 East 74th Street, Apt. 15F on the 23rd of January, 2011. Festivities will begin at 1:00pm.

For its Lincoln Center Festival residency, scheduled to take place this summer at the Park Avenue Armory, the Royal Shakespeare Company has decided to swap out that tempestuous couple Antony and Cleopatra for one of the Egyptian queen's other lovers. The company's artistic director, Michael Boyd, said that a well-received production of ''Julius Caesar'' directed by Lucy Bailey would replace Mr. Boyd's own production of ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' which had been in the lineup. He said Ms. Bailey's ''Caesar,'' which opened in London this week, ''has proved itself a great success and a landmark production of this play.''

Johnson and Johnson announced late Friday afternoon that it was recalling about 43 million packages of Tylenol, Benadryl, Sudafed and Sinutab products from wholesalers because of past manufacturing practices like insufficient equipment cleaning systems. McNeil Consumer Healthcare, the consumer products unit of the company, also was recalling about 4 million packages of Rolaids Multi-Symptom Berry tablets because of incomplete labels.

It was almost exactly 16 years ago that I made my first visit to La MaMa in a professional capacity, as a new theater critic for The New York Times. I'd been there before as a civilian, usually under the influence. (I believe it was where I first saw a foghorn-throated drag queen named Harvey Fierstein.) But even then La MaMa had for me the whiff of another time, the patchouli scent of the 1960s, when downtown theater was longhaired, renegade and rude. I wasn't around for that heady heyday of La MaMa, the willful, playful brainchild of Ellen Stewart, who died on Thursday. Yet what I saw in the East Village theater that January night in 1994 turned out to be not only absolutely of the moment but also of the future. It was a rough-hewn, rowdy, dirty little play called ''Stitches,'' put on by a brother-and-sister team that presumptuously called itself the Talent Family. Their real names? David and Amy Sedaris.

DOCTOROW--Donald, of New Rochelle, NY, died on January 13 at age 88. A trade magazine editor and publisher, he was a graduate of Townsend Harris High school and the City College of New York. He was a veteran of World War II, having served with the US Air Force as a radio operator making reconnaissance flights over the Pacific in search of German U-boats. He was the husband of the late Elly Doctorow, the first woman to be elected to the New Rochelle City Council. He was a board member of the New Rochelle Opera Company, and Temple Adas Israel in Sag Harbor, NY. He is survived by his sons, Jeffrey, David, and Jonathan, his daughters-in-law Tracy, Crystal and Lisa, his grandchildren Siena, Sarah and Louis, and his brother Edgar, all of whom mourn his passing.

The Mets are close to signing outfielder Willie Harris to a minor league deal, which means that as long as he stays in their organization, he cannot torment them with more acrobatic, game-saving catches. Harris, a 31-year-old left-handed hitter who spent the last three seasons with the Washington Nationals, was expected to sign a deal in the next few days. He has caused the Mets much anguish in recent years, making no fewer than three terrific catches late in games, two in 2008 and one last year, to rob the Mets of potential victories.

ZIFF--Margaret Durham Ziff, died on January 13, 2011 at the age of 73. She is survived by her husband Howard Ziff, daughter Sarah Durham, step-daughters Debby Ziff Cook and Amy Ziff, her brother Tony Compton, and six grandchildren. Her radiance, warmth, wit and wisdom will be missed terribly. Known to her friends as Magi, she was a pioneering female advertising executive who worked at agencies such as Tinker, Gray, Della Famina, and others during Madison Avenue's heyday. In 1996, she retired to New Braintree, MA where she devoted her energy to local politics and served for twelve years as a member of the town's select board. She proudly served as a board member for the East Quabbin Land Trust for many years. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held in her honor at the New Braintree Congregational Church in New Braintree, MA town church at 2pm on January 30. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in her memory be made to the East Quabbin Land Trust at www.eqlt.org.

''Memphis,'' the 2010 Tony Award winner for best musical, will be filmed next week in high definition and then released in movie theaters starting in the spring, press representatives for the show said on Thursday. The movie endeavor, rare for a Broadway production, is being timed to help draw attention to a coming national tour of the show, as well as to the run that is now in its second year in New York. Broadway Worldwide, a production company that has made similar live-in-performance movies of ''Smokey Joe's Cafe'' and other shows, will use multiple high definition cameras and 96 tracks of sound recording at the Jan. 18-21 performances to film the musical. The edited result will be show in theaters.

B. H. Friedman, a real estate executive who gave up his business career to write well-received novels and art criticism and whose books include an early biography of Jackson Pollock, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 84. The cause was complications of pneumonia, said his daughter, Daisy Friedman.

Bradley Manning, the soldier accused of providing classified material to WikiLeaks, misstated the amount of money donated by WikiLeaks to Private Manning's legal defense fund. It has donated $15,100, not more than $100,000. The article also misstated the association that David M. House, a friend who has visited Private Manning, has with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is a researcher there, not a graduate student.

COLLIER--Gilman, 81, noted composer, pianist, conductor and teacher, died on December 27, 2010 after a long illness. He was a resident of Oakhurst, NJ, since 1957. He was predeceased by his parents, Milton and Sadie Collier, and his sister, Audrey Eiber, all of New York City. Surviving are his wife of 19 years, Gizela Collier, and a niece and nephew: Shelley and Selwyn Eiber, respectively. Gilman Collier, born in New York City, was not only a great musician and composer; he was also a great humanitarian. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in his name may be made to the Monmouth Conservatory of Music, 50 White Street, Red Bank, NJ 07701 or to the Jewish Heritage Museum of Monmouth County, PO Box 7078, Freehold, NJ 07728.

Ravens at SteelersSaturday, 4:30 p.m.Line: Steelers by 3 Fans of Ravens-Steelers games also like scratchy old blues 78s, weather-beaten barns and gnarled produce from roadside fruit stands. Steelers-Ravens games hark back to the days when defense dominated the N.F.L., every final score was 13-10, and games were usually decided by a last-minute strip-sack or a daring long pass from a crumpled pocket. When these teams meet, drives are rare, sacks are common and punters get as much screen time as ''American Idol'' finalists. These are games for traditionalists, but they are also always close enough to entertain everyone: the last six regular-season games have been decided by a total of 19 points.

ADAMS--Ellen Noonan, of Locust, NJ age 87, born in New York City, NY, the oldest of three children of William J Noonan and Margaret Hartshorne Noonan, died peacefully at home with her family on January 11, 2011. She attended Brearly School in New York City, Garrison Forest School in Baltimore, MD and Smith College, Northampton, MA. A member of the Rumson Country Club and Seabright Beach Club, Ellen's family the Hartshornes have been active members of the Rumson community for many generations. Ellen was a tremendous champion of the mission of VNACJ Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey. In particular she advocated for mothers and children care. She served as a Board member from 1958 to Present. Ellen was Chairman of the organization 1974-1977. She is remembered with great affection for her hands on volunteer work for numerous community services. She was wife of 63 years to the late John Adams and is survived by their two daughters Ann Adams Royal of Locust, NJ and Mary Minturn Adams of New York; and two grandchildren William Christopher Royal and Elizabeth Ann Royal. A memorial service will be held at the All Saints Memorial Episcopal Church on January 23rd at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to All Saint's Memorial Episcopal Church, PO Box 326, Navesink, NJ 07752 or to the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey with note: in honor of the Ellen N Adams Health Center. A memorial service will be held for both Jack and Ellen in late Spring. Posten's Funeral Home, Atlantic Highlands, 732-291-0010 is in charge of services.

9 P.M. (Starz) AN EDUCATION (2009) Carey Mulligan (above, with Alfred Molina) stars as Jenny, an Oxford-bound 16-year-old schoolgirl suffering from ennui in the London suburb of Twickenham in 1961. Peter Sarsgaard is David, the older man who introduces her to a world of art auctions and Champagne while appealing to the pretensions of her proper parents (Cara Seymour and Mr. Molina). But soon it's apparent that David and his fabulous life aren't quite what they seem, though that doesn't stop Jenny from playing along with the charade. ''It's not that she's out of control -- quite the contrary,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film from Lone Scherfig, written by Nick Hornby and based on a memoir by Lynn Barber. ''She is deliberately and systematically, with what she imagines to be full knowledge of the consequences, seeking out what the vestigial Victorianism of her era would see as her ruin.'' He added, ''The filmmakers themselves seem too intoxicated by the mystique of the period to take full account of the sad, bleak aspects of the story they have to tell.'' Still, in the end, the film is ''a pleasure -- which I don't mean entirely as a compliment.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on the Rev. Robert Graetz, a white Lutheran pastor who worked closely with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. during the 1955 bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., that galvanized the civil rights movement and who continues to work for reconciliation. Fred de Sam Lazaro reports on the vote in a referendum on southern Sudan's independence. And a profile pays tribute to Debbie Friedman, a songwriter and singer of Jewish music, who died on Sunday.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.- The Golden Globes has weathered its share of scandals and ridicule, from bribery charges to the suggestion that "The Tourist" is a comedy. (The show's host, Ricky Gervais, not to mention some of the honored, didn't shy away from poking fun.) And the Hollywood Foreign Press Association is not always a great predictor of future statuettes for the hopefuls that populate the accolades circuit. (See: "Avatar" last year.) But this year, the winners hewed closely to the conventional wisdom of awards-watchers, honoring the same performers, writers and directors who have been marching up red carpets and fine-tuning their thank-you speeches for weeks. ("I'm trying to mix it up," Lee Unkrich, the director of "Toy Story 3," said.)

Almost 20 years ago now, in western Ecuador, I traveled with a team of extraordinary biologists studying a remnant of forest as it was being hacked down around us. Al Gentry, a gangling figure in a grimy T-shirt and jeans frayed from chronic tree climbing, was a botanist whose strategy toward all hazards was to pretend that they didn't exist. At one point, a tree came crashing down beside him after he lost his footing on a slope. Still on his back, he reached out for an orchid growing on the trunk and said, "Oh, that's Gongora," as casually as if he had just spotted an old friend on a city street.The team's birder, Ted Parker, specialized in identifying bird species by sound alone. He started his work day before dawn, standing in the rain under a faded umbrella, his sneakers sunk to their high-tops in mud, whispering into a microcassette recorder about what he was hearing: "Scarlet-rumped cacique a fasciated antshrike two more pairs of Myrmeciza immaculata counter-singing. Dysithamnus puncticeps chorus, male and female "

LOS ANGELES- The Bagger is in place on the red carpet at the Golden Globes - well, we're sitting on the floor near it, anyway, eating a cheese sandwich we brought from home; don't hate us because we're glamorous - so let's take a moment to acknowledge the films that were overlooked by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. "The Green Hornet" was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with about $34 million in ticket sales -- proof that a studio, in this case Sony Pictures Entertainment, can fix a troubled movie on the fly. After a sneak peak for "The Green Hornet" was greeted with ridicule from fanboys last summer, Sony performed triage. The film, based on the 1930s radio serial and 1960s television show, was re-edited, new scenes were shot and the advertising plan was reworked. The upshot: While sales were on the squishy side for a 3-D release costing at least $110 million, "The Green Hornet" is far from the flop that many expected.

When Edmonton's Linus Omark, in his first N.H.L. game last month, pulled a spin move just after picking up the puck at center ice, skated over the blue line, pump-faked, then slapped the puck past Tampa Bay goalie Dan Ellis, the hockey world went nuts.The Lightning players were furious, criticizing Omark for what they considered a showboat move that disrespected the game. But others said that the Lightning had been merely sore losers and that the shootout - a skills contest tacked onto what was otherwise a tie game - was meant to entertain fans. Omark's move, they argued, was entertaining. And besides, it worked.Since then, more shootout attempts have incorporated spin moves, most right in front of the goalie, and the controversy has not subsided.

The recession was not kind to the yachting industry, as the rich -- and the formerly rich -- sold many of their boats, creating a glut in the market. This is the first year that the London International Boat Show, held this month, featured used boats in addition to new ones. To get people thinking about buying boats, the show sold the idea of what you can do with them. People who can't drop millions on a fully equipped yacht watched demonstrations of a recreational jet pack and of water sports including wake boarding, brush boarding and stand-up paddle boarding.

Carmelo Anthony, whom the Knicks are considering acquiring in a trade, is sometimes thought of as a selfish player. Indeed, he is the center of the Denver Nuggets' offense. When he is on the court for them, about 30 percent of their possessions end in Anthony's shooting, going to the foul line or committing a turnover. And he is not much of a passer: over his career, Anthony has accumulated 3.1 assists per 36 minutes played, considerably less than the average of other high-volume scorers like Kobe Bryant (4.6 assists per 36 minutes) or LeBron James (6.2).
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

REAL ESTATE The Mortgages column on Jan. 2 about ''recasting'' a mortgage, an alternative to refinancing, misstated the amount by which monthly payments would drop, based on how much of the remaining principal on the loan was paid down. If you put in $20,000, the payment would drop by $184 (not $52), to around $2,002 (not $2,135). And putting in $100,000 would save $945 (not $730) a month and bring payments to $1,241 (not $1,457).

ADAMS--Ellen Noonan, of Locust, NJ age 87, born in New York City, NY, the oldest of three children of William J Noonan and Margaret Hartshorne Noonan, died peacefully at home with her family on January 11, 2011. She attended Brearly School in New York City, Garrison Forest School in Baltimore, MD and Smith College, Northampton, MA. A member of the Rumson Country Club and Seabright Beach Club, Ellen's family the Hartshornes have been active members of the Rumson community for many generations. Ellen was a tremendous champion of the mission of VNACJ Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey. In particular she advocated for mothers and children care. She served as a Board member from 1958 to Present. Ellen was Chairman of the organization 1974-1977. She is remembered with great affection for her hands on volunteer work for numerous community services. She was wife of 63 years to the late John Adams and is survived by their two daughters Ann Adams Royal of Locust, NJ and Mary Minturn Adams of New York; and two grandchildren William Christopher Royal and Elizabeth Ann Royal. A memorial service will be held at the All Saints Memorial Episcopal Church on January 23rd at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to All Saint's Memorial Episcopal Church, PO Box 326, Navesink, NJ 07752 or to the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey with note: in honor of the Ellen N Adams Health Center. A memorial service will be held for both Jack and Ellen in late Spring. Posten's Funeral Home, Atlantic Highlands, 732-291-0010 is in charge of services.

It may seem ungrateful of me to lodge this complaint around the time of Martin Luther King's Birthday. We are, after all, in a purported ''postracial'' era. But a cherished annual ritual, finding calendars to organize and inspire me during the coming year, was lost to me this past holiday season, and I can't help wondering if it's because race is passe now, in these tough-but-equal times. I usually buy four calendars for home and one for work, and I always look forward to a visual feast - artwork, landscapes, beautifully printed snippets of wisdom - from which to choose. This year, I made an earlier than usual run on a major bookseller that carries an array of the two trends I favor: calendars informed by the spirituality of the East, and those informed by the artwork and images of people like me, a brown-skinned descendant of Africa. I forfeited the after-Christmas discount, feeling sure I'd find even more bounty.

GOLEMBE--Carter H. Carter H. Golembe died peacefully at his home in Delray Beach, FL on December 18, 2010. He was a renowned speaker, writer, analyst and consultant to the banking industry. For over 30 years, he authored and published "The Golembe Reports," a commentary on banking issues. Born in Liberty, NY in 1924, Mr. Golembe was a veteran of WWII, and was a recipient of the Purple Heart. Following his military service, he earned a doctorate degree in economics from Columbia College and a law degree from George Washington University. Dr. Golembe began his career in 1951 as a financial economist with the FDIC and subsequently was employed by the American Bankers Association. In 1966, he founded a banking research and consulting firm, headquartered in Washington, DC that was nationally known and described by the head of a major banking trade association as the "Mercedes of the industry." Following the sale of Golembe Associates in 1989, he was chairman of the board of The Secura Group in DC until 1994. In 1979, he founded the International Financial Conference (IFC), an educational corporation comprised of mid-size regional banks and other international financial institutions. He served as the executive manager of the IFC for 16 years and the senior advisor to its Board of Directors until 1998. He also served for 10 years as a director of Barnett Banks of Florida. During his lifetime, he was a frequent contributor to professional journals, as well as author of numerous publications, including his co-authorship of "Federal Regulation of Banking." His most recent book, "But I Never Made a Loan," gave his take on the evolution and history of banking systems in the US. He was a true intellectual, yet could cut to the chase of a matter with his wit and insight. Mr. Golembe is survived by his wife, Patricia, his brother John of Schwetzingen, Germany, and sons: Gregory of Reston, VA and Christopher of Pompano Beach, FL; four grandchildren; four great grandchildren. A memorial service is planned in Washington for Spring 2011, followed by interment at Arlington National Cemetery. Those wishing to honor Carter's memory may consider making contributions to the Carter H. Golembe Scholarship Fund, attn: Eleanor Coufos, Columbia College, 622 West 113th St. MC 4530, New York 10025.

THE Turkish jeweler Sevan Bicakci was motivated by both myth and hard reality when making this pair of one-of-a-kind sterling silver, 24-karat gold and diamond earrings. At once a representation of Poseidon's magnificent chariot horses and a tribute to Turkey's Mount Ida, which figures prominently in Greek mythology as the site from which the gods watched the Trojan War, the sparkly steeds are also a protest against modern-day mining on such hallowed ground. ''I know this sounds odd coming from a jeweler,'' Mr. Bicakci said, ''but the natural treasure of Ida is much more valuable than gold.'' The earrings are $16,860 at Barneys New York. REGAN--John M.,Jr., former Chairman and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc. and a highly respected business leader died Monday. He was 89 and a resident of Ocean Ridge, FL. Jack Regan, as he was known, began his career in New York in the Casualty department at Marsh & McLennan in 1946. He was made assistant manager of the Boston office in 1954 and manager of the New York office thirteen years later. A series of promotions led to his appointment as President of Marsh and McLennan Companies in 1972 and CEO the following year. During his thirteen-year tenure as CEO, the company diversified its businesses significantly and developed a strategy to expand its operations globally, resulting in an eightfold growth in the company's revenue and market capitalization. The international expansion advanced markedly with Marsh & McLennan's successful 1980 merger with C. T. Bowring, a Lloyd's-based UK brokerage house. Mr. Regan lived in New York for most of his career where he was active in professional, business and charitable organizations including the Inner-city Scholarship Fund and the Cardinal's Committee on Education for the Archdiocese of New York. He retired in June 1986. Mr. Regan graduated five months early from Yale University in January 1943 so that he could join the war effort. He served as a first lieutenant and platoon commander with the U.S. 22nd Infantry of the 4th Army Division during the Normandy campaign and was seriously wounded in action during the June 22, 1944 attack on Cherbourg. After what he referred to as "gold-bricking" in an English hospital, he returned to duty in a variety of capacities throughout Europe. He earned a Bronze Star and the Purple Heart and was discharged in 1946. Born in Minneapolis, MN on June 7, 1921, John M. Regan, Jr. was the eldest of three children of John M. and Philomena M. Regan. He attended St. Thomas Military Academy and graduated from Yale with honors. He also attended the Advanced Management Program at Harvard University's School of Business Administration. Mr. Regan served as a Trustee of Notre Dame University, Connecticut College, St. Vincent's Hospital and New York Law School and as a Director of Morgan Stanley Group, ACF Industries and the A. C. Nielson Company. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Ocean Club of Florida, the Gulf Stream Bath and Tennis Club, the Misquamicut Club and the Watch Hill Yacht Club where he served as Commodore for four years. In addition to his wife of sixty one years, Prudence S. Regan, he is survived by two brothers Robert M. Regan of Minneapolis, MN and Richard F. Regan of Honolulu, Hawaii, six children including John M. Regan III of Watch Hill, RI, Deborah R. Edwards of Hartsdale, NY, Peter M. Regan of New Berlin, NY, R. Christopher Regan of Mendham, NJ, Prudence R. Hallarman of Lincolnshire, IL and William M. Regan of New York, NY and nine grandchildren. A private funeral will be held this week. A memorial service is planned for June. The family requests any donations be made to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 1st Avenue #
