MARX--Helen Zanetti, known to her friends as Noonie, died on January 12, 2011, at home of an ovarian type cancer. She was 72. She confronted her illness with her usual dignity, and grace, and with a strength that may have surprised even her. She never showed a trace of self-pity. Her legendary sense of humor was intact to the end. The last few weeks of her life were peaceful. Her children were with her constantly. It was a time of coming together, a time of understanding, a time of love. Helen Zanetti was born in Bucharest, Romania, on Christmas Eve, 1938, to George (Pearson) and Enrique Carlos Zanetti. Her father, Enrique, was later the Chase Bank representative in Buenos Aires, where the family spent eight years and where Noonie attended the French Lycee. In 1956, she graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, and from Smith College in 1960. An only child, she made many close friends at school and kept them her entire life. She continued to make friends into her seventies, a rare feat. In the 1970s, she co-owned and ran a specialty retail store on Madison Ave., Thaxton & Co., and in 1987 started The Madison Avenue Fund for Children, a resounding charitable success to this day. Noonie was also deeply involved in and on the Board of The Big Sisters, a Catholic charity which started by mentoring girls who came through the New York Children's Court. In 1996 Noonie began a successful publishing career with her imprint, Helen Marx Books, which, in association with Turtle Point Press and Books and Co. made its mark with unusual, original, and distinguished titles, a few of them best-sellers in the small press category. In 2005, Noonie won the prestigious French- American Foundation Translation Prize for the novel Silbermann by Jacques de Lacretelle, wining over an important translation of Marcel Proust's The Guermantes Way. This year, her translation of The Princess, the King, and the Anarchist, which she also published and which has already sold out its run, has again been submitted for the Translation Prize. She was one of the original founders in 1971 of the Proust Group, a reading group now in its fortieth year. She acquired over many years an outstanding collection of American art. She loved music, was an inveterate concert and opera goer, and joined the Board of The Metropolitan Opera Guild in 1990, serving as Vice President from 1994-1996. Her paradise was Paris, a city she had come to love from childhood visits with her grandmother. During her last twenty years she made sure she spent part of each year in Paris, where she did much of her translating and, as usual, added a small army of new friends. A French friend said that Noonie was the only American she had ever known who spoke like a native French-person. She was proud of being able to read her favorite author, Proust, in French. She was a long-time member (57 years) of The Colony Club. She had beauty, a sharp intelligence, and worldliness, but it was her amazing capacity for friendship for which she will be remembered and missed. A truly kind and loving person has gone from our lives, and we will never have another friend like her. She is survived by her children Pearson, Lindsay, Louis, and Geoffrey Marx, her son-in-law Stephen Mark, and her grandsons Cal and Teddy Mailer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Children's Aid Society, 105 E. 22nd St., NY, NY 10010, or The Humane Society, 306 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th St. at Fifth Ave., NY, NY 10128, on Thursday, January 27 at 4pm.

MAYBE people are getting back to their pre-Christmas fighting weight, or they're just peevish from too many pre-fall collections (are they over yet?), but everyone seems angry about something in fashion. I love it. There's actually a lot to debate -- though from the tone of some of the remarks, I hear what sounds like the us-and-them rhetoric of liberal and conservative pundits. Will I play Maddow to your Beck? Let's start with Bridget Foley's thoughtful front-page piece in Women's Wear Daily on Wednesday about the implications of fashion's populist swing toward celebrity, the Internet and mass-oriented deals with stores like H & M. Essentially, Ms. Foley argues that fashion has lost its mojo because high-end designers and companies -- which, by the way, she doesn't identify or properly hold accountable -- have fractured their own elite position. I would argue that some degree of philistinism has existed in fashion since designers and their clever business partners realized in the 1980s that they could generate quick cash by licensing their names. (Valentino toilet-seat covers, anyone?) P.R. people's role is to make you think everything is a Roman holiday.

When Mitch Kupchak became the general manager of the Los Angeles Lakers in 2000, Jerry West left him a decent parting gift: a roster that largely revolved around Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal and had won the first of three consecutive championships. Last off-season, Kupchak, 56, tweaked his roster to foster competitiveness and deter complacency. Bryant, Pau Gasol and Andrew Bynum, the core of the two-time defending champions, are signed to long-term contracts.

The National Park Service is waiving fees this weekend for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. federal holiday and on several other dates this year, the Interior Secretary, Ken Salazar, recently announced. Several of the National Park Service's sites and trails are already free (including the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site in Georgia and the Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail in Alabama), but visitors to Yosemite will save $20 per car and those who want to see the Grand Canyon will save $25 per vehicle. Several parks will also host volunteer projects for the federal holiday, a day of service.

CHANG--Victoria Sun. We mourn the loss of this elegant lady whose kindness, warmth and love radiated each day. Deepest sympathies to Jim, Melissa and Allison and their families, mother Mey En Sun, Betty and Pershing. With love, Jean, Stanley, Jonathan and Gregory Chang
LONNER--Carole Caplan. Our heartfelt condolences to the Lonner, Och, Bernstein and Prince families on their loss. Carole was an inspiration to all who knew her. With Love, The Stoppelmann Family

SCHEINFELD--Shirley. The Board of Governors and the Members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member Shirley Scheinfeld. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her husband Alex and family. Jack Irushalmi, President

THE Brooklyn duo Blondes makes shimmering electronic music, but the members, Zach Steinman and Sam Haar, used to be more interested in guitars than synths. ''In college we were into Gang of Four and Television,'' Mr. Steinman said, ''but our tastes evolved through '70s disco and Kraut, and eventually '80s electronic.'' That trajectory is evident in the sparse vocal samples and economical beats on their well-received debut EP, ''Touched.'' Their creative adventurousness also spilled over into a recent photo shoot for The Moment, for which Mr. Steinman and Mr. Haar were fittingly dressed in clothes by White Mountaineering, an emerging Japanese label that mixes American and avant-garde references with the same abandon as Blondes' experimenting on synths. ''I've definitely never worn a kilt before,'' Mr. Haar said of his outfit. Luckily, in music as in life, both men are not afraid of change. ALEXANDER FRANK From left: Zach Steinman and Sam Haar. Clothes by White Mountaineering, sold at Odin and select Barneys New York locations; barneys.com. Red Wing boots. Fashion editor:

GOLDSTEIN--Maynard, 2 December 1913-12 January 2011. On October 16, 2010, Maynard Goldstein--the last surviving veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade who fought at Jarama--spoke at a benefit event for the Archives of the Vets. He spoke passionately, bringing to life the streets of New York in the 1930's, the streets out of which he came and out of which came the seven other New Yorkers who crossed the Pyrenees with him, putting their lives on the line as they and three thousand other Americans tried to stop the spread of fascism. He spoke without hesitation. He spoke about the continued need to confront the forces of reaction. He spoke without notes. And he held the audience spellbound. Some one and one half months later he celebrated his 97th birthday. Happily? Not quite. Sadly? Not really. But he wasn't pleased with his increasing frailty and he missed Kate, his wife of sixty-eight years, no less an activist than he, who had died three years earlier. Having loving and appreciating friends and family did little to make up for her loss. And so did he go into and through his tenth decade, with all the losses inseparable from a long life, but pleased that his activism didn't stop with Spain. After all, his was the only unionized advertising agency in the City, something he insisted upon, something he brought to pass. His mind never faltered. No surprise then that he played bridge up to the last week of his life. A gathering to memorialize this most remarkable man will be held at his apartment in Manhattan, 300 East 74th Street, Apt. 15F on the 23rd of January, 2011. Festivities will begin at 1:00pm.

MARTIN COHEN went from being a star-struck commoner in the court of the Mambo Kings to the chronicler of legends. You may have seen his name on any number of bongos, congas, cowbells and timbales manufactured by Latin Percussion, the company he started in the early 1960s with little more than a fanatic's devotion to the music. Yet founding an internationally recognized brand favored by the world's leading drummers is but a sideline. Mr. Cohen's true passion is photography. From his teenage years through decades as drum maker to the stars, Mr. Cohen, 71, has taken hundreds of thousands of photographs documenting the world of jazz and Latin music.

An article last Sunday about the new ''Green Hornet'' movie misspelled the surname of the screenwriter who wrote the film ''Robocop'' and who in the 1990s helped the director of ''Hornet,'' Michel Gondry, reimagine the character and his setting. He is Edward Neumeier, not Neumeiers.

WINGATE--David Aaron David Aaron Wingate, born Aaron David Winograd on January 6, 1921, died on January 9 following a long illness, shortly after his 90th birthday. He was the beloved husband of Shoshanna; elder brother of the Honorable Eliyahu Winograd of Tel Aviv; father of Batsheva Wingate Ostrow and Ealan Wingate; father-in-law of Ronald Ostrow and Melinda Wingate; grandfather of Amanda Wingate and of Alonna Ostrow Ostad, Sharone Ostrow Gilbert, and Jonathan Ostrow, and their spouses Michael Ostad, Richard Gilbert, and Rose Ostrow; great-grandfather of Hannah, Alexandra, and Ari Ostad; Benjamin, Emma, Zachary, and Sam Gilbert; and Julian Ostrow. He also leaves a loving extended family in Israel, where he was born. He lived in Old Westbury, NY and Palm Beach, Florida. He was a strong and devoted head of his family, who adored and revered him and will remember him forever. From a young age, he was driven by curiosity. Aaron/ David became a successful business man first in Palestine, then in the newly formed Israel, where he was a fifth generation Israeli, and then in his adopted New York community. He was the CEO of Hi-Shear Industries (an NYSE-registered institution). He and his wife supported many Jewish institutions, including the Jewish Theological Seminary, North Shore Long Island Jewish Hospital, the UJA, the Solomon Schechter School, and Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, where they endowed the David and Shoshanna Wingate Center. He was a powerful presence in many lives. His own life was shaped by the love of an extraordinary and wonderful woman, Shoshanna. All who knew them admired the deep love they held for each other and their amazing partnership throughout their sixty-seven years together. David and his adored Shoshanna forged a life built on hard work, sacrifice, commitment to family and a dedication to the welfare of the Jewish Community. They shared a great love of the arts and a circle of devoted friends. He will be remembered always by all those his life touched, and by all those who knew him for his delighted and welcoming smile. May his name be forever a blessing. May his name always be included among the names of the righteous. Services are at 11:30am on Tuesday, January 11 at Temple Beth Sholom, Rosyln Heights, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in David Wingate's honor to a Jewish charity of your choice.

A picture caption on Jan. 2 with a review of ''Alice Neel,'' a biography by Phoebe Hoban, misstated the date of the photograph of Neel. It was made in 1944, not 1940. And the picture credit carried an erroneous copyright notice. The estate of Alice Neel does not hold a copyright on the photograph.

JOBIN--Judith B.,67, of Manhattan and East Hampton, died on January 13, 2011, and is mourned by her husband Daniel Leary, her brother Dennis Jobin and her sister Kathleen Sorenson. She received her B.A. in English from Skidmore (1966) and thereafter had a career as a journalist at T.V. Guide with articles, essays and reviews also appearing in The New York Times, Parents and Conde Nast publications. Her second career began in 1992 when she was 48 with her graduation, Magna Cum Laude, at Fordham University School of Law. At Rogers and Wells and later at Patterson , Belknap her practice focused on intellectual practice and media-related law. Her third career over-lapped the others. It was a decades-long hobby that became a fulfillment: graphic art. It began with summer drawing classes in Sag Harbor that led to advanced courses in life-sketching in South Hampton and scenic expression-sessions with Wolf Khan in New York. There will be a Memorial Service later this year.

COCO CHANEL once dismissed Paco Rabanne as the ''steelworker of fashion'' for his use of metal in his stubbornly futuristic designs. Mr. Rabanne, who is responsible for some acidic put-downs of his own, certainly lived up to the moniker with his ubiquitous chain-mail dresses of the 1960s. Less known, however, was his 69 bag from a collection of that year. Celebrating the designer's enduring vision of fashion, Comme des Garçons has teamed with Paco Rabanne to release nine variations on the bag, including versions in clear acrylic Perspex, pink metallic suede and black rubber. The 69 bags are priced from $965 to $2,200. Available exclusively at Comme des Garçons, 520 West 22nd Street; (212) 604-9200. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

Through the Hawks' first five games in 2011, it seemed the team couldn't lose and that shooting guard Jamal Crawford couldn't miss.Unfortunately, all good things come to an end. Atlanta's five-game winning streak was snapped by the Houston Rockets on Saturday night, and with it went a hot stretch in which Crawford put up 27.4 points a game and a 51.2 field-goal percentage. Known for his inconsistent shooting, Crawford has often been criticized for his risk-taking. Among his lowlights was the 2003-4 season, when he shot 38.6 percent from the field. Unfortunately for the Chicago Bulls, his team at the time, that percentage did not stop him from taking 16.5 shots a game.Since arriving in Atlanta last season, however, he has shown more discipline as a shooter - 44.5 percent for the season.

ESCHEN--Florence, 86, on Tuesday, January 11, 2011, of Arlington, VA. Formerly of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and Brooklyn, NY. Florence is survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Albert and sons Burt (Caryn) of New York and Andrew of Arlington; grandchildren Meryl (Chris) and Lowell. She is also survived by her brother William Askwyth (Phyllis) of Florida.

FIELDS--William F. Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A.M. mourns with profound sorrow the death on February 7, 2011, of Bro. William F. Fields at the age of 93. Bill was raised in St. Johns Lodge No. 6 in Norwalk, CT on June 14, 1947 and Affiliated with Kane Lodge September 9, 1976. He was the recipient of the Dedicated Service Award, served as Secretary of the Lodge and was the Tiler. Bill was exemplary in his support, dedication and love for the Craft and for Kane Lodge and shall be fondly remembered as a true gentleman and friend and will be greatly missed by the brethren of Kane Lodge. Paul D. Reitz, Secretary Paul G. Huck, Master
DUNDES--Lester. His birthday today, still missed by his family.

Jets at PatriotsSunday, 4:30 p.m.Line: Patriots by 81/2 Rex Ryan versus Bill Belichick: the sound of one hand clapping. If the N.F.L. were the Improv Club, Ryan would be the comedian, Belichick the brick wall. Ryan has been selling this week's game as a U.F.C. mano-a-mano grudge match so insistently that he finally goaded Belichick into an almost funny retort. ''I might have a little quickness on him; he's probably got a little more strength and power on me,'' Belichick told ESPN Boston on Monday. When you have three Super Bowl rings, no one cares that you have the comic timing of an automated answering service.
'If we win this game, it will be same old Jets, back in the A.F.C. championship game.' REX RYAN,

An article on Jan. 2 about the first female athlete to endorse a mainstream commercial product overstated the time it took a professional walker named Madame Anderson to walk an estimated 750 miles over 28 days in the 1870s, earning her about $10,000 from the heavily promoted event. It was fewer than 700 hours; it did not take her 750 hours.

Barbara Reich, a professional organizer and the subject of last week's Metropolitan cover article, answered questions from readers on the City Room blog. Almost 300 people wrote in; faced with the daunting task of sifting through the questions, she did what you would expect: she organized them. Here are a few:

SPRINGER--Katherine (Kat), passed away on December 17, 2010 in Carmel, California. She was born to William and Elsie Springer of Champaign-Urbana, Illinois, on August 17, 1943. From 1967 to 1995, Katherine worked for the United Nations Development Program (UNDP). She administered public health programs and was involved with water projects in underdeveloped countries. Katherine is survived by family members and many dear friends. Memorial contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10001, Attention: Beth Golden (specify designated for use in Africa) or to a charity of your choice.

Podcast Scheduled for this week: Excerpts from a Book Review panel discussion with the novelist Jennifer Egan, author of ''A Visit From the Goon Squad,'' and Siddhartha Mukherjee, author of ''The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. ExcerptsSelections from ''Gryphon,'' by Charles Baxter; ''The View From Lazy Point,'' by Carl Safina; and other books.

RICE--James David. James David Rice was born July 8, 1932 in Anderson, South Carolina to the late Professor Henry W. Rice Sr. and Anna Goldsmith-Rice, both teachers. He was the youngest of six siblings - Ruth Rice-Swann, Henry W. Rice II, John S. Rice, Charles W. Rice, and Dillard G. Rice. James received both his elementary and high school education at the Carolina School in Williamston, South Carolina. He earned a Baccalaureate Degree from South Carolina State College in Orangeburg, and a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. James served four years in the Army and received an Honorable Discharge in l962. From 1964 until his retirement in 2000, James Rice worked and rose through the ranks of the Nassau County Commission on Human Rights. He served as the Director of its Job Development Center. He founded the Nassau County Pre-trial Services. He was made Assistant Director of the Commission, and was appointed Executive Director in 1970. As an Administrative Judge, he had the sole responsibility for reviewing and ruling on all discrimination charges brought before him relating to age, race, religion, gender or national origin. When asked what his job entailed, he would simply say, "Law Enforcement". In the year 2000, after 36 years of service, James retired as the Commissioner of Human Rights for Nassau County. During his tenure, he received numerous awards, citations, and honors. James co-established the Nassau County Martin Luther King, Jr. Birthday Celebration and served as its Executive Secretary until 2005. He was a Mason, a member of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., and past president of 100 Black Men of Long Island, Inc. In 1988, James was united in holy matrimony with Cleo Harris Smith. Soon after retiring, they moved to Sun City Hilton Head, South Carolina. James was an avid golfer and billiards player, and the winner of many trophies and awards for his golf acumen. After an extended illness, James David Rice passed away on January 11, 2011 while hospitalized in Charleston, SC. He leaves to cherish his memory his devoted wife, Cleo, his son Kenya Smith, his wife Tanisha, grandson Christian; His brother John S. Rice, Sr., four sisters-in-law; two nephews, eight nieces; eight grand-nieces and a host of other family members and friends. A memorial service will be held in New York in the spring. For information contact: Clarence Little, 100 Black Men of Long Island, Inc. 1-516-538-6318. In lieu of flowers, family and friends are asked to donate to: The Scholarship Fund/in honor of James D. Rice, 100 Black Men of Long Island, Inc., Nine Centre Street, Hempstead, New York 11550, Tel/Fax 1-516-538-6318.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Political Heavy Hitters Take On College Bowls,'' Jan. 10: No matter how many extra games are played, there will always be some subjective criteria for choosing who plays in the playoffs, just as in the college basketball championships.

SAE INTERNATIONAL, the automotive engineering group that set the J1772 standard for electric vehicle charging ports, is working on a revision that could result in two faster charging modes in a single port. The standard would be for 240-volt alternating current chargers and also for high-voltage direct-current units, which could almost fully recharge E.V.'s in about 30 minutes.

WIESEN--Shirley Preston, born in New York City in 1921 to Harry and Rachel Preston passed away on January 14 surrounded by her children. Beloved mother of Maxwell, Robert (Yona), and Susan (James); adored grandmother of Adam (Nicole), Douglas (Julie), Kira, Jonathan, and Eric, and great-grandmother of Gideon, she lived a full life and enjoyed over 50 years of marital bliss with our father Sherman. Shirley was a graduate of Adelphi University, a great fan of William Shakespeare, and later in life, an accomplished bridge player and talented artist (designing original needlepoint canvases). Her children will miss her irreverent sense of humor and wise counsel. Funeral service will be held Monday, January 17 at 10am at Frank E. Campbell at 81st Street. The family will receive friends and relatives on Monday between 4-8pm at Shirley's residence.

THE NEWS The worst flooding in decades inundated immense areas of Queensland in northeast Australia and swamped tens of thousands of homes and businesses in Brisbane, the state's main city, killing at least 15 people. BEHIND THE NEWS The weather pattern known as La Niña drove one downpour after another for weeks into tropical Queensland, which is used to a bit of flooding each year, but nothing like last week's. The waters may take days to recede, leaving residents to ''face a reconstruction task of postwar proportions,'' as the state premier, Anna Bligh, put it.

BIGELOW--Joan Turnburke. Passed away peacefully following an unexpected illness on Sunday, January 2, 2011. Joan was an internationally renowned model for Eileen Ford, married E.R. "Dick" Bigelow of New York in 1962 and took up residence in Denver, Colorado, before returning to her hometown of Clearwater, FL. She leaves behind memories of her grace, elegance, compassion and guidance, accompanied by her special "sparkle". Funeral services were held at Church of the Ascension in Clearwater, FL on Saturday, January 15.

Last week, men once again showed their reluctance to change in matters of dress, many braving the snowstorm in expensive shoes rather than sensible snow boots. This winter, stylish men, left, right and below, seem to be eschewing exotic designer looks, personal expression coming from how familiar pieces are put together. A young man, right, adopted a style that would not have been out of place in the 1950s. Some professionals think this is the direction men's wear is taking.
The Jets' special teams have been among the best in the league this season and played a significant role in their playoff victory over the Colts.

McCLENDON--James Stewart, of New York City and Stonington, CT, died January 7, 2011. He was recently predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Mario McClendon. He is survived by his daughters, Margaret Aspinwall and Janet Vaskas, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to the University of Minnesota Law School through the University of Minnesota Foundation, C-M 3854, P.O. Box 70870, St. Paul, MN 55170-3854.

ZIMMERMAN--Susan J.,on January 9th. Beloved sister of Zelda (Alfred) Goldberg, and the late Robert. Cherished sister-in-law of Ellen Zimmerman, Devoted Aunt and Great Aunt and Dear friend. Memorial service January 22, 12 noon, Stuyvesant Town Oval Lounge. Contributions to MSKCC Breast Cancer Medicine Service, Dr. G. D'Andrea for Research.

CARPENTER--Edward N. (Tim), of Lawrence, New York, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 12th, at the age of 91. Tim graduated from The Buckley School, Brooks School and Yale University in 1942. He married Kitty Eaton and served in the Pacific as a U.S. Marine in World War II, including the battle of Iwo Jima. After the war he returned to lead the brokerage firm of Jessup and Lamont. In 1960 he retired from the world of finance to work full time as a playwright and lyricist. His wife, Kitty, died in 1971 after 29 years of marriage. In 1973 he married Margaret Owen Van Rensselaer. He is survived by his beloved wife Margaret and his devoted children Katherine Carpenter McCallum, Carolyn Carpenter Wright, Jake Burton Carpenter, Richard Owen Carpenter, Stephen Owen Carpenter, Posie Owen Carpenter and Margaret Carpenter Jones. His son, George Whitney Carpenter, USMC, was killed in Vietnam in 1967. Tim is also survived by twenty grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His family, friends and community will never forget his extraordinary principles, kindness and strength as a leader. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity St. John's Church in Hewlett, Long Island on Saturday, January 15th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the George W. Carpenter Scholarship Fund at the Brooks School, North Andover, MA 01845, or to St. John's Episcopal Hospital, 327 Beach 19th Street, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

ROSEN--David, passed away with his family by his side on January 9, 2011. Beloved husband of 58 years to Nettie. Loving father to Cynthia Kaplan (Michael), Patti. Loving grandfather to Jackie Hiatt (Evan), Matthew and great- grandfather to Lexie. He was a WWII Veteran. He will forever be missed.

SEIDEN--Melvin R. The Trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society of New York mourn the passing of beloved Board member and friend Melvin R. Seiden. A Trustee for 36 years, Mel was a champion of underserved children and families. He was a dedicated, caring and committed trustee and one of our most active committee members. A former Chair of the Audit Committee, most recently Mel served on the Pension and Personnel, the Finance and Investment and the Health Services committees of the Board of Trustees. He was a major supporter of our work. Mel's extraordinarily thoughtful and generous support made it possible for us to establish our Obesity Prevention Program. He also supported our Foster Care program, Wagon Road Camp, Chorus program and Alvin Ailey Camp program. Our hearts go out to his wife Janine Luke, also a longtime friend and benefactor to Children's Aid, and the rest of his family. He will be sorely missed at Children's Aid by all who knew him. Mark M. Edmiston, Chairman Richard R. Buery, Jr., President and CEO
Philadelphia fired the defensive coordinator Sean McDermott after it allowed 377 points, the most for the Eagles since 1974. (AP)

MURPHY--Barbara Boyer. June 1, 1929 January 3, 2011 Barbara Boyer Murphy, a resident of Sarasota, FL and Menauhant, MA passed away on January 3, 2011 after a brief illness. She was surrounded by her three children: Samuel W Murphy III of Minneapolis, MN; Rebecca Flynn of Owings Mills, MD and Constance Murphy of Newfields, NH. Barbara's husband of 50 years Samuel W Murphy Jr. predeceased her in 2001. In addition to her three children she leaves behind 5 grandchildren: Andrew Murphy, Ellen Murphy, Matt Perna, Jeffrey Flynn and Cort Flynn. She graduated from Duke University Women's College in 1951 with BA in Sociology where she was a member of student government and the Pi Beta Phi sorority. During the family's time in Madison, New Jersey, Barbara was active in civic and community activities including the town planning board, the Legal Aid Society, Planned Parenthood and as a volunteer at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. On her husband's retirement, when the couple moved to Boca Grande Florida, Barbara was an active member of The Women's Club and St Andrews Episcopal Church. A memorial service is planned for this summer at the family home in Menauhant. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to: Grace Memorial Chapel Fund PO Box 425 c/o Stan Lincoln East Falmouth, MA 02536 Boca Grande Women's Board Scholarship Fund PO Box 65 Boca Grande, FL 33921.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Warriors' Warrior,'' Jan. 9: Dolph Schayes was one of the first big men who was able to play outside the pivot, which changed the game. Among his accomplishments: all-American at New York University, N.B.A. All-Star 12 times and N.B.A. coach of the year in 1966. Schayes was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1974.

BIRD--Caroline (Mahoney), born April 15, 1915 in New York City, died January 11, 2011 in Nashville, Tennessee. She attended Vassar College, earned a B.A. from University of Toledo, and a M.A. from University of Wisconsin. She married Edward A. Menuez in 1934 (divorced in 1945); married J. Thomas Mahoney in 1957 (died 1981). She started her career as a journalist during World War II and continued as a freelance magazine writer thereafter. Her first book, "The Invisible Scar", was published in 1966. Her second book, "Born Female" (1968), established her as one of the "founding mothers" of the feminist movement. It was followed by "The Crowding Syndrome" (1972), "Everything a Woman Needs to Know to Get Paid What She's Worth" (1973, rev. 1982), "The Case Against College" (1975), " Enterprising Women" (1976), What Women Want (1979), The Two-Paycheck Marriage" (1979), The Good Years (1983), Second Careers (1992), and "Lives of Our Own" (1995). She was chief writer for "The Spirit of Houston" (1978). She was a member of the American Society of Journalists and Authors and the American Sociology Association. She is survived by her daughter Carol Menuez Barach, her son, John T. Mahoney, two grandchildren, Andrea Barach Schine and David J. Barach, and four great-grandchildren.

BULLINER--Philip Alan. On Tuesday, January 11, 2011, Philip Alan Bulliner passed away from a massive heart attack suffered on December 4, 2010. He leaves behind his spouse H. Michael Weinert, his sister Ann Evans and her partner Wayne Upshur, his nephew Mark Evans, his sister-in-law Joan Marie Weinert and her husband Stan Lear, along with many family and friends. He was currently a resident of Manhattan, NY. Services are private. Contributions in his name can be sent to Camp Rehoboth, 39 Baltimore Avenue, Rehoboth Beach, DE 19971.

HECHT--Manfred, 69, of Starlight, PA, formerly of New York City, passed away January 5th. Manfred was a graduate of Stockbridge, Rhodes, and Queens College. He was a master craftsman, engineer, and builder, who's work and persona live on. He is survived by his wife Cari, his daughter Bettina, and dear friends. He will be missed madly.
IF YOU GO In de Vrede (Donkerstraat 13, Westvleteren; 32-57-40-03-77; indevrede.be)

SWEIG--Morton Arthur, born in New York on February 13, 1915 died peacefully at home in New York on January 8, 2011. Morton was a successful and proud businessman who knew and understood the value of hard work. He was a pioneer in the building maintenance industry and a legend to those who knew him. He is survived by his wife Helen Koslow Sweig, daughter Jeannie Kligman (Gerald) of Palm Beach, FL, son Michael (Jo Ann) of Chicago, IL, grandfather to Gary (Karen) Kligman of Bloomfield Hills, MI, Wendy Kligman of Rye Brook, NY, three great-grandchildren Jacob, Amelia and Sara, step-father of Dale and Max Burger, Sally and Robert Koslow, and Vicki and Dan Kriser. He was preceded in death by his wife of greater than 50 years Charlotte (Phillips) Sweig who passed away in 1995. Morty will be sorely missed. Funeral services to be held on Monday January 10 at 11am at Temple Emanuel on Fifth Avenue and 65th street.

The City Critic column in some editions on Dec. 26, about a viewing of a lunar eclipse, referred imprecisely to the organizers of the event. While the Amateur Astronomers Association of New York invited some people to the event, it was organized by the outreach program of Columbia University's astronomy department.

When Edmonton's Linus Omark, in his first N.H.L. game last month, pulled a spin move just after picking up the puck at center ice, skated over the blue line, pump-faked, then slapped the puck past Tampa Bay goalie Matt Ellis, the hockey world went nuts. The Lightning players were furious, criticizing Omark for what they considered a showboat move that disrespected the game. But others said that the Lightning had been merely sore losers and that the shootout -- a skills contest tacked onto what was otherwise a tie game -- was meant to entertain fans. Omark's move, they argued, was entertaining. And besides, it worked.

SIMIDIAN--Darlene, 51, passed on January 11, 2011, surrounded by family and friends. A graduate of Hunter College, she worked for many years as an art director at American Lawyer magazine. She is survived by her mother and stepfather, Adrienne and Richard Baksa, sisters, Linda Simidian and Rachael Nicoll, brother-in-law, Paul Nicoll and beloved niece and nephews Grace Simidian Uvezian, Huggins Nicoll and Gabriel Nicoll. Services will be held Sunday, January 16 at 5pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street in Manhattan.

ALBERT--Regina S.,of Lakewood, NJ, formerly of New York City, died on Friday, January 14th. She is predeceased by her son Lawrence, and survived by her beloved husband, Bert, daughter Sheryl Nelson, and son Philip.

8 P.M. (NBC) THE 68TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDSRicky Gervais returns as host of this ceremony -- considered a predictor of the Oscars -- sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles. Nominees include ''Black Swan,'' ''The Fighter,'' ''Inception,'' ''The King's Speech'' and ''The Social Network'' (best picture); Halle Berry, Nicole Kidman, Jennifer Lawrence, Natalie Portman and Michelle Williams (best actress in a motion picture -- drama); Jesse Eisenberg, Colin Firth, James Franco, Ryan Gosling and Mark Wahlberg (best actor in a motion picture -- drama); and ''Biutiful,'' ''The Concert,'' ''The Edge,'' ''I Am Love'' and ''In a Better World'' (best foreign language film). Robert De Niro will be honored with the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement. Gia Mantegna, the daughter of the actor Joe Mantegna, is Miss Golden Globe. Red carpet coverage begins at 7. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR In a special ''town hall'' edition, ''After the Tragedy: An American Conversation,'' survivors of the ''Congress on Your Corner'' event in Tucson, where a gunman opened fire, reunite to discuss what happened that day. (Jared L. Loughner has been charged in the shootings.) David Muir, an ABC News anchor, will lead an audience discussion about the current state of America and the difficult questions raised by the tragedy.

POTGIETER--Leon, 48, passed away suddenly on January 10. Born in Cape Town, South Africa, graduated University Cape Town and a Fellow, Institute of Actuaries, London. Formerly with Towers Perrin, Leon was a Senior VP Human Resources, American Express. Leon leaves his wife, Barbara, and children, Luke, Sarah and Hannah; his mother, Pat; brother, Erich; sister, Jill and parents-in-law, Gary and Pat Loftie-Eaton. Services will be held at Christ Church Bronxville on Sunday, January 23rd at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Cat Assistance, PO Box 539, Ardsley, NY 10502, catassistanceny.org or the charity of your choice.

''Verizon has had the advantage of seeing the challenges and problems AT&T has faced.'' Charles S. Golvin, an analyst at Forrester Research, after Verizon announced that it would begin selling the Apple iPhone 4 next month. Some question whether the phone will strain Verizon as it has AT&T,which has struggled to address customer complaints. ''Inflation will be an endemic problem in the emerging markets.'' Russell Napier, a strategist at the investment firm CLSA in London. Some Asian countries are battling high and still-rising inflation, especially in food and energy, and their policy makers are worried about bubbles forming in their financial systems.

MORNING--Carole Ann Coleman, of New York City died January 10, 2011 at age 72 after a long illness. The only child of Dr. and Mrs. John Coleman, she was born in Berkeley, CA in 1938 and moved with her family to Los Angeles in 1943. She attended Los Angeles High School, graduated from Northfield School for Girls in Massachusetts, and from Stanford University with bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering. She worked for General Dynamics in San Diego designing systems for missiles and after a brief marriage moved to New York City in 1964 when she married graphic designer John Morning. There she worked for naval architects Gibbs & Cox and subsequently Chemical Construction Corp. After licensing as a New York State Professional Engineer, Carole became active in engineering affairs and served as chair of the New York State Board for Engineering and Land Surveying, the state licensure agency. Later becoming a faculty member at Stevens Institute of Technology in New Jersey, she then joined a precursor organization of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering, becoming a vice president. In addition, she gained a second master's degree, in statistics, from Columbia University. In 1989, she founded a consulting firm, Higher Education Extension Service, to help colleges and universities improve minority representation in engineering. She always considered her greatest achievement her two children: Dr. Ann Morning, an assistant professor at New York University; and John Morning, Esq., a partner at Prata & Daley LLP in Los Angeles. In turn their marriages have produced Sofia and Gaia Tambalotti of New York City; and Coleman, Miles and Anson Morning of San Marino, CA. She has many cousins from both parents' families, friends, and godchildren who have been of great comfort this past year, but has requested no flowers and that if desired, donations be made to United Negro College Fund, or Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY.

THE Hilltop neighborhood of Tacoma, Wash., is an unlikely cocktail hot spot. While the city has undergone a resurgence in the last decade, with a vibrant downtown antiques and arts district, Hilltop remains its roughest patch, largely ignored by visitors. But hidden there is 1022 South, home to some of the most fascinating apothecary cocktail work on the West Coast.

Some people have speculated that a town house at 29 Grace Court in Brooklyn Heights on the market for $5.95 million is not selling because it is too pink. Granted, the walls, the ceiling and the window moldings in the enormous parlor of the four-family home are covered in a bright shade of bubble gum. And after the price was reduced from $6.2 million this month, a reader on the Web site Curbed.com declared in a post: ''Beautiful interior bones. Want to sell? Hear these four words ... Ben Moore Super White.''

A review on Jan. 2 about ''Wait for Me!,'' a memoir by Deborah Mitford (now the dowager duchess of Devonshire), misstated the given name of a sister of John F. Kennedy who was married to the brother of Mitford's husband. She was Kathleen Kennedy, not Katherine.

BEKER--Erol Y.,died at 55. Survived by his loving wife Maryann. Also survived by his brothers Gary and Brian. Friends are invited to celebrate his life at 5pm January 24th at St. Peter's Church, The Erol Beker Chapel of the Good Shepherd, 619 Lexington Ave., New York, NY.

A picture credit on Dec. 12 with the Watchlist column misidentified the source of the photograph. The picture of two boxers was taken by Michelle Kunz; it was not supplied by Portal A Interactive, which produces the Web television show ''White Collar Brawlers.''

A picture caption last Sunday with an obituary about Cyril M. Harris, an acoustical engineer responsible for the sound in many prominent concert halls, misstated the date that the photograph showing Mr. Harris in Avery Fisher Hall was taken. It was 1975, not 1995.

An article on Dec. 26 about the Toronto Temperance Society (T.T.S.), a members-only bar in Toronto, included outdated information about one of the owners of the bar. While Christine Sismondo and Bill Sweete were owners of T.T.S. when Mr. Sweete was interviewed in early August, she left soon after.

ADAMCZYK--Joachim J. "Joe" died Tuesday, January 4th at his home in Madison NJ. He was 84. Born in Poland, Joe attended the Bedford School in England and graduated from Columbia University. He served in the U.S. Army in WWII. He retired as Chairman and CEO of General Drafting Co., Inc., a major road map publisher, where he worked for 40 years. Mr. Adamczyk was a civic leader in Morris County, NJ, serving as Board Chairman of Grace Counseling Center in Madison; President of the Colonial Symphony; President of the Madison Rotary Club; and was active with many other nonprofit organizations. In 2006 he published his autobiography In Search of a New Home. Besides his wife, Nancy, he is survived by four children and six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, NJ on January 22 at 10:30am. Details: bradleyfuneralhomes.com
Classical Allan Kozinn

Some of the top trends from Saturday's games: Kemba Walker, left, scored 31 points for Connecticut, which sent DePaul to its 18th consecutive Big East loss. The Blue Demons' last league victory came on Jan. 20, 2010, when they beat Marquette.

An article last Sunday about Andy Cohen, a Bravo network executive and talk show host, referred incorrectly to Morandi, a restaurant owned by Keith McNally that attracts celebrities. Since opening Morandi, Mr. McNally has opened Minetta Tavern and Pulino's; Morandi is not his newest restaurant.

CHANG--Victoria, 65, was peacefully released from her courageous battle with cancer on January 13, 2011 with her family by her side. Victoria was born on October 6, 1945 in Shanghai, China to Mey-En and Keh-Ming Sun. She was a devoted wife, dedicated mother and trusted advisor and friend to all. She loved reading, watching movies, laughing with friends and playing with her grandsons. At her request, no service will be held. In lieu of flowers or donations, the family requests that those who wish to honor Victoria do something that will benefit someone in need or the world around you. She would have appreciated such a gesture, and it will serve as a testament to her caring for others. She is survived by her husband of 43 years, James; her mother, Mey-En Sun; two daughters and their spouses, Melissa and Alec Gunn, Allison Chang and Diane Gosney; and two grandsons, Logan and Max.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Draft Can Wait as Luck Stays at Stanford,'' Jan. 7: Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck has decided to continue his college education rather than enter the N.F.L. draft. The Times wrote that he was ''risking millions of dollars by forgoing the opportunity to be the No. 1 pick in the 2011 N.F.L. draft.''

With a D.J. and dance floor, 20 iPads, 32 flat-screen monitors for gamers, and touch-screen tables, the sleek new Crush nightclub at Atlantis resort in the Bahamas would stand out on its own. But what makes the club unusual is its demographic: 13- to 17-year-olds. Opened Jan. 1, the $11 million, 14,000-square-foot club was created after the resort held focus groups with teenagers last year. It found that they wanted games and music, and ''to feel like adults,'' said Amanda Felts, vice president of guest activities and resort programming.
Think the recent trash-talking between the Jets and the Patriots was all good fun? The N.F.L. wants to make sure it stays that way.

My husband and I will be celebrating our 30th wedding anniversary this February. Could you recommend a special resort setting in Puerto Rico or Tortola? Puerto Rico because it's close and Tortola because that's where we honeymooned. We are limited to the school break in February but do not want to stay at a resort overrun with children. Looking for a quiet beach/private pool, good food and wine. Any suggestions to help us mark this milestone? M. Rossi, Merrick, N.Y. A.What about celebrating your 30th anniversary in Vieques, the small island just off the east coast of mainland Puerto Rico? In his ''36 Hours in Vieques'' (Feb. 21, 2010), Hugh Ryan wrote that the island has evolved into an upscale resort and has seen a boom in restaurants, galleries and hotels, while also offering white-sand beaches, coral reefs and a bioluminescent bay. In an e-mail, he added that one of the best things about Vieques is that it is still relatively ''quiet compared to most Caribbean islands'' and is ''a great locale for couples looking for some calm, beautiful beaches that aren't overrun with tourists - but still have some great restaurant options.''

ZIFF--Margaret Durham Ziff, died on January 13, 2011 at the age of 73. She is survived by her husband Howard Ziff, daughter Sarah Durham, step-daughters Debby Ziff Cook and Amy Ziff, her brother Tony Compton, and six grandchildren. Her radiance, warmth, wit and wisdom will be missed terribly. Known to her friends as Magi, she was a pioneering female advertising executive who worked at agencies such as Tinker, Gray, Della Famina, and others during Madison Avenue's heyday. In 1996, she retired to New Braintree, MA where she devoted her energy to local politics and served for twelve years as a member of the town's select board. She proudly served as a board member for the East Quabbin Land Trust for many years. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held in her honor at the New Braintree Congregational Church in New Braintree, MA town church at 2pm on January 30. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in her memory be made to the East Quabbin Land Trust at www.eqlt.org.

The Frugal Traveler column on Dec. 26 about spending the weekend in New York City for $100, misstated the years covered by an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum. It is ''Chaos and Classicism: Art in France, Italy & German, 1918-1936'' -- not ''1981-1936.''

STEWART--Ellen. Founder of LaMaMa ETC. The Board of Directors and Members of the Off-Broadway League mourn the passing of an Off-Off-Broadway pioneer. Ms. Stewart's vision of a multi-cultural theatre community has been a model around the world. We send condolences to Ms. Stewart's family, associates, and friends, with the promise she will never be forgotten. The Off-Broadway League

Dominik Hasek, who turns 46 on Jan. 29, just keeps on rolling. Widely considered modern hockey's greatest goalie and now tending the nets for Spartak Moscow, Hasek added another to his long list of honors this month when he was named the Kontinental Hockey League's goalkeeper of the week for winning three games, two by shutout.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Will Auburn's B.C.S. Title Stick?'' Jan. 11: If the N.C.A.A. does decide to strip Auburn of its national championship because of violations in Cam Newton's recruitment, there should be a new national championship game between Oregon and Texas Christian so the eventual national champion has really earned its title.

GEVERS--Rosalie. The board, staff and clients of The Bridge note the passing of Rosalie Gevers, mother of our Board President, Cynthia C. Wainwright. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Cynthia and the family. Dr. Peter Beitchman, Executive Director

Because of a programming error by Morningstar, tables last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, carried outdated net asset values. A corrected version is online at nytimes.com/mutualfunds.

SUKENIK--Herbert John. Died January 14, 2011 at the age of 80. Received his BA from Cornell University, his Ph.D. from the University of California Berkley and his M.D. from the University of California, San Francisco. A pioneer in the field of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Director of Space Medicine at the Martin Company and a key participant in the early installation of computers at Mass General. Leaves behind his brother Richard (Nancy) and many cousins.

CHECKLA--Natalie. Cancer took our mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, cousin, friend, collector, and hat, scarve and sweater knitter extraordinaire way too soon. If heaven has antique shows, flea markets and garage sales, buyers and sellers get ready for fun! Ira & Susan, Lisa & David, Matthew, Melanie, Jessie and Emma

REABACK--Irene S.,on January 12, 2011. Beloved wife of Raymond and wonderful mother of Ann and Felice. Cherished grandmother of Ian, Joshua, Miles, Benjamin and Steven. Devoted mother in law of Jamie and Alan. We love and adore you and will never let you out of our hearts.

RAVITZ--Francine, passed away at the age of 77 on January 12, 2011. The loving wife of Robert, and adored by her children Annie and John; daughter-in-law Berry and grandchildren Jack, Harry, Ava and Luke. She was the kindest, sweetest woman and always had time for others. She loved to paint and passed her love of art and all things beautiful to her family. The family will be at 30 East 65th St. on January 18 and 19 from 6-9pm. Donations to her memory may be made to the Lupus Research Institute, 330 Seventh Ave., Suite 1701, New York, NY 10001

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some copies last Sunday misstated the name of the church where a concert by the singer-songwriter Chris Smither is scheduled to take place on Saturday. It is the Presbyterian Church of Chatham Township, not the Chatham Presbyterian Church. The listing also gave an incorrect Web site for information about the concert. It is sanctuaryconcerts.org.

MAIER--Elise Meyer, beloved wife of Larry Maier (deceased). Survived by her daughter Barbara Kislak, her grandchildren Pamela, Valerie and Andrew, and her great-grandchildren Max, Tabitha, Zachary and Eliza.

Milan -- An artificial rain shower ended the Burberry Prorsum show this evening, pelting the models in their flasher-ready, see-through slickers and splashing all the front-row types, who had to pull up their knees. It called to mind the horror of a character Mink Coat played in John Waters's ''Desperate Living.'' ''You know I hate nature!'' she shrieked to her housekeeper, who had made the error of driving the family Mercedes through a Baltimore park. It is always amusing to see the elements invoked in fashion; weather must seem like a distant distraction to people who spend all their time in spaces that are both climate- and reality-controlled. If you have ever passed a day in, say, Oregon timber country you know why a logger might want to improvise a jacket from a blanket. The damp cold there goes bone deep, and chilblains are a threat at the height of summer.

CHALEFF--Jerrold S.,a lifelong resident of the Bronx, beloved son, brother, father and grandfather passed away on January 10 after being struck by an automobile. Jerrold was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science and Pace University. He is survived by his children, Michael (Janet), Fredric (Deborah) and Anna, his grandchildren Rachel and Mason, his brothers Richard and Paul and his mother Muriel.

Expressing concern about rusting brake lines rupturing and causing crashes, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into almost 1.8 million General Motors pickups and S.U.V.'s. In a filing posted last weekend on the N.H.T.S.A. Web site, the agency said the models covered in the so-called engineering analysis include the 1999-2003 Chevrolet Silverado, Avalanche, Suburban and Tahoe, as well as the GMC Sierra and Yukon.

ALLISON ARIEFF The winner of NewYork City's ''Taxi of Tomorrow'' competition stands to supply more than 13,000 medallion taxis for at least a decade, a deal that could be worth up to $1 billion. Imagine if, in turn, the yellow spots monopolizing New York's streets could help transform the urban landscape, perhaps by being smaller and more streamlined, having less environmental impact, or providing more comfort, convenience and aesthetics to passengers. What if the ''tomorrow'' part manifested itself not just in the object (the car) but in new initiatives inspired by the broad national movement toward collaborative consumption?-- Excerpt from ''All Tomorrow's Taxis'' DISUNION With his compromise, Crittenden hoped to achieve a lasting peace-- not just a truce -- through a geographical and constitutional ''solution'' to the slavery crisis. First and foremost, Crittenden restored the Missouri Compromise line that had been nullified in1854 by the Kansas-Nebraska Act. By reintroducing this line, and extending it west to the California border, Crittenden hoped to restore the tenuous peace created by a clear geographical distinction between slavery and freedom. Slavery would be permanently prohibited north of this line, thereby reversing the Supreme Court's 1857 ruling that Congress had no right to regulate slavery in the federal territories. In territories south of this line, however, the federal government would have no say over slavery; instead, the decision to allow or prohibit slavery would be made by those living in the territories themselves.-- SUSAN SCHULTEN, Excerpt from ''Last Chance for Compromise''

WILLIS--Alan E.,passed away on January 13 in Waterbury, CT. Engineer, Cellist, inventor, father of John, Elizabeth and Cathy, husband of Dolores, former husband of Meta and brother of David.

LONNERCarole Caplan. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with deep sadness the passing of Carole Caplan Lonner, beloved wife of Fred Lonner, and adored mother of Jane Och and mother-in-law of Daniel Och, cherished friends and prominent leaders within our community who carry on the philanthropic legacy of Carole. Dan and Jane make a profound difference in the lives of millions of people in New York, in Israel, and around the world through their exceptional generosity and leadership. Jane has served as past area chair and divisional chair for Scarsdale Women's Philanthropy. Dan is senior chair of our Wall Street & Financial Services Division's Investment Management Division, a former member of UJA-Federation's executive committee and board, and chair of the Birthright Israel Foundation. Together they exemplify unparalleled philanthropic commitment to strengthening Jewish identity. We extend our sympathies to Fred; to Jane and Dan; to Carole's grandchildren, Joshua, Alison, and Andrew Och; and to the entire Caplan, Lonner, Prince, and Bernstein families. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

SEIDEN--Melvin R. The Trustees and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the loss of Melvin R. Seiden, a committed and generous friend of the Morgan. Mel led the Visiting Committee to the Department of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts and served on the Visiting Committee to the Department of Drawings and Prints. He established the Janine Luke and Melvin R. Seiden Fund for Exhibitions and Publications and supported numerous acquisitions. Mel made gifts from his collection of drawings by Al Hirschfeld and by New Yorker cartoonists. Selections from the latter were exhibited here in 2009. We shall miss Mel greatly, and we extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Janine Luke. S. Parker Gilbert, President William M. Griswold, Director
FRUGAL TRAVELER Is there such a thing as good skiing at a bargain? Seth Kugel goes in search of it at Whiteface, N.Y., above, which at 3,430 feet has the greatest vertical drop in the East.

An article last Sunday about Stefan Duma, an engineer at Virginia Tech who is conducting tests on football helmets and compiling an online database of results, misstated a word in a quotation by him in some editions. In describing how consumers can go online to research car safety but not helmet safety, he said, ''You can go online, you can click on your exact vehicle -- frontal crashes, side-impact crashes, pole crashes, offset-frontal crashes -- every sort of impact you want, and with that is an associated risk of injury.'' He did not say ''hull crashes.''

OSORIO--Richard (Dick), passed away peacefully at his Berkeley home on November 12, 2010. An avid salsa, tango and swing dancer he and his wife Cara danced through life and traveled the world. In the 1960's and 70's he worked as company/general manager on 16 Broadway shows including the original "HAiR" and was executive producer of "HAiR" Argentina. Born July 10, 1930 he grew up in Alameda, CA, played football at UC Berkeley, was a Marine, graduated from UCLA, was in the MBA program at Harvard. He was a children's librarian at Hayward and Alameda County Libraries in California for over 30 years, taking a 5-year break to travel to India on a spiritual quest. An accomplished storyteller and magician he enthralled 1000's of children throughout the years. Flags flew at half-mast at Hayward City Hall in his honor. A life-long progressive activist, he boycotted with Cesar Chavez and marched in Selma, AL. He was a devotee of Bhagavan Sri Ramana Maharshi and published the English translation of The Path of Sri Ramana Part II. He is survived by his wife and love of his life, Cara Robin, daughter Miranda Robin-Thurmer, brother George Osorio, five nephews and a niece.

BERNAY--Elayn, Ph.D.,age 87, died on Friday, January 14th. Beloved mother of Laura Bernay, MD. She is mourned by her nieces Lana Brach, Cathy Friedman and Neva Watson and her nephew Lawrence Katz. She will be missed by her loving extended family and her many devoted friends. She was a mentor to generations of business students at Pace University.
FEIN--Lillian. Seven years have passed. Always in our hearts and minds. Nancy, Cliff & Austin

In the early '90s, it seemed that half the shops in Delray Beach, Fla., which is about an hour up the coast from Miami, were boarded up. Its streets were mostly deserted. But by the turn of the millennium it had transformed into an idyllic beach town filled with mom-and-pop restaurants, art galleries and beauty salons. Nowadays, Delray is poised to become a national destination. May 2009 saw the opening of Il Bacio Restaurant & Lounge (ilbacioofdelray.com), an indoor-outdoor hot spot with D.J.'s, V.I.P. cabanas and a dress code -- a jolt of South Beach in an otherwise sleepy town. Since then, an influx of design-conscious establishments along East Atlantic Avenue has brought in a new energy: creative, stylish and yet attitude-free. JONATHAN VATNER

The Los Angeles Clippers started the season with one victory in their first 14 games. After a 105-91 loss to Philadelphia on Dec. 15, the Clippers were 5-21 and among the worst teams in the league. The rookie forward Blake Griffin's ferocious dunks (usually coming in losses) were the lone highlights for a team that seemed to be going nowhere. But after that loss, the Clippers began to turn their season around.

FRIEDMAN--Sara T.,A retired nurse and beloved mother and grandmother, passed away on January 10, 2011, at Sibley Hospital in Washington, DC. She was preceded in death by her husband, Arnold P. Friedman, former head of the Montefiore Headache Unit and Professor of Neurology at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City. Mrs. Friedman was born Sara Fritz in the mining town of Kellogg, ID, on August 14, 1911. Following nursing school, she worked for many years in the Pacific Northwest, then in Boston as part of a World War II head injury project, and subsequently as a school nurse in New York City. A longtime resident of New York City and Tucson, AZ, she had more recently lived at the Grand Oaks Retirement Community in Washington, DC. She is survived by her loving daughter and son-in-law, Carol and Eugene Ludwig of Washington, DC, and adoring grandchildren, Abigail, Elizabeth, and David. The Memorial Service and burial are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mrs. Friedman's memory may be sent to Carondelet Neurological Institute in Tucson (Attn. Robert P. Goldfarb, M.D., 120 N. Tucson Blvd, Tucson, AZ 85716) or Septima Clark Public Charter School in Washington, DC. (c/o Ned Mandel, 2501 Martin Luther King Ave., SE, Washington, DC 20020).

GEVERS--Rosalie de Forest Crosby Wainwright, beloved widow of Maximilian E. Gevers, died January 9, 2011 at home in New York City at age 95. She is survived by her daughters Daphne Arkus-Duntov and Cynthia Wainwright, son-in-law Stephen Berger, grandchildren Nicholas Hohenberg, Alexis Arkus-Duntov, Robin Berger and Diana Berger, her stepdaughter Catherine Gevers and her niece Francoise Gevers, her nephews Ashton Crosby, Sheldon Crosby (Hilary) George Crosby (Regina) and Ford Franklin (Mary), as well as her nieces Bobbie Crosby (the late Player), Eleanor Hall (Barry), Bebe Haynes (Patrick), Louise Lawrence (Robert), and Priscilla Hindley. She is also survived by her former step-daughters Mary Lelewer (Stanley) and Audrey Warren (Charles) and many great-nieces and nephews. Rosalie grew up in Mt. Kisco, NY, was married first to Carroll Bagley, then to Townsend Wainwright who died in 1960, then to Max Gevers in 1962. He died in 1996 in Monte Carlo where they had lived since 1973. She was an interior decorator in New York City for many years prior to moving to Europe. Known for her elegance, beauty and sense of humor to the end, Rosalie was beloved by many. Special thanks to Maureen Taylor, RN, Peggy Murphy, Rita Byrne, Marie Cunningham, Ellen McCannon and Eileen Brick and the many other nurses who cared for her over the past few years. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Historic House Trust of New York City, The Arsenal, Room 203, Central Park, New York NY 10065 www.historichousetrust.org would be greatly appreciated. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

SEIDEN--Melvin R. The Trustees and staff of The Frick Collection mourn the death of our Trustee Melvin R. Seiden, a devoted friend of the Frick for three decades. As Chairman of the Library Committee in 1995 and 1996, he played a pivotal role in the successful campaign to help endow the Frick Reference Library. He subsequently served on the Frick Council and was elected to the Board in 2000. Mr. Seiden's enthusiasm and support for the Frick were boundless. Over the years, he provided substantial funding for numerous exhibitions and curatorial activities, typically in honor of friends or scholars whom he admired. His greatest pleasure however, was the Frick Art Reference Library, of which he was a tireless advocate and for which he started many book funds and helped to underwrite the Center for the History of Collection in America. We shall miss his extraordinary intelligence, judgment and dedication, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Janine Luke. Margot C. Bogert, Chairman, Anne L. Poulet, Director.
Television Ginia Bellafante

THERE really is nothing new under the fashion sun. On Thursday, ''The Master of the Blue Jeans'' opens at Didier Aaron Inc. (didieraaron.com) in New York. Originally organized by Gerlinde Gruber, a curator at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, for Galerie Canesso in Paris, the exhibition includes seven late-17th-century Italian paintings that show poor people dressed in denim, which was made then in Genoa and known by the French name for that city, Gênes. The paintings, which were once attributed to artists like Velázquez and de la Tour, are now thought to be the work of a single unknown artist. The catalog even has a brief essay by that 20th-century pioneer of stonewash, François Girbaud. ''The Master of the Blue Jeans'' runs through Feb. 4. PILAR VILADAS

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Forsaking Fact for Emotion, Musburger Keeps It Vague,'' Jan. 12: The critique of Brent Musburger was long overdue. Too many announcer teams fail to hear each other in the booth and allow egregious errors to go by without correction.

The cover article on Jan. 2 about Sydney's beginnings as a gulag for British convicts misstated part of the title of a book about Australia's colonization and gave an incorrect year for a famous case in which seven escaped convicts on Tasmania turned to cannibalism. The book, by Tom Keneally, is ''A Commonwealth of Thieves'' not ''A Confederacy of Thieves,'' and the escape took place in 1822, not 1882.

An article on Dec. 26 about Jayne Sandman and Barbara Martin, who own the Washington public relations firm BrandLinkDC, referred incorrectly to the firm's history. It was founded by several former employees of Fingerprint, another public relations firm; BrandLinkDC was not formerly known as Fingerprint, which still exists.

A classic trio in bars all over Spain - tapas, a glass of wine and a cigarette - has just lost a member. Starting this month, smoking is no longer permitted in most enclosed public spaces, including bars, cafes and restaurants. The new law, voted into effect by national legislators late last year, expands existing antismoking regulations in the country, which had already outlawed the practice in workplaces and on public transit. Under the old rules, bar and restaurant owners with spaces smaller than 100 square meters (about 1,100 square feet) were able to decide themselves whether to allow smoking; perhaps not surprisingly, almost all allowed it. But no longer.

NABAGIEZ--Vladimir A.,M.D., age 91, passed on January 11, survived by his beloved wife of 48 years, Yolande, two loving sons Andrew Nabagiez (Destiny Floyd) and John Nabagiez, M.D. (Sandra Shin, M.D.) and two adored granddaughters Melisande and Avelene. He was a lifelong member of the AMA and a Paul Harris Fellow. He was a man of uncompromising commitment, integrity and honor. A celebration of his life will take place at the Mohonk Preserve at a later date.

An article last Sunday about law schools misstated the educational history of Jason Bohn, a recent law school graduate. While Mr. Bohn took classes at Columbia Law School, his law degree is from the University of Florida. And while nearly all of his student loan debt was accumulated at Columbia University, it was incurred while he was an undergraduate and while working on a master's degree, and not at Columbia Law.

JOY MALIN'S love of dogs is obvious, even over the phone. ''When you arrive, come to apartment D, as in dog,'' she instructed a visitor. This was a fitting introduction to the East Village-based artist who estimates that she has painted oil portraits of more than 120 dogs in the last three years. Her animal portrait business started with an oil painting of her daughter's dachshund, Neo. Her daughter was delighted with the result, and Ms. Malin decided it would be a fulfilling way to supplement her art-brokering business, which had suffered during the recession.

Phone calls with a Grand Slam theme. ''It's been ringing quite a bit,'' Laver, now 72, said earlier this week.

The acclaimed, vegetable-friendly restaurant in Paris where he paid his dues is L'Arpège.

MARTIN--Louis J. January 27, 1930 December 16, 2010. Louis J. Martin was born in Philadelphia but spent a great deal of time in New Jersey. Known to the world as Jerry, he passed away in his sleep December 16, 2010 at his home in Santa Monica, California. Jerry was a retired commercial agent, having been at William Morris Agency at the time of his retirement. Other agency affiliations were he had worked include Henderson Hogan, International Famous Agency in New York and Fifi Oscard Agency, also in New York. Prior to that, he had headed the tour guide staff at NBC in New York. As a commercial agent, some of his clients included Ava Gardner, Betty Grable, Alice Faye, Gwen Verdon and Mae West. Before NBC he was in the US Navy and it was after that he moved into New York City. Because of his Navy affiliation, he requested to have his ashes taken out to sea. There will be no official funeral plans, but a gathering to celebrate his life is being planned. If anyone cares to make any donations in his honor; two of his favorite charities were the Morris Animal Foundation, and Actors and Others for Animals.
CHELSEA LOFT $1,200,000

HOROWITZ--Dr. Louise S.,78, died peacefully at home on January 14, 2011, comforted by the constant attention of her children and close friends. Born January 24, 1932 to Charles Schwartz and Bertie Grad Schwartz, Louise graduated from Fieldston High School in 1950. She attended Smith College until her marriage to David Horowitz in 1951, and then transferred to Barnard College where she received her bachelor's degree with distinction in 1954. Louise's inquiring mind and critical skills drew her to pursue graduate work in philosophy at Columbia University. Continuing her studies while raising three children, Louise received her Ph.D. degree in 1969. She joined the faculty of Long Island University's Brooklyn Campus, where she specialized in teaching Philosophy of Art and, her personal favorite, Oriental Philosophy. Highly respected among students, Louise was the campus Women's Liberation Club advisor and was frequently asked to serve as a faculty chaperon for bus trips to Washington, D.C. anti-war demonstrations. Divorced in 1972, she soon met Alton Johnson, with whom she lived until his death in 2001. In 1977 Louise left teaching to enter New York Law School, where she graduated cum laude with her J.D. degree in 1981. She practiced law until shortly before her death, specializing in civil and commercial litigation in state and federal courts. With a lifelong interest in art, music, and the theater, Louise also was a painter and frequently attended opera, ballet, and dance performances. Committed to public service, she served for many years on the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health board, including president from 1984 to 2010, and as a member of the New York Public Library Board of Trustees from 1978 to 1984. Fervent in her opinions and always loving a good argument, Louise is remembered by her friends and family for her intellect, charm, and eminent hospitality. She is survived by her brother Ernest Schwartz, children Marilyn, Roger, and Diana, and grandchildren Jason and Lucy Horowitz. A memorial service to remember her life will take place on Monday, January 17, 9:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. To recognize Louise's deep love for her home on Shelter Island, the family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent in her name to the Mashomack Preserve, PO Box 850, Shelter Island, NY 11964.

The Mortgages column on Jan. 2 about ''recasting'' a mortgage, an alternative to refinancing, misstated the amount by which monthly payments would drop, based on how much of the remaining principal on the loan was paid down. If you put in $20,000, the payment would drop by $184 (not $52), to around $2,002 (not $2,135). And putting in $100,000 would save $945 (not $730) a month and bring payments to $1,241 (not $1,457).

It is because we are not angels, she says , that we require a system of government that acknowledges "the inevitable conflicts" produced by our "imperfect passions" and yet provides mechanisms - free speech, vigorous debate - that allow us to settle those conflicts without resorting to "dueling pistols." LOS ANGELES- As the storm over Rickygate continues - Philip Berk, the president of the Hollywood Foreign Press and a target of Mr. Gervais's jokes at the Golden Globes, said that Mr. Gervais "definitely crossed the line" in a way that was, oh right, true to form for the comedian, and just happened to slightly bump the ratings - the Bagger would like to offer up a grab bag of quotes and moments from the press room to distract you from the brewing comedy non-troversy.

Last night's Golden Globe awards had the drama of an episode of "This Old House." David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin's "The Social Network" swept the ceremony winning best director, screenplay and picture, while favorites Colin Firth and Natalie Portman took the honors in acting. The only real surprise came on the red carpet. Outside of a few young things wearing neutral tones, it looked as if Los Angeles was in the grips of a stylist strike. What's with the butterfly sleeves? And the French knots? And that gimmicky neckline on one to be forever nameless redhead that made her look like she was wearing half a Snuggie without sleeves. While we were thrilled to see emerald green make a resurgence on the red carpet, wouldn't it have been nice if the dresses looked a little less like upholstery? Overall, the women looked kind of matronly - ironic in a town known for its desperate attempts to look young. With the Academy Awards about a month away, let's hope that sartorial slapfest is a little more exciting.

Yes, jackets were a bit shrunken at Dolce & Gabbana, but most notable were a few awesome color-blocked shirts: the darker or lighter colored shirt tails created the appearance of boxers bunched up and hanging out the tops of pants. Jil Sander showed suits with large, boxy-shouldered jackets in a variety of colors, each individually so pointedly monochrome that they might as well have been in beige, gray and black - and I mean that all as a compliment. Burberry went from leather jackets to raincoats this season, a sexier proposal than you might imagine; rain actually fell onto the runway for the finale, startling a front row of floppy-haired actors and rockers including Douglas Booth and the Razorlight frontman Johnny Borrell. John Varvatos had one of his better seasons: layered up textures dripped down below suit jackets cut in slim but traditional-length silhouettes.
Former Vice President Dick Cheney said he has not decided whether to seek a heart transplant for what he called his "end-stage heart failure" but said he will make that decision "at some point."

O.K., we'll admit it: the Bagger had fun at the Golden Globes afterparties. This is not a foregone conclusion; sometimes the evening amounts to chasing a good time at events that resemble a higher production-value convention. If winter is already starting to look long and chilly to you, maybe a little home retail therapy will help. Normann Copenhagen's Mormor ceramic dinnerware - by Gry Fager, a 2008 graduate of the Danish Design School - is covered with a cheery blue-and-white windowpane check that was inspired by a dish towel and by old-school kitchens in general. ("Mormor" is Danish for grandmother.) In addition to Mormor Blue, the pieces are available in two textured white finishes: Mormor Ribbed and Mormor Square, which are also textile-inspired, but with a knitted look. The milk jug ($26) and sugar bowl ($23) give your breakfast table an easy update, and the buttering boards ($26 and $36) make you want to linger over that second slice of toast.

After a rough start to the new year, the Nets' Brook Lopez seems to be back on track. January hadn't been kind to Lopez; in each of the month's first five games, he scored at a below-average rate by his season's standards, and Lopez even scored in single digits twice during that stretch. The Nets' two latest games have been a different story though, as Lopez dropped a pair of incredibly efficient, high-scoring performances against the Lakers and the Blazers. The momentary snag in Lopez's per-game scoring didn't provide any real cause for alarm, but it's nice to see him reverse course with such prolific efforts.

LOS ANGELES - The Bagger didn't make it to every party after the Golden Globes last night, but of the four we did attend, the Weinstein Company/Relativity bash earned the highest marks for production design. Drawing on its nominated films, "The King's Speech" and "Blue Valentine," the party at the Beverly Hilton Hotel was decorated to look like a British/suburban drawing room, complete with carpeting, vintage-looking tufted couches, chests of drawers painted with the Union Jack and decorated with photos from the movies. (All the extra production work that the director Derek Cianfrance did on "Blue Valentine," having his actors live together in an upstate New York house for a month, paid off in decorating savings.)

Held in the cavernous former rail station Stazione Leopolda, the main event at Pitti Uomo this time round commemorated the centennial of Trussardi, the Italian luxury brand that started as a humble glove maker. In a nod to the company's history of leather crafting, its creative director Milan Vukmirovic created the entire collection from leather. From the chamois V-neck tees and white button-front shirts to the soft suede trenches and glossy black leather motocross pants, every item started as a skin. It was an apt homage.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- At the end of his trip to Kabul in late March, President Obama declared after a high-profile military offensive that the Marines had pushed the Taliban out of the Afghan region of Marja, one of its major strongholds. But even as the president spoke those words, the Marines in Marja were telling a different story to an embedded reporter: The Taliban had retaken the momentum in much of Marja and stymied the troops' strategy to win hearts and minds. Soon, high-ranking American officials began to acknowledge that Marja was not going nearly as well as hoped.

Today is Martin Luther King day, a federal holiday. Martin Luther King Jr. was actually born on Jan. 15, 1929, but we celebrate his birthday today, guided by the great American principle that states, "No holiday shall be wasted by falling on a weekend!" Coincidentally, Jan. 17 is the birthday of another great American hero, Benjamin Franklin, who was born on this date in 1706 by the modern Gregorian calendar.

T Magazine hosted a pre-Golden Globes dinner last Thursday evening at the Gardens of Taxco, an amazingly off-kilter Mexican restaurant in Hollywood.
