Lily Collins, aside from being stunning, was impressively polite. The recent T cover boy Stephen Dorff was a real charmer, as were Vincent Gallo and Gavin Rossdale. Jessica Chastain left us desperate to see her in her new role as the title character in Al Pacino's "Salome." And Alexa Chung, her friends from the band the Like and assorted other celebs and Hollywood power types made for a great, bordering-on-wild night.

In a Monday edition of the German magazine Focus, Porsche chief executive Matthias Mueller said that the automaker's current production capacity at its Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen factory was insufficient to meet worldwide sales targets, particularly in emerging markets like China. But as Porsche integrates more fully with its parent company, the Volkswagen Group, the brand might locate production of future models - among them an S.U.V., the Cajun, which will be smaller and less expensive than the Cayenne - in either China or North America.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

It's Scorecard season again! The fall 2011 men's-wear shows kicked off in Milan on Saturday, so as ever we're here reading the deluge of reviews so you don't have to. Early observations: January showers may bring February flowers, because critics are feeling that defining and refining your signature is totally cool. (Just see Raf Simons's masterful play across the gender line of couture volumes and Technicolor from his last women's collection at Jil Sander.) But be wary not to get stuck in a disco groove.

In their new book, "Red Capitalism: The Fragile Financial Foundation of China's Extraordinary Rise" (John Wiley & Sons), Carl E. Walter and Fraser J.T. Howie paint a troubling portrait of China's economy and its financial system. Despite the nation's mind-boggling growth and images of gleaming skyscrapers and luxury cars, the authors say China's growth model is flawed and fragile, and they warn about substantial risks accumulating in its banking system.

Many of the Golden Globe winners Sunday night are talented, but they’re also very glamorous. Most of the female nominees and presenters are regularly among the top fashion vote-getters — Angelina Jolie, Anne Hathaway, Nicole Kidman, Scarlett Johansson, Amy Adams — and some of them have had contracts with major fashion houses, as Natalie Portman, who won for “Black Swan,” does with Dior. New York favorites Gang Gang Dance will release their highly anticipated (at least by the art-rock set) fifth album this spring on the 4AD label. As the band gears up for the big date, it is planning a slew of shows, among them tonight's private after-party for Capsule, a hip-enough fashion trade show held regularly in New York. Curated by Sean Hanratty, the night's bill includes Light Asylum as an opening act and a video installation by the artists Daniel Turner and Colin Snapp. The two recently began collaborating under the name Jules Marquis; this past December they debuted their joint work with a well-received show at the Martos Gallery in Chelsea. (And for those traveling to Milan in the next few days for men's fashion week, Turner has a solo show titled "Britannica" opening January 19 at the Pianissimo gallery on Via Ventura 6.)

Masato Nishihara, the executive chef of Kajitsu, an elegant vegan Japanese restaurant in the East Village, created a vegan vegetable tempura, one without eggs in the batter. "He believes that tempura batter, originally, was just flour and water, and that when you go back in history, at some point someone added eggs," said Chiaki Takada, who interpreted for Mr. Nishihara. The chef said that the differences between the two tempuras - one with eggs, the other without - are not big.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Tuesday about Richard Winters, who commanded the World War II Army unit that was the subject of the book and television series ''Band of Brothers,'' contained several errors. A 1944 battle in which he was shot in the leg was in Carentan, France, shortly after D-Day, not on Utah Beach in Normandy on D-Day. While he did serve as commander of Company E, he was not in immediate command of the company ''from D-Day to V-E Day'' (May 8, 1945). He became commander on D-Day but was promoted to executive officer of the Second Battalion on Oct. 9, 1944. (The company was part of the battalion.) And his wife is Ethel Winters, not Esther.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is identified mostly with Washington and the South, but he was officially an honorary New Yorker and the city plays a not insignificant role in his biography. In 1958, 10 years before he was assassinated in Memphis, Dr. King was autographing copies of his book, ''Stride Toward Freedom,'' in a Harlem department store when a deranged women stabbed him with a letter opener. He was taken to Harlem Hospital for surgery.

BARRY--John A.,79, of New Vernon passed away surrounded by his family on Friday, January 14, 2011. Jack was born in Newark, NJ, the son of Edwin and Loretta. He spent his youth growing up in South Orange. He was a graduate of the Seton Hall Preparatory and a proud 1953 graduate of the University of Notre Dame. Jack served in the U.S. Army during the Korean conflict. He began his Wall Street career in 1956 and in 1961 became a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a partner in the Specialist firm of Silver, Barry & Van Rault. He was a Specialist on the floor of the NYSE through several firm mergers, retiring in 1988 as a partner of Mercator Partners. Jack was a member of the Buttonwood Club for 30 years. Surviving are his wife Jean of 39 years, his children, John and wife Jill of Morristown, Tim of San Francisco, Mary Lipman of Ipswich, Massachusetts, Dan and wife Melissa of Denville, Joe of Boulder, and Kevin of Richmond, his three stepchildren, Kevin Cain of Bedminster, Margaret Cain Hynes of Mendham, and Teresa Cain Sedgwick and husband Scott of Reno, Nevada. Also Surviving are his grandchildren Ben and Ali Lipman, Adia, Spenser, and Sasha Barry, Conor, Kevin, and Kathleen Hynes, Annie and Claire Sedgwick, Charlie and Megan Cain and their mother Amy. He was predeceased by his stepson Peter Cain in 1997. The family would like to acknowledge with gratitude the caring staff at Garden Terrace in Chatham. Donations may be made in his memory to the University of Notre Dame, John A. Barry Scholarship Fund, 115 Main Building, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556-5602. GO IRISH. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Chuirch of Christ the King, Blue Mill Rd., New Vernon, NJ on Wednesday at 10:00am. Interment Private. Hours of visitation at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Ave., Morristown, NJ on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm.

6. JETS (Wild card) at 2. PITTSBURGH STEELERS When these teams played in Week 15 at Heinz Field, the Jets came from behind, then held off a last-second Steelers drive, to win, 22-17. Until Sunday's victory over the Patriots, the win in Pittsburgh was the Jets' most complete game: with a balanced offensive attack, an error-free Mark Sanchez and a defense to keep their low-scoring offense in it. The Steelers were able to run and pass on the Jets, but Ben Roethlisberger was sacked three times. Against the Patriots in the divisional game, the Jets were similarly balanced. Sanchez settled down quickly and the Jets contained Tom Brady by playing back, keeping the offense in front of them and getting pressure without blitzing. Pittsburgh was depleted in Week 15, without safety Troy Polamalu, defensive lineman Aaron Smith and tight end Heath Miller. Those are key cogs for the Steelers, who will probably want to run on the Jets again(they had 146 yards in the regular-season game). The Jets will want to run, too, but that's a tough proposition if the Steelers' defense is healthy. They are first in the league against the run, allowing only 62.8 yards a game. The Jets rushed for 106 yards in their first meeting. PLAYER TO WATCH If Sanchez's passes are as erratic here as they were against the Colts, the Steelers' opportunistic defense could make him pay. He will have to be wary of Polamalu trolling the middle of the field. Sanchez and Braylon Edwards hooked up eight times in their last game against the Steelers, a game that proved Sanchez could play well in cold weather. National Football Conference 6. GREEN BAY PACKERS (Wild card) at 2. CHICAGO BEARS (North champion)Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers has been otherworldly this postseason (49 of 63 for 546 yards, 6touchdowns, no interceptions), and he easilysolved the Falcons' defense. Jay Cutler cut down on his interceptions this season and Mike Martz, the Bears' offensive coordinator, finally seems content not to get him killed. Still, the Green Bay defense has been impressive, particularly late in the season, and it will go after Cutler. The question for the Bears, as it has been for each of the Packers' last few opponents, is if they can stay with the Packers' big-play offense. Ignore the scoring outburst against the Seahawks; it is hard to get much of a read on anything Chicago did against an opponent that looked so inept. The Falcons could not keep up, allowing Rodgers seven completions of at least 20 yards, and he was especially dangerous when he was outside the pocket. The Packers ranked 10th in points scored in the regular season; the Bears ranked 21st. Now we know why Chicago Coach Lovie Smith played his starters in the season finale in an effort to keep Green Bay out of the playoffs. After splitting games with the Packers this season, Smith probably knew this offensive explosion was coming. He will try to slow the Packers by running Matt Forte and hoping the Packers cannot block Julius Peppers. PLAYER TO WATCH Rodgers is creating his legend this season. When the Packers had no running game earlier in the season, he was virtually the sole offensive threat. Against the Falcons, he was practically flawless. He is trouble even outside the pocket and is difficult to bring down, so the Bears will have to finish sacks, not merely get pressure.

Combined album sales -- which includes CDs, cassettes, digital albums and vinyl LPs -- declined last year, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Sales fell 12.7 percent from 2009 to 2010, as music fans filled their mobile devices with single tracks. Big stars, like Taylor Swift, above, still sold complete albums. Oddly, the drop in total album sales did not include vinyl LPs: fans bought 2.8 million LPs in 2010, an increase of 14 percent from 2009. The top 10 vinyl albums included ''Abbey Road'' by the Beatles, ''Suburbs'' by Arcade Fire and Pink Floyd's ''Dark Side of the Moon.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

Twenty years and one-tenth of a decade ago, on Martin Luther King's Birthday at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks experienced a holiday miracle. Tucker hit the shot that would forever change the end-game rules of the N.B.A. clock.

The statue of Admiral Nelson high above Trafalgar Square, which has been joined over the past several years by a motley sculptural crew of contemporary-art neighbors - a marble depiction of a naked pregnant woman, a big ship in a bottle, a life-size figure of Jesus - will soon have the company of a rooster and rocking horse. The choices are a bit more sober than some of the previous ones. In 2009 the artist Antony Gormley used the plinth as a human stage, enlisting more than 2,000 volunteers who each spent an hour atop it, some of them in various states of undress, with the artist's approval. ''Nakedness is absolutely essential,'' Mr. Gormley said. ''Nakedness is to art what the ball is to football.''

GEVERS--Rosalie de Forest Crosby Wainwright, beloved widow of Maximilian E. Gevers, died January 9, 2011 at home in New York City at age 95. She is survived by her daughters Daphne Arkus-Duntov and Cynthia Wainwright, son-in-law Stephen Berger, grandchildren Nicholas Hohenberg, Alexis Arkus-Duntov, Robin Berger and Diana Berger, her stepdaughter Catherine Gevers and her niece Francoise Gevers, her nephews Ashton Crosby, Sheldon Crosby (Hilary) George Crosby (Regina) and Ford Franklin (Mary), as well as her nieces Bobbie Crosby (the late Player), Eleanor Hall (Barry), Bebe Haynes (Patrick), Louise Lawrence (Robert), and Priscilla Hindley. She is also survived by her former step-daughters Mary Lelewer (Stanley) and Audrey Warren (Charles) and many great-nieces and nephews. Rosalie grew up in Mt. Kisco, NY, was married first to Carroll Bagley, then to Townsend Wainwright who died in 1960, then to Max Gevers in 1962. He died in 1996 in Monte Carlo where they had lived since 1973. She was an interior decorator in New York City for many years prior to moving to Europe. Known for her elegance, beauty and sense of humor to the end, Rosalie was beloved by many. Special thanks to Maureen Taylor, RN, Peggy Murphy, Rita Byrne, Marie Cunningham, Ellen McCannon and Eileen Brick and the many other nurses who cared for her over the past few years. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Historic House Trust of New York City, The Arsenal, Room 203, Central Park, New York NY 10065 www.historichousetrust.org would be greatly appreciated. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

Steve Lillywhite, the Grammy-winning record producer who counts U2 as among his most frequent clients, has come aboard ''Spider-Man: Turn Off The Dark,'' the $65-million Broadway musical featuring music by Bono and the Edge, the band's chief songwriters. Mr. Lillywhite, who has been at the Foxwoods Theater this week working with the actors on the show's music, will also produce the original cast album. After an unusually lengthy preview period marked by several delays, the show is due to open February 7.

PERKINS--Maggie, died of brain cancer, peacefully and surrounded by love, in Chicago on January 13, 2011. "Pretty, perky Maggie Perkins" was Iowa's "Miss Decorah", advertising's reigning "Detergent Queen", Romper Room's "Miss Maggie", and our very own "American in Paris". Not one to suffer fools gladly, Maggie spoke her mind in boardrooms from New York to Paris to Moscow. She also quilted quilts, bottled jams, made Eskimo pies and was impossible to get off the dance floor. She will be deeply mourned by the love of her life, fiance David Saloom, brother, B.J. Jennisch, stepdaughter Susan Perkins, her many relatives and friends. A private service will be held in Decorah, Iowa at a later date. Contributions in Maggie's memory can be made to Winneshiek (WMC) Hospice, (563) 367-3024 or to her favorite celebration, Decorah's Nordic Fest (http://www.nordicfest.com/) She was a true original--we'll all miss her so much.

SCHEINFELD--Shirley. Our family honors the blessed memory of Shirley Scheinfeld. A beloved aunt to Jane and Larry Scheinfeld and our children Greg, Caroline and Philip. Aunt Shirley loved life and was generous of heart and spirit. She saw life as a celebration and always put family first. Aunt Shirley was always the first to arrive and the last to leave for any family gathering. We are so grateful for her loving presence in our lives. Throughout the years, a woman of valor, she shared her kindness and wisdom with us. Our thoughts and prayers are with our Uncle Alex, cousins Lori and Lee, Debbie and Susie and their children.

OTTAWA - Over the last quarter century, ''Money for Nothing'' by Dire Straits has moved from the Top 40 to the playlists of classic rock stations all over the world. But last week, a broadcast industry standards council ruled that the song was unfit for Canada's airwaves. The issue focused on the use of an antigay slur. At least three radio stations, including CIRK-FM in Edmonton, Alberta, defied the ban with marathon broadcasts of the song, indirectly underlining the lack of power held by the industry's self-regulatory body.

Also survived by sister Sasha Milgram. A psychologist by training, Joan loved books, art, music, dance, and her family. Services 1pm Monday January 17 at "The Riverside" W. 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be given to a charity of your choice.

9 P.M. (13) DINOSAUR WARS In the summer of 1868 the paleontologist Othniel Charles Marsh, on board a Union Pacific train on a sightseeing excursion through the country's newly opened Western frontier, realized that he was traveling through the greatest dinosaur burial ground of all time. But he had competition in his fossil hunting from his fellow paleontologist Edward Drinker Cope. ''American Experience'' follows the men's efforts as they uncover the remains of dozens of prehistoric animals, including 130 species of dinosaurs; collect thousands of specimens; provide evidence to prove Charles Darwin's contested theory of evolution; and put American science on the world map. But their professional rivalry eventually got the better of them. What began as denigrating comments in science journals led to the destruction of fossils and political maneuverings that left both men alone and nearly destitute. At 10, ''Roads to Memphis,'' an encore ''American Experience'' presentation, recalls the fatal encounter on April 4, 1968, between the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his assassin, James Earl Ray. 5 P.M. (MSNBC) OBAMA'S AMERICA In a Martin Luther King's Birthday special, Chris Matthews explores race relations. His guests include David Axelrod, White House senior adviser; Michael Steele, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee; Representative Donna F. Edwards, Democrat of Maryland; and Velma Hart, who told Mr. Obama at a town hall meeting last year that she was exhausted from defending him and impatient for the change he had promised.

On the other hand, Mr. Gethard ended his day by performing in a comedy show with Diddy, the illustrious if elusive hip-hop mogul, after a campaign that lasted over a year.

''The Green Hornet'' was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with about $34 million in ticket sales -- proof that a studio, in this case Sony Pictures Entertainment, can fix a troubled movie on the fly. After a sneak peak for ''The Green Hornet'' was greeted with ridicule from fanboys last summer, Sony performed triage. The film, based on the 1930s radio serial and 1960s television show, was re-edited, new scenes were shot and the advertising plan was reworked. The upshot: While sales were on the squishy side for a 3-D release costing at least $110 million, ''The Green Hornet'' is far from the flop that many expected. The weekend was uglier for ''The Dilemma,'' a poorly reviewed comedy directed by Ron Howard -- yes, the Oscar-winning one -- that sold about $17.4 million for second place. The inauspicious debut for ''The Dilemma,'' which cost at least $70 million to make, adds to a track record for Universal Pictures that is increasingly troubling. ''True Grit'' (Paramount Pictures) was third with about $11.2 million for a total of $126.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. ''The King's Speech'' (the Weinstein Company) was fourth with about $9 million for a limited-release total of $44.6 million. ''Black Swan'' (Fox Searchlight), was fifth with $8 million, lifting its total to a $73 million.

INTERNATIONAL The London Journal article on Thursday, about the happiness in Britain over its cricket team's improbable winning performance against Australia in The Ashes, one of the most celebrated rivalries in international cricket, misstated the age of the competition. It is 129 years old, not 125.

One old saw debunked recently was that pro sports are impervious to recessions. During the past few years, attendance has fallen in nearly every league, several franchises declared bankruptcy and a few more were sold for less than expected. Teams cut ticket prices, sold hot dogs for $1 and did anything they could to get customers in the door. The online ticket market has bucked the trend. The number of tickets bought on StubHub, the largest online reseller, as well as at other exchanges, has risen steadily even as the economy faltered. At the same time, though, prices have fallen, making it possible for cost-conscious consumers to continue attending games.

WIESEN--Shirley Preston, born in New York City in 1921 to Harry and Rachel Preston passed away on January 14 surrounded by her children. Beloved mother of Maxwell, Robert (Yona), and Susan (James); adored grandmother of Adam (Nicole), Douglas (Julie), Kira, Jonathan, and Eric, and great-grandmother of Gideon, she lived a full life and enjoyed over 50 years of marital bliss with our father Sherman. Shirley was a graduate of Adelphi University, a great fan of William Shakespeare, and later in life, an accomplished bridge player and talented artist (designing original needlepoint canvases). Her children will miss her irreverent sense of humor and wise counsel. Funeral service will be held Monday, January 17 at 10am at Frank E. Campbell at 81st Street. The family will receive friends and relatives on Monday between 4-8pm at Shirley's residence.

Romulus Linney, a playwright who roved along many intellectual paths, exploring the Southern Appalachian culture of his upbringing, refashioning classical works for modern times and adapting contemporary novels for the stage, died on Saturday at home in Germantown, N.Y. MARX--Helen Zanetti, known to her friends as Noonie, died on January 12, 2011, at home of an ovarian type cancer. She was 72. She confronted her illness with her usual dignity, and grace, and with a strength that may have surprised even her. She never showed a trace of self-pity. Her legendary sense of humor was intact to the end. The last few weeks of her life were peaceful. Her children were with her constantly. It was a time of coming together, a time of understanding, a time of love. Helen Zanetti was born in Bucharest, Romania, on Christmas Eve, 1938, to George (Pearson) and Enrique Carlos Zanetti. Her father, Enrique, was later the Chase Bank representative in Buenos Aires, where the family spent eight years and where Noonie attended the French Lycee. In 1956, she graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, and from Smith College in 1960. An only child, she made many close friends at school and kept them her entire life. She continued to make friends into her seventies, a rare feat. In the 1970s, she co-owned and ran a specialty retail store on Madison Ave., Thaxton & Co., and in 1987 started The Madison Avenue Fund for Children, a resounding charitable success to this day. Noonie was also deeply involved in and on the Board of The Big Sisters, a Catholic charity which started by mentoring girls who came through the New York Children's Court. In 1996 Noonie began a successful publishing career with her imprint, Helen Marx Books, which, in association with Turtle Point Press and Books and Co. made its mark with unusual, original, and distinguished titles, a few of them best-sellers in the small press category. In 2005, Noonie won the prestigious French- American Foundation Translation Prize for the novel Silbermann by Jacques de Lacretelle, wining over an important translation of Marcel Proust's The Guermantes Way. This year, her translation of The Princess, the King, and the Anarchist, which she also published and which has already sold out its run, has again been submitted for the Translation Prize. She was one of the original founders in 1971 of the Proust Group, a reading group now in its fortieth year. She acquired over many years an outstanding collection of American art. She loved music, was an inveterate concert and opera goer, and joined the Board of The Metropolitan Opera Guild in 1990, serving as Vice President from 1994-1996. Her paradise was Paris, a city she had come to love from childhood visits with her grandmother. During her last twenty years she made sure she spent part of each year in Paris, where she did much of her translating and, as usual, added a small army of new friends. A French friend said that Noonie was the only American she had ever known who spoke like a native French-person. She was proud of being able to read her favorite author, Proust, in French. She was a long-time member (57 years) of The Colony Club. She had beauty, a sharp intelligence, and worldliness, but it was her amazing capacity for friendship for which she will be remembered and missed. A truly kind and loving person has gone from our lives, and we will never have another friend like her. She is survived by her children Pearson, Lindsay, Louis, and Geoffrey Marx, her son-in-law Stephen Mark, and her grandsons Cal and Teddy Mailer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Children's Aid Society, 105 E. 22nd St., NY, NY 10010, or The Humane Society, 306 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th St. at Fifth Ave., NY, NY 10128, on Thursday, January 27 at 4pm.

An untested idea -- allowing regular people to create an online encyclopedia -- went live on Jan. 15, 2001, with no fanfare. No one knew whether people would contribute to such a project, and if so, whether the information they submitted would be reliable. Fast forward to today, and that upstart Web site, Wikipedia, is an important source of information for millions of topics. Although it has suffered its share of inaccuracies and hoaxes, it remains among the Internet's most visited sites -- bigger than eBay.

China has established an extra large, extra red beachhead in Times Square. Some of the screens stay red - with Chinese characters in white - while the video is playing on the other screens with images of Chinese celebrities like the martial-arts movie star Jackie Chan; the basketball player Yao Ming; the astronaut Yang Liwei; and the pianists Lang Lang and Yundi. Xinhua said the video would be shown 15 times an hour, 20 hours a day, through Feb. 14, and on CNN through Feb. 13.

The downtown legend glided across the stage in impossibly high heels, opening with his now infamous Billie Holiday number, followed by a lineup of covers that spanned several decades. Who says youth is wasted on the young? Lily Kwong is a 22-year-old sociology and urban studies major at Columbia, who is also a sometime fashion blogger and Elite model. She previously did stints at GQ and as the studio director for her cousin, the emerging designer Joseph Altuzarra, and she also works with her father on Nuvana, a social media and educational gaming company. It makes sense, then, that when she collaborated on a shoot with her photographer friend Elle Muliarchyk, the pair's point of departure was fittingly baroque. "Maybe it's because I had recently been to the Met," Kwong jokes, "but we were inspired by Old Masters paintings - everything from the light to the gestures - and David Lynch movies. We really wanted to marry the two." What, no digital component? "Actually," she says, "it was shot in the apartment of Cindy Gallop, the social entrepreneur behind ifwerantheworld.com."

The winter doldrums have arrived at most of Broadway's box offices, as they usually do this time of year. Many musicals and plays had swaths of empty seats last week, and 19 of the theater district's 40 houses were dark because of shows closing or being on hiatus. Broadway productions grossed a total of $14.9 million last week, compared with $20.8 million the week before and $17.6 million for the comparable week in January 2010. The slowdown in ticket sales traditionally sets in mid-January, with the end of holiday vacations and the resumption of school, and often lasts until the advent of spring vacations and new productions.

At the beginning of December, I checked out the John Dory's new digs. It was 10 p.m. and I was meeting a good friend, who happens to be a chef, for a celebratory dinner - a three-year-long project had finally come to fruition. We were hungry, and we weren't going to settle for anything less than excellence. We pulled up to the actual oyster bar in the back of the boisterous seafood saloon, ordered some champers and perused the menu. Under the "Snacks" heading, I read Carte da Musica. What was that? I asked my pal the chef. She didn't know. So we interrogated one of the able shuckers manning the bivalve station in front of us. The term, he said, refers to an Italian cracker that is named for its resemblance to sheet music (i.e., carte da musica) - it's that thin and delicate. At the John Dory, he followed up, these crackers provide the foundation for a sandwich of butter and bottarga.

The London transit authority reports that rush-hour cycling traffic has doubled on two downtown thoroughfares since the creation of bike-lane "superhighways" on the streets last year. LOS ANGELES- The British Academy of Film and Television Arts, the Old Country version of the Academy, announced its nominees for the Orange British Academy Film Awards on Tuesday morning, and "The Fighter" swept. Nope, not at all. The highest honors went, of course, to "The King's Speech," the most British of films. In a rare accolades-season setback for "The Social Network," it earned only six nominations; "The King's Speech" got 14, including best picture, best actor, best director, best supporting actress and actor, best cinematography, best screenplay, best score and best British film. "Black Swan" also did well, earning 12 nods, and "Inception" received 9. The Bafta winners have coincided with the Oscar best-picture winner four times over the last decade. For the full list of hopefuls, look here. The winners will be announced on Feb. 13 in London.

Juergen Teller has not one but two exhibitions in the German capital these days. "Paradis," at Johann König Galerie in Berlin Kreuzberg, shows large-format prints of a naked Charlotte Rampling with an equally naked Raquel Zimmermann, rambling about the Louvre and posing alongside the Mona Lisa and a marble Napoleon. Originally published in the French magazine Paradis in 2009 and shown at Lehmann Maupin in New York the same year, the images have lost none of their beauty or inherent shock factor. Teller's other, much smaller, show in Berlin is equally revealing. Located in an ingeniously designed third-floor space run by the Berlin-based 032c Magazine, the exhibition comprises new work that Teller has simply called "Men and Women." An image of a naked Vivienne Westwood, broadly grinning and with her legs splayed, presides over the show like a regal cross between Annie Sprinkle and Marie Antoinette, while next to her the photographer William Eggleston, photographed at home in Memphis, and Teller's own 9-year-old son, Ed, photographed in the gym of a hotel in the Maldives, seem goofily adrift. "It's really a show about impotence," remarked a guest at the opening on Saturday night. "In the middle you have Vivienne, all powerful and sexual, and to the left and to the right you have an old man who can't really do it anymore, and a young man who can't do it yet." No word from Teller himself whether he subscribes to the same interpretation - when pressed for a quote during dinner after the opening, Teller simply pointed to a David Hamilton photograph on the wall and said, "I like those breasts."

SEIDEN--Melvin R.,age 80, died of a massive brain hemorrhage on January 14, 2011. The eldest son of Katherine and Murray Seiden, Mel attended schools in New Jersey and graduated from Harvard College (1952) and Harvard Law School (1955). He served in the Navy from 1955-1958 and retired as a Lieutenant. Mel was inspired by the life of Paul J. Sachs who, after a successful career at Goldman Sachs, became an associate director of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard. Mel started in the investment field at Loeb Rhoades & Co. (1958-1961), then founded Seiden & deCuevas (1962-1986). He was chairman of several venture capital funds in the 1970's. Mel was also a trustee of various Merrill Lynch mutual funds and investment companies from 1981-2002, and he was most recently a consultant and director of Edge Management. After retiring from active work in the financial field, he devoted himself to art and philanthropy. As he was colorblind, he developed a special interest in drawings, cartoons (New Yorker) and caricatures (Al Hirschfeld) and most recently illuminated medieval manuscripts, all of which he collected on behalf of institutions. His philanthropic activities were centered at Harvard, including Villa I Tatti, The School of Public Health and various art museums and libraries. He also derived enormous pleasure, and made great friends, at the Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund in Boston where he was a trustee from 2004-2010. His New York philanthropies were centered at The Morgan Library, where he was on several visiting committees; The Frick Collection, where he was a trustee; and The Childrens' Aid Society, where he was also a trustee and helped develop programs to counter obesity and teenage pregnancy. He supported art by financing catalogues and exhibitions around the globe from The Shanghai Art Museum, The Ambrosiana in Milan, the Museums of Scotland, The Albertina in Vienna, British libraries and museums. Mel had an iconoclastic turn of mind, an astonishing memory and delightful wit. He was kind and thoughtful in conversation and a wonderful companion, friend and mentor. In addition to legions of friends, he leaves his wife, Janine Luke, three sisters, numerous nieces and nephews and his devoted associates, Bea Pappagallo and Chiquita Harding, all of whom colored his life and provided love and fun. There will be a Memorial Service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to any of the New York charities listed below would be appreciated: The Childrens' Aid Society, Attn: Richard R. Buery, Jr., 105 East 22nd St., New York, NY 10010; The Frick Collection, Attn: Anne Poulet, 1 East 70th St, New York, NY 10016; The Morgan Library, Attn: William M. Griswold, 225 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10016.

HOROWITZ--Louise, J.D.,Ph.D. The Board of Directors and staff of the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health (MCMH) and the Metropolitan Institute for Training in Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy (MITPP) mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Louise Horowitz, who was a cornerstone of our organizations. Dr. Horowitz, an attorney and former philosophy professor, was President of MCMH for more than 25 years and before that, was President of MITPP. She devoted herself to MCMH tirelessly and gave unstintingly. Her impressive intellect and questioning mind contributed enormously to MCMH's development and growth. We send our deepest condolences to her children and her entire family. She will be missed.

CARPENDALE, Australia -- The smashed remains of Kapernick's Bridge -- with its bent guardrails and a hanging concrete slab where road once was -- are as sure a sign as any that the Lockyer Valley's decade-long drought is finished. Next door, at the vegetable farm of Steve Kluck, the same inland tsunami that last week smashed apart towns and killed more than a dozen people in the northeast Australian state of Queensland left a deep gouge in the earth covering nearly a hectare, or two acres. Water is now plentiful; soil, unfortunately, no longer is.

In 1990, as the AIDS epidemic was gathering strength in Africa, the Tanzanian songwriter, singer, guitarist and bandleader Remmy Ongala released an ebullient dance track called ''Mambo Kwa Soksi'' (''Things With Socks''). Its lyrics called for men to use condoms (''socks'') to prevent AIDS, and it stirred up controversy; Radio Tanzania refused to play it. But it became one of Mr. Ongala's best-known songs in a career as Tanzania's most beloved and influential musician, on and off the dance floor, with songs that had both a groove and a conscience. He sang serious thoughts about poverty, corruption, mortality, faith and Tanzanian pride, and he called his music ''ubongo beat'' -- ''ubongo'' is Swahili for ''brain.''

8 P.M. (TCM) SPOTLIGHT: HAL ROACH STUDIOS They called it ''the lot that laughter built.'' From 1914 to 1960 the Hal Roach Studios set in motion the careers of Laurel and Hardy, Harold Lloyd, Harry Langdon (left) and Our Gang, competing with film industry bigwigs through a prodigious output of comedy shorts, independent features and television series. This monthlong tribute continues with a collection of 10 episodes from the ''Screen Directors Playhouse'' not seen on television since the debut of the series on NBC in the 1955-56 season. The evening's highlight, at 8:30: a new digital video transfer of ''Rookie of the Year'' (1955), directed by John Ford in a rare foray into television and starring John Wayne as an unemployed sportswriter who recognizes a hot young pitcher as the son of a former baseball hero who was banned for throwing a game. The series also features the directors Leo McCarey, H. C. Potter, George Marshall, Ida Lupino, David Butler, Fred Zinnemann and Allan Dwan, and actors including Peter Lawford, Buster Keaton, Peter Lorre, Jeanette MacDonald, Errol Flynn, Ray Milland, Rod Steiger, Angela Lansbury and Dennis Hopper. Ten shorts from the 1920s and '30s, starring Langdon, Our Gang, Charley Chase, Thelma Todd and ZaSu Pitts, will follow at 1 a.m. 7:15 P.M. (Sundance) LADY CHATTERLEY (2006) Marina Hands portrays Lady Constance, the bored young wife charged with caring for the much older Sir Clifford Chatterley (Hippolyte Girardot), who has recently returned to his estate from war paralyzed from the waist down. Jean-Louis Coulloc'h is Parkin, the gamekeeper who brings her to life. Pascale Ferran directed this version, which won César awards for best actress, cinematography, costume design, film and adaptation.

He was a New York City heath inspector, union official and avid photographer. But mostly, a loving family man who will be missed. Services at Gutterman's in Woodbury, L.I., Wednesday at noon.

GALENSON--Eleanor, M.D. died suddenly at home in Manhattan on January 15, 2011 at the age of 94 She practiced psychiatry and psychoanalysis in New York for 65 years, and continued to see patients regularly and to work on new research ideas until her death. A lifelong resident of New York, she was born in the Bronx and graduated from Evander Childs High School at the age of 15. She graduated from Barnard College in 1936 and was one of a handful of women admitted to Columbia University's College of Physicians & Surgeons, from which she received the MD degree in 1940. After medical school she completed an internship at Belleview Hospital and residencies in pediatrics and psychiatry. She went on to train as a psychoanalyst at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, graduating in 1950. She had a distinguished academic career in child psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and at Mount Sinai Hospital, where she was a Professor of Psychiatry until the time of her death. In addition to maintaining a busy practice of child and adult psychiatry and psychoanalysis, Dr. Galenson was a leading researcher on infant and early childhood development and psychiatric disorders, and founded clinics for the treatment of disturbed infants in the Bronx and East Harlem. She was considered a pioneer in the field of infant psychiatry, and co-founded the World Association for Infant Psychiatry (now World Association for Infant Mental Health), which awarded her its highest honor in 1996. Her first husband, Aaron Himmelstein, M.D., who served as the Chief of Cardiac Surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died in 1959. Her third husband, Leonard Weinroth, M.D., died in 1988. She is survived by two adoring sons, Paul R. Himmelstein and David U. Himmelstein, M.D., both of New York; her daughters-in-law Beth Wladis and Steffie Woolhandler; M.D., and two granddaughters Kathryn E. W. Himmelstein and Georgia E. W. Himmelstein who were the light of her life. A memorial will be held on Wednesday, January 19, 2:00pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. Contributions may be made to the Aaron Himmelstein/Eleanor Galenson Scholarship, Fund c/o Ann Viney, Columbia University Medical Center, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY 10029.

WEINTRAUB--George, died on January 14, 2011 at age 89. He is survived by his wife Eve, children Roberta and Jeff, grandchildren Eric, Brian, Michelle, and Jennifer and great-granddaughter Cayla. His eldest son Barry pre-deceased him. Born in the Bronx, New York George was educated in the east before enlisting in the Air Force. He received commendation for his courage during the raids at Anzio and Nettuno beach heads as a member of a fighter control squadron. After the war he began his career in menswear. He worked his way to the top of the men's clothing industry and then made the decision to go into business for himself. George started his own company George Weintraub and Sons along with his sons Barry and Jeff. George was an icon in the menswear business. His unique selling style, unbeatable personality, drive and work ethic earned him a reputation as a leader and entrepreneur. George opened up doors for many young men and women in the industry whom he either mentored or gave opportunities through advancement in his own company. He always had great respect for working people whether they were his customers, picked clothing in his warehouse or were executives in his company. His honesty and business acumen throughout his career was greatly respected. George was very philanthropic giving to a multitude of charities. He was a big advocate of animal causes long before the popularity of animal rights. George's zest and enthusiasm for life made him a magnet for young and old alike. He was loved deeply by family and friends and will be missed by the many people whose lives he touched. Donations in George's memory can be made to a charity of your choice.

After coming back from a two set deficit to force a fifth set, Gilles Simon looked brazenly confident as he outhit Roger Federer from the baseline. He had the tactical hook deep in Federer's side, and the momentum was on his side.

Paris men's week opened today with a relaunch of the Thierry Mugler brand. Immediately obvious from the street scene at the entrance - a horde of excited teenagers clambering to sneak in - was the fact that Paris, unlike Milan, is awash in youth culture. That energy bled onto the runway, where Nicola Formichetti, the creative director behind the relaunch, and Romain Kremer, the new designer of the men's collection, presented their first show. Kremer is a young Parisian known for his futuristic, bright and shiny pieces, and Formichetti is a stylist renowned for his ground-breaking work with young magazines like Dazed and Confused, not to mention his collaborations with Lady Gaga. She created the music for the evening, a new song that can be heard by watching a video of the show, available below. Gaga fans hungering for her latest will ensure that this collection is immediately injected into the pop culture consciousness, regardless of the clothes.

Last month at Design Miami, the Dutch designer Kiki van Eijk showed a collection of seven objects for Venice Projects, an Italian gallery that commissions contemporary artists to work with traditional Venetian glass techniques. The collection is now available at veniceprojects.com. Van Eijk's fanciful, craft-intensive and extravagant objects ("Love," shown here, is $19,200) invest everyday items like a cooking pot or a watering can with emotional resonance by virtue of juxtapositions (a stack of glass pillows topped by an hourglass in "Rest") and color (red for passion in "Love"). Van Eijk and her partner, the designer Joost van Bleiswijk, will also be part of the exhibition "Glasstress 2011," which opens June 3 to coincide with the Venice Biennale.

The nine films that will move on to the next stage of competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film were revealed on Wednesday, and as is typical, there were surprises - and snubs. So were two other films that address cultural conflicts between the West and Islam: Canada's "Incendies" and Denmark's "In a Better World," which won the Golden Globe for best foreign-language film last weekend.

Given recent events it is sometimes easy to forget that there are members of the Sheen family besides Charlie, and that they also live and work and contribute to the artistic community. But there are, and two who have lately avoided the glare of the headlines are collaborating on a memoir. Martin Sheen, the "Apocalypse Now" and "West Wing" star and Sheen family paterfamilias, and his son Emilio Estevez, the "Breakfast Club" actor and "Bobby" director, will write a book called "Along the Way" for the Free Press imprint of Simon & Schuster, the publisher said in a news release. The memoir, which is planned for publication around Father's Day 2012, is said to chronicle the "physical and spiritual journey" of Mr. Sheen and Mr. Estevez, "along the Camino de Santiago, Spain, the 1,000-year-old pilgrimage path, which  traverses Galicia, the area from which Sheen's father emigrated to the U.S., and to which Estevez's own son has returned." The book, written with Hope Edelman, will "celebrate their profound bond, give candid insights into the actors' lives and relationship, examine the triumphs and challenges and inner and outer stages of the journey of a father and son." (It will also discuss "The Way," a coming film directed by Mr. Estevez and starring Mr. Sheen.) (Or as the organization puts it: "um, winner.") It beat out worthwhile contenders like "Sex and the City 2" and "Piranha 3-D." The win was especially notable because Steven Antin, the director of "Burlesque," only recently told the Bagger that he didn't care for the film's reception. "It really wasn't what I was aiming for, the camp," he said of the film starring Cher and Christina Aguilera. "I wanted to make a fun film that was a throwback to Hollywood's golden age of musicals, and people perceived it as camp for obvious reasons. I was surprised it was perceived that way."

It has long been a cliché that muscle bulk doesn't equate to intelligence. In fact, most of the science to date about activity and brain health has focused on the role of endurance exercise in improving our brain functioning. Aerobic exercise causes a steep spike in blood movement to the brain, an action that some researchers have speculated might be necessary for the creation of new brain cells, or neurogenesis. Running and other forms of aerobic exercise have been shown, in mice and men, to lead to neurogenesis in those portions of the brain associated with memory and thinking, providing another compelling reason to get out at lunchtime and run.

SEIDEN--Melvin R.,age 80, died of a massive brain hemorrhage on January 14, 2011. The eldest son of Katherine and Murray Seiden, Mel attended schools in New Jersey and graduated from Harvard College (1952) and Harvard Law School (1955). He served in the Navy from 1955-1958 and retired as a Lieutenant. Mel was inspired by the life of Paul J. Sachs who, after a successful career at Goldman Sachs, became an associate director of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard. Mel started in the investment field at Loeb Rhoades & Co. (1958-1961), then founded Seiden & deCuevas (1962-1986). He was chairman of several venture capital funds in the 1970's. Mel was also a trustee of various Merrill Lynch mutual funds and investment companies from 1981-2002, and he was most recently a consultant and director of Edge Management. After retiring from active work in the financial field, he devoted himself to art and philanthropy. As he was colorblind, he developed a special interest in drawings, cartoons (New Yorker) and caricatures (Al Hirschfeld) and most recently illuminated medieval manuscripts, all of which he collected on behalf of institutions. His philanthropic activities were centered at Harvard, including Villa I Tatti, The School of Public Health and various art museums and libraries. He also derived enormous pleasure, and made great friends, at the Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund in Boston where he was a trustee from 2004-2010. His New York philanthropies were centered at The Morgan Library, where he was on several visiting committees; The Frick Collection, where he was a trustee; and The Childrens' Aid Society, where he was also a trustee and helped develop programs to counter obesity and teenage pregnancy. He supported art by financing catalogues and exhibitions around the globe from The Shanghai Art Museum, The Ambrosiana in Milan, the Museums of Scotland, The Albertina in Vienna, British libraries and museums. Mel had an iconoclastic turn of mind, an astonishing memory and delightful wit. He was kind and thoughtful in conversation and a wonderful companion, friend and mentor. In addition to legions of friends, he leaves his wife, Janine Luke, three sisters, numerous nieces and nephews and his devoted associates, Bea Pappagallo and Chiquita Harding, all of whom colored his life and provided love and fun. There will be a Memorial Service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to any of the New York charities listed below would be appreciated: The Childrens' Aid Society, Attn: Richard R. Buery, Jr., 105 East 22nd St., New York, NY 10010; The Frick Collection, Attn: Anne Poulet, 1 East 70th St, New York, NY 10016; The Morgan Library, Attn: William M. Griswold, 225 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10016.

Market analysts contend that these businesses are too diverse and that separating them will allow the market to fully recognize each company's inherent value. The real question, though, is whether this will really create that extra value. Can one plus one equal more than two, or is this is yet another Wall Street fad?

HOROWITZ--Dr. Louise S.,78, died peacefully at home on January 14, 2011, comforted by the constant attention of her children and close friends. Born January 24, 1932 to Charles Schwartz and Bertie Grad Schwartz, Louise graduated from Fieldston High School in 1950. She attended Smith College until her marriage to David Horowitz in 1951, and then transferred to Barnard College where she received her bachelor's degree with distinction in 1954. Louise's inquiring mind and critical skills drew her to pursue graduate work in philosophy at Columbia University. Continuing her studies while raising three children, Louise received her Ph.D. degree in 1969. She joined the faculty of Long Island University's Brooklyn Campus, where she specialized in teaching Philosophy of Art and, her personal favorite, Oriental Philosophy. Highly respected among students, Louise was the campus Women's Liberation Club advisor and was frequently asked to serve as a faculty chaperon for bus trips to Washington, D.C. anti-war demonstrations. Divorced in 1972, she soon met Alton Johnson, with whom she lived until his death in 2001. In 1977 Louise left teaching to enter New York Law School, where she graduated cum laude with her J.D. degree in 1981. She practiced law until shortly before her death, specializing in civil and commercial litigation in state and federal courts. With a lifelong interest in art, music, and the theater, Louise also was a painter and frequently attended opera, ballet, and dance performances. Committed to public service, she served for many years on the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health board, including president from 1984 to 2010, and as a member of the New York Public Library Board of Trustees from 1978 to 1984. Fervent in her opinions and always loving a good argument, Louise is remembered by her friends and family for her intellect, charm, and eminent hospitality. She is survived by her brother Ernest Schwartz, children Marilyn, Roger, and Diana, and grandchildren Jason and Lucy Horowitz and Andrew Hendrix. A memorial service to remember her life will take place on Monday, January 17, 9:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. To recognize Louise's deep love for her home on Shelter Island, the family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent in her name to the Mashomack Preserve, PO Box 850, Shelter Island, NY 11964.

Comerica agreed on Tuesday to buy Sterling Bancshares, a bank holding company based in Houston, for $1 billion. The all-stock deal, which will help expand Comerica's footprint in the Texas market, values Sterling at $10 a share. That represents a nearly 30 percent premium to the closing price on Jan. 14.

Yum Brands, which has been prospering abroad, announced on Monday that it planned to sell a pair of domestic-focused businesses, Long John Silver's and A&W All-American Food. In recent years, Yum, a fast-food purveyor best known for its KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut franchises, has been increasing its focus on China and other fast-growing foreign countries. International markets now account for 65 percent of its profit, up from about a third in 2002.

Mark Twain observed: ''One speaks of french vivacity and german gravity and english stubbornness. Th ere is no american temperament. The nearest that one can come at it is to say there are two -- the composed northern and the impetuous southern; and both are found in other countries.'' (The only unifying American characteristic, according to Twain, was ''the national devotion to ice water.'') With Twain's words in mind, we present a glossary of arcane national caricatures from writers curiously fascinated with difference.

Lyon A Manhattan take on a bouchon, itself a Lyonnaise take on a bistro. It serves the salads and snails and sticky bits of pork and beef that are requisite to Lyonnaise cuisine in a beautiful wooden room under yellow light. The space is beautiful. Roman and Williams, the firm that designed the room, ordered oak panels and detailed trim throughout the dining room, which runs along Greenwich Avenue, and placed enough inset slate boards and custom cabinets within them to have kept a finish carpenter in health insurance for months. The restrooms, downstairs, are papered with classic French cartoons. And Chris Leahy, the chef, shows real talent with soup and salad, not to mention charcuterie. Entrees are weak, with the exception of a lamb shank and some pig trotters, but if roast chicken or steak frites ever arrive on the menu, Lyon could have a nice little West Village run. SAM SIFTON

CHICAGO - As the race for mayor of this city has intensified, the usual low-key announcements of endorsements - from various business leaders, preachers and members of Congress from Chicago - have churned forth. Then came Rahm Emanuel, who on Tuesday raised the ante a bit when it came to endorsers (the campaign equivalent of show-and-tell), standing on a stage beside his old boss, former President Bill Clinton. While 700 admirers (with free tickets) watched inside the Chicago Cultural Center in the heart of downtown, Mr. Emanuel praised Mr. Clinton as a mentor, a teacher, an inspiration, a role model and a ''great president for our nation.'' Mr. Clinton, in turn, lauded Mr. Emanuel as someone who ''was always fearlessly honest'' with him, and who had the backbone to lead Chicago, particularly through times of such fiscal challenges.

8:39 p.m. | Updated Cargill said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its 64 percent stake in the Mosaic Company, a big producer of important ingredients in fertilizer, leaving Mosaic open for a possible sale at a time when mining and agriculture giants are on the prowl for acquisitions. The complicated tax-free transaction - worth more than $24 billion - will also help keep Cargill, one of the biggest American companies, private. Cargill will distribute its 286 million Mosaic shares to its own shareholders and debtholders.

ADAMS--F. Gerard (Jerry) 81, prominent economist who spent the bulk of his career at the University of Pennsylvania, died Saturday, January 15 in Newton, MA of complications related to pancreatic cancer. He was the author of a substantial body of research over a distinguished career. After spending 37 years at the University of Pennsylvania, he moved to Northeastern University in Boston. He completed his final teaching assignment there this last December, 2010. Prof. Adams was born in Breslau in 1929. His family emigrated to the United States in 1939. He attended the University of Michigan, receiving an undergraduate degree in 1949 and then continuing on to obtain a Ph.D. in 1956 under the supervision of Lawrence Klein, who subsequently went on to win the Nobel Prize in Economics. In 1961, he joined Klein, who had moved to the University of Pennsylvania, where he remained until 1998. He helped Klein to create the Wharton Model, one of the first econometric forecasting models using computers to simulate the world economy. It subsequently grew into the Link Model, which forecasts the economy using a variety of input data from smaller models around the world, and which contributed to Klein's Nobel Prize in 1980. Prof. Adams served as the director of the Economics Research Unit at the University of Pennsylvania and a principal investigator on the Link Model. Together with Klein, he was one of the founding members of Wharton Economic Forecasting Associates. He was the author of over 250 research articles and over a dozen books, including "The Business Forecasting Revolution," "East Asian Development: Will the East Asian Growth Miracle Survive?," "Macroeconomics for Business and Society," "The E-Business and the New Economy," and "East Asia and the New Economy." He submitted the manuscript for his newest book "Globalization and the New Economy" in December. Prof. Adams is survived by his wife Heidi Vernon, his brothers Peter Adams and Robert Adams, his four children Leslie Martin, Colin Adams, Loren Burton, and Mark Adams, his stepchildren Joshua Wortzel and Jennifer Stiller, his ten grandchildren, and his cats Minou and Maomi, all of whom will miss him greatly. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Adams Prize of the Economics Department at Swarthmore College, 500 College Ave., Swarthmore, PA 19081-1397.

8:15 P.M. (Sundance) WOMEN WITHOUT MEN (2009) The visual artist Shirin Neshat is celebrated for her explorations of women's lives in Islamic societies. In this, her directorial debut, she follows four Iranian women from different classes and backgrounds during August 1953, when elements in favor of the monarchy ousted Mohammed Mossadegh and his democratically elected government and restored Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi to power, with the help of clandestine support from Britain and the United States. Zarin (Orsi Toth) is an emancipated prostitute who has fled her brothel for refuge at a public bath; Munis (Shabnam Tolouei, above) is a virtual prisoner in the house she shares with her fundamentalist brother, whom the religiously devout Faezeh (Pegah Ferydoni) secretly longs to marry; and Fakhri (Arita Shahrzad), a wealthy 50-year-old, is suffering in an unhappy marriage to a general who reviles her for being menopausal. ''This visually transfixing film, which originated as a video installation, has the feel of an exhibition of Ms. Neshat's work whose figures have stirred to life to play out a tragic feminist allegory,'' Stephen Holden wrote in his review in The New York Times. The film is loosely adapted from a novel by Shahrnush Parsipur, who appears briefly as the bossy madam of the brothel. 8 P.M. The top official of the Smithsonian, G. Wayne Clough, who has been sharply criticized for his decision late last year to remove a video from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, defended that decision in a telephone interview on Tuesday morning. He said it was in the interest of protecting the exhibition as a whole, as well as protecting the Smithsonian's larger educational mission and its ability to make a strong case to Congress for federal support. He called the decision ''painful'' and acknowledged that he wished he had taken more time and consulted with more art museum directors within the Smithsonian. But ''in the interest of that exhibition and this institution and its legacy and maintaining it in the strongest possible position, I think I made the right decision - in that context,'' he said. ''I'll let the art world debate it in another context.''

EVANS--Edward P.,died peacefully on December 31, 2010. Ned was born in Pittsburgh, PA on January 31, 1942 to Thomas Mellon Evans and Elizabeth Park Evans Kase. He is survived by two brothers Thomas M. Evans, Jr. and Robert S. Evans, his niece, Ashley Evans and his nephews Jonathan Evans, Thomas M. Evans, III and Mark Johnson Evans. Ned graduated from Yale University in 1964 and earned an MBA from Harvard Business School in 1967. He had a long and successful business career beginning in 1968, holding executive positions with a number of family businesses. In 1980, Ned became Chairman and CEO of MacMillian, Inc. Beginning in 1988, he became involved with personal business interests and investments including breeding and racing thoroughbred horses. Ned was also known as a generous philanthropist. He formed the Edward P. Evans Foundation and contributed to a number of charitable organizations in various fields throughout the United States. Most recently, he made a gift to the Yale School of Management that will allow Yale to begin the construction of the new unified campus and building for the Yale School of Management. The building will be known as Edward P. Evans Hall. Mr. Evans' greatest joy was racing thoroughbred horses and breeding thoroughbreds at his farm in Casanova, Virginia known as Spring Hill Farm. He bred over 100 stakes winners and as of his death was the 4th leading breeder and 7th leading owner in North America. Ned was consistently named as one of the Top 10 breeders in North America. His horse Quality Road was one of the favorites for the 2009 Kentucky Derby and won or placed in 12 out of 13 starts. Quality Road was injured before the 2009 Derby and was unable to compete in any of the Triple Crown races in that year. The Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association named Ned the Virginia Breeder of the Year nine times, most recently in 2009, and the National Breeder of the Year in 2009. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation, 100 Park Avenue, Suite 108, Rockville, MD 20850.

When he leaves home to make his way around the city, Martin Greeenberg wears a badge. It's the simplest way to let other pedestrians know he is both deaf and blind. Mr. Greenberg, 58, works as an accountant and teaches American Sign Language classes. He was born and raised in New York City, and has fond childhood memories of the subway - rush hour and the underground lights. In his mind, the trains represented freedom. After he lost his sight at 26 to retinitis pigmentosa, however, the world underground world became much more challenging. Today, he discerns the world as if through a bright fog. While he enjoys dining out with friends, he often feels scared, lonely and isolated when night falls. Summer daylight - though brighter and longer - is harder on his eyes.

In the Broadway musical ''American Idiot,'' the character of St. Jimmy is a wild force of nature who thrashes around the stage like an adrenaline-charged rock star - which is partly why the role has suited Billie Joe Armstrong, the front man of the punk rock band Green Day, who is playing the part off and on this winter (and whose band's music provides the show's score). Now the producers are going to give another rocker a try at St. Jimmy: Melissa Etheridge will take over the role for one week, Feb. 1 to 6, in between Mr. Armstrong's appearances Tuesday to Jan. 30 and Feb. 10 to 27. The director, Michael Mayer, who also wrote the book of the show with Mr. Armstrong, said in a statement: ''Billie Joe and I always believed that it would be incredible to have a woman take on the role of St. Jimmy. This character is seductive, thrilling and dangerous. Melissa Etheridge is all that and so much more.''

LUDWIG--Robert J.,of Schenectady, NY passed away on January 18, 2011 in his 92nd year. Predeceased by his beloved wife Dorothy in 1986. Survived by his loving brother Bert and his wife Phyllis. Served devotedly by his assistant, Lucas Pearson. Admired and respected by all who knew him for his outstanding efforts as a volunteer and fundraiser for so many humanitarian causes and for his own steadfast and generous philanthropic support for them. Graduate of Colombia University (BS/MA) and Western Reserve University (School of Applied Social Sciences). A WWII Veteran with four years of service in the South Pacific as a Master Sergeant in the US Army. An inspiring educator with 39 years of service in the Schenectady, NY Public Schools, first as a teacher of French and later as the Supervisor of Foreign Languages for the school district. Named as New York State teacher of the year in 1975, honored three times by the French government, receiving the highest rank of commandeur for his efforts to expand French language and culture in the world. 32 years of service as a member, past President and officer for the New York State Association of Foreign Language Teachers, past President of the Countrywide American Council of Foreign Language Teachers, the New York State Alliance for Art Education, and the New York State Council of Educational Associations. Extremely Active in his efforts for the community, serving as President of the United Jewish Federation of Northeastern New York, the Schenectady Interface Community, and the Haven Grief Counseling Center, and the honorary VP of Temple Gates of Heaven and Chair of the Board of Advisors, Chairman of the Joint Committee of Christians and Jews and devoted volunteer and Board Member of the United Way for the Greater Capital Region. He was the proud sponsor of the Robert and Dorothy Ludwig Jewish Community Center of Schenectady. "His life was gentle, and the elements/So mix'd in him, the Nature might stand up/And say to all the world, 'This was a man!" Please call 800-427-0280 for date of funeral services.

The opening this week of a new gallery in Midtown has generated unusual confusion in the worlds of art and fashion. Because the gallery's name is fordProject, it has been promoted as a division of Ford Models, and many of us who have seen fashion climb on the back of art - and vice versa - to broaden its audience naturally assumed that the gallery was an offshoot of the agency.

When his wife, Stefanie Graf, was inducted into the International Hall of Fame in 2004, Andre Agassi gave a memorable, emotional speech introducing her, giving himself a tough act to follow now that he has been inducted himself.

Men's fashion owes a lot to uniforms, military and civilian, and contemporary designers seem to love both the traditions as well as the sense of heroism. Dries Van Noten presented his fall collection on Thursday night in a sculpture museum, where the figures were suitably larger than life. White cotton trousers, peacoats with rough fur-trimmed lapels, and chunky fisherman sweaters alluded to the sea, while wide-leg flannel suits and top coats pointed to an elegant urban uniform.

The Palestinian Authority refused to grant permission for a rally to celebrate the overthrow of Tunisia's authoritarian president on Wednesday in Ramallah, the administrative capital of the West Bank.

Gail Collins, who has known Joe Lieberman since he was a local politician in Connecticut, ends her column about his decision not to seek re-election with a threat to write a book entitled, "Everything Bad Is Joe Lieberman's Fault."

JPMorgan Chase said on Thursday that it had hired James C. Woolery, one of the top deal lawyers at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, as one of its senior mergers bankers, marking the latest big shift by a lawyer into banking.

Who Took $1 Billion Out of Man? Man Group, the publicly traded London-based hedge fund giant, disclosed on Thursday that a single investor withdrew $1 billion. The client, who was not identified, did not want to be exposed to European stocks any longer, the company said. Still, Man did not seem too concerned, noting that the money was in long-only funds, "a very low margin" business for the company. Bloomberg News

Covington & Burling, one of Washington's blue-chip law firms, has signed on to represent Alassane Ouattara, the former Ivory Coast prime minister, in his widely supported effort to claim the west African nation's disputed presidency.

Malynda Vigliotti opened her waxing salon, the Boom Boom Brow Bar, in the spring of 2008, the same week the financial markets began their drastic downturn. And her potential customers, a species of well-maintained New Yorkers who operate under a "No Follicle Left Behind" edict, stayed home.

The notable exception is "American Idiot," which received a heady injection of pop excitement this month with the return of Green Day front man Billie Joe Armstrong to the role of St. Jimmy. (Of course, rumor has it there's a score for some new show by a rock band called U2, but I haven't heard a lick of it yet. Some distant day, perhaps.)

Sarah Palin may be inching toward a presidential run in 2012 as she heads next week to Nevada for two speeches and her advisers quietly begin talking to Republican activists in Iowa.
In a surprise announcement on Thursday, Google said that one of its co-founders, Larry Page, will become its chief executive on April 4, taking over for Eric E. Schmidt.

Hewlett-Packard announced Thursday afternoon that it was adding five new members to its board, including Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay and most recently the unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor of California. But four other board members will not stand for re-election.

Think of all those empty seats in cars headed to school or work in cities around the world. The idea that filling them is a communal good goes back at least to World War II, when the Office of Price Administration put out a poster proclaiming, "When You Ride ALONE You Ride With Hitler!"

Ian McEwan, the author of "Amsterdam," "Atonement" and "Saturday," among other books, is the 2011 winner of the Jerusalem Prize, Israel's highest literary award for foreigners. The award, $10,000, is granted every other year during the Jerusalem International Book Fair, and will be given to him on Feb. 20th. The prize has gone to authors including Bertrand Russell, Susan Sontag, Milan Kundera, Mario Vargas Llosa and Haruki Murakami. It honors writers whose work "promotes the idea of freedom of the individual in society."

Stanford Makishi will step down as executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Feb. 28, the center said on Thursday. Mr. Makishi, 45, a Harvard-educated former dancer, has held the post for three years, serving as the right-hand man of Mikhail Baryshnikov, the founder and artistic director.

The Environmental Protection Agency and the Chrysler Group announced on Wednesday that they would work together to develop a light-duty hydraulic hybrid vehicle. Current plans call for the system to be installed in the Chrysler Town & Country minivan.
Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

Taking a page from the solar industry, Bloom Energy on Thursday unveiled a service to allow customers to buy the electricity generated by its fuel cells without incurring the capital costs of purchasing the six-figure devices.

Sales of digital music now account for 29 percent of record companies' global revenue, but digital growth is slowing even as new online services continue to proliferate throughout the world, according a new report by the music industry's international trade group.

Louis Vuitton will open a new store in Place Vendôme sometime soon. That made me breathe a sigh of relief. Its latest men's collection, designed by Paul Helbers and shown at the start of the Paris fall collections this week, may look austerity-minded in its drab tones and dense layers, but we all know the customer for this kind of deluxe understatement isn't affected by the European Union's troubles, though maybe that's an optimistic statement.
Here's one way to save on gym costs: set up your own home gym filled with used equipment bought from Craigslist.

Last week, I wrote a post featuring a small-business owner, Ann Price, whose restaurant in Atlanta has been getting lots of press. Unfortunately, the attention has been focused less on the quality of her food and more on the fact that no one wants to buy her business.

Danielle Chiesi's guilty plea to three counts of conspiracy to commit insider trading leaves the Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, as the last of the seven defendants from this case fighting the government's charges. His trial is scheduled to start on Feb. 28 and the deal with Ms. Chiesi shows that prosecutors are taking a hard line that may make any offer to resolve the case unacceptable to him.

The fashions shown during the recently concluded Milan fall/winter 2011 collections were, in a word, manly. Front and center was the re-emergence of the strong shoulder in coats and suits with bold, masculine shapes. Hunting-inspired gear like quilted pants and jackets, tartan plaid flannels and long johns aplenty were trotted down sometimes rain-soaked, sometimes snow-covered catwalks. And those hats! Proper felt hats, not those stingy-brimmed "Mad Men" fedoras but full-on felt hats, with true grit, just like the clothes.
Shares in the American International Group plunged more than 14 percent on Thursday, hitting $43.80 in midafternoon trading.

This is how Broadway works nowadays: Lincoln Center Theater producers have a new critically acclaimed play, "Other Desert Cities," in their Off Broadway space, the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. The producers want to capitalize on the strong reviews and transfer the play this spring to a Broadway house, where visibility will be far greater, more money stands be made, and Tony Awards are a possibility. (Off Broadway shows don't qualify for Tonys.) But at this point Lincoln Center Theater will have to wait until the fall of 2011 to transfer the play, rather than this spring, because the 40 Broadway houses are all booked, according to executives involved with the transfer discussions.

Two Grand Slam champions square off in a marquee third-round match today in the Rod Laver Arena. Justine Henin, whose sterling play so far suggests that her elbow woes are behind her, faces Svetlana Kuznetsova in a match that could easily be a semifinal.

Even though Congress's first order of business under Republican control was Wednesday's vote to repeal the health care law, most Americans said that they do not understand how the law affects them, and the public thinks job creation rather than health care should be the top priority for Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

One of the big questions lingering in the wake of the news that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPhone is how the smaller wireless carriers in the United States, like Sprint and T-Mobile, will fare without it.

Though the Caten brother duo surprised critics by going back to black, it was Alessandro Sartori who proved through his non-flannel suits for the experimental line of the 100-year-old Ermengildo Zegna men's fashion empire that the presence of the past can be felt in techno tailoring.

The NBC small-town comedy "Parks and Recreation" returns for its third season on Thursday night after a long break. NBC opted to hold the comedy out of its fall lineup, which struck some as a puzzling choice for a show that was just starting to gain momentum in its second season.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics is out with a new report today showing that pay trends in 2010 were not as good as they had been in 2009. In 2009, real weekly pay had risen for every educational group -- high-school dropouts, high-school graduates, people with some college and four-year college graduates. In 2010, pay fell for every group.

Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group announced this month that it would ban smoking for travelers renting cars at all United States Dollar and Thrifty corporate-owned locations and participating franchise locations.

Probably every plus-size woman has a story like Helen's in the Neil LaBute play "Fat Pig," says the actress Heather Jane Rolff. Helen is courted by another character, Tom, who is much thinner, only to have their deepening relationship founder because he can't man up with his friends, who mock her for being overweight. Ms. Rolff's variation on such ugly reality involved arriving to perform at a dance recital at age 13, only to be told by her instructor, "You look fat in that costume, and I'm not allowing you to go onstage."

In some ways, a Rick Owens show changes little from season to season, and you'll occasionally hear grumblings of this from editors. But then, men change their style little from season to season anyway. And Owens does have a distinct idea that he constantly pushes further along. One significant aspect of that idea is the dropped, skirtlike waistline - often created with multiple draped layers of fabric. Occasionally an actual skirt appears, but usually some variation of a long shirt hem shows below the bottom edge of a suit jacket. Sometimes it just shows in the back, approximating the visual effect of wearing a shirt tied around the waist - an easy jumping off point for understanding how a skirt can look masculine on a guy.

SAN FRANCISCO- You know a film is a front-runner when the charges of smear campaigns begin. The latest victim? "The King's Speech," the subject of an email circulated a few weeks ago in which the writer claims the film is losing Academy voters because of its subject's apparent anti-Semitic and pro-Nazi proclivities. The email, from a person who claimed Academy membership, was sent last month to the blogger Scott Feinberg, who published it after checking its sources, which ultimately led back to a 2002 article in The Guardian. (Mr. Feinberg was unable to determine if the letter writer was in fact an Academy member.)

BAGHDAD - Jubilant Iraqi soccer fans ignored government orders and lit up the Baghdad night sky with gunshots on Wednesday, after the national team beat North Korea 1-0 in the Asian Cup tournament to qualify for the quarterfinals.

The auto industry recalled about 20.3 million vehicles last year, and three of the five automakers with the most recalls were Japanese, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Wednesday.

Lieberman.Mr. Murphy emerged from an already crowded field of possible candidates in both parties who are giving thought to entering the race to replace Mr. Lieberman, an independent who on Wednesday formally announced his plans to retire when his term ends in January 2013.

On Wednesday, I mentioned the idea of "short-time" work policies, in which workers and companies avoid layoffs during tough times by cutting everyone's work hours. Alex Keyssar, author of one of the definitive histories of unemployment, points out that the debate over short-time work is nothing new.
