The 42nd edition of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival will take place over two weekends this spring, from April 29 to May 1 and May 5 to 8, and its lineup continues a long trend toward ever-more-mainstream rock and pop. The headliners include Bon Jovi, Kid Rock, Arcade Fire, Jimmy Buffett, John Mellencamp, Tom Jones, Wilco, the Strokes, Robert Plant and John Legend and the Roots, festival organizers announced on Thursday.

Technology can make it easier for people to connect with others, but it can also take a toll on relationships. On this week's Tech Talk show, J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Sherry Turkle, a professor at M.I.T. whose new book is "Alone Together: Why We Expect More From Technology and Less From Each Other." Ms. Turkle, the founder and director of the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and the Self, says that hyperconnectivity can make people feel lonely.

In what could be a breakthrough for the next phase of digital music, Sony Music Entertainment has signed a deal with Spotify, a sleek British online service, for distribution in the United States. Spotify, which streams music and has a smartphone app, has been a hit in Europe but its move across the Atlantic has been long delayed. Sony is the first major label group to sign for American distribution.

It's hard to find projections for both global energy demand and emissions of carbon dioxide from fuel burning that don't have a sustained upward trajectory for decades to come. The latest such forecasts were issued on Wednesday by Exxon Mobil, at the World Future Energy Summit in Abu Dhabi, and by BP. I'll focus more on the BP report because it's posted online, while Exxon's is still awaiting publication.

Ron Franklin, the sportscaster fired last month by ESPN for remarks he made to a sideline reporter in a hotel lobby before the Chick-fil-A Bowl, filed a wrongful termination lawsuit in a Texas county court Wednesday saying that he could be dismissed only for a "failure to perform" his job.

Over the course of their more than 50-year design partnership, Evelyn and Jerome Ackerman created ceramics, tiles, wood carvings and textiles (among many other design items for the home) that helped shape what we now know as midcentury California modernism. While many of us grew up with the Ackermans' work, the couple was less well known (although no less productive) than their contemporaries Charles and Ray Eames. The Ackermans and their work will be celebrated when a long-overdue retrospective, featuring more than 200 examples of their work, opens on Jan. 23 at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Even in ordinary circumstances, the failure of France's "Of Gods and Men" to make the Oscar shortlist for best-foreign language film announced Wednesday would have been controversial, especially in France. The film received rapturous reviews there, was a box office success and has won numerous awards, including that of best foreign-language film of 2010 as voted by the National Board of Review in the United States. "Grand prize winner at the last Cannes festival, Xavier Beauvois's 'Of Gods and Men' doesn't even qualify for the preliminary list," was the incredulous reaction of the magazine Paris Match on its Web site.

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. Sarah Palin's infamous $150,000 shopping spree during the last presidential elections underscored the fact that in politics, a woman's wardrobe can all too easily eclipse her ideology. Whether she's working a trailer park-friendly plaid shirt at a campaign stop or an ethereal Dior gown at a state dinner, there is no escaping sartorial scrutiny.

SAN FRANCISCO- For those still wondering about the legitimacy of the Banksy film "Exit Through the Gift Shop," the Cinema Eye documentary award the film just won might help. The pseudonymous British artist even worked up an acceptance speech for the ceremony - although Banksy did not, of course, turn up to read it. That fell to the movie's producer, Jaimie D'Cruz. Might have been a good thing, too, as Banksy went a little Gervais in mocking his fellow filmmakers.

Yesterday I posted a brief note about how to think about the 2000-2007 expansion, now that we know that there was an unsustainable housing-and-debt bubble. My point was that this doesn't mean that the growth was somehow fake; real output of goods and services did indeed rise, even if the legacy of that growth was debt that create macroeconomic problems now.

I'm a big fan of Yankee Candle--my favorites include Christmas Cupcake and Fluffy Towels-but ScentScape might be a smell too far for me. For $70, Scent Sciences, a San Jose, Calif.-based company that displayed this goodie at CES last week, will sell you the ScentScape, a plug-and-play-and-smell gadget that connects via a USB port to a Windows computer and can be programmed to emit up to 20 scents (not at the same time, I'm told): chocolate, a forest, an ocean, a cinnamon bun, turkey dinner. Unfortunately, no inclusion (yet) of the fried clams at the Hingham Lobster Pound near Boston.

MURRAY--Gordon Stewart. On January 15, 2011. Beloved husband of Randi Glass Murray, loving father of Sam Murray and Ben Murray. Devoted son of Ursula Koerber, the late Gordon C. Murray and Louis Koerber. Cherished brother of Norma and Ken Iglehart, Gillian and Bryan Koerber; son-in-law of Barry Glass, the late Shirley Glass and Sandra Glass. Beloved brother-in-law of Karen Glass, Ira Glass and Anaheed Alani. Gordon is also pre-deceased by his grandparents Ruby and Reginald Stewart, and Edward and Norma Murray. Gordon grew up in Baltimore, MD. He worked for 25 years in the securities business in senior management positions at Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Credit Suisse First Boston (CSFB). After retiring from CSFB in 2001, Gordon worked as a consultant with Dimensional Fund Advisors. After Gordon was diagnosed with glioblastoma he dedicated himself with even more passion to issues of financial reform and investor education. In 2010, after a recurrence of brain cancer, Gordon collaborated with his friend Dan Goldie to write a groundbreaking book "The Investment Answer," published by Business Plus, an imprint of Grand Central Publishing. Gordon was known for his integrity, passion, deep and abiding friendships, and his sense of humor, which frequently involved practical jokes and prank phone calls. He loved his family, friends, his yoga practice, and playing tennis and bridge. Gordon's indomitable spirit was never in greater evidence than during his two-year battle with cancer. At Gordon's request there will be no memorial or funeral service. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gordon's name can be made to these charities: UCSF Foundation in honor of Gordon Murray, c/o Erin Hickey, 220 Montgomery Street, Fifth Floor, San Francisco, CA 94104; The Gordon Murray Memorial Fund c/o UC Berkeley Foundation/Cal Parents Fund, 2080 Addison Street 4200, Berkeley CA 94720-4200; or The Fibrolamellar Cancer Foundation in honor of Gordon Murray and Tucker Davis, 20 Horseneck Lane, 2nd Floor, Greenwich, CT 06830.

LONDON - In the energy business, companies usually think big. But for a cross-border, multibillion-dollar deal, BP went small, selecting a little-known boutique firm as its sole adviser. Philip S. O. Lambert, a former investment banker, and his firm, Lambert Energy Advisory of London, advised BP on a partnership with Rosneft of Russia to explore the Russian Arctic. The deal, which was announced on Friday, includes a share swap agreement between the companies worth about $7.8 billion.

A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about a warning to the Atlanta school system that it could lose its accreditation referred incorrectly to the terms of a probation set by the accrediting agency AdvancED. The probation affects only high schools in Atlanta, not the entire school system. And the report, using information from a spokeswoman for AdvancED, misstated the significance of the probation. It is the second largest system -- not the largest -- that the agency has taken action against.

Offering cinephiles just a taste of the full range of offerings in the annual New Directors/New Films series, the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday announced the first batch of movies in this year's festival, six international offerings from Europe, Canada, Mexico and China. The lineup includes Denis Villeneuve's new film ''Incendies,'' about twins grieving for their dead mother who learn that their father is still alive and that they have a missing brother; the dark family comedy-drama ''Curling,'' from the Canadian director Denis Cote (''All That She Wants''); ''At Ellen's Age,'' from the German director Pia Marais (''The Unpolished''), about a woman who joins a group of animal activists after losing her job and learning her husband has been unfaithful to her; ''Summer of Goliath,'' by the Mexican director Nicolas Pereda, a mix of fiction and documentary about the people of a rural Mexican town; and the Chinese comedy ''Winter Vacation,'' by the director Hongqi Li, about four teenagers preparing to return to school.

The ailing Brooklyn Philharmonic is hanging in there. Having halted most of its orchestra concerts over the last two seasons and cut staff because of money problems, it said on Wednesday that it had hired a new artistic director, Alan Pierson, and promised a ''new era.'' Mr. Pierson is the artistic director and conductor of the contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound. An earlier version of this post, and its headline, misstated Mr. Pierson's new title. It is not music director.

Amber Doyle and Jake Mueser, graduates of the Fashion Institute of Technology, have opened up their second shop, Doyle Mueser, in the West Village at 19 Christopher Street; (347) 982-4382, doylemueser.com. The design duo (pictured wearing their creations) specialize in bespoke suits including tweeds and pinstripes, in styles including power suits and British eccentric ($3,250 to $6,000). Off-the-rack suits are measured to fit ($2,700). Ties are made in England ($175). Their first store, Against Nature, is on the Lower East Side at 159 Chrystie Street.

His long, full life serves as an example to many and he will be missed by all who had the honor of working with him. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his children and their families.

BRUSSELS -- The European Commission suspended trading in greenhouse gas emissions permits on Wednesday for at least a week after the theft of permits worth millions of euros via online attacks. The Emissions Trading System was a target of ''recurring security breaches'' over the last two months, the commission, the executive agency of the European Union, announced on its Web site Wednesday.

EISEMAN--Harriet. The partners, attorneys and staff of Golenbock Eiseman Assor Bell & Peskoe LLP acknowledge with great sorrow the passing of Harriet Eiseman, beloved mother of our founding partner, David J. Eiseman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Marvin, her three sons, David, Marc and Jonathan, her daughters-in-law, Gloria, Ellori and Robin, her seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Harriet Eiseman set an unparalleled example of devotion to her family and her community. Her legacy is proudly continued by her children through the family's continued involvement in Jewish life and learning.

In November 2009, we ran an article that explored the difficult economics of opening a cupcake shop, and we asked this question: Are cupcakes a viable business? This week we got an answer -- at least for one cupcake chain, Crumbs Bake Shop. Crumbs, which is based in New York, announced plans to go public in a $66 million deal. It claimed 2010 revenue of $31.1 million with earnings of close to $2 million. When we first asked about the viability of cupcake businesses, we received more than 100 comments offering wildly divergent opinions. What do you think now? What, if anything, does Crumbs's success suggest about the cupcake business?

SCOTT--David E.,husband of Deborah Scott and father of Kendall, Lyric and Mattox died suddenly at the age 53 on January 15, 2011. Formerly in Senior Management at Colgate, was a co-founder and built EPAM Systems, which designed software systems globally, that grew into an internationally recognized organization. Visitation will be on Friday, January 21, 2011, from 5-9pm at the Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, 323 E. Washington Ave., Newtown, PA 18940. Memorial Services will be held on Saturday, January 22, 2011, at 10:30am Grace Point Church, 592 Washington Crossing Road in Newtown with a visitation from 9:30- 10:30am at the church. Memorial donations can be made to Upper Makefield Fire Company, P.O. 125, Washington Crossing, PA 18977.

SMITH--John McNeill, Jr. Defender of civil rights, died, at 92, on January 15, 2011. A service will be held at West Market Street United Methodist Church, Greensboro, N.C., on January 22, 2011, at 2pm. McNeill Smith graduated from UNC-CH in 1938 and Columbia University School of Law in 1941. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1945 and practiced law in Greensboro, NC, with the law firm known now as Smith Moore Leatherwood LLP. An obituary published on January 17, 2011, is available at www.news-record.com.

EISEMAN--Harriet. Died on January 18, 2011, after a marriage of 62 years to her loving husband, Marvin. She was the devoted mother of David, Marc and Jonathan, loyal sister to Florence and Annette, adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. She was the matriarch of a large and loving family and will be profoundly missed by them and her many friends.

Executive Limousine operates a fleet that includes town cars, stretch limos and party buses. The company, which is based in Bellmore, N.Y., offers travel options that range from airport transportation to bachelor parties and winery tours. Like many businesses that went online years ago, it began with modest expectations. ''We launched our first Web site about 11 years ago,'' said Douglas Schwartz, the company president, ''and for the first six or seven, I thought the Web site was an online brochure for us to send clients to. I held on to the original Web site for years thinking it was great; boy, was I a fool!''

A brief update on the juvenile red-tailed hawk that smashed into a window in the glass-walled courtyard of The New York Times Building last week: An X-ray showed that his wing was not broken, and his prognosis remains good. But six days after he was injured, he is still not flying, said the rehabilitator on Long Island who is caring for the bird. ''Its attitude is coming back, it's eating well, but it's not beating its wings, so we're thinking it's still in pain,'' said the rehabilitator, Bobby Horvath of Wildlife in Need of Rescue and Rehabilitation in Massapequa. Mr. Horvath said that the bird, which is about 7 months old, could have damaged a ligament.

An article in some copies on Jan. 9 about increased thefts from passengers in the Paris public transport system misstated the circumstances surrounding the death of a 27-year-old woman last December in a Paris Metro station. The police said the woman was struck by a suspected thief and fell down the stairs, suffering a fatal head injury, as he was escaping with the handbag of another passenger; she did not fall while chasing the suspect.

A picture on Tuesday with an article about the scheduled closing of the Tevatron particle accelerator carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of a superconducting dipole magnet used in the accelerator was taken by Reidar Hahn, not by Fred Ullrich.

In my exercise of sorting through the great composers of history to determine the Top 10, I have been putting off dealing with the 19th-century Romantic era (except for those giants of opera, Verdi and Wagner, who have already made the cut). But there is a reason. Music lovers have long been understandably enthralled with Chopin, Schumann, Mendelssohn, Berlioz, Liszt, Tchaikovsky, Brahms and their Romantic brethren. For better or worse, their works still dominate the standard repertory. Yet their music is so personal and idiosyncratic that it is hard to assess it in terms of greatness.

Kodak, the company that brought photography to the masses, as well as the ability for amateurs to develop and print pictures at home, is now bringing 3-D to the standard pictures you print from your digital camera. At last week's Consumer Electronics Show, the company showed off the new, as-yet-unnamed capability, which will be included as part of the feature set of its new $100 ESP C310 model, to be introduced this spring.

Last week I invited you to put in your two cents about the dark side of information technology, along with any praise that came to mind. Thanks much to the many of you who did so. There were a lot of great comments -- too many, unfortunately, for me to be able to single them all out or otherwise address them here. Though I'm going to dedicate this post to selectively recapping the comments and seeing what perspective we can wring out of them, it won't be my last word on the subject. And some of the comments I neglect here will influence future posts. Some of you took pains to emphasize that information technology is, over all, a pretty good thing for small businesses. As Josh Patrick pointed out in his comment, it can be ''a life saver'' that allows operating at much lower costs, enough to tip a company into profitability. And crucially, noted Erwin Susara, it has ''leveled the playing field'' with big companies in some ways, especially in terms of market reach -- and maybe even by allowing small companies to get ahead of the big guys by adopting new technologies more quickly, added Kalen.

An article on Friday about the funeral of Christina-Taylor Green, the 9-year-old who was killed during the Jan. 8 shooting rampage in Tucson, referred incorrectly to her brother, Dallas. At 11, he is older than Christina, not younger.

Last week, we published a case study about the challenges facing First Quality Music, a family-owned supplier of stringed musical instruments, including guitars and mandolins, along with parts and accessories. Founded in 1970 in Louisville, Ky., the nine-employee company also makes its own banjos as well as game calls for hunters. Co-owners Jeff and Eric Sullivan were hurtling toward bankruptcy and afraid of losing the company their father had started in 1970. Looking for a solution, they decided to spend $500 for an initial assessment from American Management Services, a consulting firm. When the assessment came in, the Sullivan brothers wondered whether they should pay $170,000 to have the firm develop a full turnaround plan.

LAZARUS--Leonard, passed away Saturday, January 15, 2011 at his home in Manhattan. He was 100 years old. Born on January 21, 1910, Leonard lived and loved life for over a century. He nurtured and cherished all his colleagues, friends and loved ones. Leonard was a self-made man. He actively practiced law into his 90s. He was a bright lawyer with a gift for bringing both allies and adversaries together to make "things work." He was a mentor to many lawyers and a man of his word and handshake. For over 70 years Mr. Lazarus played a part in the resurgence after World War II of the real estate markets in Manhattan, Queens and Long Island, engaging in a successful private practice with a schoolmate Richard Klugherz. Mr. Lazarus was born in the Bronx to German immigrants, had one brother Edward, and a sister, Nettie, both of whom predeceased him. When Leonard was very young, his father, Henry, took them to North Adams, MA because there was work there in its factories and mills. Leonard's father contracted TB and upon the doctor's advice relocated to the Adirondacks in Saranac Lake. Leonard's mother, Lillie, was very resourceful and found a place big enough, with land, to run a boarding house and for her husband to run a kosher chicken and egg business. His father was one of the first in the area to save enough money for a new Ford delivery truck, and the few Jewish families in the area loved to patronize such an enterprise. At a young age Leonard helped his parents. He had the largest paper route in the neighborhood and took furs to the rail station for a furrier. His respect for hard work, people and the love he developed for nature, while living, hiking and canoeing in the Adirondacks stayed with him throughout his life. Many years later he gave more than one hundred and fifty acres to a land trust in the Adirondacks to preserve nature from development. Mr. Lazarus' father died two days after his high school graduation so proud of his son who was the first person in the family to graduate high school. He won the state championship on the debating team and was Publisher and Treasurer of his yearbook. After his father's death, the family relocated back to the Bronx where his mother opened a family grocery business where Leonard worked. One of the customers, Rose, became his first wife. Leonard won a state scholarship to Columbia University at sixteen. He worked for the New York Times and became a soda fountain man in a movie house that showed the first talkie movie with Al Jolson, and then became the manager of the cafeteria at Columbia. While in college, Leonard befriended August Gold, a friendship which lasted a life time. In later years, August persuaded Leonard to support and invest in affordable development projects in Ossining, NY. After graduation from Columbia University School of Law during the depression, Leonard made fast friends with an older respected lawyer named Mr. Lochen who saw Leonard's potential. Leonard represented the bus driver's union, three to four hundred men on strike, and conducted labor negotiations with Mayor La Guardia. Mr. Lazarus was a conscientious objector; however he served in the Army for two years in his capacity as an attorney stationed at the Pentagon. After the Army, he lived and practiced law in Jamaica, Queens. He became associated with William Edwards, a real estate entrepreneur, who convinced Mr. Lazarus to move his law practice to Long Island and open an office in Mineola. Mr. Lazarus was instrumental in the development, leasing and sale of many buildings. A project of which he was most proud was Sheldon Solow and his building, The Solow Building at Nine 57th Street, the legendary Manhattan skyscraper designed by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, and built in 1974. Mr. Lazarus also was a partner in the Americana Mall, a luxury destination shopping mall in Manhasset, Long Island. He enjoyed working with Steve Hess Associates, William Edwards, Milt Levin, the Castagna Family, among other businesses from Long Island. He consulted with the late Fred Trump, the Parker family and the LeFraks. Mr. Lazarus married Rose Lazarus in 1936. They lived in New York for almost fifty years. Rose was an accomplished pianist and teacher. After a tragic car accident took Rose's life in 1986, Leonard remarried a longtime friend, the widow of one of his friends from college, Henrietta (Hindy) Creamer, an accomplished economist, interior decorator and artist. Mr. Lazarus was a supporter of numerous charitable foundations, including Columbia University, C.A.R.E., Saranac Lake High School and Central Park Conservancy, Inc. Mr. Lazarus is survived by two sons, Frederic Lazarus of Bradenton, FL and David Lazarus of Queensbury, NY; three grandchildren, Dana, Nicole and David Paul as well as a recent newborn great-grandchild, Annabel Rose, all from Queensbury, NY. He also leaves his sister's children, his niece Iris Greenwald Hamburger and her husband Jerome Hamburger of Lawrence, NY and his nephew, Richard Greenwald and his brother Edward's children, his nieces Susan Qubein and Ellen Lazarus. He is also survived by his close friend and companion, Denise Bibro, and all of his caretakers who loved and took care of him for many years. Funeral services are being arranged with the Campbell Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue, New York City. A memorial will be planned in the near future. For information you may call: 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to one of Mr. Lazarus' favorite charities or a similar charity of your choice will be appreciated.

EVANS--Edward P. Died peacefully on December 31, 2010. Ned was born in Pittsburgh, PA on January 31, 1942 to Thomas Mellon Evans and Elizabeth Park Evans Kase. He is survived by two brothers Thomas M. Evans, Jr. and Robert S. Evans, his niece, Ashley Evans and his nephews Jonathan Evans, Thomas M. Evans, III and Mark Johnson Evans. Ned graduated from Yale University in 1964 and earned an MBA from Harvard Business School in 1967. He had a long and successful business career beginning in 1968, holding executive positions with a number of family businesses. In 1980, Ned became Chairman and CEO of MacMillian, Inc. Beginning in 1988, he became involved with personal business interests and investments including breeding and racing thoroughbred horses. Ned was also known as a generous philanthropist. He formed the Edward P. Evans Foundation and contributed to a number of charitable organizations in various fields throughout the United States. Most recently, he made a gift to the Yale School of Management that will allow Yale to begin the construction of the new unified campus and building for the Yale School of Management. The building will be known as Edward P. Evans Hall. Mr. Evans' greatest joy was racing thoroughbred horses and breeding thoroughbreds at his farm in Casanova, Virginia known as Spring Hill Farm. He bred over 100 stakes winners and as of his death was the 4th leading breeder and 7th leading owner in North America. Ned was consistently named as one of the Top 10 breeders in North America. His horse Quality Road was one of the favorites for the 2009 Kentucky Derby and won or placed in 12 out of 13 starts. Quality Road was injured before the 2009 Derby and was unable to compete in any of the Triple Crown races in that year. The Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association named Ned the Virginia Breeder of the Year nine times, most recently in 2009, and the National Breeder of the Year in 2009. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation, 100 Park Avenue, Suite 108, Rockville, MD 20850.

Goldman Sachs has long had a knack for beating the market, even in uncertain financial times. But lately it seems the lackluster economy has gotten the better of the firm. The Wall Street bank, which reported a 53 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday, experienced a noticeable slowdown in most of its important divisions, citing increased competition and depressed client activity amid economic uncertainty.

An article last Thursday about Beth Katleman, a ceramic artist, misidentified the group that provided her with an artist-in-residence position in the late 1990s. It was the John Michael Kohler Arts Center -- not Kohler, the kitchen and bath company, which helps finance the arts center.

Batman has found a nemesis for his next cinematic adventure - and, it appears, a love interest, too. On Wednesday, Warner Brothers Pictures announced a new cast member and the role of another in ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' the third Batman movie to be directed by Christopher Nolan, the ''Inception'' and ''Memento'' filmmaker. Joining Christian Bale, who returns as Batman and his daytime alter ego, Bruce Wayne, is Anne Hathaway (of ''Love and Other Drugs'') who will play Selina Kyle; the film will also feature Tom Hardy, a co-star of ''Inception,'' as the villain Bane. As comic-book fans know, the Selina Kyle character is the secret identity of Batman's sometime paramour (and sometime foe) Catwoman, and Bane is a muscular bad guy powered by an addictive drug called Venom. But a news release from Warner Brothers gave no descriptions of how these characters would be utilized in Mr. Nolan's film. Mr. Nolan said in a statement only that Ms. Hathaway was ''a fantastic addition to our ensemble as we complete our story'' and that he was ''delighted to be working with Tom again and excited to watch him bring to life our new interpretation of one of Batman's most formidable enemies.''

Michelle Obama's gown for the state dinner for President Hu Jintao of China sent out a number of signals. Fortunately, they were not mixed. The red silk organza dress, with a streaky print of black petals, invited the suggestion that the color was chosen in honor of the Chinese leader. Mrs. Obama has worn black and red before - memorably, on the night her husband was elected president.

The guessing game is over: The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., the first major rock festival of the year and a bellwether for the summer touring season, has announced the lineup for its 12th installment. For a stark illustration of how record sales have changed in recent years, take a look at Billboard's charts this week for albums and track downloads. For decades the Top 200, the magazine's album chart, has been the music industry's standard sales yardstick, since record companies have traditionally earned most of their profits from full CDs. But as record stores have vanished and people have turned to digital music -- according to Nielsen SoundScan, digital downloads now account for 46 percent of all music purchases, including both full albums and individual tracks -- sales of full albums have fallen. And fallen. For students of the music industry, the weekly album chart can be a grim read, as the numbers hit historic low after historic low.

BAIRD--Donald Heston Baird (b. July 3, 1921) passed away on January 18, 2011. Don was a gifted scientist, the holder of many patents for his work in lasers, electro-luminescence, and bubble memory for GTE Laboratories, where he was manager of the Material Physics Group. Son of Ora Belle (Davenport) and Robert W. Baird (founder of Robert W. Baird & Company), Don grew up in Wauwatosa WI, and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Haverford College in 1943. Immediately after Haverford, he completed basic training and was recruited into the Manhattan Project (1943-1946) while serving in the Army. After graduate work at Harvard in physical chemistry (PhD 1950), Don joined GTE Laboratories, where he spent his entire career. Don had lifelong passions for golf and Gilbert & Sullivan. A longtime resident of Newton, MA, in retirement he enjoyed many years as a volunteer at the Boston Museum of Science. He was a wonderful, cherished husband to Annette, beloved father to Allison and Douglas, and grandfather to Gregory, Katie and Julian. He will be missed by all who knew him for his kindness and his gentle, unfailing sense of humor.

SIEGEL--Abraham. Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research learned with great sadness of the passing of Abraham Siegel on January 16. Abraham, then Dean of the MIT Sloan School of Management, joined our Founding Board of Directors in 1982 and was instrumental in guiding Whitehead Institute through its formative years. Abraham's intelligence, wisdom, and personality made him an ideal adviser, representative, spokesperson, and leader during his ten years of service on our Board and later as a Board member emeritus. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife Lillian and the entire Siegel family. David Page, Director

Carolyn Ryan, who helped lead The New York Times to a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the downfall of Eliot Spitzer when he was governor of New York, has been named the paper's metropolitan editor. Ms. Ryan, 46, has worked at The Times for three and half years. In that brief time, she has steered the paper's coverage of some of the biggest regional political stories in recent memory, including Mr. Spitzer's resignation, former Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal's exaggeration of his war record, and the ethical problems plaguing Representative Charles B. Rangel and former Gov. David A. Paterson.

An article on Wednesday about the forthcoming publication of ''O,'' an anonymously written novel about a 2012 presidential campaign, misspelled the name of another novelist. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

An article on Saturday about the activities of Jared L. Loughner on the day he killed six people and wounded 13 others in Tucson misidentified the Walgreens store at which he picked up photos of himself. Investigators said he picked up the film early on the day of the shooting at a Walgreens, but not at the one in the same shopping complex where the shootings took place.

9:30 P.M. (HBO) A PRESIDENT TO REMEMBER: IN THE COMPANY OF JOHN F. KENNEDY (2008) On the 50th anniversary of the inauguration of President Kennedy, Robert Drew combines film footage from four of his documentaries from the early 1960s (''Primary,'' ''Adventures on the New Frontier,'' ''Crisis: Behind a Presidential Commitment'' and ''Faces of November'') to create an overview of Kennedy's life, from his campaign as a young senator to his assassination in 1963. Using critical moments captured by Mr. Drew and his associates, Albert Maysles, D. A. Pennebaker, Richard Leacock, Hope Ryden and James Lipscomb, the film follows Kennedy as he meets with union workers as a fledgling candidate; watches approvingly as his wife, Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, gives a stump speech; strategizes with staffers about election tactics; deals with the Soviet Union and Nikita S. Khrushchev during the Cuban missile crisis; and works with his attorney general, his brother Robert F. Kennedy, during a showdown with Gov. George Wallace over the integration of the University of Alabama. The documentary, narrated by Alec Baldwin, ends with scenes of a grieving nation. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL In Part 2 of the Season 10 opener the judges Randy Jackson, Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler audition singers in New Orleans.

SCHECHTER--Alfred, of Scarsdale and Remsenberg, NY passed away at 90. After serving in Africa during WWII, he married Shirley Bogen and started one of the first companies to manufacture plastic film for consumer products later sold to the St. Regis Company. His next business was manufacturing plastic containers for food and other products later sold to Phillips Petroleum. As a co-investor with Charterhouse Group International and Chairman of Paco Pharmaceutical Services he oversaw growth from 250 employees to over 1,400 and listing on the NYSE. He also served as Chairman of several other companies including Charter-Crellin, Stanley Furniture and Cryenco. Alfred formed a private foundation that provided scholarships to hundreds of students studying physical and occupational therapy and nursing as well as graduate study in other fields. He leaves behind his wife of 62 years Shirley Schechter, children Claudia and Robert, daughter-inlaw Francine, and grandchildren Ethan, Leah and Sarah. Services will be held 1:00, Thursday January 20th at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, NY.

What works and what doesn't work to solve a social problem is often no mystery.  The mystery is why we so often persist in doing what doesn't work.  The topic of Tuesday's column - prisoner re-entry into the community - offers myriad examples.   One is the practice of dropping people getting out of jail or prison right back into the neighborhoods where they got in trouble in the first place.  Intuition tells us that this is a bad idea: the old street corners and the old friends seem like a recipe for the old troubles.  Research on this idea is rare and hard to do - it's tough to get around the problem that the person who chooses not to go home may have other qualities that make him successful.

John Galliano revisited the familiar territory of the Russian Revolution, this time with Rudolf Nureyev in tow. Since 1946, T. Anthony has provided the upper crust with an alternative to its French rivals with equal parts luxury and versatility. That isn't to say that the old guard doesn't have a fondness for the finer things - at a price, of course. T. Anthony's latest luggage pieces, the alligator calf collection, blends the other half's need for long-lasting quality luggage (the leather is from a tannery in Italy) with rich yet tastefully understated style. Embossed to mimic alligator hides in a deep chocolate, the prices - ranging from $895 for a classic duffel to $2,200 for a 31-inch wheeled packing case - won't make you shed any crocodile tears. Think of the collection as a guaranteed first-class upgrade the next time you travel.

The Hofstra senior guard Charles Jenkins, a two-time winner of the Haggerty Award as the best college basketball player in the New York metropolitan area and the defending Colonial Athletic Association Player of the Year, has raised his game this season under the first-year coach Mo Cassara. Jenkins recently passed Loren Stokes for third place on the Hofstra career scoring list and is getting closer to Antoine Agudio's record of 2,276 points. But he has more than individual honors on his mind. Showcasing his desire to finally get his team to the N.C.A.A. tournament, he's averaging almost 6 points more after halftime - when games are won and lost - than in the first half. In addition, his second-half shooting tops 63 percent.

Television cameras are often mirrors, reflecting back the message of the times. In an article in the Styles section this weekend, my colleague Bruce Feiler looks at the hit show "Modern Family" through that lens, asking "what does 'Modern Family' say about modern families?"

"She's a foul-mouthed alcoholic nun," Kathleen Turner said of Sister Jamison Connelly, the character she portrays in "High," a new play coming to Broadway this spring. "What I love is that she hasn't made these choices about her religion lightly," Ms. Turner said in her familiar deep-throated growl. "It makes me think of how much we operate every single day on faith and belief," regardless of any connection to organized religion.

The former British prime minister Tony Blair appeared, for a second time, before Britain's official inquiry into the invasion of Iraq on Friday. During four hours of testimony, Mr. Blair tried to shift the debate from Iraq to Iran - the former, a subject on which he was taken to task for during his appearance in January 2010. On Friday, he accused Tehran of supporting terrorist groups in the region and seeking to block Middle East peace efforts, even saying that they "facilitate a situation in which that region cannot embark on the process of modernization it urgently needs."

Shakespeare's Globe Theater will present a familiar array of the writer's plays in 2012 but in some unfamiliar languages. The reconstructed theater, in the Southwark section of London, announced what it calls a "Cultural Olympiad," in which all of the plays will be performed, each in a different language. The idea is to present a theatrical counterpart to the Olympic games which are scheduled to take place in London that year.

The N.B.A. season is not unlike the lunar cycle in that it exists as a series of phases during which portions of the whole rotate through periods of high visibility. Teams essentially take turns in a position of prominence, while the rest of the league goes about its business in semi-obscurity. The news media's obsession with up-to-the-minute sports coverage (which is the chicken and which is the egg I'll leave you to decide) and basketball fans hungry for the hottest team in the game have created a system that anoints kings for a day, if only so they can be dethroned and replaced in short order.

Any parent of small children knows that the cost of hiring a baby sitter is often higher than the cost of tickets to a play. So now Playwrights Horizons is offering affordable, professional child care during three of its Sunday matinees. "The combined cost of theater tickets and child care is the factor most often cited by people with young children as the reason they rarely attend the theater," Leslie Marcus, the managing director, said in a statement. "Our hope is that this program will become a model for other performing arts organizations in New York." The program, called Playtime!, will be available on Feb. 27, March 20 and April 2 during the afternoon performance of "Kin," a new play by Bathsheba Doran. While parents are watching the show, their children (4 to 12) will be upstairs in a rehearsal space and watched by Sitters Studio, a baby-sitting company made up of working artists. The service is free for members and $15 for non-members. The Theater Subdistrict Council, a nonprofit corporation, is helping to finance the project.

As the Institute for Curatorial Practice in Performance at Wesleyan University says, performance art "is first and foremost a social experience that happens on a person-to-person level." That has not stopped the institute from creating a new professional certificate program in curating performance art that primarily occurs off-campus. The nine-month program, the first of its kind, is scheduled to begin this summer and is targeted at professionals with one to five years of experience. The course involves three short residencies. Danspace Project in New York City collaborated on the design and implementation of the program.

Rafael E. Cestero, commissioner of the city Department of Housing Preservation and Development, is leaving his job for a private-sector post. Mr. Cestero, who has served two stints in city government but spent most of his career in the private sector, will become managing director at L+M Development Partners, a developer of affordable and market-rate housing nationwide. Mr. Cestero will be involved only in projects outside of New York City, the housing preservation department said.

Few contemporary architects have earned more prestigious and prominent commissions in Berlin than the British-born David Chipperfield. His office in Mitte is currently working on at least three projects in the German capital, in addition to another dozen or so in different parts of Germany, Austria and Switzerland. With so much on their plate, Chipperfield and his team barely have time for lunch every day, let alone for deciding where to eat. Which is why Chipperfield has leased out part of his Berlin office's courtyard space to a restaurant aptly called Kantine (canteen).

The fourth volume of "Stepping on Roses," published by VIZ Media, enters our manga list at No. 8 this week. At the center of the series is Sumi Kitamura, who is having immense financial troubles. Her prayers seem to be answered when she meets the wealthy Soichiro Ashida, who offers her money to marry him and enter high society. "Stepping on Roses" asks, can Sumi pass as a member of the elite and is the sham marriage worth it? You may not have realized that the balloon dog you bought for a buck from a street clown might be a collector's item. But the artist Jeff Koons, who constructed a 10-foot tall "Balloon Dog" that has been exhibited in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and elsewhere, sent a cease-and-desist letter to a Canadian manufacturer and San Francisco gallery for producing and selling "Balloon Dog" bookends. Now the gallery, Park Life, has asked a federal court for a declaratory judgment that states the canine shape cannot be copyrighted, according to Courthouse News Service. "As virtually any clown can attest, no one owns the idea of making a balloon dog, and the shape created by twisting a balloon into a dog-like form is part of the public domain," the gallery says in its federal complaint. "Any similarities between the Balloon Dog Bookend compared with the Balloon Dog Structure are driven by the wholly unprotectable idea of depicting the shape of a balloon dog in a solid form."

President Obama ordered federal agencies Tuesday to weed out regulations "that conflict, that are not worth the cost, or that are just plain dumb." At Dries Van Noten, plenty swirled beneath the opaque surface of the designer's intent, from Bowie glam to aristocratic refinement. But clear understanding could be found in the left lapel of the collection's jackets. These were doubled: a white, navy or fur second layer buttoned to the inside of the jacket and folded around on top, duplicating the true left lapel. Graphically, the effect was a contrasting sweep across the chest, almost a sash, reminiscent of military regalia. According to Van Noten, this sort of construction has its origins in the military uniforms for which lapels were first invented. Often one would be buttoned across the neck for extra warmth, but because that interrupted the shape (particularly a problem if any battle medals happened to be hanging there), a second lapel was needed to cover the chest.
"There are no words."

PARK CITY, Utah - Hoodies and corsets, sweats and power suits are all being celebrated as the year's best cinematic outfits by the Costume Designers Guild. The group announced its nominees on Friday and there were more nominees in the contemporary film category than either period or fantasy. The Academy usually favors period fare, so maybe it will take a page from the guild - the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Local 892 - and nominate "The Fighter," "The King's Speech" or "True Grit." The contemporary hopefuls are "Black Swan," the not-at-all campy "Burlesque," "Inception," "The Social Network" (go hoodies!) and "Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps." The fantasy films are "Alice in Wonderland," "Tron: Legacy" and "The Tempest."

My latest adventure at sea - a cruise around the eastern Caribbean with my partner aboard the Celebrity Eclipse - taught me two valuable lessons. First, some people are just addicted to cruising. We met several passengers who were well beyond their 25th voyage, a milestone we may never get to. But this cruise, which began in Miami and had ports of call in Puerto Rico, St. Maarten and St. Kitts, whetted our appetite for more. Which brings me to Lesson No. 2: Cruise-ship food doesn't have to be bad. In fact, the Eclipse's was quite memorable.

With each passing season, the need to reclassify basketball's positional system becomes more obvious. Waves of unique players come into the N.B.A. every year, and many pay the price for its reluctance to adapt; some of the league's most intriguing talents are poorly utilized, buried deep on the bench, or cast off because they don't fit neatly into the game's positional molds. The lines that separate positions are arbitrary and limiting, and though a willingness to cross those lines is sometimes lauded (Hedo Turkoglu can run an offense!), just as often a cross-positional player is maligned for some transgression against the game (Monta Ellis isn't a real point guard! Burn him at the stake!).

The financially troubled Washington National Opera is merging administrative functions with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the two organizations announced this morning. The move is intended to stabilize the opera company, which in recent years has reduced its season and borrowed against its endowment. Under the new structure, which will take effect on July 1, the Washington National Opera will maintain a separate board; its endowment will be accounted for separately; and donations designated for the opera will be spent on the opera. Otherwise, the organizations' finances will be merged. Programming decisions will be made jointly by Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the Kennedy Center, and a new artistic leader for the opera, to be hired by Mr. Kaiser and the opera's board. The Washington National Opera's current general manager, Placido Domingo, is leaving when his contract expires in June.

BEIJING -- China's economy grew at a rate of 9.8 percent in the fourth quarter from the same period a year earlier and inflation eased only slightly last month, showing that a series of cooling measures by Beijing over the past year have had only a limited effect. Data released by the National Bureau of Statistics on Thursday put the pace of growth at 10.3 percent for the full year, up from 9.2 percent in 2009.

FERNANDO--Laura Mahnil (nee Sumanadasa) was born on April 14, 1940, in London, England. Her father, L.H. Sumanadasa, and mother, Miriam de Mel, were from Ceylon (known today as Sri Lanka). Her father was an aeronautical engineer working in England for the Royal Air Force. In 1943, after years of war, her parents decided to return to Ceylon. They were part of a convoy of thirteen ships that set sail. Their ship was separated from the convoy during a terrible storm. German submarines torpedoed the convoy, and in the end because of the storm, theirs was the only ship to make it home safely. Laura Mahnil used this as an allegory as she bravely fought cancer these past two years. Laura Mahnil attended Ladies' College in Colombo. She then completed her licentiate from the Royal Schools of Music in piano performance, training under Ithalie de Saram. She married C.K. Fernando in 1965, and they promptly moved to New York, as her husband was chosen as a Fulbright scholar to pursue graduate study at NYU in physical therapy. Laura Mahnil began studying under Joseph Raieff, Professor at the Juilliard School. She won first prize in the 1969 Open Piano Competition of Radio Ceylon. She eventually chose to sacrifice her career in performance to bring up her children. While living in New York, she and her husband had two daughters, Netasha and Tanya, and later while living in Denmark, they had a son, Rajiv. In 1974, the family moved to the Chicago area. Laura Mahnil started teaching piano, and taught a whole generation of students in the Hinsdaleak Brook area. She was active in the music circles, and was a member and President of the Hinsdale Music Club. In 1996, she and her husband moved to Naples, Florida. She continued to be active in music. She played for services at the Unitarian Congregation of Naples, and was on the board of the Naples Music Club. She also began to perform again. She performed both solo concerts, playing with the Naples Orchestra and Chorus, and music for two pianos with concert pianist, Richard Bosworth. They performed in Naples, Chicago, as well as Colombo, where they gave a charity concert for Mallika Home for Elderly Women, an organization founded in part by her grandmother, Laura de Mel. Laura Mahnil's grace, beauty, goodness, and gift of music will continue to touch all those who knew and loved her. She is survived by a loving husband, Dr. C.K. Fernando; three devoted children, Netasha Scarpiniti, Tanya Fernando, and Rajiv Fernando; two beloved grandchildren, Anthony and Giana, and son-in-law, Frank Scarpiniti; three adoring siblings, Lelani Chinnadurai, Ananda Sumanadasa, and Madera Gunewardane; and a cherished community of family and friends. Memorial services will be held in Oak Brook, Illinois and Naples, Florida. The family kindly requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Laura Mahnil Fernando Memorial Fund for Cancer Care: Harris Bank, 141 West Jackson Blvd., Main Floor, Chicago, Il 60604.

Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 3 about China's increasing economic ties in Central Asia misstated the year in which China helped establish a precursor to the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, a regional strategy group that includes Russia and most Central Asian nations. It was in 1996, not in 1966.

Museum of the City of New York (Wednesday) We know the Brooklyn Bridge is loved from the number of paintings, photographs and works of literature that have immortalized it. But just why it is so loved will be the topic of ''The Bridge as Muse,'' a discussion at 6:30 p.m. with some of those it captivates, including Richard Haw, author of ''Art of the Brooklyn Bridge: A Visual History''; the artist and author Bascove; and Jonathan Smith, who photographed it for ''The Bridge Project,'' sponsored by the Design Trust for Public Space. The discussion, co-sponsored by the Design Trust and the museum, is in conjunction with ''Glorious Sky: Herbert Katzman's New York,'' a display of more than 80 cityscapes, 19 of them with views of the bridge -- including Mr. Katzman's ''Brooklyn Bridge, 1951-52,'' above. The exhibition will run through Feb. 21. The Brooklyn Bridge, however, is on view indefinitely. Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street; $12; $8 for students and 62+; $6 for members; reservations are required: (917) 492-3395, mcny.org. (Anne Mancuso)

At a screening of a movie about Antarctica in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, guests shivered, pressed close together for warmth and breathed curls of vapor into the frigid air. It was, after all, an outdoor event, and the 50 or so cinephiles watched the film huddled on benches around bonfires in a backyard in Clinton Hill, their feet plunked in drifts of snow. ''Battling nature is more interesting than your standard rooftop screening,'' said Shalin Scupham, 25, a freelance photographer who hosted the event behind the row house he shares with several roommates. ''It's more interesting to overcome adversity than luxuriate.''

In Shakespeare's tragedy, Romeo is so steeped in love poetry that Juliet accuses him of kissing ''by the book.'' By contrast, Lazer Weiss, who plays the lead role in the new film ''Romeo and Juliet in Yiddish,'' did not understand the concept of romantic love until he was in his 20s, he said. Mr. Weiss was raised in an Orthodox Jewish household and broke with the faith in his teens. ''Romance wasn't something we talked about growing up,'' he said. Not only that, Mr. Weiss, 26, said he had never heard of Shakespeare until the film's director, Eve Annenberg, enlightened him.

An article on Tuesday about initial results of an experiment in charging for newspaper Web content misstated part of the name of a Columbus, Miss., newspaper that is among those involved in the venture, called Journalism Online. It is The Commercial Dispatch, not The Columbus Dispatch.

The 42nd edition of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival will take place over two weekends this spring, from April 29 to May 1 and May 5 to 8, and its lineup continues a long trend toward ever-more-mainstream rock and pop. The headliners include Bon Jovi, Kid Rock, Arcade Fire, Jimmy Buffett, John Mellencamp, Tom Jones, Wilco, the Strokes, Robert Plant and John Legend and the Roots, festival organizers announced on Thursday. But of course that's not all. For jazz fans, there is also Sonny Rollins, Ahmad Jamal and the Ron Carter Trio. And as part of the festival's signature focus on New Orleans and Louisiana music, the lineup also includes Trombone Shorty, the Neville Brothers, Dr. John, Allen Toussaint, Irma Thomas, Kermit Ruffins, the Dirty Dozen Brass Band, Buckwheat Zydeco, the Rebirth Brass Band, Galactic and dozens more, as well as the feature that clinches the trip for many fans: lots and lots of mouthwatering New Orleans food, in what festival organizers have called ''world's biggest backyard barbecue.''

SAN FRANCISCO -- Google made the biggest management shake-up in a decade on Thursday, handing the reins of the company to one of its co-founders in an effort to rediscover its start-up roots. As it has grown into the dominant company in Silicon Valley, Google has lost some of its entrepreneurial culture and become a slower-moving bureaucracy, analysts and insiders say, in contrast to Facebook, Twitter and other younger, more agile competitors.

2:56 p.m. | Updated Warren Buffett, the investor whose guidance is considered gospel by many on Wall Street, is leaving his long-held position on the board of the Washington Post Company. The Post Company announced on Thursday that Mr. Buffett, 80, would not seek re-election to the board after his term expires in May. Mr. Buffett has been with the board for nearly 40 years, with the exception of an eight-year period when he stepped aside to serve on the board of Capital Cities, which was the parent company of the rival media company ABC at the time.

PERAZA--John P.,72, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan, surrounded by his family, on January 19 , 2011. He bravely battled throat cancer for almost two years. John was born in the South Bronx, NY. His parents Ruben and Margaret (nee Mulhern), wives Mary Ann Koelbe and Lynn Lepofsky and niece Christina Marie Fey predeceased him. As a young boy, John enjoyed scouting and with diligence earned his Eagle Scout Badge. He graduated from the Academy of Aeronautics and L.I. University with a Bachelor of Science degree. An Honorary Doctorate of Science Degree was bestowed by Vaughn College in 2004. John proudly served in the Naval Reserves. As an engineer, working at Photronics in Flushing, NY, John designed many optical-mechanical instruments, such as heat seeking optics for the Red Eye Missile and optical choppers for the CIA and Columbia University used to plot the movement of Russian submarines. He also secured several US Patents and eventually became Vice President of the company. John later changed directions and became a successful entrepreneur. He was very generous to both family and friends. John was an avid reader and had a vast library particularly books of an historical nature. He and his wife Lynn traveled the world and collected an array of artifacts from the countries they visited. John loved fishing with his buddies on the charter boat "Oh Brother" out of Montauk, NY. John equally enjoyed all the cultural aspects of Manhattan. John will be greatly missed by his sisters Mary Ellen Fey, Margaret Manganelli (Al) and Catherine Peraza, his brother Thomas, his nephews Thomas Fey (Susan), Troy Emmi (Sandy), his nieces Amy Peraza (Michael), Kimberly Koren, and many grandnieces and nephews. John's wish was to be cremated and his ashes to be scattered on the waters off Montauk Point. A private memorial will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to VNSNY Hospice Care, 225 West 34th Street, Suite 910, New York, NY 10122.

GILES--Mark Hudson, on January 14, 2011 of Leukemia. An avid sports fan, Mark was passionate about his loving family and treasured friendships. He considered himself fortunate for these relationships that nurtured and sustained him throughout his 56 years. Mark is survived by his adored wife of 28 years, Diane Kelley; sons, Matt (fiancee, Cora Howey) and Rob; sister, Susie Ferruzza and Meg Giles Mercer; nieces, Kait and Kara; nephews, Randall and Danny; and many other loving relatives and friends, especially Bill Giles, Michael McGrann and Tom McGoldrick. Father, Henry; mother Joan McCauley; and brother, Patrick, predeceased him. In his 34 years as a journalist at Money Magazine and ESPN The Magazine, Mark's great talent as an editor was surpassed only by his humanity and wit. Funeral Mass will be St. Simon & Jude in Brooklyn, NY on January 22, 2011 at 1pm. A Memorial Service will be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Mark Hudson Giles Memorial Fund, 633 East Third St., Brooklyn, NY 11218. Services entrusted to Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6th St, Brooklyn, NY. www.cusimanoandrusso funeralhome.com

Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers. Last summer, the Denver Nuggets and Al Harrington agreed to a five-year, $33 million free agent deal. The signing looked bad at the time and looks even worse now; according to numerous reports, Harrington's contract was one of the stumbling blocks in Denver's' scuttled trade of Carmelo Anthony to the Nets.

REGAN--William Mahon, of Bronxville died peacefully at his home surrounded by his family on January 20, 2011. He was 94. He was born on November 4, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of John Francis Regan and Mabel Mahon Regan. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Preparatory School, The College of the Holy Cross and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he served as an Intelligence Office in the United States Coast Guard. After the War, he was appointed Assistant United Sates Attorney for the Southern District before joining the General Electric Company, as an Assistant to the Chief Counsel. He left General Electric to found the New York law firm of Regan, Goldfard, Powell & Quinn, later to become Regan, Goldfarb, Heller, Wetzler & Quinn. He also owned and operated a number of specialty printing businesses over a span of thirty years. He was devoted to his Roman Catholic Faith and to his family. He was a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Knight of Malta, former member of the Board of Trustees at Fordham Prep, a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Archdiocese of New York. He was a member of the Presidents' Councils of several colleges including his Alma Mater. Mr. Regan was predeceased by his loving wife of over 60 years, Grace O'Neil Regan and his older brother, John. He is also survived by his eight children, Grace (John Conway), Loudonville, NY; William Jr. (Alice), Bronxville, NY; John (Sarabeth), Bronx- ville, NY, Hugh, (Gail Fanelli), New York City, Neil, Bronxville, NY; Jane (Michael Considine), Bronxville, NY; Ann, Bronxville, NY; Mary, New York City and 20 grandchildren and two great-granddaughters. He maintained until the end his childhood loyalty to Babe Herman and the Brooklyn Dodgers. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Committee for Mission Responsibility of the Archdiocese of New York. He will be waked in his home on Sunday, January 23 from 2 to 7pm, Two Northway, Bronx- ville, NY. A Mass of the Christian Burial will take place at The Church of Saint Joseph, Bronxville, NY at 10am Monday, January 24, 2011.
DHOBI GHAT (MUMBAI DIARIES) Opens on Friday nationwide.

''American Idol'' is supposed to allow young people to live their wildest dreams. The show's 10th season, which began Wednesday on Fox with new judges, looked more like an older woman's fantasy - a Nancy Meyers movie about the revenge of the scorned first wife. The introduction of the new stars, Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler, was labored, long and almost painfully lighthearted, like a divorced husband awkwardly presenting the new wife to his grown but unforgiving children. And all the while, over on CBS, Paula Abdul, who was replaced as an ''Idol'' judge last season by Ellen DeGeneres, shimmered, preened and gloated on her own reality contest, ''Live to Dance.''

The App Smart column on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday, about apps for guitarists, described a feature of one such app, AmpliTube, incorrectly. It includes in its recording section a so-called re-amping feature, which allows guitarists to test the app's different sound effects on a recorded track; it is not the case that the re-amping feature is missing.

KUH--Richard. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Richard Kuh, beloved husband of our long time member, Beth Holland. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

TAFEL--Edgar A. Died at home January 18 at age 98. From 1932 to 1941 Edgar was an original member of Frank Lloyd Wright's Taliesin Fellowship; he is the last survivor. While there he served as project architect for Fallingwater, Johnson Wax and Wingspread among many others. He was principal of his own highly creative architectural practice in New York from 1945 to 1986 that produced many churches and synagogues, college buildings and houses. Known for his sharp wit and acerbic commentary, Edgar authored two books on Frank Lloyd Wright. He was also active in community affairs, serving on his local community planning board as well as being President of the Washington Square Association. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and an Associate of the National Academy of Design. He will be missed by his cousin Joan Scott, his loving caregiver Lerna Gillett and her entire family, his devoted physician Dr. Jerry Clements, and his close friends Robert and Roberta Silman, as well as the entire architectural community to which he gave so much. A memorial service is planned for early February at the Center for Architecture.

FINK--David Martin, Ph.D. age 82, of Metuchen, New Jersey died on Tuesday, January 18th from complications of pneumonia. Dr. Fink, originally from Brooklyn, New York, attended Bronx High School of Science, played basketball in his college years at Brooklyn College and got his PhD in Psychology at Rutgers University. David Fink was a clinical psychologist in private practice. He is survived by his wife of 58 years Harriet Pinson Fink, three daughters, Marcy, Linda, and Hildy; five grandchildren, Matthew, Lucia, Natalia, Adam, and Hallie; and sons-in-law Ernesto and Rick.

ZWEIBON--Herbert, 84, beloved founder and Chairman of Americans for a Safe Israel/AFSI, is mourned by all who knew and loved him. Herb lived his life as a proud Zionist who remained constant in his conviction that only a safe, secure, and impregnable Israel, within its legitimate and historic borders, was the sole guarantor of Jews throughout the world. He will be remembered for his kindness, wisdom, dedication, vision, and concern for Israel and the Jewish people. He headed Z&R Management Corp. in NYC. He leaves behind a loving family his wife, Sheila, of 58 years, his sons, Donald and wife Robin, Mark, and Kenneth and wife Jessica, and grandchildren Zachary, Jesse, Danielle, Michelle, and Shou, and his sister and her husband, Lillian and Carl Rudnick. The funeral will take place on Friday, 11 AM, January 21, at the Greenburgh Hebrew Center, 515 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Zweibon home. Memorial donations may be made to AFSI.

Stanford Makishi will step down as executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Feb. 28, the center said on Thursday. Mr. Makishi, 45, a Harvard-educated former dancer, has held the post for three years, serving as the right-hand man of Mikhail Baryshnikov, the founder and artistic director. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Jan. 12 about the discovery in Peru of a new source of a prized variety of cacao was accompanied by a photograph showing one of the cacao pods. After a reader raised questions, editors learned that the picture had been digitally altered by a marketing firm that supplied it. The firm worked for one of the companies involved in using the cacao. (The alteration made the pod appear purely yellow, rather than the mottled yellow-and-green of the original picture.) Had editors known of the alteration, the picture would not have been used.

VAN NOSTRAND--Mary (Burns), 82, of Asheville, NC, formerly of Huntington, NY, died Tuesday, January 18, 2011. Predeceased by her husbands, John Richard Burns, who died in 1982, and Hugh Van Nostrand, who died in 1999; and by two sons, James T. Burns and Stephen G. Burns. She is survived by her sons, Richard D. Burns and partner, Robert Berg, of New York, NY, and Peter M. Burns and wife, Allyson, and their children Mackenzie, Abby and Maggie of Fairfield, CT; two stepdaughters, Barbara Van Nostrand and her daughter Nicole of Atlanta, GA, and Jean Hughes and husband, Wayne, and their children Tyler and Katie of Richardson, TX; daughter-in-law, Carrie Teegardin and children Warner and Kate of Atlanta, GA; three sisters, Bonnie McNamara of Alpine, TX, Suzanne Jones of Brewster, MA, and Kathleen Montagne of Hendersonville, NC. Born December 23, 1928 in Minneapolis, MN to Dale and Ethel Snure and lived in Huntington, Long Island, NY for twenty-five years. She was a 1950 graduate of Mount Holyoke College. She moved to Hendersonville in 1993 and to the Givens Estates in Asheville in 2006. She was a member of Trinity Presbyterian Church and choir. Services 3pm Saturday, January 22, 2011 at Trinity Presbyterian Church in Hendersonville, NC. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Mount Holyoke College, 50 College Street, South Hadley, Massachusetts 01075, or to the Givens Estates Resident Assistance Ministry, 2360 Sweeten Creek Road, Asheville, NC 28803.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about the difficulties of getting a short-term lease misstated the number of buildings in London Terrace Towers on West 23rd Street. London Terrace Towers consists of four of the six buildings in the London Towers complex; it does not have ''half a dozen'' buildings itself.

The Books of The Times review on Jan. 6, about the novel ''Three Seconds'' by Anders Roslund and Borge Hellstrom, misidentified the nationality of a police informant killed by mobsters. He was Danish, not Swedish.

EDWARDS--Felix Z. III, born in Sherman, TX 82, died January 18, 2011. Died peacefully in his sleep in his Greenwich Village, New York City home. Felix worked for American Airlines for many years as a Special Services Manager. Felix loved traveling, garden tours through out Europe and gardening in his New Milford, CT home. A memorial is planned for Saturday, February 5 at The Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue corner of 12th Street at 10:30 a.m.

BAIRD--Donald Heston Baird (b. July 3, 1921) passed away on January 18, 2011. Don was a gifted scientist, the holder of many patents for his work in lasers, electro-luminescence, and bubble memory for GTE Laboratories, where he was manager of the Material Physics Group. Son of Ora Belle (Davenport) and Robert W. Baird (founder of Robert W. Baird & Company), Don grew up in Wauwatosa WI, and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Haverford College in 1943. Immediately after Haverford, he completed basic training and was recruited into the Manhattan Project (1943-1946) while serving in the Army. After graduate work at Harvard in physical chemistry (PhD 1950), Don joined GTE Laboratories, where he spent his entire career. Don had lifelong passions for golf and Gilbert & Sullivan. A longtime resident of Newton, MA, in retirement he enjoyed many years as a volunteer at the Boston Museum of Science. He was a wonderful, cherished husband to Annette, beloved father to Allison and Douglas, and grandfather to Gregory, Katie and Julian. He will be missed by all who knew him for his kindness and his gentle, unfailing sense of humor.
COHEN--Hassiba. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. David J. Nathan, Parnas

When his wife, Stefanie Graf, was inducted into the International Hall of Fame in 2004, Andre Agassi gave a memorable, emotional speech introducing her, giving himself a tough act to follow now that he has been inducted himself. Agassi, 40, was announced as the Hall of Fame's only player inductee this year and will speak on his own behalf at the induction ceremony on July 9 in Newport, R.I. Christopher E. Clouser, chairman of the International Tennis Hall of Fame & Museum, said there would be one other inductee, from the contributor category, who will be announced next week.
WALLACE--Dr. Roslyn, 87, passed on peacefully on January 6, 2011. She was an extraordinary therapist, artist and beloved friend.

HAMILTON--Cordelia. The American Folk Art Museum mourns the loss of founding trustee and longtime friend Cordelia Hamilton. Ms. Hamilton operated the important Stony Point Folk Art Gallery in Rockland County, New York, with Adele Earnest, another museum founder. Through their gallery, Ms. Hamilton and Ms. Earnest were instrumental in the recognition of American folk sculpture, particularly weathervanes and decoys, as major artistic expressions. The gallery also promoted the work of major early-twentieth-century self-taught artists, including William Edmondson, Clark Coe, and John Scholl. Through Ms. Hamilton's efforts on behalf of the American Folk Art Museum, significant works of art by these and other artists are in the museum's holdings.
GABI ON THE ROOF IN JULY Opens on Friday in Brooklyn.

CLUNE--Barbara, 75, of Mamaroneck, on January 19. Beloved wife of the late J. Russell Clune. Loving mother of J. Russell Jr., Kevin (Jeanne), Timothy (Theresa), and the late Kathleen. Visiting Sat 2-4 and 7-9pm at Lloyd Maxcy & Sons Beauchamp Chapel, New Rochelle, where a service will be held Sunday at 11am.

SCHWARTZ--Meryl, cherished wife of Jeffrey Salat, devoted daughter of Ann Schwartz and the late Robert Schwartz, loving sister and sister-in-law of Laura Schwartz, Michael Caruso, Melissa Schwartz and David Muenzer, beloved aunt of Benjamin and Emily Schwartz Muenzer, and niece of Wendy and Steven Gelman and Barnett Rukin, passed away at home surrounded by her family on January 20, 2011. A strong, loving woman, she was deeply devoted to her family and friends, and will always be remembered for her thoughtfulness and caring. A gifted and passionate educator, Meryl changed the lives of hundreds of children with learning disabilities as the Elementary School Principal of The Churchill School and Center in Manhattan, and earlier, as a teacher at The Lab School of Washington, D.C. Treating each child as an individual, she found their special strengths and taught them to believe in themselves. To honor her memory and continue her legacy, donations may be made to The Meryl Schwartz Fund for Special Activities at The Churchill School and Center. The Fund will provide financial assistance to families to ensure all children are able to participate in special school activities that Meryl believed fostered a love of school and promoted the children's social development. Services will be held at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, January 23, 2011 at 11:30am, interment thereafter at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Route 109, Farmingdale, NY.

FEENEY--Richard Joseph, Richard Joseph Feeney born April 19, 1925. A Brooklyn native who raised his family in Hempstead, NY and retired to Wood-Ridge, NJ. Richard can be identified by his love of family, friends, and country. He passed away on January 18, 2011 at 85 years of age. Survived by his loving wife, Nancy, children Barbara Kennedy and husband Dennis, William Feeney, Richard Feeney and wife Elizabeth, Robert Feeney and partner Nancy, Kathy Waters and husband Frank, grandchildren Brian Feeney, Shawn Feeney, Kelly Harris and husband Dave, Lauren Kennedy, Alexander Waters and Olivia Waters. Preceded in death by parents Richard and Loretta Feeney, siblings Emily Burke and Theresa Olsen, and grandson Grant Feeney. Survived by siblings, Charles, Loretta Micciantouno, and Margaret Castiglia. He served proudly during World War II with the Navy Seabees in the Pacific Theater, specifically in the Philippine Liberation. He was a Knights of Columbus member for over fifty years and served as an Usher for Our Lady of Loretto Parish in Hempstead, NY for over twenty years. He loved bowling, and during his time as a second-generation route man for the Daily Mirror, he traveled with his dad, Richard, to bowling tournaments with the newspaper league. When the Daily Mirror went out of business, he began working for The New York Times and remained with that organization until his retirement. Visiting hours Friday, January 21, 2011, O'Brien-Sheipe Funeral Home, 640 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY from 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00pm. Mass on Saturday, January 22, 2011 at 10:00 am at St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY. Remains to be cremated, and Navy burial will take place at sea at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Healing Heroes Program of the AMVETS would be appreciated, www.amvetsnsf.org/ donate.html. Mailing Address: AMVETS National Service Foundation, 4647 Forbes Boulevard, Lanham, MD 20706. Toll Free: 800-810-7148. Maryland: 301-459-6181

Stirring a potentially explosive debate over faith and politics, the first Muslim woman to serve in the British cabinet said Thursday that prejudice toward the country's Islamic minority is so prevalent that it is seen by many as normal and uncontroversial and has ''passed the dinner table test.'' The cabinet member, Sayeeda Warsi, told an audience at the University of Leicester: ''It seems to me that Islamophobia has now crossed the threshold of middle-class respectability. For far too many people, Islamophobia is seen as a legitimate, even commendable, thing.'' Lady Warsi is the chairwoman of Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party and a minister without portfolio.

SCHAEFFER--Stanley. February 2, 1921 January 18, 2011. Our darling Stanley and his Blossom enjoyed a 61 yearlong honeymoon together. They never spent one day apart. Stanley was a true man of honor, devoted family man, had a contagious zest for life, and amazing sense of humor. Stanley always greeted everyone with Happy New Year! He was a successful businessman, WWII War veteran, a Mason, avid golfer and handball player. Stanley was truly admired, respected and loved by his family, friends and all who knew him. His children Cindy, Christy, Todd, and Tyler, worshipped him, as did his daughter-in-law Jeri and Amy. His grandchildren Morgan, Lindsay, Andrew and Matthew adored him. For all years to come he will be remembered and celebrated everyday. Stanley succumbed to pancreatic cancer after a three year long courageous battle. In lieu of gifts, donations can be made in his name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday, January 23, 2011 at 12pm. Shiva Sunday following cemetery from 4pm and Monday after 6pm at the Schaeffer residence.

Joe Turner will indeed come to Waterbury, Conn. After three hours of discussion on Wednesday night and testimony from community members and other interested parties, including the dean of the Yale School of Drama, the Waterbury Board of Education allowed a public school's production of the August Wilson play ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' to proceed in February. In doing so, board members overruled an initial decision by their schools superintendent, who had tried to cancel the play because its dialogue includes several uses of the word ''nigger.''

KIRSHNER--Don. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to our life-long friend Suzette, her sister, Sheila, Roy, and the entire Kirshner Family as we mourn the passing of Don Kirshner. May he rest in peace. The Fischman Family The Haber Family

Mary Martin's curtain-fabric dirndl from the Broadway production of ''The Sound of Music'' was meant to look homemade for a reason. In the show, the governess Maria, played by Martin, dresses the von Trapp children in clothing made from curtains. But the dirndl, cut from a blue-and-white scrolled wool broadcloth, was the work of a notable 20th-century designer, Mainbocher, who designed some of Martin's clothing on and off stage.

Kelly Walsifer, the fiancée of Police Officer Christopher Matlosz, was embraced at his funeral on Thursday in Lakewood, N.J. He was shot to death last week.
MOGITZ--Elliott, the Millman family extends its deepest sympathy to Michelle Zitwer and the Mogitz family on Elliot's passing. Elliot was a dear and cherished friend. We will him miss sorely.
