(CBS) MEDIUM After seven seasons and a move from one network to another, this series ends with Allison (Patricia Arquette, above with Enrique Murciano) and Joe (Jake Weber) being pulled in different directions -- and their family forever changed -- when she becomes a lawyer, and he starts a new job. 7:20 P.M. (Starz) 2012 (2009) The director Roland Emmerich ''cracks the planet like a nut, splitting its crust, toppling its mountains and cities, and laying its every creeping thing to inevitable tedious waste,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this doomsday drama. Woody Harrelson plays the fellow who has predicted it all, taking his cue from a Maya prophecy. The cast is rounded out by John Cusack as a divorced dad and Amanda Peet as his eye-rolling ex; Danny Glover as the American president; Chiwetel Ejiofor as a sort of mad scientist; Oliver Platt as a sleazy White House aide; and Thandie Newton as the president's daughter. ''Mr. Harrelson looks like he's actually having the kind of good time stupid movies should provide but that this one roundly fails to deliver,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''Despite the frenetic action scenes, the movie sags, done in by multiple story lines that undercut one another and by the heaviness of its conceit.''

The hedge fund manager Grange Johnson of LaGrange Capital Partners had a banner year in 2010. His two portfolios returned nearly 70 percent in a period when the average hedge fund gained about 10 percent. But those gains will bring new challenges this year. With his total assets now above $150 million, Mr. Johnson will have to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under a new rule created to increase industry oversight.

JPMorgan Chase said on Thursday that it had hired James C. Woolery, one of the top deal lawyers at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, as one of its senior mergers bankers, marking the latest big shift by a lawyer into banking. Mr. Woolery will assume the title of co-head of North American mergers and acquisitions, working alongside Chris Ventresca, who already serves in that role. Jeff Stute, the other existing co-head, will take over as head of JPMorgan's North American health care coverage from Robbie Huffines, who will become a vice chairman of investment banking.

CHICAGO -- Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, has raised more than $10 million in his quest to become mayor of Chicago. Filed with state election officials on Thursday, the campaign reports of Mr. Emanuel and his opponents offered a first real look at the financial side of this city's first competitive race for mayor in years.

BORENSTEIN--Irving. The entire National Jewish Health community is shocked and saddened at the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Irving Borenstein, who passed away last Monday. For 32 years, he was the guiding force of National Jewish Health in New York City, raising millions of dollars for patient care and research through the legendary Real Estate, Financial Industry, and Retail Industry dinners. Founded in 1899 as a nonprofit hospital, National Jewish Health is the nation's preeminent respiratory hospital and research institution, specializing also in cardiac and immune related diseases. Irving's talent, dedication and integrity brought great honor to National Jewish Health and forged relationships of warmth and respect with some of the leading philanthropists in New York. We send our condolences to his family and friends. Irving will be greatly missed. National Jewish Health Michael Salem, MD President & CEO Larry Silverstein, Treasurer

New York City's unemployment rate fell below 9 percent in December to its lowest level in 20 months, but not because more residents found work at the end of the year. The decline in the unemployment rate to 8.9 percent, from 9.1 percent in November, resulted from a decrease in the number of people looking for work, possibly because they were discouraged about their prospects. Indeed, data released Thursday by the state labor department showed that the number of private-sector jobs in the city declined slightly in December, shrinking by 3,600 jobs, or 0.1 percent.

PARK CITY, Utah- Morgan Spurlock's new documentary, a humorous look at product placement and advertising called "The Greatest Movie Ever Sold," was shrouded in an abnormal amount of secrecy before its Sundance screening on Saturday. Some reporters figured out what was going on, but a superheroic effort by Mr. Spurlock's publicity firm, Ginsberg/Libby, kept the most crucial secret just that.

In 2004, Johnny Damon and Manny Ramirez were two of the main actors on the rambunctious and resilient Boston Red Sox team that made a historic comeback in the American League Championship Series and then went on to win the franchise's first championship in 86 years.

President Obama's planned State of the Union address is the focus of the Sunday television talk shows, as lawmakers and former presidential advisers discuss their expectations for the speech and the next two years. Rafael Nadal went into his semifinal match at the Beijing stop on the ATP Tour in fall 2009 in seemingly fine form again. He had vanquished Marcos Baghdatis and James Blake in tight early-round matches then thrashed Marat Safin in the quarterfinals with the loss of only four games.

LAKE FOREST, Ill. - Although Chicago Bears quarterback Jay Cutler and his Green Bay counterpart, Aaron Rodgers, are friends, they have spent the past week avoiding their usual exchanges of text messages as each prepares for Sunday's N.F.C. championship game.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - Not that you asked, but when I became a mother for the first time, I realized that I was hideously unprepared. When you rock your baby to sleep, a good mother should automatically have a whole repertoire of soothing melodies to croon, shouldn't she?

My Sunday column is a show-and-tell of an experiment I conducted in Beijing to look for the boundaries of what is permissible on the Chinese Internet. A Chinese editor I much admired, Qin Benli, taught me a wonderful expression in Chinese, 擦边球, or cabianqiu, meaning a ping pong ball that just nicks the edge of table. It's legal, but with no room to spare. Qin told me that that is exactly what a good Chinese journalist aims to do with each article. So I tried to construct a blog and micro-blog (the Chinese equivalent of Twitter) to find out where the cabianqiu are.  Below are pictures of a micro-blog and blog that I started in Beijing in December:
Win

The chatter among festival programmers has been that the film's female lead, a young British actress named Felicity Jones, is this year's Carey Mulligan ("An Education").

PARK CITY, Utah- Walking up Main Street here on Friday afternoon, John Hawkes was recognized by some fans and happily posed for a few photos. Mr. Hawkes has always been a Sundance darling, but now the rest of the world is taking note. As the menacing addict and familyman Teardrop in Debra Granik's Ozarks drama "Winter's Bone," he's received awards buzz and nominations, the most attention of a career that has included roles in "Deadwood" and Miranda July's 2005 Sundance hit, "Me and You and Everyone We Know." Mr. Hawkes is back at Sundance with two films: "Martha Marcy May Marlene," in which he plays a cult leader; and "Higher Ground," Vera Farmiga's directorial debut. (He also voiced a talking cat in Ms. July's second feature, "The Future," which had its premiere here on Friday, though she eventually replaced him with her own voice.)

On Thursday, NBC's news division staged an elaborate presentation for advertisers, seeking to sell commercial time in NBC's news programs over the next year. All the members of MSNBC's prime-time lineup spoke at the lunch with one exception: Keith Olbermann, the network's biggest star.

PARK CITY, Utah- It's hard to keep your head on straight amid the whip and whirl of Sundance, especially if you are a reporter getting besieged by breathless emails from squadrons of publicists. What's real buzz and what's fake buzz? Who knows, really. But here's a one-word warning about hopping too quickly on any bandwagon: "Hesher."

The Toronto tough guy Colton Orr was so out of control in the Maple Leafs' 7-0 loss to the Rangers on Wednesday that John Tortorella, the Rangers' coach, sat his top defensemen, Marc Staal and Dan Girardi, for much of the third period.

PARK CITY, Utah- Sundance is known for showcasing gritty documentaries, and this year's festival is no exception. "How to Die in Oregon," about assisted suicide for the terminally ill, opens with a cancer patient literally dying on camera. Enjoy!

The N.B.A. may be a league of superstars, but it can be fun to root occasionally for the home team to win. With that in mind, fans may want to circle their calendars for when Washington comes to town.

As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Tunisia's uprising began in the impoverished town of Sidi Bouzid, where a street vendor whose wares were confiscated by the police set himself on fire outside of a government building in December.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - If you were born and raised in the United States, odds are good that you have not had a lot of exposure to cryptic crosswords. I fall into that group, but I've resolved to fix that. American-style crosswords are wonderful, but just look at the variety of puzzles we have available to us every Sunday in The New York Times. Sometimes the brain needs a little something different on which to nosh, no?

Samuel Brittan points us to John Kemp suggesting that global growth is hitting supply-side limits. The argument is that while high unemployment and low inflation may prevail in advanced economies, the rest of the world is facing accelerating inflation, together with rising commodity prices. And that is, indeed, a fair picture of what's going on.

ROME-Tod's, the Italian luxury group, pledged $34 million on Friday toward the restoration of the Colosseum. The work-which includes cleaning and reinforcing the exterior of the nearly 2000-year-old monument, its circular galleries and some underground spaces currently off-limits to the public-could begin by the end of the year and is expected to last between two and three years. The Colosseum will remain open during the restoration, which will be monitored by the Culture Ministry.

CHASANOFF--Michael J.,born February 22, 1932 died January 21, 2011. Son of the late Hanna and Harris Chasanoff, he leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Judy, and their children: Nancy and Michael Butler, Stephen and Susan, Robert and Veronica; grandchildren: Daniel, Allison, Jenna, Chloe, Brian, Jamie; brother: Allan, and Joanna Bayless. Mickey was graduated from Yale University in 1953, where he was the starting varsity catcher. Baseball, horse racing, fishing, all were active interests in his life. He was a baseball coach to many young people. He owned, raced, and bred horses for 45 years. To him, the sport of fishing was an occasion for bonding with others. Mickey was a self-realized, successful man. A visionary developer, he was a major force in Long Island real estate. He served on numerous boards with zeal and commitment, including several terms as a Commissioner of the Port Authority of NY and NJ. Mickey was a generous friend to many, both in word and deed. Above all, he adored his family. Funeral services will be held on Monday, January 24, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC, at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Mount Sinai Medical Center of New York, where Mickey received exemplary care.

When (or perhaps if) ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' opens on March 15, it will be a day of emotion and fulfillment for that long-delayed musical's cast, creative team and producers, and also for Jackie Mason. Yes, you read that right: Mr. Mason, the comedian, actor and monologist, has his own reasons for awaiting the official opening of ''Spider-Man,'' after what will have been at least five delays of its opening night and more than 100 preview performances. On that day, Mr. Mason will no longer hold what appears to be the record for the most previews performed by a Broadway show before its opening, set in 1969 when his play ''A Teaspoon Every Four Hours'' played 97 previews - and then closed on its opening night.

SCHIFFMAN--Paul. Poet, merchant mariner, freighter captain, and bartender died peacefully on Wednesday, January 19th at his home in Manhattan. He was 84. He served at sea for over 25 years and then worked as a bartender at the Lion's Head, a famed watering hole in Greenwich Village for another 25 years. He will be greatly missed by many. A funeral service will be held this Sunday 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

You may not have realized that the balloon dog you bought for a buck from a street clown might be a collector's item. But the artist Jeff Koons, who constructed a 10-foot tall ''Balloon Dog'' that has been exhibited in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and elsewhere, sent a cease-and-desist letter to a Canadian manufacturer and San Francisco gallery for producing and selling ''Balloon Dog'' bookends. Now the gallery, Park Life, has asked a federal court for a declaratory judgment that states the canine shape cannot be copyrighted, according to Courthouse News Service. ''As virtually any clown can attest, no one owns the idea of making a balloon dog, and the shape created by twisting a balloon into a dog-like form is part of the public domain,'' the gallery says in its federal complaint. ''Any similarities between the Balloon Dog Bookend compared with the Balloon Dog Structure are driven by the wholly unprotectable idea of depicting the shape of a balloon dog in a solid form.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Shakespeare's Globe Theater will present a familiar array of the writer's plays in 2012 but in some unfamiliar languages. The reconstructed theater, in the Southwark section of London, announced what it calls a ''Cultural Olympiad,'' in which all of the plays will be performed, each in a different language. The idea is to present a theatrical counterpart to the Olympic games which are scheduled to take place in London that year. In a statement Dominic Dromgoole, the Globe's artistic director called it ''a terrifically clear and simple and slightly bananas idea'' that would demonstrate Shakespeare's international appeal. The roster, scheduled to begin on Shakespeare's birthday, April 23, includes ''The Tempest'' in Arabic, ''Titus Andronicus'' in Cantonese, ''Julius Caesar'' in Italian, ''Henry VIII'' in Spanish and ''Taming of the Shrew'' in Urdu. A performance of ''Love's Labour's Lost'' in British sign language is also planned. ''His plays have been translated into every major living language,'' Mr. Dromgoole said, ''and there is a long tradition of Shakespeare performances around the world in people's own vernacular.''

A picture caption on Page 19 this weekend with the continuation of a cover article about the 10 greatest classical composers misspells the given name of Verdi. He was Giuseppe Verdi, not Guiseppe.

Two Roman Catholic grade schools on the West Side of Manhattan will merge in September as part of a broad reorganization plan that calls for the closing of 27 schools at the end of the current academic year, the Archdiocese of New York announced on Friday. The merger will combine the student bodies of Holy Cross School, on 43rd Street, and Sacred Heart of Jesus School, on 52nd Street, each of which has about 200 students in kindergarten through eighth grade. The schools will use the Sacred Heart of Jesus building, which has the larger capacity and is said to be in better physical condition.

12:05 a.m. | Updated Keith Olbermann, the highest-rated host on MSNBC, announced abruptly on the air Friday night that he was leaving his show, ''Countdown,'' immediately. The host, who has had a stormy relationship with the management of the network for some time, especially since he was suspended for two days last November, came to an agreement with NBC's corporate management late this week to settle his contract and step down.

The Sports of The Times column on Jan. 14, about the increased toxicity of the rivalry between the Jets and the New England Patriots in recent years, misstated the year the Jets and the Miami Dolphins met in the American Football Conference championship game. It was January 1983, not 1982.

Hoodies and corsets, sweats and power suits are all being celebrated as the year's best cinematic outfits by the Costume Designers Guild. The group announced its nominees for its annual awards on Friday, and there were more nominees in the contemporary film category than in either period or fantasy. ''The Fighter,'' ''The King's Speech'' and ''True Grit'' are nominated in the period film category, while the contemporary hopefuls are ''Black Swan,'' ''Burlesque,'' ''Inception,'' ''The Social Network'' and ''Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.'' The fantasy film nominees are ''Alice in Wonderland,'' ''Tron: Legacy'' and ''The Tempest.'' The nominee for ''Black Swan,'' Amy Westcott, was responsible for the clothing that the cast wore offstage, but the ballet costumes for the final-act performance were handmade by the sisters behind the fashion line Rodarte.

Evan Bayh, the former senator from Indiana, has joined Apollo Global Management, the New York private equity firm. Mr. Bayh, considered a centrist Democrat and once on the short list of vice presidential candidates for President Obama, announced a year ago he wasn't seeking re-election after serving two terms in the senate.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a management shake-up at Google misstated the details of the company's control. The co-founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, and the chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, together control the company through their shares; they do not each have ''controlling stakes.'' (While the three hold slightly more than 20 percent of the outstanding shares, a dual stock structure gives each of the founders about 28 percent of the voting power and Mr. Schmidt about 9 percent.)

Tod's, the luxury goods company, pledged $34 million on Friday toward the restoration of the Colosseum in Rome. The work, which includes cleaning and reinforcing the exterior of the nearly 2,000-year-old monument, above, its circular galleries and some underground spaces, could begin by the end of the year and is expected to last two to three years. The Colosseum will remain open during the restoration. At a news conference in the Colosseum, Diego Della Valle, the chief executive of Tod's, said he was pleased to be able to give something back to his country and pledged that he would not exploit the sponsorship for commercial purposes. ''I hope other businessmen will follow suit,'' he said. Drastic funding cuts by the government have sharply reduced the number and scope of restorations that can be carried out each year, and private sponsorship is not widespread in Italy. Rome's mayor, Gianni Alemanno, said such a large donation ''sends an important signal,'' particularly in a time of economic crisis.

Updated, 4:33 p.m. | A federal judge in Manhattan refused on Friday to overturn to overturn the conviction of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani on a sole count in a trial stemming from the 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa, which killed 224 people. Mr. Ghailani, the first Guantanamo detainee to be tried in the civilian system, was acquitted on Nov. 17 of more than 280 counts of murder and conspiracy, while being convicted of a single count of conspiracy to destroy government buildings and property.

The second installment of Fox's new season of ''American Idol'' delivered 22.9 million viewers on Thursday, down more than three million from the premiere on Wednesday but far ahead of any other programming on the night, according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox led the night over all, garnering 10.9 million viewers for ''Bones'' at 9 p.m., after ''Idol.'' CBS ranked second, benefiting from ''CSI'' (14.3 million) and ''The Mentalist'' (14.7 million) from 9 to 11 while earning strong ratings for its sitcoms in the 8 p.m. hour, ''The Big Bang Theory'' (13.6 million) and ''$#*! My Dad Says'' (10.3 million). NBC and ABC tied for third with NBC broadcasting new episodes of its comedy lineup, including ''The Office'' (8.3 million) and ''30 Rock'' (5.3 million) and premieres of ''Perfect Couples'' (4.2 million) and ''Parks and Recreation'' (6.2 million). ABC garnered solid results for ''Wipeout'' at 8 (8.3 million) but meager ratings for reruns the rest of the night.

A month after Universal Music Group hired away a top executive from Sony Music Entertainment, its chief rival, the company is making several changes in senior management positions and cutting about 60 lower-level jobs. The moves begin what is expected to be a series of staffing changes in coming weeks that could reshape the lines of power at the world's largest record company.

TENENBAUM--L. Jay. Renowned arbitrageur and philanthropist L. Jay Tenenbaum died peacefully at his Woodside, California home on January 16, 2011. He was 88. L. Jay grew up in St. Louis, Missouri, and attended Vanderbilt University. In 1942, he joined the U.S. Army, achieving the rank of 2nd Lieutenant and serving with the 10th Mountain Division in Italy. He received a Silver Star, Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts for his service. L. Jay joined Goldman Sachs in 1953 and went on to head the Trading and Arbitrage department. A great source of professional pride was hiring and training some of the firm's most distinguished future leaders. He retired in 1976. Following retirement, L. Jay served as vice-chairman of the board of the San Francisco Ballet; board member of the Commonwealth Club of California, Youth Tennis Advantage, KQED and Stern Grove Association; and Deputy Chief of Protocol of San Francisco under Mayor Frank Jordan. L. Jay is survived by his wife, Gretchen; his sons and their wives, Harry (Rafaela), Bruce (Julie), Kurt (Kristina); his granddaughter, Layne; and his sister, Joy Dunkelman (Mel). The family recognizes those who cared for L. Jay during his illness and the extraordinary compassion he received both at home and at the Stanford University Hospital. A memorial will be held today, Saturday, January 22 at 1:00pm at the Menlo Circus Club in Atherton, California. Donations in L. Jay's memory may be directed to the San Francisco Ballet, or the Commonwealth Club. A celebration of his life is being planned in New York City for later this year.

Risque scenes on the hit MTV drama ''Skins'' have caused one company to remove its commercials from the program and have spurred a call by a TV watchdog group for a federal investigation. Taco Bell said Thursday that it had shifted its ads to other programs because ''Skins'' was ''not a fit for our brand.'' MTV did not respond to repeated requests for comment on Friday.

An article on Tuesday about the failure of many published papers on clinical trials in medicine to cite previous related studies, using information from researchers at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, erroneously included work by Dr. Beverly B. Green of Group Health in Seattle as an example of such a lapse. One of Dr. Green's papers, about blood pressure monitoring and control, and published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, did in fact cite a scientific review of prior studies that included many of the 21 trials that the Hopkins researchers said her paper ignored. It was not the case that her paper failed to cite any of those 21 studies. (The article included a response from Dr. Green in which she explained her general approach to choosing citations, but did not specifically address the 21 trials. After the article appeared, she contacted The Times to give a more precise rebuttal to the Johns Hopkins findings.)

MARCUS--Natalie Snider, 94, matriarch, philanthropist and flooring industry legend died peacefully in her home in New York City on Thursday, January 20, 2011 in the same graceful way that she lived. The only child of Esther and Ellis Snider, Natalie was born in Brookline, MA. She graduated from Smith College in 1938 and later received a Masters Degree at McGill College. In 1939 she married her husband of 53 years, Robert Marcus who passed away in 1992. Natalie became an integral part of her husband's business known as Amtico Flooring, spearheading the company's design department and earning 15 awards from the Association of Interior design. She was also a great philanthropist heading the effort to refurbish the Greenwood House, also known as The Jewish Home for the Aged in Ewing, NJ. Her remarkable efforts have been recognized throughout the Jewish community and the home is now known as Robert and Natalie Marcus Home for the Jewish Aged. Natalie is survived by her two sons and daughters-in-law, Roger and Sondra; and Richard and Beth; four grandchildren, Elissa, Julie, Teri, and Todd; and six great-grandchildren. During her long life, she was a resident of Trenton, NJ; Rancho Mirage, CA; Princeton, NJ; and finally New York, NY. Funeral services are Sunday, 1pm at Har Sinai Temple, 2421 Pennington Road, Pennington, NJ. The burial will follow at Greenwood Cemetery, Hamilton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully requests memorial contributions be offered to: Greenwood House Foundation, Inc., 53 Walter St., Ewing, NJ 08628. Shiva will be observed on Monday, January 24, 1-9pm at the Marcus residence, 721 Fifth Avenue (Entrance on 56th St. between 5th and Madison Aves.) For info: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, (609)883-1400

Despite strong reviews and robust ticket sales, Lincoln Center Theater will have to wait until the fall of 2011 to transfer Jon Robin Baitz's ''Other Desert Cities'' to Broadway because the 40 Broadway houses are all booked, according to executives involved with the transfer discussions. Philip J. Smith, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, the biggest and most powerful theater owner on Broadway with 17 houses, said that he and his staff have had ''Other Desert Cities,'' which stars Stockard Channing and Stacy Keach, above, on their radar for months. But a quick move from Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater isn't as easy as it was under the previous Shubert leadership team, the late Gerald Schoenfeld and Bernard B. Jacobs, who were known for making deals to move hot shows quickly into their houses. Philip Rinaldi, a spokesman for Lincoln Center Theater, declined to discuss the details of talks with theater owners, but said: ''It is our intention to move the show to Broadway in the fall as there are no theaters available this spring.'' He added that it was too early to talk about casting for a Broadway run of ''Other Desert Cities.''

The days of the free debit card may be coming to an end at some banks. That would make it the first bank that we know of to adopt such fees.

Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack is considering a sale of the company, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Pep Boys, the auto-parts chain based in Philadelphia, has hired Bank of America to seek out potential buyers, said this person, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about the matter. It is unlikely that another company will acquire Pep Boys. Instead, a likely buyer would be a large private equity firm like Apollo Global Management or Bain Capital. A sale of Pep Boys would be the latest signal that corporate boards have confidence in executing mergers and acquisitions amid a revived credit market and a stable stock market. At the same time, private equity firms are awash with cash that they are looking to put to work. On Thursday, DealBook reported that Warner Music Group is on the auction block. J. Crew, the retail chain, announced a deal last year to be acquired by TPG, the private equity firm. Shares of Pep Boys traded higher Thursday after Bloomberg first reported the company was in play. In midday trading Friday, Pep Boys shares rose $2.42, or 19.6 percent, to $14.74. That gives the company a market value of about $775 million. Pep Boys was founded in 1921 by Emanuel ''Manny'' Rosenfeld, Maurice ''Moe'' Strauss, Moe Radavitz and Graham ''Jack'' Jackson with a single store in Philadelphia. Today it has more than 600 locations across the country that sell auto parts and provide repair services. The auto-parts retailing business is fiercely competitive, with the largest players being AutoZone, Advance Auto and O'Reilly Automotive. The recession has had a positive effect on the companies because consumers are keeping their cars longer, which has created more demand for parts and services. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHWARTZ--Meryl, cherished wife of Jeffrey Salat, devoted daughter of Ann Schwartz and the late Robert Schwartz, loving sister and sister-in-law of Laura Schwartz, Michael Caruso, Melissa Schwartz and David Muenzer, beloved aunt of Benjamin and Emily Schwartz Muenzer, and niece of Wendy and Steven Gelman and Barnett Rukin, passed away at home surrounded by her family on January 20, 2011. A strong, loving woman, she was deeply devoted to her family and friends, and will always be remembered for her thoughtfulness and caring. A gifted and passionate educator, Meryl changed the lives of hundreds of children with learning disabilities as the Elementary School Principal of The Churchill School and Center in Manhattan, and earlier, as a teacher at The Lab School of Washington, D.C. Treating each child as an individual, she found their special strengths and taught them to believe in themselves. To honor her memory and continue her legacy, donations may be made to The Meryl Schwartz Fund for Special Activities at The Churchill School and Center. The Fund will provide financial assistance to families to ensure all children are able to participate in special school activities that Meryl believed fostered a love of school and promoted the children's social development. Services will be held at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, January 23, 2011 at 11:30am, interment thereafter at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Route 109, Farmingdale, NY.

To his beloved wife Judy and their cherished children Nancy, Stephen and Robert, our heartfelt condolences. Mickey's legacy will live on in the many people who loved him. Martin Berkowitz and Millie David

BLAKE--Edmund J. Jr.,husband of Carol Blake died January 20, 2011. He was a loyal friend to everyone that had the fortune of knowing him. Edmund was born 1928 Medford, MA. He graduated from Boston Latin School, Harvard College and Harvard Business School class of 1953. He was an active competitive sailor 210 Class in Marblehead. Edmund's first job was assistant to Peter Grace. He then became treasurer of Philip Morris, and a partner in venture capital with Louis Marks and Dan Lufkin. For the last 20 years Edmund was with Pinnacle Associates as an investment manager and economist. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst and sat on the board of examiners. He was president and active supporter of Madison Square Boys and Girls Club. Edmund was also a board member of the American Liver Foundation, Sacred Heart at 91st Street and New York Academy of Sciences. While he was a successful investor in finance, his greatest investments were in friendships that he fostered throughout the years. He will truly be missed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Madison Square Boys and Girls Club. Funeral Mass will be held 10:30am on Monday January 24th at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st Street, New York, NY.

(Science) AN IDIOT ABROAD On the heels of his merciless stint as host of the Golden Globes, Ricky Gervais, above left, turns the humor on himself as he and his longtime collaborator Stephen Merchant, above right, send their ''simple curmudgeon of a friend,'' Karl Pilkington, center, around the world to see the Seven Wonders. Mr. Merchant says he wants the journey to broaden Mr. Pilkington's mind, while Mr. Gervais wants to sully his friend's experience for his own amusement. Mr. Pilkington's reaction to the grand scheme is anyone's guess. The men begin their practical joke turned social experiment with a discussion like those they have on the animated ''The Ricky Gervais Show'' (Fridays at 9 p.m. on HBO) in which they reveal the methods behind their madness. At 10, Mr. Pilkington heads to the Great Wall of China, where he partakes of traditional fire massage, learns kung fu and hears some disturbing news about his future from a fortune teller. PARK CITY, Utah- "Docbuster" is what Morgan Spurlock calls his product placement documentary "The Greatest Movie Ever Sold" - excuse us, "Pom Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold" (as our colleague Brooks Barnes told us yesterday). In the film, Mr. Spurlock, the stunt documentarian behind "Supersize Me," doesn't address whether (or how well) marketing sponsorships and tie-ins work on consumers, but at the premiere of the film on Saturday, it was kind of clear. Appearing at the Q&A wearing a suit adorned with the logos of the corporations that funded his movie - Pom pomegranate juice, JetBlue Airways, Ban deodorant, etc. - Mr. Spurlock brought the company executives, a k a his cast, up front with him for a resounding round of applause. He began drinking a bottle of Pom. "I'm 40 percent happier, suddenly," he said.

The Green Bay Packers are headed back to the Super Bowl after beating the Chicago Bears, 21-14, in the N.F.C. championship game at Soldier Field. But before their trip to Dallas was sealed, they had to withstand a rally attempt led by perhaps the most unlikely figure in championship game history. Caleb Hanie, the Bears' third-string quarterback, was forced into action after Jay Cutler and Todd Collins were both knocked out with injuries. Hanie threw a 35-yard touchdown to Earl Bennett with 4:43 remaining that pulled the Bears within 7 points, but his inexperience showed. He threw one interception that was returned B.J. Raji 18 yards for a score and he was picked off by Sam Shields with about 40 seconds left, a play that sealed the Packers' victory.

My husband has a major birthday coming up in March. To celebrate, I would like to take him for a long weekend within about four hours' drive from New York City. I am looking for a romantic inn with a comfortable lounge and fireplace and good food at a rate of less than $300 a night. We prefer small places rather than large resorts. We don't ski but would like to be close to some good hiking (providing there is not too much snow) or some interesting place to visit. Do you have any suggestions? Wendy Johnson, New YorkA.I loved the Waybury Inn (wayburyinn.com) in East Middlebury, Vt., at the base of the Green Mountains, where I stayed in October. The drive from New York is five hours but well worth it, since it will meet your needs: it is romantic, with a comfortable lounge and fireplace, and has excellent dining options; doubles, with bathroom, start at $130. The 13 rooms vary in size and decor; I stayed in the sumptuous Robert Frost room - he was a frequent diner at the inn - with a sitting area and a Jacuzzi in the bathroom; in the room, you'll also find the ''secret'' wooden box with hundreds of letters written by past guests - reflections on life - which can easily take up hours of your time.

On Thursday, NBC's news division staged an elaborate presentation for advertisers, seeking to sell commercial time in NBC's news programs over the next year. All the members of MSNBC's prime-time lineup spoke at the lunch with one exception: Keith Olbermann, the network's biggest star. For the last several weeks, Mr. Olbermann and the network have been in negotiations to end his successful run on MSNBC, according to executives involved in the talks who requested anonymity because the talks were confidential. The deal was completed on Friday, and Mr. Olbermann made the announcement on his final ''Countdown'' hours later.

The Anaheim Ducks were headed to Montreal for a rare visit Saturday night, but more significant for Canadiens fans is the return of Saku Koivu, the Canadiens' former captain. Koivu's tenure in that role was mixed. He had a record of perseverance and achievement, but it was complicated by the difficulties of leading hockey's most storied team - and the cultural pressures of playing in Montreal, where language can be a politically charged issue.

SHAPIRO--E. Donald. The Trustees and Dean of California Western School of Law celebrate the life of former New York Law School Dean E. Donald Shapiro. Shapiro served as a member of California Western's Council of Visitors from 2002 until his death on December 27, 2010. A visionary in legal education and the field of health law, Shapiro left a lasting impact on the many students, colleagues, organizations, and institutions he touched throughout a career spanning five decades. California Western honored Shapiro's work with the E. Donald Shapiro Professorship in the field of health law, founded in 2007. The school has established the E. Donald Shapiro Memorial Scholarship for an outstanding student in health law. Dean Steven R. Smith, along with the Trustees, faculty, and staff of California Western School of Law, recognize the life and career of Dean Shapiro and send their deepest condolences to Merle Shapiro and family.
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

EVERY January, the mayor stands at a lectern and delivers the State of the City address, a snapshot of the metropolis from 30,000 feet, with a few local details -- a new fishing pier here, a new middle-income housing development there -- tossed in to help make his case that the government is hard at work to make your life better. That's one municipal truth. But there are other realities. New Yorkers live in the city, but we also live in a specific place: a borough, a neighborhood, a block. And on the block -- there are about 70,000 of them in New York -- is where things happen that affect the texture and the quality of life as it's actually lived.

DRIBBEN--Elizabeth L.,New York City, passed away on January 20, 2011 after a long illness. Elizabeth was born in Buffalo, NY on August 20, 1937 and was the daughter of the late Louis Dribben and Clara Franklin. A graduate of Lafayette High School (Buffalo) and University of Buffalo, "Liz" enjoyed a four-decade career encompassing almost every aspect of broadcast news from writing to producing to on-air reporting, both locally on Buffalo's WKBW-TV and nationally for CBS News, in both radio and television. A pioneer among women in her field, Dribben continued to mentor younger reporters in her capacity as a member of the Adjunct Faculty of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University. At CBS from 197293, Dribben was principal writerproducer for Mike Wallace and Dan Rather, and produced her own program, One on One, eventually racking up some 2000 in-depth interviews with newsmakers in politics and the arts, from jurist Robert Bork to actress Helen Hayes. Her passion for theatre was legendary. She created and managed the network's (and the world's) first satellite radio unit. Ms. Dribben was a 2001 inductee of the Buffalo Broadcasting Hall of Fame, and a 2008 inductee to the Lafayette High School Hall of Fame. While she leaves no immediate family, she is survived by cousins in Albany, New York City and Israel, with her "family of friends" intertwined world-wide throughout the broadcasting and performance arts world. Elizabeth's generosity extends beyond her life, with the donation of her body to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Contributions in her memory may be made to the University at Buffalo (Attn: Cindy Johannes E. Dribben Archives, P.O. Box 730, Buffalo, NY) or the Buffalo Broadcasters (Buffalo Broadcasters Association, 5672 Main Street, Williamsville, NY 14221) to help with the archiving of over 2,000 items from Elizabeth's vast portfolio from personal correspondence to reel to reel tape interviews. Memorial services in Buffalo and New York City will be planned over the next few months. Toot-a-loo, Elizabeth - and spin that prayer wheel for us!

CROSSON--Matthew T. We are deeply saddened by the untimely death before Christmas of our former colleague, as Deputy and Chief Administrator of New York's Courts. He was a professional of impeccable integrity and incisive intelligence whose immeasurable contributions were also marked with a lively wit. Matt had only recently embarked on the next phase of his career as CEO of the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce after 16 years as President of The Long Island Association. May his beloved wife Elaine and son Daniel find consolation from treasured memories and widespread appreciation for his sterling record of public and private sector service. Sol Wachtler & Joseph W. Bellacosa

The cover article on Jan. 9 about the 41 places to go in 2011 gave the incorrect nationality of an architect who is designing a series of artists' studios in former houses and churches on Fogo Island, Newfoundland, and misspelled his surname. He is Todd Saunders, not Sanders, and he is Canadian, not Norwegian.

SCHATZKIN--Arthur Gould, aged 62, died on January 20, 2011 after a year-long battle with glioblastoma. Dr. Schatzkin was a physician and Chief of the Nutritional Epidemiology Branch of the Division of Cancer Epidemiology at the National Cancer Institute and was an internationally renowned pioneer in the field of nutrition and cancer. He was the author of over 400 publications and cared deeply about the impact of his work on public health. Beloved husband of Tamara Harris Schatzkin, loving father of Eric and Rebecca and father-in-law of Gregory Vincent, cherished brother of Paul Schatzkin and Dorothy Schatzkin Higgins. Dr. Schatzkin graduated from Yale University in 1969, from SUNY Downstate College of Medicine in 1976, and from Columbia University School of Public Health, Sociomedical Sciences, in 1982. Arthur was a man of principle, passionate about his work, his family, and his hope of a better, more equal world. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in support of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). Donations are accepted online at www.fnih.org or by check at Foundation for NIH, 9650 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20814. Please indicate that this gift is in memory of Dr. Arthur Schatzkin in support of DCEG, NOB, and NCI research.

The N.F.L. is stretching the meaning of a ticket to the Super Bowl, the most prized ticket in sports. The league is selling several thousand $200 tickets for fans to watch the championship showdown - not in Cowboys Stadium, but outside the $1.12 billion behemoth, on television. This is the first time the N.F.L. is selling tickets to a Super Bowl television party, because Cowboys Stadium - known for its gargantuan 72-by-160-foot dual video screens hanging over the field - also has big monitors outside.

EAST LANSING, Mich. -- The epiphany hit Michigan State basketball Coach Tom Izzo a few weeks ago while he was reviewing game video. He did not say anything about the discovery at first, but asked the senior point guard Kalin Lucas to watch the same cut with him. The video was from last season, months before Lucas collapsed to the floor during an N.C.A.A. tournament game with a ruptured Achilles' tendon, and it featured Lucas driving the lane with ease against Texas.

The auto industry recalled about 20.3 million vehicles last year, and three of the five automakers with the most recalls were Japanese, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Wednesday. It was the fourth-largest number of vehicles recalled since the safety agency began keeping track in 1966. The nadir was 2004, when 30.8 million vehicles were recalled. In contrast, about 16.6 million vehicles were recalled in 2009.

ADAMS--F. Gerard (Jerry) 81, prominent economist who spent the bulk of his career at the University of Pennsylvania, died Saturday, January 15 in Newton, MA of complications related to pancreatic cancer. He was the author of a substantial body of research over a distinguished career. After spending 37 years at the University of Pennsylvania, he moved to Northeastern University in Boston. He completed his final teaching assignment there this last December, 2010. Prof. Adams was born in Breslau in 1929. His family emigrated to the United States in 1939. He attended the University of Michigan, receiving an undergraduate degree in 1949 and then continuing on to obtain a Ph.D. in 1956 under the supervision of Lawrence Klein, who subsequently went on to win the Nobel Prize in Economics. In 1961, he joined Klein, who had moved to the University of Pennsylvania, where he remained until 1998. He helped Klein to create the Wharton Model, one of the first econometric forecasting models using computers to simulate the world economy. It subsequently grew into the Link Model, which forecasts the economy using a variety of input data from smaller models around the world, and which contributed to Klein's Nobel Prize in 1980. Prof. Adams served as the director of the Economics Research Unit at the University of Pennsylvania and a principal investigator on the Link Model. Together with Klein, he was one of the founding members of Wharton Economic Forecasting Associates. He was the author of over 250 research articles and over a dozen books, including "The Business Forecasting Revolution," "East Asian Development: Will the East Asian Growth Miracle Survive?," "Macroeconomics for Business and Society," "The E-Business and the New Economy," and "East Asia and the New Economy." He submitted the manuscript for his newest book "Globalization and the New Economy" in December. Prof. Adams is survived by his wife Heidi Vernon, his brothers Peter Adams and Robert Adams, his four children Leslie Martin, Colin Adams, Loren Burton, and Mark Adams, his stepchildren Joshua Wortzel and Jennifer Stiller, his ten grandchildren, and his cats Minou and Maomi, all of whom will miss him greatly. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Adams Prize of the Economics Department at Swarthmore College, 500 College Ave., Swarthmore, PA 19081-1397.

JACKMAN--Robert "Bob". 65, devoted husband, father and grandfather, passed away on December 10, 2010 from lung cancer after a ten and one-half year battle that he fought bravely and valiantly with his family at his side. Bob, who spent over 38 years at the former Bear, Stearns & Co., was a retired senior managing director in charge of municipal bond trading, short-term trading and retail trading. He retired from the firm in early 2006. A Vietnam Veteran who was awarded the Army Commendation Medal for meritorious service in Vietnam, Bob served in the army from 1965-67. He was past President of the Municipal Bond Club of New York, a member of the Shawnee Indian Bond Club and a recipient of the "Blue Chip" award from the Wall Street Charity Fund. This fall, he was tapped to serve on the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board. Bob founded the Brooke Jackman Foundation in memory of his 23-year-old daughter Brooke who died in the World Trade Center during the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. The foundation is a non-profit organization that creates and supports literacy programs for disadvantaged children and their families in the New York City area. Bob's reputation throughout the Municipal Bond Community was that of the rare gentleman who was a highly respected industry leader known for his professionalism, leadership, kindness, loyalty and uncompromising sense of doing what was right. He was a beacon of honesty and integrity. Mr. Jackman was also a civic minded person. He served as a coach of PBC sports, director on the Board of the Oyster Bay-East Norwich Youth Council and President of the Oyster Bay-East Norwich School Board for five years. He was also honored by the Oyster Bay Jewish Center for his fund-raising efforts. Jackman is survived by his wife of 41 years, Barbara; a daughter, Erin; a son Ross; a daughter-in-law, Iris; two grand-daughters, Blake and Elle; a sister, Sandra Jackman Hoffman; a sister-in-law and brother-in-law, Gayle and Chuck Steinberg; and many nieces and nephews. He also had a sister, Ann Kushner, who predeceased him. His family, friends and community will never forget his extraordinary principles, kindness and strength. He was loved, cherished and will be dearly missed.

To the Editor: Although The New York Times makes no secret of its interest in serving a readership whose addresses don't extend south of 59th Street or north of 110th, it's a shame that the Travel section keeps falling into this trap. From reading the article ''The 41 Places to Go in 2011'' (Jan. 9), you'd think that the target Times reader had $35,000 to blow on a typical vacation, and de- sires nothing more intellectually challenging than buying a $370 T-shirt (and maybe seeing a bird or two, or ducking into a museum for 20 minutes before caviar service). Many people are interested in travel for the purpose of self-enrichment. Maybe an article once in a while for us commoners?JOHN BUCKHOLZ Canton, N.Y.

SEIDEN--Melvin R. The Trustees and staff of the Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund mourn the death of Melvin R. Seiden, a dedicated Trustee from 2002 through his retirement in 2010. Mel was a champion of the Gift Fund's mission of furthering the American tradition of philanthropy by providing programs that make charitable giving simple and effective. During his tenure on the Gift Fund's Audit, Investment and Trustees' Philanthropy Fund committees, Mel offered an invaluable perspective to the Board's deliberations on a range of matters. Under Mel's guidance, the Board was inspired to continually evaluate policies, procedures and programs, and to reflect and evolve pioneering principles for donor advised funds. The Board and Staff of the Gift Fund extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Janine Luke. Scott Bergeson, Chair and Sarah C. Libbey, President

EICH--Clarence. Clarence Eich, 90, died on January 8, 2011. He was born in Cleveland, OH, graduated from Columbia College with an A.B. in 1942 and from Columbia Engineering School with a B.S. in 1943. After graduation he served in the US Navy. After the war, he joined Combustion Engineering where he worked as a mechanical engineer until 1962, when he went to work for Foster Wheeler Corporation in New Jersey where he retired as Executive VP in 1984. Mr. Eich is survived by his wife Ellen, three children, two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

To the Editor: I have great respect for Jonathan Galassi in his various capacities, but some of the liberties he takes in translating Giacomo Leopardi's ''Canti'' -- many more than even hinted at in Peter Campion's elegant review -- stick in my craw (''The Solitary Life,'' Dec. 19). Take Leopardi's most famous poem, ''L'infinito,'' which Galassi renders correctly in the body of the poem but entitles ''Infinity.'' Yet the poet did not call it ''Infinità,'' which is vague and vaporous, but ''The Infinite,'' which is more specific, more immediate, and so more alluring and overwhelming.

TUNG--Ruth Hung-Fang Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, and respected teacher to many students, passed away after a long and rich life at the age of 96 in New York City. She was born near Shenyang, in Northeast China. Her father, Tung Jing-Cheng (also named Hsu-Tsong), was a Confucian scholar, and her mother, Grand Duchess Wang Shou-Kun, was the founder and head of a girls school. Professor Tung, as she liked to be called, graduated from Harbin Normal College for Women, and was the first Government sponsored graduate student to attend Ochanomizu Women's University in Tokyo. To escape the massacres during the Chinese Civil War, she, together with her three infant sons, sought refuge in Japan. There she established herself as a respected professor of Chinese Culture and Literature at Keio University. To supplement her modest academic salary in order to raise her three sons, she wrote poetry, translated books and movie subtitles, and taught Chinese cooking at home and on television. After sending each of her sons to the United States for high school, she joined them there, taught at American University in Washington, D.C., and worked as a researcher in the Chinese Collection of the U.S. Library of Congress. As a daughter of a Confucian scholar, she memorized the Chinese Classics, and even in her 90s she would recite Tang poems and passages from the Analects. She was proudest of her three sons-number one son, Roger Ko-Chih, graduated from St. Louis High School in Honolulu and Dartmouth College and received his Ph.D. from the University of Stockholm, and just retired as Regional Director of the UNESCO Institute for Statistics, Asia-Pacific Region; number two son, Alan Ko-Jen (known by his Japanese name Katsumi Tanaka), graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, Harvard College and Harvard Law School, and is a business man in Hawaii, an advisor specializing in US-Asia transactions, and a well-known commentator on political and economic affairs; and number three son, Barry Ko-Yung, graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, Harvard College, Harvard Law School, attended the University of Tokyo, is an international lawyer practicing with Morrison & Foerster and a visiting lecturer and senior research scholar at Yale Law School, and served as the Vice President and General Counsel of the World Bank. In addition to her sons, Prof. Tung is survived by six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. For those who wish, please contact Ko-Yung at ktung@mofo.com for place to make any honorary donations.

JACOBS--Bruce, Maj. Gen.,85, the first Historian Emeritus of the National Guard and the author or editor of books and articles on military history subjects, died after a long illness on January 13, 2011 at his home in Kensington, MD. He retired in 1985 after 42 years of active, Guard and reserve service. His honors included the Army Legion of Merit with two oak leaf clusters, the Bronze Star Medal, and the Army General Staff Identification Badge. He was a Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor. A native of Brooklyn, NY, and '42 graduate of Boys High, General Jacobs later lived in Park Ridge, NJ, and in Cleveland, OH before he and his wife settled in Alexandria, VA in 1971. He attended New York University and received a master's degree in diplomatic history from Georgetown University. Beloved husband to the late Shirley Klein Jacobs for over 62 years, he is also survived by two daughters, Louisa Yates of Healdsburg, CA (Richard), and Martha Schilling of Edison, NJ and a son, Philip H. Jacobs, of Bethesda, MD (Marjorie) and four grand-children. Burial, with full military honors, will be at Arlington National Cemetery at a date yet to be determined. Memorial contributions may be made to the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund, PO Box 84. West Point, NY 10996.

(13, 49) BIRDS OF THE GODS The depths of New Guinea's rainforest are inhabited by birds of unimaginable color and beauty, with plumes so fabulous that when Europeans first saw them in the 16th century, they believed the creatures were heaven-sent and called them birds of paradise (above, the Raggiana bird of paradise). The people of New Guinea say the birds possess supernatural powers. But to find these birds, and to witness their extraordinary mating displays, is next to impossible. In this ''Nature'' presentation, David Attenborough prepares a team of young scientists for a grueling expedition to uncover and film these fantastical birds, a quest considered the ultimate goal of wildlife filmmakers. 10 A.M. A century ago, Israel Zangwill popular- ized the term in his play, ''The Melting Pot.'' From a Lower East Side rooftop, the protagonist proclaimed, ''What is the glory of Rome and Jerusalem, where all nations and races come to worship and look back, compared with the glory of America, where all races and nations come to labor and look forward?''New York has evolved into a greater crucible of race and ethnicity today than it was back then, but the city also remains very much a mosaic -- a variegated montage of neighborhoods in which certain groups predominate.In a month or so, the 2010 census will most likely confirm a record high in the city's foreign-born population. American Community Survey data released last month revealed a striking metamorphosis during the last decade. Traditional ethnic enclaves sprawled into adjacent communi- ties. Once monolithic tracts of white and black and native-born residents have become bespeckled with newcomers.Nearly 700,000 foreigners have settled in the city. Most of those immigrants who gave birth were from China, but Mexicans were close behind -- now outranking Dominicans. The share of foreign-bornLargest population group, census tractsBy race, ethnicity and place of birth* WhiteChinese fell below half in Manhattan's Chinatown, but surpassed it in Flushing. Queens is home to the most and leastdiverse census tracts in New York, when examining the balance among the 10 major ethnic/immigrant groups. In Queens Village, a few square blocks included 388 immigrants from Central and South America, 315 from South Asia, 294 from Southeast Asia, 167 from Eastern Europe, 141 from the Caribbean and 114 from East Asia, as well as 585 people born in the United States -- 235 of them black, 198 Asian-American, 152 non-Hispanic white. Then there is Breezy Point, at the western tip of the Rockaways, where 4,375 American-born whites, most of them Irish and Italian, are joined by 10 blacks, 67 Hispanics and 132 people born abroad.Brooklyn rivals Queens in diversity. Asians moved to Bensonhurst, Russians to Seagate, Haitians to Flatlands and Marine Park, Bangladeshis to Bath Beach, Arabs to Bay Ridge, Mexicans to Bushwick, Pakistanis to Parkville. ''There's a gentleman's agreement,'' said Joseph J. Salvo, director of the City Planning Department's population division. ''We don't have to love each other but we have to tolerate each other.

SEIDEN--Melvin R. Our Museum has lost a true friend. The comprehensive catalogue for the recent Michelangelo exhibition as well as the publication of "The Great Masters of the Albertina" would not have been possible without Mel's devotion and generous support. His enthusiasm and ever readiness to assist our curators and conservators will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Janine Luke and the family. Dr. Klaus Albrecht Schroeder, Director, International Friends of the Albertina Museum

TAFEL--Edgar A. Died at home January 18 at age 98. From 1932 to 1941 Edgar was an original member of Frank Lloyd Wright's Taliesin Fellowship; he is the last survivor. While there he served as project architect for Fallingwater, Johnson Wax and Wingspread among many others. He was principal of his own highly creative architectural practice in New York from 1945 to 1986 that produced many churches and synagogues, college buildings and houses. Known for his sharp wit and acerbic commentary, Edgar authored two books on Frank Lloyd Wright. He was also active in community affairs, serving on his local community planning board as well as being President of the Washington Square Association. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and an Associate of the National Academy of Design. He will be missed by his cousin Joan Scott, his loving caregiver Lerna Gillett and her entire family, his devoted physician Dr. Jerry Clements, and his close friends Robert and Roberta Silman, as well as the entire architectural community to which he gave so much. A memorial service is planned for early February at the Center for Architecture.

KERN--Irving John, 96, passed away peacefully in his sleep on Friday, January 7, 2011, at his home in San Francisco. He was born in New York City in 1914 and was graduated Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1934. During World War II, he rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel in the U.S. Army. After returning home in 1945, he worked for Dellwood Foods in Yonkers, New York. In 1966, he became president and CEO, a post he retained until he retired in 1982. For several decades, Dellwood was known as New York City's premium brand of milk and dairy products, made popular by their slogan, "From Dellwood with Love." The company was a member of the Fortune 1000. Mr. Kern was a former director of the Scarsdale National Bank and the National Dairy Council. He was also a former member of the Military Advisory Council, Center for Defense Information and an adjunct professor of Political Science at San Diego State University. He was an avid outdoor sportsman and yachtsman. He was survived by his loving wife of 69 years, Beatrice, and is currently survived by their three sons John, Arthur, and Robert his granddaughter Erin, and his niece Judy Kleinberger who, along with his extended family, will miss him greatly. Donations can be made to University of California at San Francisco. Home Health Care, c/o the UCSF Foundation, Box 0248, San Francisco, CA 94143-0248. There will be a private memorial service in the New York area for the family this spring.

SIODMAK--Sybil, 96, of Laguna Woods, CA, died on January 8, 2011. Born Sybil Haber in Manhattan, she remained a New Yorker at heart, even while living in Larchmont and Laguna. She loved the theater, chocolate, and, most of all, her late husband Manfred, with whom she glided through 72 years of a truly happy marriage. Sybil leaves two daughters, Judy (Victor) Ratner and Midge Sanford (Peter Broderick), four grandchildren, Kate and Jonathan Sanford and Deborah and the late Elizabeth Ratner, two great-grandsons, Will and Ben Lockhart, her niece, Jane Orans, and her caregiver, Nooria Lieber. Gifts in her memory would be welcomed by the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 W. 65 Street, New York 10023.

KIRSHNER--Don. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to our life-long friend Suzette, her sister, Sheila, Roy, and the entire Kirshner Family as we mourn the passing of Don Kirshner. May he rest in peace. The Fischman Family The Haber Family

PARL--Jack, of Bayside, NY. and Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully on January 18, 2011 after a valiant battle with NSIP, an uncommon auto immune disease of the lungs. Jack was born January 11, 1943 in Tallinn Estonia to the late Charles V. and Ann and is survived by his brother Charles. He graduated Stuyvesant High School and attended Cornell University and Queens College and received his Ph.D. in English Literature from St. John's University. He wrote his Ph.D. thesis about Henry Miller the controversial 20th Century writer. He taught at St. John's and over 25 years at Union County College, New Jersey at the Scotch Plains and Cranford campuses from where he retired in 2005 with the title of Emeritus Professor. He was an avid tennis player and was a member of Northshore Tennis Club in Bayside where he played on the Senior Mens Team and in Palm Beach he played for the Phipps Park Senior Mens Team. He was an intellectual gentleman and will be fondly remembered for his wit and charm and his passion for literature. Jack will be remembered at a Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday, February 11, 2011 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Estonian Educational Society, 243 East 34th St., New York 10016

OF the boroughs outside Manhattan, Brooklyn gets the most buzz -- as a tourist attraction, a ''hipster brand'' and an incubator of art and artisanal products. That has provoked a backlash from longtime Brooklynites and others wary of smugness from the borough's Brownstone Belt. However entertaining these debates, Brooklynites -- and, I dare say, all of us in the non-Manhattan boroughs -- share one common problem: we're essentially powerless. We lack meaningful local government, as well as broad-based media and civic organizations.

THE warm, caramel tones of Dima Gavrysh's newest pictures, part of a personal project shot in New York City, evoke something quite unlike his greater body of work. They are not pictures of Uganda or Niger or Chernobyl or Afghanistan. They are pictures of coffee -- good coffee, in Mr. Gavrysh's estimation -- and the coffeehouses in which it is most appreciated.

It has long been a cliché that muscle bulk doesn't equate to intelligence. In fact, most of the science to date about activity and brain health has focused on the role of endurance exercise in improving our brain functioning. Aerobic exercise causes a steep spike in blood movement to the brain, an action that some researchers have speculated might be necessary for the creation of new brain cells, or neurogenesis. Running and other forms of aerobic exercise have been shown, in mice and men, to lead to neurogenesis in those portions of the brain associated with memory and thinking, providing another compelling reason to get out at lunchtime and run. Since weight training doesn't cause the same spike, few researchers have thought that it would have a similar effect. But recent studies intimate otherwise. Several studies involve animals. It's not easy, of course, to induce a mouse or a lab rat to lift weights, so the experimenters have to develop clever approximations of resistance training to see what impact adding muscle and strength has on an animal's brain. In a study presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in November, researchers from Brazil secured weights to the tails of a group of rats and had them climb a ladder five sessions a week. Other rats on the same schedule ran on a treadmill, and a third group just sat around. After eight weeks, the running rats had much higher levels of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (B.D.N.F.), a growth factor that is thought to help spark neurogenesis, than the sedentary rats. So did the rats with weights tied to their tails. The weight-bearing rats, like the runners, did well on tests of rodent learning and memory, like rapidly negotiating a water maze. Both endurance and weight training seemed to make the rats smarter.

RENTSCHLER--Frederica Schlaff was born on January 2, 1941, in Grosse Point, Michigan, and passed away on January 17, 2011, in Delray Beach, Florida after a two year battle with lung cancer. Freddie, as she was known by her family and many friends, was born and raised in Grosse Pointe, MI, the eldest daughter of Nelson and Mary Schlaff. Freddie attended The Academy of the Sacred Heart and graduated from Grosse Pointe High School in 1959. She worked at Ford Hospital in Detroit as a lab technician. After moving to New York City, she joined Goodson-Todman Productions as a production assistant, working on the network TV shows What's My Line? and Password. Freddie was a member of The Maidstone Club, The Colony Club where she was a member of the Flower Committee, the Central Park Zoo Committee, and proud to be the youngest member of The City Gardens Club. She was an active bridge player, an avid golfer and sportswoman, even holding an East Hampton Township shellfish permit. She was well known for her fantastic sense of humor and her impromptu after dinner speeches. She is survived by her beloved daughters, Farley Mitchell Rentschler and Mary Montgomery Rentschler, both of New York City. In addition, she is survived by her brother Nelson Schlaff of Grosse Pointe, MI, and sisters Mary Shepley of St. Johnsbury, VT. and Suzy Kerr of Fairlee, VT, as well as her long time friend, Jerry B. Campbell of East Hampton, NY. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Saturday, May 21, 2011, 11am at the Grosse Pointe Academy in Grosse Pointe Michigan. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Cancer Society. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL in charge of service.

GELLER--Dr. Jack. Dr. Jack Geller, known for his ambidextrous forehands and ground-breaking prostate research, passed away January 6, in his home in La Jolla, Ca. from lymphoma aggravated by recent radiation treatments. Dr. Geller was in the forefront of research into medical treatment of BPH (benign prostatic hypertrophy) and was instrumental in the development and use of Finesteride, or Proscar, for treatment of prostatic enlargement. Son of the late Dr. Max and Ida Geller, Jack was born 1925 in New Rochelle, NY. When he was ten, after losing his right thumb in a school accident, he learned to play tennis again with his left hand, becoming Number One in the East in the 15 and under boys division, captaining the Yale tennis team, and later ranking 29 in the U.S. before the days of pro tennis. After a year at Yale, WWII had started, and Dr. Geller, handicap and all, enlisted in the army and gained the rank of First Lieutenant before returning to Yale, graduating in 1948. He attended NYU medical school, graduating in 1952. In 1957 he was chosen as the Moritz Rosenthal Fellow in Endocrinology at Mt. Sinai Hospital. After his fellowship, he started his academic career at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and advanced to Associate Professor of Medicine and Director of the Hormone Assay Lab. In 1970, Dr. Geller moved to California as Director of the Internal Medicine Training Program at Mercy Hospital and Adjunct Professor of Medicine at the University of Calif. School of Medicine, San Diego. He held these positions for 23 years. Dr. Geller contributed 108 original papers and 79 abstracts to medical lit. In l978, he originated the concept of panandrogen (adrenal and gonadal) blockage in the treatment of benign and malignant diseases of the prostate. He was honored with the rarely awarded Mastership in the American College of Physicians. As a physician, he trained over 500 house officers, providing outstanding teaching and enduring leadership as a human being, he was simply an inspiration, exuding warmth and humility with a heart of immense porportion. He leaves his wife of 64 years, Suzanne Brenner Geller, his children, Dr. Jon Geller of Fort Collins, Co. and Jacqueline Geller Newman of La Jolla, CA.; four grandchildren, Alexandra and Josey Geller, Joshua and Jamee Newman, three sisters, Genevieve Wyner of Boston, MA, Harriet Greenfield of Danbury, CT, and Marjorie Levitan of Wayland, MA. Donations in his memory can be made to the Mercy Hospital Foundation, Cancer Center, 4077 Fifth Ave., MER 42, San Diego, CA 92103
