ZUCKERMAN--Lee, of Langhorne, PA.,died peacefully on January 22 at the age of 92. She was the beloved wife of 57 years of the late Morris Zuckerman. Born in New York she lived in Hicksville, NY for over 44 years and was a resident of Langhorne for the past 12 years. She was a woman of many talents who loved to cook, bake and share her favorite recipes with family and friends. Always willing to play a game of chance, she looked forward to trips to Atlantic City with her many friends. Lee gave her time to many causes including St. Mary's Medical Center, volunteering for over 4500 hours. She was a loving, devoted mother of three sons and a proud grandmother and great-grandmother. She is survived by her sons; Dr. Nathan Zuckerman and his wife Joanie, Howard F. Zuckerman and Dr. Joseph D. Zuckerman and his wife Janet; six grandchildren; Brian (Jennifer), Andrew (Beth), Lawrence (Kim), Ryan (Grace), Scott and Matthew; six great-grandchildren; Jake, Carlye, Mason, Ryan, Brayden and Brendan; and her dear friend of 55 years Bertha Gordon. Her funeral was held in Langhorne on January 23. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York, an institution that she always supported and was important to her.

VISITING LVIV, UKRAINE To the Editor: I was excited to read Clifford J. Levy's article extolling the virtues of Lviv, Ukraine, ''Impos- sible to Forget'' (Jan. 9). I spent a week in Lviv in July 2009 with 40 other descendants of residents of Bolechow, a village nearby. We were there to dedicate a wall we had fi- nanced around the village's historic Jewish cemetery. We visited the old main synagogue on Brothers Mikh- novskych Street, where Rabbi Mor- dechai Bald and his wife, Sara Bald, are doing an incredible job of revi- talizing Jewish life in this region of Galicia. The synagogue has been re- stored to its former glory through fi- nancing from British and American sources and is a must-see for any visitor to this gem of a city. BILL GOTTDENKER Mountainside, N.J.

Jets at SteelersSunday, 6:30 p.m.Line: Steelers by 31/2 The Jets may be guilty of many sins but they cannot be accused of taking the easy way out. The Colts-Patriots-Steelers gantlet has taken them to three teams that hoard the A.F.C. championship like preteens who won't let their little brothers play with the Kinect. The last team outside the Big Three to represent the conference in the Super Bowl was the Raiders in 2002. Yes, it has been that long.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. -- Jerricho Cotchery has played football for 21 years, since he was 7 in Birmingham, Ala., and to do something for that long, especially at a high level, requires a lot of emotion. Still, he loves football. He loves it in a much quieter way than, say, Braylon Edwards and Santonio Holmes, the two receivers brought in since October 2009 to fortify, if not electrify, the Jets' passing attack. Cotchery gets along fine without calling as much attention to himself as do Edwards or Holmes.

Delta Air Lines has been rolling out a procedure that allows passengers to name the price that they'd have to be paid to be bumped from flights, a spokesman, Paul R. Skrbec, said recently. Under the program, now available at most Delta locations in the United States, domestic travelers who are checking in online or at kiosks are asked whether they would be open to taking different flights. Passengers who volunteer are then asked how much in compensation (in the form of travel vouchers) they would want to change their travel plans. If a flight is indeed oversold, agents at the departure gate are notified of the offers, and can get an early start on looking for alternative flights for interested passengers. At the gate, agents then present those travelers with flight options, at which point they have a last chance to back out.

STUART--Spencer Raymond, age 88, died peacefully after a long Alzheimer's illness on January 17, 2011. Son of William and Helen Stuart, he was born on September 25, 1922 in Baltimore, MD. Spencer Stuart attended Morgan Park Military Academy and graduated from Haverford College. He served as an infantry officer in WWII and in 1949, married Eugenia P. Birdsall. He worked for the Martin-Senour Paint Company, Booz Allen Hamilton, and in 1956 he founded SpencerStuart, currently one of the largest and most respected executive search firms in the world, where he still holds the position of Honorary Chairman. He donated his time and expertise to the Silvermine Guild Art Center and the Boy Scouts of America where, in 1980, he was awarded the Silver Beaver award. He served on numerous boards including; Enhance, InveQuest, UST, and Western Airlines. Spencer is survived by his wife Eugenia, his three children; Spencer Stuart, Jr., Cooper Stuart (and wife Trudy), and Eugenia Davey and his six grandchildren; Spencer Stuart III, Hillary Stuart, Christine Stuart, Cooper Stuart, Jr., Elizabeth Clark and Ashley Clark.

A picture caption in some editions last Sunday with an article about troubles at a Harlem school misstated the given name of a former assistant principal. As the article correctly noted, he is Andrew Sullivan, not Andre.

LAZARUS--Leonard, passed away Saturday, January 15, 2011 at his home in Manhattan. He was 100 years old. Born on January 21, 1910, Leonard lived and loved life for over a century. He nurtured and cherished all his colleagues, friends and loved ones. Leonard was a self-made man. He actively practiced law into his 90s. He was a bright lawyer with a gift for bringing both allies and adversaries together to make "things work." He was a mentor to many lawyers and a man of his word and handshake. For over 70 years Mr. Lazarus played a part in the resurgence after World War II of the real estate markets in Manhattan, Queens and Long Island, engaging in a successful private practice with a schoolmate Richard Klugherz. Mr. Lazarus was born in the Bronx to German immigrants, had one brother Edward, and a sister, Nettie, both of whom predeceased him. When Leonard was very young, his father, Henry, took them to North Adams, MA because there was work there in its factories and mills. Leonard's father contracted TB and upon the doctor's advice relocated to the Adirondacks in Saranac Lake. Leonard's mother, Lillie, was very resourceful and found a place big enough, with land, to run a boarding house and for her husband to run a kosher chicken and egg business. His father was one of the first in the area to save enough money for a new Ford delivery truck, and the few Jewish families in the area loved to patronize such an enterprise. At a young age Leonard helped his parents. He had the largest paper route in the neighborhood and took furs to the rail station for a furrier. His respect for hard work, people and the love he developed for nature, while living, hiking and canoeing in the Adirondacks stayed with him throughout his life. Many years later he gave more than one hundred and fifty acres to a land trust in the Adirondacks to preserve nature from development. Mr. Lazarus' father died two days after his high school graduation so proud of his son who was the first person in the family to graduate high school. He won the state championship on the debating team and was Publisher and Treasurer of his yearbook. After his father's death, the family relocated back to the Bronx where his mother opened a family grocery business where Leonard worked. One of the customers, Rose, became his first wife. Leonard won a state scholarship to Columbia University at sixteen. He worked for the New York Times and became a soda fountain man in a movie house that showed the first talkie movie with Al Jolson, and then became the manager of the cafeteria at Columbia. While in college, Leonard befriended August Gold, a friendship which lasted a life time. In later years, August persuaded Leonard to support and invest in affordable development projects in Ossining, NY. After graduation from Columbia University School of Law during the depression, Leonard made fast friends with an older respected lawyer named Mr. Lochen who saw Leonard's potential. Leonard represented the bus driver's union, three to four hundred men on strike, and conducted labor negotiations with Mayor La Guardia. Mr. Lazarus was a conscientious objector; however he served in the Army for two years in his capacity as an attorney stationed at the Pentagon. After the Army, he lived and practiced law in Jamaica, Queens. He became associated with William Edwards, a real estate entrepreneur, who convinced Mr. Lazarus to move his law practice to Long Island and open an office in Mineola. Mr. Lazarus was instrumental in the development, leasing and sale of many buildings. A project of which he was most proud was Sheldon Solow and his building, The Solow Building at Nine 57th Street, the legendary Manhattan skyscraper designed by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, and built in 1974. Mr. Lazarus also was a partner in the Americana Mall, a luxury destination shopping mall in Manhasset, Long Island. He enjoyed working with Steve Hess Associates, William Edwards, Milt Levin, the Castagna Family, among other businesses from Long Island. He consulted with the late Fred Trump, the Parker family and the LeFraks. Mr. Lazarus married Rose Lazarus in 1936. They lived in New York for almost fifty years. Rose was an accomplished pianist and teacher. After a tragic car accident took Rose's life in 1986, Leonard remarried a longtime friend, the widow of one of his friends from college, Henrietta (Hindy) Creamer, an accomplished economist, interior decorator and artist. Mr. Lazarus was a supporter of numerous charitable foundations, including Columbia University, C.A.R.E., Saranac Lake High School and Central Park Conservancy, Inc. Mr. Lazarus is survived by two sons, Frederic Lazarus of Bradenton, FL and David Lazarus of Queensbury, NY; three grandchildren, Dana, Nicole and David Paul as well as a recent newborn great-grandchild, Annabel Rose, all from Queensbury, NY. He also leaves his sister's children, his niece Iris Greenwald Hamburger and her husband Jerome Hamburger of Lawrence, NY and his nephew, Richard Greenwald and his brother Edward's children, his nieces Susan Qubein and Ellen Lazarus. He is also survived by his close friend and companion, Denise Bibro, and all of his caretakers who loved and took care of him for many years. Funeral services are being arranged with the Campbell Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue, New York City. A memorial will be planned in the near future. For information you may call: 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to one of Mr. Lazarus' favorite charities or a similar charity of your choice will be appreciated.

NOVINS--Dr. Jay Robert, 76 died on January 21 at home after fighting Alzheimer's for almost six years. B.A. Columbia University, 1955; M.D. New York University, 1959. Gifted Pediatrician and Psychiatrist for almost 50 years. Devoted to and beloved by his patients. Mourned by his wife of 54 years, Rochelle Pechman, his children Douglas, Andrea, Kevin, Kara, Scott, and his four treasures: Sylvie, Lena, Sam and Alex. Dr. Jay had a passion for learning, laughing, and people. Funeral at Woodlands Temple, 11am Monday.

COHEN--Marilyn ("Missy") Silverstein, died peacefully at home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL on Monday, January 17, 2011 after a prolonged illness bravely borne with dignity and composure. She was adored by all who knew her. A brilliant flame has been extinguished. She is profoundly missed by her heartbroken husband Max; by her devoted son Richard Heller and daughter-in-law Renee; by her loving granddaughters Alexa and Drew; and by her loving stepchildren Simon and Talya. A private burial service will be held in Valhalla, NY.

SHRIVER--Sargent. The world has lost a treasured and most valuable human being, Sargent Shriver. A man of great faith and eternal optimism, he served our nation and changed the lives of millions as a public servant. The D'Urso family was blessed to know Sargent Shriver, his beloved wife Eunice Kennedy Shriver and their children as special, dear friends. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and dearest love to their devoted children, Maria, Robert, Timothy, Mark and Anthony, as well as their 19 grandchildren and all of the Shriver and Kennedy families. The Roman Catholic faith that was born in his childhood home and nurtured as an altar boy serving Mass for the Sulpicians at St. Mary's in Roland Park, Maryland became the driving force of Sargent Shriver's incredible life of service to his country and his fellow man, his eternal hope for the future and his compassion for humanity. Sargent Shriver was truly an American hero who cared for the least among us, was a voice for the voiceless, and inspired the best in all of us. Embodying St. Benedict's rule, "Ora et Labora" - Pray and Work - Sargent Shriver was a daily communicant at Mass who spent each day of his life tirelessly working for the betterment of humanity. As Founding Director of the Peace Corps, architect of the War on Poverty, U.S. Ambassador to France, advocate for the Special Olympics with his beloved wife and founder, Eunice, and now their son Timothy, and in his countless other good works for justice and peace throughout the world, Sargent Shriver's vision, unbridled enthusiasm and charismatic leadership were born of love, the Love of Christ and reverence for the sanctity of each human life. Msgr. John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, founder of Boys Town of Italy in Rome wrote, "The secret of happiness is to love, but the essence of love is to serve." The United States has lost a treasure, but, surely Heaven has gained a saint. A devoted husband and father, Sargent Shriver's dedication to public service was matched only by his love for his family. May Sargent Shriver's legacy live on in the service, vitality, faith, hope and love of a new generation, a legacy already embodied in the works of service of his amazing children. Sargent Shriver had a well-worn Rosary. Let us remember to pray daily to Divine Mercy, which the world so needs, and to say often "JESUS, I TRUST IN YOU!" -- The Holy Family -"Help me to live by the example of the Holy Family united in respect and love with all mankind. Bless me, my friends, and family, that by drawing close to You, we may come closer to each other. Protect us from all evil, and bring us to everlasting life. We ask this through Our Lord, Jesus Christ. Amen." The D'Urso family shared Sargent and Eunice Kennedy Shriver's great love for Blessed Mother Teresa who said, "The World today is Hungry not only for Bread, but Hungry to be Loved." She also said, "If we Pray, we will Believe. If we Believe, we will Love. If we Love, we will Serve." In gratitude for his heroic, unselfish life, Florence D'Urso and her family, who also serve the poorest of the poor throughout the world, will make a contribution to the Special Olympics in India in memory of our dear friend, Sargent Shriver.
Pop Jon Pareles

Sometimes things that happen in the world of New York City real estate, even in just one building, are so bizarre that one might wonder: Is this a hallucination? A meeting between developers of one of the most expensive and contentious condominium conversions in city history grew so heated that one partner hurled a metal ice bucket at the other.

BANGKOK -- It is the most vilified army in Southeast Asia, known for crushing pro-democracy demonstrations in Myanmar and for its brutal suppression of ethnic groups seeking self-rule in the region's longest-running civil war. The 400,000-strong army in the former Burma is remarkable for its cohesion, cemented by a system of rewards and punishments, and military analysts have found little sign of dissent in its ranks.

EVANS--Edward P.,devoted Yale alumnus and friend of the University, passed away on December 31, 2010, less than two weeks after the announcement of his magnificent gift to support the construction of the new Yale School of Management campus. The entire Yale community wishes to express its deepest sympathy and condolences, as well as ongoing gratitude for Ned Evans' transformative contribution to his alma mater. President Richard C. Levin and Dean Sharon Oster

CHASANOFF--Michael J.,born February 22, 1932 died January 21, 2011. Son of the late Hanna and Harris Chasanoff, he leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Judy, and their children: Nancy and Michael Butler, Stephen and Susan, Robert and Veronica; grandchildren: Daniel, Allison, Jenna, Chloe, Brian, Jamie; brother: Allan, and Joanna Bayless. Mickey was graduated from Yale University in 1953, where he was the starting varsity catcher. Baseball, horse racing, fishing, all were active interests in his life. He was a baseball coach to many young people. He owned, raced, and bred horses for 45 years. To him, the sport of fishing was an occasion for bonding with others. Mickey was a self-realized, successful man. A visionary developer, he was a major force in Long Island real estate. He served on numerous boards with zeal and commitment, including several terms as a Commissioner of the Port Authority of NY and NJ. Mickey was a generous friend to many, both in word and deed. Above all, he adored his family. Funeral services will be held on Monday, January 24, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC, at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Mount Sinai Medical Center of New York, where Mickey received exemplary care.

An article last Sunday about whether the Tucson shooting had created more civility in the nation misstated Senator Joseph McCarthy's connection to the Army-McCarthy hearings in 1954, cited as an example of a national turning point that was not violent. Senator Mc- Carthy was serving on the committee investigating suspected Communist in- filtration of the Army; he was not at the hearings to testify. The article also de- scribed incorrectly an exchange be- tween McCarthy and Joseph Welch, a lawyer for the Army. Mr. Welch's fa- mous remark -- ''Have you no sense of decency, sir, at long last?'' -- came dur- ing a heated exchange with McCarthy, not during an ''interrogation of McCar- thy'' by Mr. Welch.
SWEIG--Morton Arthur. In addition to those people previously mentioned as survivors of the late Morton Sweig, he is survived by his sister Carol Lurie whose name was previously omitted in error.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Hunt column, about Diana Jensen's search for an apartment in Brooklyn, misstated the size of the co-op in Ditmas Park that she was selling. As the article noted, it was a two-bedroom, not a one-bedroom.

Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his son's busy life on the road. ''He'd tell me, 'Oh, son, you really don't need me,' '' Nantz said. But really, he wanted his gregarious father -- his first and best confidant and a former college football player -- with him as much as possible and to enjoy the Masters, the Super Bowl and the N.C.A.A. Final Four together. They were maybe a year from that goal.

The look that dominates high fashion in New York is a long stretch of leg, ankle boots and a new posture. Every era has a defining stance, and at present, it is standing with your legs crossed, like a model or a dancer en pointe. The key to the look is the ankle boot, some with platforms and stiletto heels. Christian Louboutin's signature designs with red soles are at right. What pushed the silhouette to the top was the discarding of heavy-looking knee-high boots for the showgirl display of shapely legs.
Theater Ben Brantley

REGAN--William Mahon, of Bronxville died peacefully at his home surrounded by his family on January 20, 2011. He was 94. He was born on November 4, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of John Francis Regan and Mabel Mahon Regan. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Preparatory School, The College of the Holy Cross and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he served as an Intelligence Office in the United States Coast Guard. After the War, he was appointed Assistant United Sates Attorney for the Southern District before joining the General Electric Company, as an Assistant to the Chief Counsel. He left General Electric to found the New York law firm of Regan, Goldfard, Powell & Quinn, later to become Regan, Goldfarb, Heller, Wetzler & Quinn. He also owned and operated a number of specialty printing businesses over a span of thirty years. He was devoted to his Roman Catholic Faith and to his family. He was a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Knight of Malta, former member of the Board of Trustees at Fordham Prep, a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Archdiocese of New York. He was a member of the Presidents' Councils of several colleges including his Alma Mater. Mr. Regan was predeceased by his loving wife of over 60 years, Grace O'Neil Regan and his older brother, John. He is also survived by his eight children, Grace (John Conway), Loudonville, NY; William Jr. (Alice), Bronxville, NY; John (Sarabeth), Bronx- ville, NY, Hugh, (Gail Fanelli), New York City, Neil, Bronxville, NY; Jane (Michael Considine), Bronxville, NY; Ann, Bronxville, NY; Mary, New York City and 20 grandchildren and two great-granddaughters. He maintained until the end his childhood loyalty to Babe Herman and the Brooklyn Dodgers. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Committee for Mission Responsibility of the Archdiocese of New York. He will be waked in his home on Sunday, January 23 from 2 to 7pm, Two Northway, Bronx- ville, NY. A Mass of the Christian Burial will take place at The Church of Saint Joseph, Bronxville, NY at 10am Monday, January 24, 2011.

BLAKE--Edmund J.,Jr. The Board of Trustees, staff and many members of the Madison Square Boys & Girls Club extend our deepest sorrows and sympathies to the family and friends of Edmund J. Blake, Jr. in the wake of his passing. President of the Madison Board of Trustees from 2003 to 2007 and Chairman from 2007 until his passing, Ed's loyalty, dedication and spirit will be missed by those who knew him and the thousands of children and young adults whose lives were made better because of his time on this world.

SLAVIN--Michael L.,passed away peacefully on January 20, 2011, at the age of 70, after a brief and brave battle with lung cancer. He loved jazz, his cats, and of course a good cigar. He was an exceptional father. He will be missed always and terribly by his daughter Kate.

A report in the Slap Shot hockey column last Sunday about N.H.L. rules that allow for spin moves during both penalty shots and shootouts misstated the given name of the Tampa Bay goalie against whom Edmonton's Linus Omark scored a shootout goal last month after making a spin move. He is Dan Ellis, not Matt.

The historical record shows that despotic heads of state with exotic-car fetishes generally meet ignominious ends. But after the fall, where do their cars go? At Jalopnik on Tuesday, a video was posted showing a yellow Ferrari 599 GTB Fiorano belonging to the deposed Tunisian president, Ben Ali, on a forklift, being carried down a highway to an unknown resting place. Whether the supercar was a singular pleasure or one of hundreds in Mr. Ali's possession is not known.

BLAIR--Wesley Kenneth Jr. A Memorial Service for Wesley Kenneth Blair Jr. will be held on Saturday, February 5, 2011, 2:00pm at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, Pondfield Road and Midland Ave., Bronxville.

GEISS--Tony. The Management and Board of Trustees of Sesame Workshop, along with the entire cast, crew, writers, puppeteers, educators and producers of Sesame Street mourn the passing of Tony Geiss, our longtime multiple Emmy award-winning writer and lyricist. Tony's brilliant words, his sense of humor, his musical virtuosity, and his respect for children in this country and around the world, brought laughter, love and learning together for generations. His work will continue to be shown and treasured by millions for years to come.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about a securities arbitration case brought against S.E.C.U. Brokerage Services on behalf of an elderly widow, misstated the company affiliation of the person who met with her and sold her the investment at issue. He was employed by a firm that was later acquired by S.E.C.U.; he did not work for S.E.C.U.

A PARIS hotel du jour blends boutique DNA with expansionist ambition. Le Pavillon des Lettres is a sibling property of Le Pavillon de la Reine in the Marais, but with a literary theme. The designer Didier Benderli gave each of the 26 rooms a letter of the alphabet. Room H has text by Victor Hugo (get it?) stenciled on the wall. For English translations, boot up the room's dedicated iPad. The hotel is at 12 rue des Saussaies; 011-33-1-49-24-26-26. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

AUERBACH--Jody (Silverbush). Beloved daughter of Kenneth and Carol Silverbush and cherished sister of Stacey Mihaly. Died in Irvington, NY on Friday, January 21st, 2011. Born December 22nd, 1960. Jody was a respected special education teacher in both the New York City and Westchester school systems. She leaves a 12 year old daughter Alexa. Jody will be missed more than words can ever say.
CHASANOFF--Michael. Farewell to our brave friend, Mickey and love to Judy and all the family. Bud & Gloria Baron, Vivian & Harold (d.) Kokol Joanne & Bill Kass

PRICE--Reynolds. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Novelist, poet, playwright, and memoirist, he used all of writing's resources to explore the heart's struggles. He was a voice of Southern history, and an American artist of the first rank.

Last month at Design Miami, the Dutch designer Kiki van Eijk showed a collection of seven objects for Venice Projects, an Italian gallery that commissions contemporary artists to work with traditional Venetian glass techniques. The collection is now available at veniceprojects.com. Van Eijk's fanciful, craft-intensive and extravagant objects (''Love,'' shown here, is $19,200) invest everyday items like a cooking pot or a watering can with emotional resonance by virtue of juxtapositions (a stack of glass pillows topped by an hourglass in ''Rest'') and color (red for passion in ''Love''). Van Eijk and her partner, the designer Joost van Bleiswijk, will also be part of the exhibition ''Glasstress 2011,'' which opens June 3 to coincide with the Venice Biennale. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KING--Marcia Gygli. Noted artist of San Antonio, Texas and New York, passed away January 18, 2011 after a long battle with leukemia. Mrs. King was born in Cleveland, Ohio June 4, 1931 to Robert and Ruth Farr Gygli. She attended Laurel School in Shaker Heights, Ohio and received a BA in English from Smith College. She did post graduate work at the Corcoran School of Art in Washington, DC and received a Master of Fine Arts from the University of Texas San Antonio. Mrs. King moved from Texas to New York City in 1979 as her art career prospered but she continued to return to her home in San Antonio throughout her life and lived at home in San Antonio in her final years. In 2009, her 40 year Retrospective of work was on display simultaneously at three institutions in San Antonio: San Antonio Museum of Art, Southwest School of Art and Craft and the University of Texas at San Antonio. She spent her summers in Sagaponack, New York, where she painted, enjoyed the beach and the special light of Long Island with her family and friends. She had numerous one-person and group shows at galleries, museums and colleges and received wide-spread critical acclaim. Her work can be seen in museums such as the Guggenheim and Brooklyn Museums in New York, Newark Museum, Cleveland Museum of Art, San Antonio Museum of Art, McNay Museum of Art and National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, DC. She also sold to private collectors around the world and notable corporate collections such as Clear Channel Communications, Goldman Sachs, Phillip Morris, British Petroleum, Continental Life Insurance and others. The art critic Grace Glueck commented recently on her work: "Marcia King was a dynamic and inventive artist who shunned trendy art world modes and movements to focus on her own vision. Her passionate paintings, tempered by humor, covered a broad range, from tumultuous landscapes to keenly-observed floral specimens; from deeply-felt portrayals of humans and animals to salient narratives of the human condition. As she worked, she developed ingenious techniques to enhance her expansive large-scale images, notably that of surrounding them with exuberant frames that became part of the painting, often spilling over into the viewer's space. What she did, she did with deep conviction; she was an artist who would not be swayed from her own humanistic path.'' Mrs. King was an energetic person who loved life, her family and many friends. She had wide-ranging interests including art, style, business and philosophy. She enjoyed long walks and bike rides with her two sons and her five grandchildren whether in Texas or Long Island. Her family and its history were important to her and she researched her roots back to Switzerland where she arranged a trip with her two boys to meet their distant Swiss cousins. She is survived by her loving sons Rollin W. King, Jr. of San Antonio and Edward P. King and daughter-in-law Wendy D. King of Dallas, her five grandchildren Ann E., Ellie, Rollin III, Prescott and Charlie King and her niece Lynn Gygli MacDougall of Newport Beach, California. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in San Antonio, Texas on Friday, January 28th at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to MD Anderson Cancer Center-AML Research in Houston www.MDAnderson.org, McNay Art Museum in San Antonio www.McNayArt.org, or the Marcia Gygli King Endowed Scholarship in Art at the University of Texas at San Antonio www.UTSA.edu.

Michael Langham, a classical-theater director who honed his craft in a Nazi prisoner-of-war camp and went on to become the artistic head of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada, and the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and to direct Shakespeare and Molière on Broadway, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Kent, England. He was 91. Mr. Langham did not recover from a chest infection contracted before Christmas, said Ann Swerdfager, a spokeswoman for the Stratford festival, where Mr. Langham was artistic director from the 1956 season through the 1967 season. He was also the director of the drama division of the Juilliard School from 1979 to 1992.

BLAKE--Edmund J. Jr.,husband of Carol Blake died January 20, 2011. He was a loyal friend to everyone that had the fortune of knowing him. Edmund was born 1928 Medford, MA. He graduated from Boston Latin School, Harvard College and Harvard Business School class of 1953. He was an active competitive sailor 210 Class in Marblehead. Edmund's first job was assistant to Peter Grace. He then became treasurer of Philip Morris, and a partner in venture capital with Louis Marks and Dan Lufkin. For the last 20 years Edmund was with Pinnacle Associates as an investment manager and economist. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst and sat on the board of examiners. He was president and active supporter of Madison Square Boys and Girls Club. Edmund was also a board member of the American Liver Foundation, Sacred Heart at 91st Street and New York Academy of Sciences. While he was a successful investor in finance, his greatest investments were in friendships that he fostered throughout the years. He will truly be missed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Madison Square Boys and Girls Club. Funeral Mass will be held 10:30am on Monday January 24th at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st Street, New York, NY.

WHO says youth is wasted on the young? Lily Kwong, 22, is a sociology and urban studies major at Columbia who is also a sometime fashion blogger and Elite model. She previously did stints at GQ and worked as the studio director for her cousin, the emerging designer Joseph Altuzarra. She also works with her father on a social media and educational gaming company. It makes sense, then, that when she collaborated on a shoot with her photographer friend Elle Muliarchyk, the pair's point of departure was fittingly baroque. ''Maybe it's because I had recently been to the Met,'' Ms. Kwong said, joking, ''but we were inspired by Old Masters paintings -- everything from the light to the gestures -- and David Lynch movies. We really wanted to marry the two.'' What, no digital component? ''Actually,'' she says, ''it was shot in the apartment of Cindy Gallop, the social entrepreneur behind IfWeRanTheWorld.com.'' HORACIO SILVA

Packers at BearsSunday, 3 p.m.Line: Packers by 31/2 The Packers and the Bears first met in 1921, when the Bears were the Staleys, the N.F.L. was the A.P.F.A., and F. Scott Fitzgerald was 25 years old. A trainload of 300 Packers fans, joined by a brass band in woodsman costumes (the Cheeseheads came later), traveled to Chicago to watch the 20-0 loss. Pete Stinchcomb opened the scoring with a 45-yard touchdown, then Pard Pearce set up a second score with that pinnacle of 1920s innovation, a forward pass, to Dutch Sternaman.

FEISS--Dorothy Kalina. It is with tremendous and profound sadness that we announce the passing of Dorothy Kalina Feiss. For over 60 years Dorothy was the devoted and adored wife of Murray Feiss. She was an extraordinary mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt and great-aunt. Dorothy was born in the Bronx, New York on January 23, 1928 and lived her entire life in New York, first as a homeowner in New Rochelle and for the past 30 years in Purchase, New York. Dorothy made an indelible impression on everyone who met her, as evidenced by the overflowing mourners at her service on Sunday, January 16th at her beloved Temple Shaaray Tefila, in Bedford Corners, New York. Her Rabbi, repeatedly described her as the richest woman he knew, because she was always content with what she had and valued everyone so dearly. She was seen by anyone who met her as the happiest, friendliest most loving woman who always saw the world with a positive outlook and imbued everyone around her with the feeling that they were special and could accomplish anything they wanted to. Dorothy didn't simply have friends, she had fans. Dorothy was at Murray's side as together they built a business, traveled the world, practiced a life of philanthropy and "shepped nochas" from children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Dorothy passed suddenly and peacefully on Saturday January 15th. To honor Dorothy's memory her husband Murray and her children Andrea and Robert Greene and June and Ron Hersh ask that anyone wishing to make a donation do so to the The Dorothy and Murray Feiss Foundation, 4 Orchard Drive, Purchase, New York 10577. She will be missed, cherished, remembered and loved forever.

Once a sea of faceless office towers and sleepy-eyed office workers, the Marunouchi district in Tokyo is now a place to linger, rather than escape. A steady string of additions have successfully diversified the area into a polished shopping and after-work entertainment destination. The latest piece of the transformation puzzle, which was unveiled in September 2009, is the Marunouchi Brick Square, a refreshingly low-rise complex surrounding a leafy, sculpture-dotted courtyard. Some big names have already swooped into the charming urban oasis -- a cafe from Joël Robuchon; an outpost of the popular San Francisco pizzeria A16; Échiré Maison du Beurre, the first specialty shop from a beloved French butter brand -- but the revamped neighborhood also harbors some surprising and quirky gems. INGRID K. WILLIAMS

Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group announced this month that it would ban smoking for travelers renting cars at all United States Dollar and Thrifty corporate-owned locations and participating franchise locations. Renters who do not comply with the new policy and return vehicles after smoking in them may face a charge of up to $250. All cars in the fleet will display a ''No Smoking'' sticker notifying renters of the possible noncompliance charge.

For more than a decade, TripAdvisor.com has been a popular Web site for users to rate hotels, restaurants and activities. Now it has added airlines to the roster of ratable items. The new feature, which debuted last week as part of TripAdvisor Flights, the site's online flight search tool, allows travelers to add feedback on airlines in eight categories, as part of their booking process. ''It's something we've always wanted to do,'' said Bryan Saltzburg, general manager of TripAdvisor Flights. ''We're giving customers all the right tools to make the best decision possible.''

The most frustrating economic news of 2010 wasn't that the recession had worsened - it was that things had improved markedly for corporations, but not for the labor force. Even Alan Greenspan expressed concern that the U.S. is evincing "fundamentally two separate types of economy" - one in which big companies and high earners thrive, the other in which millions struggle to find jobs and make ends meet. One group that has been particularly hard hit by the recession is youth. Among workers aged 16 to 24, the unemployment rate is almost 20 percent. For young Latinos, it's over 24 percent, and for young African Americans, it's over 32 percent. Some 4.4 million youths are currently unemployed.This is of serious concern to a country with a rapidly aging population. And while today's best jobs require post-secondary schooling, 30 percent of U.S. public school students fail to graduate from high school (pdf), and more than half of those who enroll in higher education fail to earn a degree or credential within eight years.

Not even 24 hours after the Paris men's shows had ended they were a dim memory. The women had moved in for the spring haute couture shows, like a temperance league. The tent for Dior today was so big, set up behind the Musée Rodin, you could have run three men's shows simultaneously. I saw writers who had sprawled easily on benches at the men's shows now squeezed delicately into gold spindle chairs. The mood became tense, watchful. And you have the clients and the paparazzi, who must get the same pictures every year but don't seem to care. It's kind of like family. A curious phenomenon swept the frigid streets of New York City today, where temperatures plummeted to 8 degrees: people looked where they were going. The lure of warm destinations, the primal urge to rush indoors and a deep reluctance to expose tender fingers to the brutal cold meant that iPhones, Blackberrys and other P.D.A.'s were tucked away. Strolling the streets, seeing so many people untethered to various electronic distractions or jabbering away in halfalogues, one could be forgiven for thinking it was 2002 all over again.

Last season the model Arizona Muse clocked 26 runway shows - and could have done more had she not had an exclusive with Prada in Milan. This season, you can bet the 22-year-old Muse, a recent mom, will be practically ubiquitous. Four cities (New York, London, Milan and Paris) and about 100 shows per - well, you do the math. "Fashion Week is the busiest time of each season," she told us as she geared up for New York. "Whether or not I actually get any free time beforehand remains to be seen, ha!" Right now, she fills her "idle" hours with running and Pilates. If she's lucky, she will be able to take a short break between cities. "I plan to spend some time in London," she says. (She is from New Mexico, but her mom is English.) "I have dear dear family and friends there." More than anything, she tells us that she's ready for the shows to get going. "I like how busy it is, running around from one place to another. It's quite exhilarating," she says. "I know that it will end. And when it does I think I'll go home to Santa Fe, where I grew up, and eat lots of green chili." Hot stuff.

This week, A. O. Scott looks back at "Billy Liar," John Schlesinger's 1963 drama about a young daydreamer (Tom Courtenay), who escapes from the boredom of his life into a fantasy world. Mr. Scott appreciates the film for its pathos and comedy, which stems, he says, from "the tension between two different kinds of imagination. One kind involves making up things that aren't true. The other kind, which is no less creative, involves recognizing the world for what it is." Have you seen "Billy Liar?" Please share your thoughts.
In the matter of its new letter-grade system that rates the cleanliness of restaurants, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has given itself an A.

Something really strange has happened to the debate over economic policy in the face of the Great Recession and its aftermath -- or maybe the real point is that events have revealed the true nature of the debate, stripping away some of the illusions. It's a bigger story than any one point of dispute -- say, over the size of the multiplier, or the effects of quantitative easing -- might suggest. Basically, in the face of what I would have said is obviously a massive shortfall of aggregate demand, we're seeing on all-out attack on the very notion that the demand side matters.

The brother of Robert Mann - a founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet and a major figure in American chamber music - has donated $6 million to endow chairs in Mr. Mann's name. For seven seasons, first on NBC and then on CBS, "Medium" put across some of prime time's most outlandish story lines by grounding them in one of television's most believable marriages. ThinkFun, a maker of puzzle and game software, has developed a chess application for the iPhone, iPad and iTouch. Called Solitaire Chess, the application presents a series of problems with chess pieces on a four-by-four grid. The challenge is to eliminate all but one piece through a series of captures. The problems vary in difficulty from easy to expert. There is a demonstration Web site for people to test out the application.

KABUL, Afghanistan - Triumphalism is not supposed to be in the prayerbook of the American military's Church of Coin these days, but last Wednesday, Jan. 19, proved to be something of an exception. At the morning standup that day, Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan, was uncharacteristically jubilant. "We've got our teeth in the enemy's jugular now, and we're not going to let go," General Petraeus exulted after being briefed on the military operations of the past 24 hours, according to two senior officers who saw the classified standup that day.

"I don't think turtlenecks have ever gone out of style," says Vanessa Traina, T's fashion editor. "But the whole minimalist movement in fashion right now has definitely influenced their presence in the pre-fall collections." Indeed, turtlenecks were the underpinning of choice in collections from Celine to Proenza Schouler. We suspect that a certain nude bodysuit from the Chloé spring runway might have started a chain reaction. Hannah MacGibbon had us uttering "sexy" and "turtleneck" in the same sentence - who knew? "It keeps your look smart," says Ethel Park, T's senior fashion editor, who suggests pairing a turtleneck with a pencil skirt or wide-legged pants. Of course, a turtleneck goes with just about anything. Says Traina: "I used to wear them as a child under my school uniform."

In the general absence of parks and open spaces, the street is the nucleus of communal life in Mumbai. It's where meals are sold and eaten, where groceries are purchased on the commute home and where neighbors gather every evening for a chat. But until recent years, art and culture remained off the city's streets, strictly confined to galleries and theaters frequented by the elite. The debut of the Kala Ghoda Arts Festival (KGAF) in 1999 changed that. This year's version will take place Feb. 5 to 13, spread over several streets in Mumbai's tiny but beautiful colonial-era art district.

PITTSBURGH -- Throughout this season, the Jets reinforced their status as the most talkative team in football, a boastful bunch who, with a series of last-second victories, backed up their big talk. But Sunday, the loudest team in football shuffled around its locker room in silence, stunned, still processing a second straight Jets season that reached the doorstep of the Super Bowl and ended there. The Pittsburgh Steelers had managed to complete what for most of this season seemed impossible, had pushed the mute button on the Jets with a 24-19 triumph in the American Football Conference championship game. The Jets trudged home, out of words. The Steelers will face the Green Bay Packers in the Super Bowl on Feb. 6.

Apple sold more than 16 million iPhones in the last quarter, according to its earnings report. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhone's rivals, will it have to sell its signature mobile device on other networks as well? Some analysts say yes. The iPhone's fiercest competitor is Google's Android platform, in phones that are available on all the major United States carriers.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. -- With officials from the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission lending an air of urgency, the board that oversees athletic equipment safety finished its annual meeting Saturday vowing to pursue several updates to football helmet standards. Dr. Robert Cantu, the vice president of the National Operating Committee on Standards for Athletic Equipment and a leading expert in sport-related concussion, announced that the group would attempt to devise standards that consider the complex forces that cause concussions, as well as a new standard for helmets worn by young players. He added that Nocsae would work with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to better communicate to parents of young players the limits of current safety standards.

''She's a foul-mouthed alcoholic nun,'' Kathleen Turner said of Sister Jamison Connelly, the character she portrays in ''High,'' a new play coming to Broadway this spring. ''What I love is that she hasn't made these choices about her religion lightly,'' Ms. Turner said in her familiar deep-throated growl. ''It makes me think of how much we operate every single day on faith and belief,'' regardless of any connection to organized religion. Ms. Turner has performed the play, written by Matthew Lombardo and directed by Rob Ruggiero, in Hartford, Cincinnati and St. Louis, enduring rewrites and revisions along the trail. ''Each step of the way, it was getter better,'' Ms. Turner said by telephone. ''We were learning what the audience understands or doesn't understand. It's a luxury to have almost six months to do.'' Ms. Turner's last appearance on Broadway, in 2005 as Martha in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf,'' won her a Tony nomination. Joining her on stage will be Stephen Kunken and Evan Jonigkeit. Previews begin March 25 with an opening scheduled for April 19 at the Booth Theater.

The Packers and the Steelers, so steeped in N.F.L. history, can look strikingly similar: they each have a mobile quarterback and a solid defense. The Packers found a running game late in the season, but they should not count on that against a Steelers defense that obliterates the run. Pittsburgh's cornerbacks are vulnerable, though, especially if safety Troy Polamalu is not completely healthy. That could provide a field day for Aaron Rodgers, who was probably the league's best quarterback in the second half of the season.

JACOBS--Bruce, Maj. Gen.,85, the first Historian Emeritus of the National Guard and the author or editor of books and articles on military history subjects, died after a long illness on January 13, 2011 at his home in Kensington, MD. He retired in 1985 after 42 years of active, Guard and reserve service. His honors included the Army Legion of Merit with two oak leaf clusters, the Bronze Star Medal, and the Army General Staff Identification Badge. He was a Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor. A native of Brooklyn, NY, and '42 graduate of Boys High, General Jacobs later lived in Park Ridge, NJ, and in Cleveland, OH before he and his wife settled in Alexandria, VA in 1971. He attended New York University and received a master's degree in diplomatic history from Georgetown University. Beloved husband to the late Shirley Klein Jacobs for over 62 years, he is also survived by two daughters, Louisa Yates of Healdsburg, CA (Richard), and Martha Schilling of Edison, NJ and a son, Philip H. Jacobs, of Bethesda, MD (Marjorie) and four grand-children. Burial, with full military honors, will be at Arlington National Cemetery at a date yet to be determined. Memorial contributions may be made to the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund, PO Box 84. West Point, NY 10996.

An article on Friday about the Knicks' needs at the midpoint of the N.B.A. season gave an outdated name for the San Antonio Spurs' arena, where the Knicks lost to the Spurs 101-92 on Friday night. It is now the AT&T Center, no longer the SBC Center.

Nothing spurs talk of gun-control legislation quite like a highly publicized crime committed with the aid of a handgun. Such was the case 100 years ago this month, when a brazen murder committed near Gramercy Park led to the enactment a few months later of New York State's landmark Sullivan Law, which required police-issued licenses for those wishing to possess concealable firearms and made carrying an unlicensed concealed weapon a felony (pdf).

CHASANOFF--Michael J.,born February 22, 1932 died January 21, 2011. Son of the late Hanna and Harris Chasanoff, he leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Judy, and their children: Nancy and Michael Butler, Stephen and Susan, Robert and Veronica; grandchildren: Daniel, Allison, Jenna, Chloe, Brian, Jamie; brother: Allan, and Joanna Bayless. Mickey was graduated from Yale University in 1953, where he was the starting varsity catcher. Baseball, horse racing, fishing, all were active interests in his life. He was a baseball coach to many young people. He owned, raced, and bred horses for 45 years. To him, the sport of fishing was an occasion for bonding with others. Mickey was a self-realized, successful man. A visionary developer, he was a major force in Long Island real estate. He served on numerous boards with zeal and commitment, including several terms as a Commissioner of the Port Authority of NY and NJ. Mickey was a generous friend to many, both in word and deed. Above all, he adored his family. Funeral services will be held on Monday, January 24, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC, at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Mount Sinai Medical Center of New York, where Mickey received exemplary care.

PARL--Jack, of Bayside, NY. and Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully on January 18, 2011 after a valiant battle with NSIP, an uncommon auto immune disease of the lungs. Jack was born January 11, 1943 in Tallinn Estonia to the late Charles V. and Ann and is survived by his brother Charles. He graduated Stuyvesant High School and attended Cornell University and Queens College and received his Ph.D. in English Literature from St. John's University. He wrote his Ph.D. thesis about Henry Miller the controversial 20th Century writer. He taught at St. John's and over 25 years at Union County College, New Jersey at the Scotch Plains and Cranford campuses from where he retired in 2005 with the title of Emeritus Professor. He was an avid tennis player and was a member of Northshore Tennis Club in Bayside where he played on the Senior Mens Team and in Palm Beach he played for the Phipps Park Senior Mens Team. He was an intellectual gentleman and will be fondly remembered for his wit and charm and his passion for literature. Jack will be remembered at a Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday, February 11, 2011 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Estonian Educational Society, 243 East 34th St., New York 10016

Federal regulators are weighing whether to downgrade the risk classification of electroshock devices, reinforcing what many psychiatrists consider a deepening acceptance of electroshock in modern therapy. The procedure has had a resurgence in recent years. And an estimated 100,000 Americans -- two-thirds of them women -- undergo the treatment for major depression and other illnesses each year. Patients, anesthetized, receive a jolt of electricity from electrodes for several seconds, inducing a brain seizure and convulsions of up to a minute.

The race to build the biggest, most comprehensive and specialized cache of at-your-fingertips information and analysis on the business of Washington has added one more combatant. CQ Press is creating a service called First Street, which will serve as a Congressional staff directory, legislative almanac and lobbyist locator all in one. It is scheduled to be fully up and running by April.

STESSIN--Herbert. With deep sadness, The Julliard School notes the passing of Herbert Stessin, a member of the School's piano faculty since 1960. As a dedicated and insightful teacher, Herbert guided generations of pianist in preparation for a career as a soloist, chamber musician, teacher, and administrator. His quick wit and generous personality were a source of goodwill for all who knew him. His legacy will continue at Julliard far into the future. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost & Dean

Nintendo's new portable 3-D gaming system is in a ''category of one,'' said Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of the company's American operation, at an event in New York on Wednesday in which he laid out the details of the product's introduction. But he acknowledged that even the most novel of gaming devices is now pitted against a range of competitors extending far beyond the traditional gaming world. He said that Nintendo saw the device as more than a hand-held gaming console, and stressed the importance of the device's ability to display 3-D video without the need for glasses, and its ability to function as a 3-D camera. ''Consumers have a limited amount of time every day to invest in entertainment,'' he said. ''Therefore we've got to bring out more compelling entertainment experiences than what others are doing.''

LOS ANGELES - Never mind Ricky Gervais. There may not even be a Golden Globes ceremony next year if things don't get moving in court here. In a little-noticed court filing on Tuesday, lawyers for the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which presents the Globes, said there might not be time to find a new producer, a network and advertisers for next January's show if the association's legal dispute with its longtime producer, Dick Clark Productions, continued at the current pace.

YouGov rates consumer perceptions of a brand by subtracting negative from positive scores, within a range of negative 100 to positive 100. Most high-scoring brands, like the Discovery Channel, which broadcasts ''Deadliest Catch,'' above, gain or lose a few points each year. Ford was not even in the top 50 in 2009, but it improved its score to 39.3 last year, from 26 in 2009. In what has been a beneficial cross-pollination, Mike Rowe, the star of ''Dirty Jobs'' on the Discovery Channel, has been promoting Ford cars and trucks since 2007. SHELLY FREIERMAN

RockTenn said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Smurfit-Stone, a maker of packaging products that emerged from bankruptcy protection last year, for $3.5 billion in cash and stock. The merger will combine two of the biggest names in packaging, creating a company with 9.4 million tons of production capacity. It will also expand RockTenn's business in the Midwest and West Coast. The combined company will keep RockTenn's headquarters in Norcross, Ga.

NBC Universal will announce on Monday that John Miller, the former chief marketing officer for its television group, is coming out of semiretirement to set up and head the NBC Sports Agency. The ad agency will market all parts of the NBC Sports Group, which will soon include Comcast's sports cable channels. Its formation is another indication that Comcast wants to seize opportunities in the sports arena, where ESPN is dominant. The agency will be modeled after the NBC Agency, which Mr. Miller helped to start in 1999 and which markets all of NBC's television properties.
ALBERT--Felix, age 97, died peacefully in his sleep on January 21. His children David and Ann Mary were with him. A courageous, witty and kind man. We will miss him.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about restaurants that are turning to social media to attract and keep customers, misstated the surname of the vice president of marketing at Loopt, a social media company in Mountain View, Calif. She is Alice Lankester, not Lancaster. The column also gave the incorrect context for a comment by Ms. Lankester. When she said: ''It got people off their feet. Some 1,300 people checked in during a four-hour period,'' she was referring to a promotion by Virgin America, not by Bob's Burgers.

On an 18-hour flight from California to Singapore a few years ago, Timothy D. Cook, Apple's chief operating officer, had little time for small talk with a colleague. Glued to his business class seat, Mr. Cook had his nose in spreadsheets, preparing for a thorough review of Apple's Asian operations. The two landed at 6 a.m., took time to shower and headed into a meeting with Apple's local executives. Twelve hours later, and well past dinnertime, the local executives were ready to call it quits.

A headline and a report in the Sports Briefing column on Jan. 10 about a World Cup super-G ski race in Altenmarkt-Zauchensee, Austria, misstated the circumstances of Lara Gut's victory over Lindsey Vonn, and referred incorrectly to Vonn's performance. Gut won with a time of 1 minute 12.82 seconds in her first and only run -- not her second. (There is no second run in Super-G competition.) And Vonn led the competition after her run and up to the point that Gut raced -- not after the first round. (There also are no rounds in the competition.)
CHASANOFF--Michael. A lifetime of memories of a truly remarkable friend. Our hearts are heavy. Love and condolences to his devoted family. Sue and Burt

9 P.M. (13, 49) PANAMA CANAL On Aug. 15, 1914, the Panama Canal opened, connecting the world's two largest oceans and signaling the emergence of the United States as a superpower. The technological achievement trumped the efforts of the French, who had failed at a similar endeavor a few years earlier, losing nearly 22,000 workers in the process. The cost for America? The loss of 5,600 lives over more than a decade of grueling labor and an outlay of $350 million, the largest single federal expenditure at that time. This ''American Experience'' presentation tells the story through archival photographs and film footage, interviews with workers and firsthand accounts of life in the Canal Zone. (IFC) ROGER DODGER (2002) Campbell Scott plays Roger Swanson, a slick-talking lothario, and Jesse Eisenberg is his 16-year-old nephew, Nick, who shows up at his New York office unannounced with the excuse that he has come to visit the campus of Columbia. An evening of drunken carousing ensues. Nick craves sexual experience, and who better to tutor him on picking up women than his uncle? Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden described the role of the oily Roger as ''a small coup for Mr. Scott, who is normally the quintessence of earnest sincerity on the screen.'' But it is Mr. Eisenberg (''The Social Network'' ) who steals the show. ''The young actor's portrayal of an innocent but adventurous high school student finds a lovely balance between crude adolescent avidity and an inner sweetness that contradicts everything Roger stands for,'' Mr. Holden wrote. ''It is this sweetness that wins over the women they meet and earns Nick his first serious kiss.''

Murray, a former Wall Street executive who chose not to go quietly into the night, writing and publishing himself a popular paperback guide for ordinary investors while he was struggling with terminal cancer, died Saturday at his home in Burlingame, Calif., days before his book was scheduled to come out in hardcover. He was 60. The cause was glioblastoma, an aggressive brain cancer, his wife, Randi, said.

Friends and colleagues will gather on Monday to celebrate the life and work of Jerry Bock, who wrote the music to some of the most memorable songs in musical-theater history. The public is invited, too. Mr. Bock, who died in November, is best known for ''Fiddler on the Roof'' (1964), which won nine Tony Awards and became a theater staple throughout the world. But he and the lyricist Sheldon Harnick also won the Pulitzer Prize for the 1959 musical ''Fiorello!,'' and their 1963 show ''She Loves Me'' has been regularly revived in New York and around the country.

Suddenly, Republicans face an unanticipated problem: less than three months after their midterm triumphs, President Obama has regained political momentum. Before his first 2011 clash with Republican adversaries who now share governing responsibility, those surveys also show that Americans credit Mr. Obama with greater commitment to finding common ground.

MANSOUR--Gary Paul. Founder of Mansour Travel Company, a leader in luxury travel services, and owner and founder of Avion Private Jet Club. He was born on December 20, 1952 in Youngstown, Ohio. Gary is, was and will always be in our hearts. He was an unbelievable person - a man of honor, full of kindness, love and devotion to others, a caring, gentle man. A Memorial Service to remember Gary will be held on Tuesday, January 25th at the Four Seasons Hotel, The Metropolitan Suite (57 East 57th street, New York, NY) from 10am to 12pm. The Theater Hall of Fame, which this year is celebrating its 40th anniversary honoring lifetime achievement in American theater, has announced its new inductees. They are the directos Michael Blakemore, music director Paul Gemignani, the playwright Caryl Churchill, the actors Linda Lavin, Brian Dennehy and Fritz Weaver, the director and librettist James Lapine and, posthumously, the director and writer Joseph Chaikin. Pia Lindstrom will be the M.C., and the directors Harold Prince and Robert Falls will be among the presenters at the annual Hall of Fame induction on Monday at Broadway's Gershwin Theater, where the plaques with the names of each year's honorees are hung.

GEISS--Nicholas Anthony (Tony), beloved writer, composer and lyricist for generations of performers and characters from Groucho Marx to the Muppets, died January 21 of complications from a fall. Born in New York on November 16, 1924 and raised in the West Village, Tony was cherished by his colleagues, friends, and family for his warmth, playfulness, lively wit, sweetness, modesty, extraordinary sense of humor and celebratory spirit. Those qualities also made him a national treasure. Tony delighted and nurtured generations of viewers of Sesame Street, where he worked for nearly 40 years, winning 22 Emmys for both script-writing and song-writing. He created the Muppet characters the Honkers and most recently Abby Cadabby and was a co-creator of Elmo's World, composing its theme song. In addition to a long list of television-writing accomplishments and awards, Tony co-wrote three films with Judy Freudberg: "Sesame Street Presents: Follow That Bird," "An American Tail," and the story for "The Land Before Time." Readers interested in seeing and hearing more of Tony Geiss can enjoy this experience at htttp://www.emmytvlegends.org/interviews/people/tony-geiss. His adored wife of more than 60 years, the former Phyllis Eisen, died December 6, 2009. Devoted friend, adoring husband, Tony leaves behind a large loving extended family, the McKeon, Armando, Townsend, Schlesinger, Saperstein, Mason and Singer families, many close friends, colleagues, and admirers of all ages, who joyfully sang along with his songs without knowing their author, nourished by his creative brilliance. Tony -- we miss you and love you!!! Memorial service will be Thursday, January 27, 11:45am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St; family at 10:45am, public at 11:45am.

Greg Long plans his life and surfing adventures from a spartan garage apartment in San Clemente, Calif., about a mile from his boyhood home. On a recent afternoon, Long, a fit and wiry 27-year-old, tracked a major storm on his laptop in order to time a trip to Hawaii. Scheduling surfing competitions is often subject to nature, and this week a storm in the Pacific was expected to send mammoth waves to Hawaii's Waimea Bay, conditions necessary to contest the Quiksilver in Memory of Eddie Aikau, one of surfing's most prestigious events. The competition can be conducted only in surf of 20 feet or more, so some years it is not held. It has been run only eight times in 25 years.

Meet the new buzzword, same as the old buzzword. In advance of the State of the Union, President Obama has telegraphed his main theme: competitiveness. The President's Economic Recovery Advisory Board has been renamed the President's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness. And in his Saturday radio address, the president declared that ''We can out-compete any other nation on Earth.'' This may be smart politics. Arguably, Mr. Obama has enlisted an old cliché on behalf of a good cause, as a way to sell a much-needed increase in public investment to a public thoroughly indoctrinated in the view that government spending is a bad thing.

FRANKFURT -- Leaders in business, politics and academia from around the world will gather in Davos, Switzerland, this week to try to rescue the planet. It's a safe bet that, for the 41st year in a row, they will fail. Even if it were possible to save the world in five days, the list of global problems just keeps getting longer -- to the point where Klaus Schwab, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum, is worried.

Theoni V. Aldredge, who died on Friday, created clothes that required sunglasses. I don't mean as an accessory for those who wore them; I mean for the people looking at them. (A slide show of costumes designed by Ms. Aldredge is here.) Sure, she could do the bread-and-butter contemporary stuff with subdued elegance in naturalistic productions like ''The Best Man'' (1960), ''A Delicate Balance'' (1966) and ''That Championship Season'' (1972). But more than perhaps any other Broadway costume designer of the past half century, she understood that for a certain kind of show, nothing less than all-out dazzle would do.

If you were a visitor from Mars, watching tonight's State of the Union address and Paul Ryan's Republican response, you would have no reason to think that the looming insolvency of our entitlement system lies at the heart of the economic challenges facing the United States over the next two decades. From President Obama, we heard a reasonably eloquent case for center-left technocracy and industrial policy, punctuated by a few bipartisan flourishes, in which the entitlement issue felt like an afterthought: He took note of the problem, thanked his own fiscal commission for their work without endorsing any of their recommendations, made general, detail-free pledges to keep Medicare and Social Security solvent (but "without slashing benefits for future generations"), and then moved swiftly on to the case for tax reform. Tax reform is important, of course, and so are education and technological innovation and infrastructure and all the other issues that the president touched on in this speech. But it was still striking that in an address organized around the theme of American competitiveness, which ran to almost 7,000 words and lasted for an hour, the president spent almost as much time talking about solar power as he did about the roots of the nation's fiscal crisis.

... was as bad as you might expect. Lots of breast-beating about deficits; you'd never know that no leading Republican, Ryan very much included, has offered a serious proposal to cut the deficit. Some cooked statistics about federal spending. And then there was this curious assertion:

The prize goes each year to people whose work "aims to promote the advancement of science and technology for the peace and prosperity of mankind." The award is for $600,000. Ten previous recipients have also won Nobel Prizes.

Picking 25 favorites out of more than 1,000  recipes from The Minimalist - the last weekly column appears this week - is an awesome task. This week marks the last weekly appearance of the Minimalist column by Mark Bittman. Since 2006, Gabe Johnson, a video journalist with The New York Times, has shot and produced all the videos that accompany the column - more than 200 of them. (The Times has compiled some of the most watched.) He also sampled each and every recipe Mr. Bittman cooked on camera. There will be more Minimalist videos in the future, drawing on recipes from the Times archives, but Diner's Journal asked Mr. Johnson to talk about the best thing he's tasted so far.

For the "bootleg artist" known as Swampy, the world is an endless living canvas. Variations on his signature "swampdonkey" tag -- the skull of some imaginary tusked creature -- can be found in almost every imaginable setting across America: dilapidated skyscrapers in Oakland, Calif.; train trestles in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico; gallery walls in Atlanta or Brooklyn. Though he's best known for his graffiti, Swampy's output varies wildly and incorporates a kaleidoscope of materials, styles and settings. His studio is almost entirely mobile, his materials are liberated as needed from large art supply chains, and he travels entirely for free by hopping freight trains. Trains, and train hopping, are a central theme in the hundreds of works he displays on Flickr and at swmpdnky.com. T caught up with Swampy, who had just spent several months traveling by train through Mexico taking photos for a new book, from his home in Oakland. This is his first published interview.
As time goes on, I only look back and exclaim, "How naïve I was.''

On Monday night, the Cleveland Cavaliers fell, 101-103, to the Nets, losing their 17th straight game. Losing is a way of life in Cleveland these days; the most surprising part of the Cavaliers' most recent defeat wasn't the result, but the fact that the game was close at all. Cleveland has become so spectacularly awful that even competitive games are a rarity. In fact, prior to last night's game, the Cavaliers hadn't lost a game by fewer than five points since the day after Christmas. This Cleveland team doesn't just lose. They've raised incompetence to high art, and use each contest as a creative outlet through which to uniquely express their profound failures as a basketball team.

Solange Azagury-Partridge was born in the Chinese Year of the Ox, which by definition means she's not only incredibly strong-willed but a firm believer in tradition. Her 12 hand-carved and painted lacquer critters set on 18-karat-gold bands and pendants share a similar dualism, serving double duty as conventional commemorative gifts for the coming Chinese New Year and as unconventional tokens of love for Valentine's Day, which falls in the same month. "You can feel love emanating from these sweet creatures, and they are incredibly personalized," Ms. Azagury-Partridge says of the designs, which start at $2,450 and include a plump purple poodle for those born in the Year of the Dog. "I definitely like unconventional gifts." Admirers, take note.

N.F.L. Rule, Section 9 Instant Replay, Coaches' Challenge In each game, a team will be permitted two challenges that will initiate Referee Replay reviews. Each challenge will require the use of a team timeout. If a challenge is upheld, the timeout will be restored to the challenging team. A challenge will only be restored if a team is successful on both of its challenges, in which case it shall be awarded a third challenge, but a fourth challenge will not be permitted under any circumstances. No challenges will be recognized from a team that has exhausted its timeouts. A team that is out of timeouts or has used all of its available challenges may not attempt to initiate an additional challenge.

The nominees for best director are Darren Aronofsky (for "Black Swan"), David O. Russell ("The Fighter"), Tom Hooper ("The King's Speech"), David Fincher ("The Social Network") and Joel and Ethan Coen ("True Grit"). "The King's Speech" led the pack with 12 nominations total, including Colin Firth (nominated for best actor), Helena Bonham Carter (best supporting actress) and Geoffrey Rush (best supporting actor).

BIG BETS PAY OFF In his 2010 year-end letter to investors, John Paulson, left, tracks the next phase for several large bets at his firm, Paulson & Company, which famously profited from the subprime mortgage crisis. Now, he's making money on the recovery. His Citigroup holdings, which he started amassing in the middle of 2009, are up about $1 billion so far. The bank was the firm's most profitable bet of 2010. AZAM AHMED GAINS ON BAD ASSETS The Treasury Department's equity investment in impaired mortgage assets -- a federal program that combined capital from the government and private asset managers -- has grown 27 percent since it was created in 2009, according to new data released Monday. The gains have come as the mortgage bond market has staged a comeback, producing generous returns over the last year. BEN PROTESS WHO NEEDS AN INHERITANCE? Mittal, left, ArcelorMittal's chief executive, recently purchased a sizable stake in the quantitative hedge fund Roc Capital, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Mets passed over Wally Backman as their major league manager this off-season, hiring Terry Collins instead. But Backman was a finalist for the job and remains on track to possibly manage in Flushing someday. Backman will manage Class AA Binghamton this season, the Mets said Monday. Tim Teufel will manage Class AAA Buffalo after a season with Binghamton.

NATIONAL An article on Monday about the ways in which some colleges have responded to tragedies on campus, by creating and improving student services, misstated the name of a national mental health advocacy organization. It is the National Alliance on Mental Illness, not the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill.

SHRIVER--R. Sargent. The staff, Board and friends of Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A ("Brooklyn A") deeply mourn the death, but celebrate the life of our founder and guiding light, R. Sargent Shriver. He not only created the national network of free civil legal services programs for low income people as part of the War on Poverty, but he instilled in it and in us the mission of not just defending poor people in court, but in working in and partnering with the residents of low income localities to build, sustain and grow non-profit locally controlled institutions in those neighborhoods that would provide high quality, affordable and caring housing, medical, childrens, senior citizens, and other basic services meeting the needs of their residents, and protecting those residents' ability to stay and indeed control the future of their communities. We are and will remain committed to working to fulfill your vision despite the obstacles we and our clients face, because it is the right thing to do! Thank you Sarge for a life well lived and for the great legacy that you left for us!

8 P.M. (TCM) SPOTLIGHT: HAL ROACH STUDIOS They called it ''the lot that laughter built.'' From 1914 to 1960 the Hal Roach Studios, which set in motion the careers of Laurel and Hardy, Harold Lloyd, Harry Langdon and the Our Gang crew, presented a prodigious number of comedy shorts, features and television series. This monthlong tribute concludes with a 24-hour marathon of 17 of the studio's feature films, starting with ''Sons of the Desert'' (1933), in which Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy play friends who hatch a scheme to attend a convention over the objections of their wives. It continues with ''General Spanky'' (1936), starring George McFarland as Spanky, Carl Switzer as Alfalfa and Billie Thomas as Buckwheat, youngsters mixed up in the Civil War, at 9:15; and, at 10:30, the first in a ''Topper'' trilogy, starring, above, Roland Young, left, Cary Grant and Constance Bennett. 8 P.M. (13, 49) PIONEERS OF TELEVISION The topic is westerns, that emblem of American identity -- from Fess Parker's portrayal of Daniel Boone and Davy Crockett to James Arness's depiction of Marshal Matt Dillon in ''Gunsmoke.'' James Garner talks about playing a card shark in ''Maverick,'' and Linda Evans recalls the strong female characters she and Barbara Stanwyck created in ''The Big Valley''
