If you'd recently taken on the weighty assignment of directing two movies adapted from J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Hobbit,'' then defended that project during a potentially catastrophic labor crisis, you might be under some stress, too. So have sympathy for Peter Jackson, who will likely take some time off from that mammoth fantasy franchise after undergoing surgery for a perforated ulcer. Melissa Booth, a publicist for Mr. Jackson, told Agence France-Presse that the filmmaker had been experiencing stomach pains and on Wednesday night was admitted to Wellington Hospital in New Zealand, where doctors gave him the diagnosis and operated on him. Mr. Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the ''Lord of the Rings'' movies, stepped in last year to direct the ''Hobbit'' films after Guillermo del Toro withdrew, then fought a pitched battle against labor unions in New Zealand and Australia over hiring practices, with Mr. Jackson warning he could move the films out of New Zealand if the unions did not back down. Production on ''The Hobbit'' was to begin next month, but Ms. Booth said there would likely be a ''slight delay'' as Mr. Jackson recuperates. Asked how long that delay could be, Ms. Booth replied, ''How long is a piece of string?''

An article on Thursday about a legal dispute over the foreclosure of a former service member's home by agents of Deutsche Bank reported incorrectly the sequence of steps that JPMorgan Chase took to correct errors in its own handling of military mortgages. Chase began reversing its improper foreclosures before, not after, it issued its public apology in mid-January. The article also referred incorrectly in some editions to a military consumer protection team. It is based in the Treasury Department, not the White House.

A report in the Supreme Court roundup on Tuesday about an employment discrimination case that was sent back to the lower courts, misstated, in one instance, the surname of a man who complained that he was unfairly fired after his fiancée filed a discrimination case against their employer. He is Eric L. Thompson, not Thomson.

SIEGEL--Phyllis Musiker Passed away on January 25, 2011, in Fort Collins, CO, at age 86, from cancer. Phyllis was born on October 17, 1924, in Brooklyn, NY, where she graduated from James Madison High School. In 1946, she married Leonard S. Siegel, and moved to Manhattan, NY, where she lived until 2003, when she moved to Fort Collins to be close to her son and his family. While in New York, she often spent summers in "Musiker Acres" in Mount Freedom, NJ. She was a leader of the B'nai B'rith Jewish service organization in Manhattan, holding leadership positions in the New Israel Chapter, District No. 1, and B'nai B'rith Youth Organization. She was President of the Sisterhood for the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York, and generous to the Har Shalom Synagogue in Fort Collins. She is survived by her son, Howard Jay ("H.J.") Siegel, daughter-in law, Janet, granddaughter, Sky, and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins and their families. She was predeceased by her parents, Pauline and Maurice Musiker, her sisters, Myra Mandell and Sylvia Regan, and her ex-husband, Leonard S. Siegel. Phyllis had a great sense of humor and had the strong personality of a determined New Yorker in whatever she approached. She was a loving, caring, generous, and giving person. She had a long and happy life. She is deeply missed. There will be a cemetery service at King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ, at 2pm on January 30.

New York University: 'Art/Memory/Place: Commemorating the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire' (Tuesday through Saturday) Memorials for the more than 140 lives lost at the Triangle Waist Company in Greenwich Village have taken place faithfully since the day the fire blazed: March 25, 1911. An exhibition that chronicles those memorials is on view at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University -- in a building complex on the site of the fire -- featuring photographs, artworks, pamphlets, theatrical props and other items, among them a 1911 photograph of a mourners' procession, above. Special events are also planned in conjunction with the exhibition, including a discussion at the gallery on Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. with the show's two curators, Lucy Oakley and Marci Reaven, and the students who assisted them. The exhibition will be up through March 26 and, after a two-week hiatus, will reopen on April 12 and run through July 9; a permanent memorial is planned. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (Wednesdays until 8 p.m.), and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; 100 Washington Square East, between Waverly Place and Washington Place, (212) 998-6780, nyu.edu/greyart. The talk is free, but there is a $3 suggested donation for the exhibition; admission is free for N.Y.U. students, faculty and staff. (Anne Mancuso)

Representative Mike Pence of Indiana announced Thursday that he would not be a Republican candidate for president in 2012, but he left the door open to running for governor. ''In the choice between seeking national office and serving Indiana in some capacity, we choose Indiana,'' Mr. Pence wrote in a letter to supporters. ''We will not seek the Republican nomination for president in 2012.''

DAVOS, Switzerland -- A small explosion caused some broken glass but no injuries on Thursday morning at a four-star hotel in Davos, not far from the main meeting center of the World Economic Forum. Thomas Hobi, a spokesman for the police in the Swiss canton of Graubunden, where Davos is located, said there had been a ''little detonation'' in an underground storage area of the Posthotel Morosani around 9 a.m. local time. Some windows were broken but no one was hurt, he said.

Seiji Ozawa, whose health problems have forced him to cut back on performing for the last year, is canceling his spring appearances at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Ozawa's doctors believe he will not have recovered enough from recent back surgery to repair herniated discs, Carnegie said. The concerts were scheduled for April 1 and 2. Mr. Ozawa was to have conducted his youth orchestra, the Seiji Ozawa Ongaku-juku, as part of Carnegie's JapanNYC festival, of which he is the artistic director. The hall said ticket holders would be reimbursed for the canceled concerts. Mr. Ozawa scaled down his appearances with the Saito Kinen Orchestra during the festival's December portion because of his ailments, which included esophageal cancer and chronic back problems. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Judy Murray was there in the front row for her son as he advanced to the Australian Open semifinals on Wednesday, just as she was there at the beginning when Andy Murray's tennis matches were often played against his older brother in the living room of the family home in Dunblane, Scotland. ''When it was winter, he and Jamie would line up all their little trophies and things across the middle of the living room, and that would be their net,'' Judy Murray said in an interview at Melbourne Park. ''A sponge ball isn't going to hurt anything. I didn't mind.''

HEINEKEN'S INSIGHTS The World Economic Forum's annual meeting is taking place in Europe, but the real economic action is in emerging markets. So on Thursday executives got advice from an experienced hand on how to do business in those markets, an urgent question when growth in Europe and the United States remains tepid. Jean-François van Boxmeer, chief executive of Heineken, said at a breakfast at the forum, in Davos, Switzerland, that his company assessed countries according to a simple formula: population growth multiplied by economic growth times political stability. By that measure, Nigeria may be a safer place than Greece, he said -- at least for a beer maker. JACK EWING CLINTON'S WIDE RANGE If there is anyone who is tailor-made for the global talk-fest in Davos, it is Bill Clinton. On Thursday, Mr. Clinton, who first attended the forum a decade ago as president, took the main stage for an interview with Klaus Schwab, the founder of the conference. In a wide-ranging chat, he discussed topics including Haiti, American politics, the Middle East, particle physics and the Neanderthal genome project. PETER LATTMAN DEFENDING THE EUROThere is no shortage of euro skepticism at the forum, but the beleaguered currency had its defenders as well.

Some of the Tea Party's most prominent candidates never made it to Washington (think Christine ''I am not a witch'' O'Donnell of Delaware), but the movement that perhaps best embodied the anti-incumbent sentiment of 2010 has nonetheless gained a toehold in the upper chamber of Congress. And on Thursday it became official: Senator Jim DeMint of South Carolina, the Tea Party patron, and the freshmen senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Mike Lee of Utah held the first official gathering of the Senate Tea Party Caucus. But other newly elected Republican senators have refused to join, including some who had Tea Party support in the fall campaign, like Senators Patrick J. Toomey of Pennsylvania, Kelly A. Ayotte of New Hampshire, and Marco Rubio of Florida. And Mr. DeMint, who has been flirting with the idea of a presidential run, was the only nonfreshman senator to sign on. With its small membership, the Tea Party Caucus amounts to fewer than 10 percent of Republicans in the Senate, making it a minority within the minority. Mr. Lee, in an interview on CNN, said size did not matter. ''It's a relatively small group at this point, and I don't necessarily think it needs to be big,'' Mr. Lee said. ''We're not intending this to be a full-blown, influential caucus. We're intending this to be a conduit for information to pass between individuals who sympathize with the Tea Party movement and the United States Senate.'' Mr. Lee added, ''In time, it may grow.'' The House Tea Party Caucus, led by Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, held its first event late last year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Casting is complete for the first major New York revival of ''Cactus Flower,'' the Abe Burrows romantic farce that had 1,234 performances on Broadway from 1965 to 1968 and netted Goldie Hawn a career-making Best Supporting Actress Oscar for the 1969 film version. Ms. Hawn's character, Toni, the young girlfriend of a commitment-phobic dentist, will be played by Jenni Barber, who drew critical praise in the Off Broadway production ''From Up Here'' in 2008 and played Olive in one of the replacement casts for the Broadway musical ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee.'' Maxwell Caulfield (''Grease 2,'' the television series ''The Colbys'') will play the dentist, Julian, and Lois Robbins (a veteran of several soap operas) will be his shy assistant Stephanie, who comes to double as his make-believe wife. (In the original Broadway run, Lauren Bacall played Stephanie and Brenda Vaccaro received a Tony Award nomination for playing Toni.)

The Cavaliers faced a stern test that evening, though, as LeBron James made his much-anticipated return to Cleveland..Playing in front of an electric crowd, the Cavaliers jumped to a 17-12 lead over the Miami Heat with 4 minutes 31 seconds remaining in the first quarter.

GANTZ--Emanuel, beloved husband of Pat for 62 years. Devoted father to Karen (Eric), Kim (Sanford), Kathy (Lary) and JoAnn (Bobby). Adoring grandfather to Rebecca, Benjamin, Ross, Austin, and Ariel. Mr. Gantz, known as Manny, was born on September 3, 1917 on the Lower East Side of New York City. The family moved to Port Chester where Manny's father, Joseph Gantz, started Empire Brushes. Manny was responsible for the first battery powered toothbrushes, hair brushes, and hand-vacs. Manny graduated from Port Chester High School, the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School, class of 1941. He proudly served as an officer in the U.S. Army during World War II and was stationed in Eritrea with the Signal Corps. He was the only member of Old Oaks Country Club to start as a caddy and later become a member. Manny served as president of the American-Israel Chamber of Commerce, sponsored scholarships for Ethiopian Jews at the University of Samaria in Ariel, Israel, established the Philip and Emanuel Gantz Kindergarten in Jerusalem. His lifetime commitment to Israel was exemplified by his passionate involvement in helping to create the Israel Air Force Center in Herzilya, Israel. Funeral service will take place on Friday, January 28, 2011, at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY, at 12:00pm. Donations may be made to Israel Air Force Center, Herzilya, Israel; Scholarship Fund for Ethiopian students at the University of Samaria, Ariel, Israel; and the Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

An obituary on Jan. 20 about the writer Wilfrid Sheed referred incorrectly to one aspect of his education. He attended Downside in Bath, England, after -- not before -- immigrating with his family from Britain to the United States, in 1940. (He enrolled at Downside after they returned to England, in 1946.) Because of an editing error, the obituary also misstated the height of Mr. Sheed's mother, Maisie Ward, in describing her appearance. According to her family, she was about 5-foot-3, not six feet tall.

ZUCKERMAN--Lee, of Langhorne, PA.,died peacefully on January 22 at the age of 92. She was the beloved wife of 57 years of the late Morris Zuckerman. Born in New York she lived in Hicksville, NY for over 44 years and was a resident of Langhorne for the past 12 years. She was a woman of many talents who loved to cook, bake and share her favorite recipes with family and friends. Always willing to play a game of chance, she looked forward to trips to Atlantic City with her many friends. Lee gave her time to many causes including St. Mary's Medical Center, volunteering for over 4500 hours. She was a loving and devoted sister, mother of three sons and a proud grandmother and great-grandmother. She is survived by her brother, Bernard Fox; her three sons Dr. Nathan Zuckerman and his wife Joanie, Howard F. Zuckerman and Dr. Joseph D. Zuckerman and his wife Janet; six grandchildren; Brian and Jennifer, Andrew and Beth, Lawrence and Kim, Ryan and Grace, Scott and Matthew; six great-grandchildren; Jake, Carlye, Mason, Ryan, Brayden and Brendan; and her dear friend of 55 years Bertha Gordon. Her funeral was held in Langhorne on January 23. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York, an institution that she always supported and was important to her.

An article on Friday about tax increment financing, or TIF, paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Brian White, an advocate of affordable housing and a candidate for alderman of Chicago's 49th Ward. The State of the Art column on Thursday, about Internet calling apps, described the capabilities of such apps incorrectly. A few of them allow free calls to regular phone numbers from cellphones; it is not the case that no apps meet that description. The column also misstated the capabilities of Google Voice. Besides offering free domestic calls from your computer, the service also allows free calls from a landline phone and, with the use of an app called Talkatone, from a cellphone. It is not the case that it does not allow free calls from a phone.

The second episode of MTV's ''Skins'' suffered a dramatic drop in the ratings this week, to 1.6 million viewers from 3.3 million the prior week, as a half-dozen advertisers publicly distanced themselves from the provocative new drama series. Wrigley Jr. division of Mars, the Taco Bell division of Yum Brands, H&R Block, the Schick division of Energizer Holdings and Subway restaurants have all withdrawn from the series. MEYER--PEARL. Steven Hall & Partners mourns the passing of Pearl Meyer, our founder and Senior Managing Director. We have lost a great colleague and a dear friend. Pearl was not only one of the most trusted advisors to Boards of Directors and senior executives, but also a giant in the field of executive compensation and corporate governance who helped to elevate the profession and inspired so many to act with integrity and independence. On a personal and professional level, Pearl was a woman of great wit, charm and intensity. She did everything with grace, style and quality. She was the first woman inducted in the Directorship Corporate Governance Hall of Fame in 2009 and was recognized by many organizations for her pioneering work in the field of executive compensation and for her community spirit. We are proud to have been her partners for over 30 years and even prouder to have called her our friend.

If this was how Colin Quinn and Jerry Seinfeld planned to get themselves back on television, they certainly picked a roundabout way of doing it: ''Colin Quinn Long Story Short,'' Mr. Quinn's one-man show about the ascent and decline of civilization, which is also Mr. Seinfeld's Broadway directorial debut, will be taped by HBO to be shown as a special in April, the cable network announced on Thursday. Mr. Seinfeld, who has previously appeared on HBO in his own comedy specials like ''I'm Telling You for the Last Time'' (not to mention the ''Seinfeld'' reunion season of ''Curb Your Enthusiasm''), said in a phone interview that the network began expressing interest in ''Long Story Short'' over the summer, when Mr. Quinn was performing the show off Broadway at the Bleecker Street Theater and preparing to transfer it to the Helen Hayes Theater.

On the evening of Jan. 30, 1861, a slow freight train chugged into the small hamlet of Charleston, Ill., having completed a 12-mile run from Mattoon. Or nearly 12 miles - the train didn't quite make it all the way to the station. A few people straggled out of the caboose and trudged through slush and ice toward the depot, where a gaggle of townsfolk loitered. To their astonishment, they realized that the tall man coming toward them, wearing a shawl, was Abraham Lincoln.

He lost last year in straight sets to Roger Federer. While the two know each other well, they have only met seven times on the tour. Djokovic holds a slight edge 4-3, but Murray has won their last three meetings.

Below, the full set of rule changes proposed at USA Hockey's Winter Meeting last weekend in Colorado Springs. The proposals seek to raise the minimum age for body checking in boys hockey from 11-12 to 13-14, make all contact to the head-and-neck area illegal at all age levels and, in those classifications in which fighting does not result in immediate expulsion, provide for extra penalties when one player tears off an his own helmet or an opponent's helmet during a fight.

Impressionism and the Super Bowl might seem like strange bedfellows, but they will be getting a little bro time together this year in the spirit of the game. Continuing an art tradition that began last year, the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh and the Milwaukee Art Museum (the closest museum to Green Bay, Wisc., home of the Packers), have agreed to make a gridiron bet. If Green Bay wins, the Carnegie will send Pierre Renoir's ''Bathers with a Crab'' from the 1890s to Milwaukee as a temporary loan. If the Steelers win, the Carnegie's patrons will get a brief visit from a Gustave Caillebotte, another water-focused scene titled ''Boating on the Yerres'' from 1877. Daniel Keegan, director of the Milwaukee Art Museum, predicted boldly (in a prepared statement) that he would soon be welcoming the Renoir to his turf, ''where the public can enjoy it and be reminded of the superiority of the Green Bay Packers.''

Californians, with their year-round balmy weather, wouldn't know a good stout beer if it hit them on their sun-kissed heads. At least that's how Brian Profilio, 36, an art teacher, said he sees it as he stood gulping a wintry East Coast brew at a beer tasting Thursday night in his hometown, Staten Island. The event was billed as a battle between beers and brewers from either side of the country. The East Coast Versus West Coast Punk Rock Brew Tour had a Warped Tour sensibility - the four craft brewers lecturing to the members of the local beer appreciation group, the St. George Taps and Barley Beer Club - wore black T-shirts with beer tour dates listed on the back, and some had beards that would have been at home at a Korn concert. But the 20 or so club members who braved the snow frothing up the front door of the Wild Goose Publick House wouldn't have made it through the doors at Webster Hall: there were enough Pendleton plaid shirts to make guests think they'd stepped off Forest Avenue into Portland, Ore.

BEDFORD, N.Y. -- Though it was billed as a joint recital, they never appeared together. Atka took the stage first, sweeping right to the piano and striking a commanding pose. But with the keys covered and the lid down, there wasn't much else he could do. He being a wolf. After he was led away, Hélène Grimaud entered, opened the lid and let loose with music from her new album, ''Resonances,'' on Deutsche Grammophon. It was a preview, of sorts, of her appearances (without Atka to set the stage) on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall and on Monday evening at Le Poisson Rouge.

The Brooklyn tortilla factory where a Guatemalan worker died on Monday after he fell into an industrial dough mixer has been shut down by the state because it has been without workers' compensation insurance for nearly a year, state officials said Friday. Brian Keegan, a spokesman for the state Workers' Compensation Board, said the insurance for the company, Tortilleria Chinantla, ran out last March 28 and the business has since accrued $56,000 in penalties for noncompliance.

DRESSNER--Karen. On behalf of the students, parents, alumnae, faculty, and staff of the Nightingale-Bamford School, we mourn the death of one of our most talented and inspiring faculty members, Karen Dressner. A Lower School science teacher at Nightingale since 1988, she was a source of humor, wisdom, and, above all, vitality. With an ever-present smile, Ms. Dressner connected with everyone in the schoolhouse. She will remain in our hearts and memories always, and her legacy can be seen in the hundreds of Nightingale girls and women who share her passion for science and the natural world. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Sunday, January 30, at Nightingale, 20 East 92nd Street. Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School Nina Joukowsky Koprulu, President, Board of Trustees

DRISCOLL--Barrie Keohane. Born, the Bronx, 1935, to Bart and Josephine (nee Keohane) Driscoll. Retired partner of Coopers & Lybrand, graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School(1953), Manhattan College (1957) and Fordham Law School (1962). Donovan, and daughters, Christine (Paul) Hogan and Marie (James) Spoto, and seven grandchildren: James Barrie, Charlotte, Bridget, Maeve and Lorelei Hogan, and Barry and James Spoto. Funeral on Monday, January 31, at 9:30am from St. Anthony's RC Church, Hawthorne, NJ. Viewing Sunday, January 30th, at Browning, Forshay Funeral Home, Hawthorne, NJ from to 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

MEYER--PEARL. Steven Hall & Partners mourns the passing of Pearl Meyer, our founder and Senior Managing Director. We have lost a great colleague and a dear friend. Pearl was not only one of the most trusted advisors to Boards of Directors and senior executives, but also a giant in the field of executive compensation and corporate governance who helped to elevate the profession and inspired so many to act with integrity and independence. On a personal and professional level, Pearl was a woman of great wit, charm and intensity. She did everything with grace, style and quality. She was the first woman inducted in the Directorship Corporate Governance Hall of Fame in 2009 and was recognized by many organizations for her pioneering work in the field of executive compensation and for her community spirit. We are proud to have been her partners for over 30 years and even prouder to have called her our friend.

NOTO--Robert M.,92, on January 11. Beloved Uncle. Caring friend to many. Loving surrogate father and grandfather. Proud WWII veteran. Quintessential New Yorker - The Times, W. 69th, Hells Kitchen. Owned "Noto" first on W. 43rd, then on W. 72nd and after many years opened the company, "Gargoyles." Terrific storyteller, always ending with a laugh. Loved the arts, from sculpture to ballet. A sweet, charming man with a generous spirit. Last of the Noto boys. Donations can be made to the VNS-NY Hospice Care. A celebration of his life will take place Spring 2011.

There is, apparently, a distinction even rarer than being granted a license to kill by Her Majesty's Secret Service, and that is having a bronze sculpture of your likeness displayed in the Estonian capital, Tallinn. Sean Connery is now that most exceptional of actors who can claim both honors: on Thursday, a bust depicting the well-preserved star of seven James Bond films (not to mention ''The Hunt for Red October,'' ''Highlander'' and ''The Untouchables'') was unveiled outside Tallinn's Scottish Club, an organization for Scottish expatriates and admirers of all things Scottish in Estonia, The Associated Press reported. Peter Carter, Britain's ambassador to Estonia, said at the unveiling of the $14,000 sculpture that Mr. Connery was ''without a doubt, an icon,'' adding: ''He is variously known as James Bond or the sexiest man of the century. He's a great British actor, a great Scot actor and a great symbol for Scotland.'' Mr. Connery was not present, but said in a statement: ''One cannot help but be flattered by the Scottish Club's gesture. My best wishes to the members of the club and to all the people who made this possible.'' The statement was read by Mart Haamer, president of the Scottish Club, hopefully in his best Sean Connery accent.

Count on Rocco Landesman to stir the pot. Speaking at a conference about new play development at Arena Stage in Washington on Thursday, Mr. Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, addressed the problem of struggling theaters. ''You can either increase demand or decrease supply,'' he said. ''Demand is not going to increase, so it is time to think about decreasing supply.'' His comment reverberated through the blogosphere. ''What does he mean there's too much supply?!?'' wrote Trisha Mead, the public relations and publications manager at Portland Center Stage in Oregon. ''What does he mean we can't increase demand?!? Who determines which theater companies are wheat and which are chaff?!?'' In another post, Durango Miller, a playwright and director, said: ''Why not just increase funding? Maybe the N.E.A. is outdated and should be replaced by another system for funding the arts in the United States. Or maybe the people who are running the N.E.A. should be replaced.'' In a telephone interview on Friday Mr. Landesman defended his comments. ''There is a disconnect that has to be taken seriously - our research shows that attendance has been decreasing while the number of the organizations have been proliferating,'' he said. ''That's a discussion nobody wants to have.'' Foundations and agencies like the endowment should perhaps reconsider re-allocating their resources, he said, perhaps giving larger grants to fewer institutions. ''There might be too many resident theaters - it is possible,'' he said. ''At least we have to talk about it.'' This month a group of Republican lawmakers called for the elimination of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities. Mr. Landesman said he was reserving judgment about that. ''I think we have to see what comes out in the away of actual legislation,'' he said. ''I'm optimistic that the N.E.A. and the N.E.H. are going to be O.K.''

CUNDILL--Peter. Peter Cundill was born in Montreal in October 1938. He was educated at Lower Canada College where he made his mark on the football field and on the basketball team. He gained a Bachelor of Commerce degree from McGill University in 1960, after which he qualified as a Chartered Accountant and entered the investment business. In 1963 he began to keep the daily journal that he maintained for more than 40 years as he built and grew the Cundill Value Fund for which he became famous. Peter had what he called his "epiphany" on a plane when he read about the value investment principles of Benjamin Graham. His comment was "This Is What I Want To Do For The Rest Of My Life" and he did, with a success that richly rewarded thousands of investors, not least those with small resources and precious savings. His record over 35 years as a global mutual fund manager was unrivalled. In 2001 he received the Analysts' Choice Career Achievement Award in recognition of proven superior performance and his lifetime contribution to the financial community. At the Canadian Investment Awards ceremony he was introduced as "the Indiana Jones of Canadian Money Managers" - an epithet in which he took great delight. But Peter was in no sense one dimensional. He had a passion for physical challenges, running 22 marathons including a "sub 3" when aged over 40, of which he was immensely proud. His interests were exceptionally wide ranging, springing from his insatiable curiosity, a characteristic which he regarded as a vital component in every aspect of life. He was a voracious reader and an inveterate traveller, once commenting "if I haven't been on a plane for a week I begin to feel restless". He was never happier than in a hotel suite where he could smoke his cigars and eat his favourite "junk" foods (typically hot dogs with lashings of mustard and vanilla ice cream smothered in caramel sauce). Although he lived in London for the past 20 years and loved that city he remained inordinately proud of being Canadian, profoundly interested in everything about his country. He relished nothing better than being among a gathering of Canadians with a bit of Montreal gossip, some Bay Street news and Vancouver views. His abiding passion for history and his belief that it is only possible to comprehend the present and arrive at a measured perspective about the future if one understands the past, led to his founding of The Cundill International Prize in History at McGill, the largest in the world. The Cundill Foundation, which now controls his very considerable wealth, has supported and will continue to support a wide range of charities as well as research projects and educational and enterprise gifts to young people. In 2006 Peter was diagnosed with Fragile X Tremor/Ataxia Syndrome, an as yet untreatable neurological condition. As a result he retired from daily operational fund management in 2009, becoming Chairman Emeritus of Mackenzie Cundill. Nevertheless, far from giving up or wallowing in self pity, Peter fully embraced the challenge of his condition with unwavering cheerfulness and a determination to lead as full a life as possible and to continue to guide and support all those within his wide reach in a personal and professional sense. His influence has been profound. He was very anxious to provide some legacy of his investment genius which might be useful to others and this culminated in the production of a book, There's Always Something To Do The Peter Cundill Investment Approach. To his immense delight the first copy was pressed into his hands in hospital two days before he died. It will be released at the end of February. Peter was pre-deceased by his beloved wife, Joanie, and is survived by his stepdaughter, Evelyn, two grandchildren, his stepson, Roger, and his brother, Grier. He will be deeply missed by a large international circle of friends and all of his ex-colleagues and associates. Following his wishes, Peter will be cremated and his ashes will be scattered in Quebec and British Columbia. Memorial services will be held in Vancouver, Toronto and London at dates to be announced. If you would like to make a donation in his memory, please consider the VGH & UBC Hospital Foundation, www.worldclasshealthcare.ca. Condolences to: peter.cundill.family@gmail.com

Alpha Natural Resources is close to a deal to buy Massey Energy, the besieged coal mine operator, for about $7 billion in cash and stock, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Friday. If completed, the deal would merge two of the biggest American producers of coal -- and potentially help Massey finally move past litigation over several prominent disasters in recent years. The chief among them was an explosion at the company's Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia last year, which killed 29 people.

Besides playing the title character and the president of the United States, he also played a British officer -- not an American general who orders a nuclear attack on Russia. 8 P.M. (HBO) REPO MEN (2010) In this dystopic satire, adapted from the novel ''The Repossession Mambo,'' by Eric Garcia (who wrote the screenplay with Garrett Lerner), and set 20 years in the future, Jude Law, above, stars as Remy, an employee of a corporation called the Union. The company has developed synthetic, life-extending prostheses known as artiforgs for every body part. The implants can cost nearly $600,000 each and are sold by zealous door-to-door insurance salesmen. If someone falls too far behind in his payments, a repo man arrives on the scene with a body scanner and a scalpel, the better to detect company property and cut it out. But when Remy tries to reclaim the artificial heart of a musician named T-Bone (the rapper RZA), he's knocked unconscious from an electric shock and emerges from a coma to discover that he, too, has been implanted with a fake pumper. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that ''as a recession-era satire,'' this nasty, comic thriller from Miguel Sapochnik ''strikes a very bitter chord.'' He added: ''In today's climate of widespread home foreclosures in which most banks refuse to modify the terms of mortgages, the movie offers a grotesque funhouse reflection of this scarily Darwinian environment. Then there is the matter of escalating health care costs and the insurance industry's resistance to reform. We are halfway there already.'' A viral infection has forced James Levine to cancel a performance at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. Mr. Levine was to have led the Met Chamber Ensemble, made up of members of the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, in a challenging program of works by Brahms, Lukas Foss, Leon Kirchner and George Perle. Mr. Levine said the infection had prevented him from rehearsing enough. He withdrew from a performance of Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra'' at the Met on Monday but was expected to conduct it on Friday evening, Carnegie said. Mr. Levine missed a number of performances in the past several seasons because of a series of health problems but returned with new vigor this season. Carnegie Hall said ticket holders would receive refunds or exchanges.

It was an exciting weekend in college basketball, with No. 1 Ohio State and No. 2 Pittsburgh barely escaping on the road and No. 3 Duke getting manhandled by St. John's at Madison Square Garden. But the most astonishing moment came at the end of the game between Manhattan and Marist. That's right, Manhattan and Marist. The Red Foxes held a 59-57 lead in the final seconds when Manhattan's Michael Alvarado got the ball on an inbounds pass with two seconds left, began dribbling up the court and let go of the ball well before the halfcourt line. It banked in off the glass, giving the Jaspers a 60-59 victory and Alvarado a shining moment in January.

One of the discouraging features of economic debate today -- maybe it was always thus, but it seems especially intense now -- is how much of it rests on "facts" that aren't, but which become articles of faith. I've been surprised, for example, to encounter assertions that Fannie and Freddie held a third of subprime mortgages, which I knew wasn't remotely true. Where did that come from? Mike Konczal points us to James Kwak, explaining that the source for that number is a consultant to the mortgage industry who made up his own definition of subprime -- one that bears little resemblance to the standard definition, and which happens to produce a vastly inflated number for Fannie/Freddie.

LOS ANGELES- Tom Hooper, the director of "The King's Speech," picked up the top prize at the Directors Guild of America awards on Saturday night, a surprise victory that scrambled the prognostications of the Oscar experts. The win came at the expense of another front-runner, David Fincher, the director of "The Social Network," and followed a similar upset at the Producers Guild of America awards when the British period drama took the top honor. (David O. Russell ("The Fighter"), Darren Aronofsky ("Black Swan") and Christopher Nolan ("Inception") were the other nominees last night.)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, January 15th 2011, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

LEVINE--Lawrence F. Larry has been a major part of the life of the Lorber family for more than 35 years. His visits with us to Fisher Island, during the winter months and Southampton in the summer will be forever missed. Breakfast without him will never be the same. We will always remember him. He was a man never to be forgotten. The Lorber Family

MCCARTHY--Joseph T.,on January 27, after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Kathryn (nee Duffy) Devoted father of Martin. Retired member of MaBSTOA and The Equitable. Martin had served in The United States Coast Guard Reserves an was a member of the Army Navy Union, the Fighting 69th Infantry Regiment as well as the American Irish Historical Society and the New York Irish History Roundtable. Martin also held life membership in the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. A visitation will be held on Monday, January 31, at the Gannon Funeral Home 152 East 28th Street New York City 2-5 and 7-9pm Funeral mass will be celebrated Tuesday at Church of the Epiphany (22nd Street and 2nd Ave.) at 10:00am Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery Valhalla, New York.

JACOBS--Doris Pollock, 92, died peacefully January 26, 2011. Cherished wife of the late Aaron "Ollie" Pollock and the late Dr. Mike Jacobs. Adored by her children Mark and Jodi Pollock and Susan and Eliot Cherson. Beloved mother-in-law to Carol Pollack. Much loved grandmother of Adam, Keith, Jeremy, Jordan, Ali and Blair. Great-grandmother of Max. Cousin of Marvin Shain. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

STONE--Clara (Wettenstein) on January 27, 2011. Born April 1, 1925, in Bridgeport, CT. She is survived by her beloved husband of 62 years, Irving; son Philip (Katie Green) of Princeton, MA; and daughter Louise (Jos Ruks) of Portland, ME. Pre-deceased by her son Daniel. She was a loved and cherished mother, friend, sister, aunt, step-grandmother, teacher, and activist for peace and social justice. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, January 30th at 1pm at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st St., New York. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Riverside Park Fund, in memory of Clara Stone.

An article last Sunday about the singer Wanda Jackson erroneously attributed a distinction to her. She was among the first women to record a rock song -- but not the first, a distinction that remains much in debate. (Another singer cited as the ''first'' is Janis Martin, the so-called ''female Elvis.'')

GALONSKY--Mildred. The Yeshiva University family was deeply grieved at the recent passing of Mildred Galonsky, a cherished alumna of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work, and a Yeshiva University Guardian who was a very cultured, philanthropic, self-made woman of compassion and kindness, who started out as a secretary and then advanced to becoming an excellent social worker, who cared about others beyond the requirements of the profession. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her brother, Dr. Aaron (and Marion) Galonsky; nephew, Marc (and Patricia) Galonsky, Esq.; niece, Lee Anne (and David) Sanderson and her cousins. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

Last Monday, ice shrouded the Bryant Park fountain; by Wednesday, most of it had melted. On Thursday, beautiful snow transformed the city. Down coats and enormous down hoods enveloped people and dogs. On Seventh Avenue, designers lugged bolts of fabric for their fall collections, and a model dripping in fake fur resembled the fountain.

Travelers seeking a sustainable getaway have a new resource in the Web site Green.travel. The site, which went live last week, provides just over 4,500 searchable listings of lodgings, cruises and tours in over 60 countries ranked by their eco-credentials on a scale of zero to five green suitcases. It was created by the nonprofit organization Sustainable Travel International.

MEEKER--Warren C. The Meeker family sadly announces the death of Warren C. Meeker on January 18, 2011 in Naples, Florida after a lengthy illness, bravely borne. Warren was born on February 10, 1922 in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Columbia University, NYC, in 1943. Immediately entering the US Army, he served honorably with the 79th Infantry, ETO. He returned to Columbia and received an MA in Political Science. Warren began his career in 1951 with the Lawyers Cooperative Publishing Co, (LCP, now a part of Thomson Reuters) in Rochester, NY. In 1966, he was promoted to President of the LCP subsidiary, Bancroft Whitney in San Francisco. Warren returned to NYC in 1970 to become Chairman and CEO of the Research Institute of America until retirement. Warren was an ardent supporter of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) and served as a director. He served on the Committee of Americans for the Panama Canal Treaty and the Citizens Commission on Indochinese Refugees following the end of the Vietnam War. Warren was an avid tennis player and a self-taught pianist; his family fondly remembers him belting out the ragtime blues. Warren is survived by his wife of 30 years, Lynda, his children Jeffrey S. Meeker (Cheryl Markowitz), Leslie Meeker (Enver Bismillah), Amy Meeker, Warren J. Meeker (Michelle Adams) and grandchildren Molly, Hannah, Joshua, Emma, Grace, Morgan, Ryan and Kylan.

Some of the top trends from Saturday's games. FOUR IS ENOUGH Dee Bost, left, one of four Mississippi State players to score, had 24 points in win over Florida. He played with his front teeth glued together after being elbowed during the week.

LEIBOWITZ--Herbert H. (January 10, 1923-January 24, 2011) died peacefully at home of natural causes. Born in Brooklyn, he was trained as a social worker and devoted his life to helping others. He received his BA from NYU, MSW from the University of Pittsburgh, and EdD from Teachers College at Columbia University. He worked in Social Work administration in New York, New Mexico and California. He worked with the Navajo Nation early in his career and again when he was more senior. After spending two years in India as a Peace Corps Regional Director he then worked as a Regional Research Director with the Federal Rehabilitation Services Administration. He was an early mentor to Ed Roberts and others in the Independent Living Movement of People with Disabilities in the 1970s-90s and helped CIL and WID become important and valuable resources for the rehabilitation system and people with disabilities and their families. Loving Husband, Brother, Father, and Grandfather, he is survived by his sister Nesha Hammerschmidt, sons Mark and David, daughter-in-law Kass, and grandchildren Matt and Nick. He is in our hearts forever. Memorial contributions can be made to a local hospice.

New Orleans quarterback Drew Brees, the most valuable player in last year's Super Bowl, is in Honolulu to participate in Sunday's Pro Bowl. Last week, he teamed with Procter & Gamble on Oahu to help build a playground at the Leeward Y.M.C.A., one of five community service projects of the 2011 N.F.L. Play 60 Community Blitz, which promotes youth health and wellness.Q.Who was your idol growing up?A.I had a lot of them. I also played baseball growing up, and one of my idols was Ted Williams, I knew every one of his statistics. That's why I wear No. 9. I also idolized Ken Griffey Jr. I tried to emulate his swing. I had a chance to play golf with him a few years ago and I was in awe. In terms of football, my heroes were Joe Montana and Troy Aikman. Q.Who will win the Super Bowl?A.I don't really know. Both teams are playing very well right now. They each have similar-style defenses. Pittsburgh uses more ball control, but they have big-play capability with Ben Roethlisberger and his receivers. On the flip side, Green Bay is an aggressive team that likes to air it out. I don't know if there's a real favorite here.Q.How do you stack up against Roethlisberger and Tom Brady?A.Drew Brees? Who's that? In all seriousness, I consider Tom Brady and Peyton Manning to be the two best quarterbacks in the league, and the rest of us are kind of nipping at their heels. They are the cream of the crop, and hopefully, when it's all said and done, I can be mentioned in that same sentence.Q.Will there be a lockout?A.I hope not, but it's a legitimate concern. We as players are preparing ourselves for that possibility. In the last three years, we've experienced some of the greatest gains in terms of popularity and generating total revenue. Our salaries are predicated on how well the league does financially, so if the league is making money, that means we're making money. And yet we are being asked to take an 18 percent pay cut. We are also being asked to go to an 18-game schedule, which will increase our chance of injury and long-term health risks. Considering that revenues continue to go up and up, these are not very fair requests.Q.What do the Saints need to do to get back to the Super Bowl?A.We just have to get some much-needed rest and then get back to work. We also need to get some guys healthy again. I'm excited about some of our young players and feel that we have as good a shot as anyone to get back to the Super Bowl.Q.Tell us something no one knows about you.A.I'm not a surfer, but I like to paddleboard. It's something I did for the first time a few years ago during a family vacation in Hawaii, and I just kind of got hooked. It's a great workout and very therapeutic.Q.What will you do in the off-season?A.I'm going to spend time with my family. I'm finally feeling that the ride from the 2009 Super Bowl is now ending, and now I have a chance to relax a bit. I need to recharge my batteries, both physically and mentally.

RICH--Martha, 84, of Short Hills died Thursday. Born in Hungary, came to the United States in 1946, lived in Yonkers, and moved to Short Hills in 1981. A Holocaust survivor, she was tireless and passionate about lecturing at schools and clubs to educate the world of the atrocities of the Holocaust. In 2004, Martha was appointed by Governor McGreevey to the New Jersey Commission on Holocaust Education. She played a pivotal role in "The Paper Clip Project," which was started by eighth graders in Whitwell, TN. Martha was a driving force and founding benefactor of the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York City. The Holocaust Council of Metrowest established the Martha Rich Scholarship Fund, and the Women's Philanthropy Council awarded Martha the Lion Of Judah Award. Martha served on the board of directors of the Women's Division of Metrowest. She is survived by her beloved husband, George. Martha was the devoted mother of Michael Leob and his wife, Kathy, Diane Herzog and her husband, Bob; stepmother to Monica Kosann and her husband, Rod, and Rina Langer and her husband, David, and grandmother of Jason, Daniel, Danielle, Laura, Marc, and Julia. Funeral services will be held Sunday, January 30, at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, on Sunday at 10:30am. Interment will follow at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

Visitors to the British Library have a new tool to help guide them: a mobile app that highlights more than 100 works from its collections. Included are portions of the Codex Sinaiticus, a handwritten manuscript of the Christian Bible written in the middle of the fourth century; Galileo's letters; Leonardo da Vinci's notebooks; the original version of ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' and Jane Austen's teenage writings. ''It's basically the history of Western civilization'' said Aaron Radin, chief executive of Toura, a technology company that developed the app. ''In a world where you can get anything you want on the Internet, having professionals curate information for you is of extraordinary value.''

Massey Energy, the embattled coal mine operator, agreed on Saturday to sell itself for about $7.1 billion in cash and stock in a deal that will create a new giant in coal production - and could help Massey shed legal burdens arising from a marred safety record that includes the explosion last year at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia. Under the terms of the deal, Alpha Natural Resources will pay 1.025 of its own shares and $10 in cash, for a total of $69.33 as of Friday's market close, for each Massey share. That represents a 21 percent premium to Massey's Friday closing price of $57.23. The deal will unite two of the biggest American producers of coal, with more than 110 mines and about five billion tons of combined reserves throughout the Appalachian region, the Midwest and Wyoming. It will also bolster Alpha's presence in the growing market for metallurgical coal, which is used to make steel. Massey has enormous reserves of metallurgical coal, and it has increased its exports to countries like India and Brazil, where strong demand has driven up global prices for the material.

MEYER--PEARL. Steven Hall & Partners mourns the passing of Pearl Meyer, our founder and Senior Managing Director. We have lost a great colleague and a dear friend. Pearl was not only one of the most trusted advisors to Boards of Directors and senior executives, but also a giant in the field of executive compensation and corporate governance who helped to elevate the profession and inspired so many to act with integrity and independence. On a personal and professional level, Pearl was a woman of great wit, charm and intensity. She did everything with grace, style and quality. She was the first woman inducted in the Directorship Corporate Governance Hall of Fame in 2009 and was recognized by many organizations for her pioneering work in the field of executive compensation and for her community spirit. We are proud to have been her partners for over 30 years and even prouder to have called her our friend.

IF you remember the construction of Citicorp Center in 1977 or the opening of the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1978, imagine your counterparts from the mid-20th century. Some were old enough to recall horse-drawn street cars and 32-story ''skyscrapers'' even as they sped around by subway or ascended to the 102nd floor of the Empire State Building. Sobersided planners and wide-eyed visionaries thought this astonishing pace of transformation would never abate. A dreamer named W. Parker Chase proposed in 1932 that the 50 million people living in New York City 50 years on would ride vacuum-tube escalators and take air taxis to their 250-story office towers. The Regional Plan Association envisioned a 1,200-foot-long bathhouse complex at Great Kills Park on Staten Island. Robert Moses, who usually had the power to get things done, tried to persuade the United Nations to build a Brasília-like center at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens. (Midtown Manhattan, he warned in 1946, would by then ''not be a proper, dignified and practical location'' for the United Nations.)
Art Ken Johnson

Well respected, world renowned surgeon in the field of colorectal cancer. Memorial service will be planned for March.

On Tuesday, Cyclone Power Technologies of Pompano Beach, Fla., announced that it would attempt to break the land-speed record for an unlikely race class: steam cars. A British team set the existing record of 148.308 miles per hour in 2009. The prior record holder? A 1906 Stanley Steamer.

SCHREYER--William A.,William A. Schreyer, who began his career marking stock prices on a chalkboard at a storefront office and rose to become chairman and CEO of Merrill Lynch died on Saturday, January 22, 2011. During a 45-year career with Merrill Lynch, he led its transformation from US stock brokerage to diversified global investment bank. He was 83 and died peacefully at his Princeton, NJ home surrounded by family. During the stock market crash of 1987, "Bill" Schreyer gained wide recognition for his decisive leadership, when he counseled investors not to panic, via nationally televised commercials, signing-off with the signature line: "At Merrill Lynch, we're still bullish on America." He was known as a visionary leader, a generous mentor and an irrepressible optimist. An active philanthropist, he gave $55 Million to his alma mater, Penn State, to establish the Schreyer Honors College. Bill Schreyer was born in Williamsport, PA where his father managed the local office of a stock brokerage acquired by Merrill Lynch. Long before the age of instantaneous electronic data transmission, he worked part time marking a storefront chalkboard with securities prices wired from New York. After graduating from Penn State University in 1948, Mr. Schreyer joined Merrill Lynch as a junior executive trainee, and was sent to Buffalo, NY as an account executive-now called financial advisor. There, he met Joan Legg, the daughter of a local banker, and in 1953 they were married. He served for two years as a lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force stationed in Germany- where he developed his interest in international financial markets. In 1963 he entered management as head of the company's Trenton, NJ office and held a succession of positions in the company's retail branch office system, culminating in 1972 as regional director in the New York metropolitan area. As he moved up the management chain, he began to advocate that the company develop beyond its brokerage base and create a separate capital markets division. In 1981, he was put in charge of that division. Two decades later, in 2003, that division accounted for 50 percent of the company's net revenues and 70 percent of pretax profits. Mr. Schreyer became president of the parent company in 1982, and rose to CEO and chairman of the board in 1985. A period of substantial international investment followed. Merrill Lynch was among the first group of foreign firms admitted to membership in the Tokyo Stock Exchange (1986) and became the first U.S. investment bank to open a representative office in the People's Republic of China (1993). On the eve of his retirement, Forbes magazine gave this assessment of Mr Schreyer's tenure as CEO: "If ever a chairman deserved well of his shareholders, Schreyer does." Mr. Schreyer served on the Penn State Board of Trustees from 1986 to 1998, including two terms as president (1993-1996). He also chaired the university's first capital campaign which ran from 1984-1990, raising over $350 million. He was a trustee and international councilor of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a bipartisan public policy institute based in Washington, D.C. Mr. Schreyer also served as a trustee of the George H.W. Bush Presidential Library Foundation, and was a consultor for the Vatican's Patrimony of the Apostolic See. In addition to his wife, Mr. Schreyer is survived by his daughter, DrueAnne Schreyer, a son-in-law, Rodney Frazier, and two grandchildren, Kelly and Charles Frazier. A private service for family members will be held in Princeton, and a memorial service will be planned for the spring. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, any donations in Mr. Schreyer's memory be made to The Schreyer Honors College at Penn State, in University Park, PA; the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, DC; the Princeton HealthCare System, in Princeton, NJ, or Daytop Village, in New York, NY. In his 2009 memoir, "Still Bullish on America," Schreyer examined the "cataclysmic" financial events of the two previous years with this conclusion: "Yes, I'm an optimist. The pessimists are correct at any given points in history, but never over the long term. I believe in the regenerative powers of capitalism, as long as there are people at work with intelligence, imagination, courage, character and the desire to make a better life. I don't see any of those human qualities going away anytime soon."

THE NEWS The 2008 financial crisis was an ''avoidable'' disaster caused by regulatory neglect, corporate bungling and heedless risk-taking by Wall Street, a federal investigation concluded. BEHIND THE NEWS The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission's report, backed by its six Democrats but not by its four Republicans, knocked down other theories, saying low interest rates, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and federal housing policies were not major culprits. Dissenters focused more blame on cheap money and the drive to increase homeownership.

Kurt Thomas played in only five of the Chicago Bulls' first 24 games and on many nights he was on the bench in a suit rather than on the floor in a uniform. Then on Dec. 15 Joakim Noah was injured and was expected to be out six to eight weeks with a torn ligament in his thumb. Suddenly, Thomas was starting at center. Signed last off-season as insurance, Thomas has flourished as a starter, playing solid defense, rebounding and knocking down open jump shots. He is a big reason the Bulls were 16-6 through Friday without Noah.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

MATTHEWS--William O'Connell, died peacefully at his home in Bronxville, NY on January 27, 2011. He was also a resident of Osterville, MA, and Palm Beach, FL. Bill was devoted to his faith and family. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years, Janet (Ross), two adoring children, Jennifer Matthews Frost of Bronxville, and her two children, Elizabeth M. Frost and Gerard G. Frost, III, and son William O. Matthews, Jr., and his wife Angela of Pacific Palisades, CA and their three sons, William O'Connell Matthews, III, Tristen V. Matthews, and Trevor C. Matthews. He is also survived by his sister Mary J. Matthews of Manhattan and several nieces and nephews. William is a direct descendant of Daniel O'Connell, the famed Irish Patriot and writer who served with distinction in the British House of Commons and for whom the O'Connell Bridge in Dublin is named. Born in Boston, Mr. Matthews joined the U.S. Navy, finished submarine school and served on the USS Spinax SS489. Upon completion of Naval service, he attended Boston College from which he graduated in 1955. Beginning his long and productive career in the investment business, Mr. Matthews joined Kidder, Peabody in Boston and later moved to Paine Webber before moving to New York where he held positions of increasing responsibility. He completed his distinguished career in 1998, retiring as a General Partner and Managing Director at SG Cowen & Company. Long a supporter of Boston College, Mr. Matthews donated a Student Lounge and a Computer Lab to graduate business school now called the Carroll School of Management. In addition, he was a major benefactor of the Irish Studies Program. Mr. Matthews was also generous with his time as a member of the Knights of Malta, and the Boston College Wall Street Council, which provides a wide range of scholarships. He was a long time member of the friendly Sons of St. Patrick as well as the Rotary Club of Bronxville. He was a long time member of the Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville; and the Oyster Harbors Club in Osterville and The Beach Club in Centerville, MA. In Palm Beach he was a benefactor of The Society of Four Arts, and also a member of The Beach Club and the Breakers Ocean Golf Club. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, 4 to 8pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's church, Bronxville, on Thursday February 3rd at 10am. A private burial will be held in Boston, MA. A memorial service is being planned in Osterville in the summer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, N.Y. 10707. www.jansenhospice.org

Neboh Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

SHORTLY after presenting his first collection for Theory, Olivier Theyskens shocked (make that thrilled) the fashion world when he announced he would become a fixture at the company, overseeing a new higher-end Theyskens' Theory collection as well as the label's more accessible main line. The new clothes, worn here by Hanneli Mustaparta, a fashion blogger, ''are what I would wear if I were a girl,'' Mr. Theyskens said. Look forward to wardrobe staples like a sharp, fitted wool blazer and a variety of knits and printed silk dresses, along with more of-the-season pieces like silk palazzo pants, cropped blouses and sexy bodices. The line, priced from $90 to $1,150, is available at theory.com and at the Theory flagship, 40 Gansevoort Street (near Greenwich Street); (212) 524-6790. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

ROSENTHAL--Dr. Leslie. Dr. Leslie Rosenthal, 89, eminent psychoanalyst, died of heart failure on November 22, 2010. Author of over 50 innovative articles and the seminal book, Resolving Resistances in Group Therapy, he was awarded two Gradiva Awards from the National Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis. He dedicated his life to healing patients and training psychoanalysts, and maintained a full-time practice in New York City until the age of 88. Known for his repertoire of humorous stories illuminating the human condition, he used them to help patients and supervisees better understand their emotions. He was a co-founder of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies where he was Dean of Group Studies and specialized in an experiential teaching approach. He maintained 30 year associations with the Jewish Board of Guardians and Montefiore Hospital and was a consultant to countless mental healthprograms. He married his high school sweetheart, Renee Reiff. They were life long residents of the Amalgamated Houses in the Bronx and Three Arrows Cooperative in Putnam Valley, and remained actively devoted to the values of those cooperative communities. Dr. Rosenthal is survived by his children, Regina, David, and Alice, and his grandchildren, Jesse, Alex and Joy. A memorial service is planned for February 26 at CMPS.

MARTUSCELLO--Joseph M.,a former NY State Assemblyman and business executive, died on January 28, 2011. He was 72. Son of the late Supreme Court Justice, Appellate Division, Second Department, Hon. M. Henry Martuscello and the late Kathryn (nee Sessa). He is survived by his wife, Caroline G. Martuscello, son Henry K. Martuscello, daughter Kathryn-Mary Martuscello-Hoff, daughter-in-law Ariana L. Martuscello, son-in-law Edward F. Hoff Jr., granddaughters Caroline E. Hoff, Isabella M. Hoff, and Veronica G. Martuscello, grandson Edward F. Hoff III, his sister Michele M. Hug, brother Henry A. Martuscello, Esq., sister-in-law Mary Mihalakos Martuscello, Esq. and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Martuscello graduated from Brooklyn Preparatory School and attended St. Bonaventure University in Olean, NY. He represented the 52nd A.D. in the New York State Assembly (1970-1972). He had many business interests in the insurance, real estate and marine industries. He was president of Serres, Visone & Rice, Inc., American Marine Underwriter, Inc, and Trans-State Brokerage, Inc., insurance firms in New York City and Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Tri-State Dry Dock in Perth Amboy, New Jersey. Mr. Martuscello served in the US Army Reserve attaining the rank of Sergeant and was honorably discharged. He was on the Boards of Trustees of St. Vincent Services, Brooklyn, NY, Xaverian High School, Brooklyn, NY, and Board of Regents of Le Moyne College in Syracuse, NY. He was a founding trustee of the Brooklyn Jesuit Preparatory School, Brooklyn, NY and the Olympian Bank, Brooklyn, NY. He was the owner of Caracello Ristorante in the Financial District. He was a Knight of Malta and a long time member of the New York Athletic Club, North Hills Country Club, Tiro e Segno Rifle Club, Columbus Club and the Fisher Island Club. He had residences in New York City, East Hampton, NY, Palatine Bridge, NY and Fisher Island, FL. A Wake will be held at F.G. Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, New York 11231, Thursday and Friday, February 3rd and 4th, from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 10pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Hearts and St. Stephens Roman Catholic Church, Saturday interment immediately following at Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to St. Anthony's Breadline, 135 W. 31st St., New York, New York 10117-0710.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments in response to Anthony Tommasini's choosing the 10 best classical composers. ''I am a 24-year-old cellist living in New York, playing in a piano trio -- Trio Cleonice -- and traveling around playing concerts. I wanted to write and tell you how much I've enjoyed your articles, videos and blog posts on the Top 10 composers. I love music and spend so much of my time absorbed in it -- rehearsing, teaching, performing -- but I rarely enjoy reading about it. Somehow it seems a little healthier to separate this thing I adore from the other many things I adore (to read Dickens and spend plenty of time cooking, in other words).

An answer in the Q & A column on Jan. 16, about lead-based paint hazards in multiple-unit dwellings in New York City, incompletely described a landlord's obligation under New York City law to address such hazards. Landlords of buildings constructed before 1960, when the city banned the use of lead paint, must abate all such known hazards before the beginning of a new tenancy -- not just in instances where there will be a child under 6 in the residence. Under federal law, all known history about lead hazards must be disclosed to tenants of buildings put up before 1978. A landlord's failure to comply with either law could be grounds for a tenant to break the lease.

A picture caption in some editions on Jan. 16 with an article about troubles at a Harlem school misstated the given name of a former assistant principal. And a correction in this space last Sunday misstated his surname. He is Andrew Stillman, not Andre Sullivan.

HERTZ--Walter, age 78, died January 27. Revered leader of Sealy Mattress Company of New Jersey for 53 years and a former director of Sealy, Inc. Survived by his beloved wife of 51 years Natalie, his cherished children Lisa and Steven Marcus and Sharyl and David Hertz, his adored sister Rose Naiman and his treasured grandchildren Andrew, Allison, Julia, Samuel, Sydney and James. A true gentleman who leaves an unparalleled legacy of kindness, integrity, dignity and strength.
Pop Jon Caramanica
The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Croton Reservoir, which once stood at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street in Manhattan, misstated its capacity. It was 25 million gallons, not 250,000.
'Oh, I can imagine it. We just did it. We still have battle scars.' MIKE D'ANTONI,

Not every player with multiple Super Bowl rings is a superstar like Ben Roethlisberger or Tom Brady. If the Pittsburgh Steelers win Super Bowl XLV, quarterback Charlie Batch will receive his third Super Bowl ring. Batch did his part this season, helping win two games during Roethlisberger's suspension, but three Super Bowl rings would be hefty compensation for 184 passes scattered across nine years. Batch is not the first N.F.L. player to receive a lot of hardware for a little bit of work. Here is a far-from-complete list of individuals who earned at least two Super Bowl rings while contributing little to the winning cause. Some were starters, others were hangers-on and a few were good for a few seasons. All shared one great gift: a knack for being in the right place at the right time, and staying there.

SONIN--Robert, age 85, died peacefully on January 26, 2011 after a short illness. He will be sadly missed by his brother Bernard, sister-in-law Pat, niece Amy Robke, her husband Michael, son Benjamin, nephew Andrew Sonin, his wife Karen, children Kaitlyn, Aaron and Evan. A world-renowned expert on Pre-Columbian artifacts, he will be sorely missed by his friends and colleagues. The family suggests donations to the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation. Memorial services will be held at a later date.

An article last Sunday about two ailing men whom a younger relative is trying to care for in their home gave an incorrect affiliation for an organization, supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, that is helping the family. It is the Hospice and Palliative Care program of the Metropolitan Jewish Health System, or MJHS; the organization is not part of the Metropolitan Jewish Hospital.

HYATT--Edna Rice Vogt, the beloved wife of Judson A.V. Hyatt, passed away on January 17, 2011. Edna was born to Carl Vernon Vogt and Edna Smith Vogt on July 10, 1919. The daughter of a prominent lawyer, Edna and her brother Edward LaClerc Vogt were raised in Morristown, New Jersey. Edna graduated Wellesley College in 1940 and married Judson A.V. Hyatt on September 1, 1945. Their marriage lasted until Judson's death on March 29, 1999. Edna raised four boys in Huntington, L.I., where she was a member of the Old First Presbyterian Church choir, Treasurer of Heckscher Museum, volunteer at the local Planned Parenthood chapter, President of Wellesley-on-Long Island, member of the Nathan Hale Garden Club, an avid boater, and enjoyed needle pointing. Edna and Judson traveled extensively throughout the world. Edna's favorite color was lavender and she was often heard to say, "Is there a better color for a dress, shoes or a pocketbook?" Edna is survived by her four sons, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Hyatt of Austin, Texas, Mr. Carl A. Hyatt of Portsmouth, New Hampshire, Mr. James V. Hyatt of Longmont, Colorado and Mr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Hyatt of Avon, Connecticut. Additionally, Edna is survived by six grandchildren, four greatgrandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. A Graveside service will be held on Saturday, February 12, 2011 at 2pm at the Huntington Rural Cemetery in Huntington, L.I.

OPENING tomorrow at the Design Museum Holon, in Holon, Israel, is the provocatively titled ''Post Fossil: Excavating 21st Century Creation.'' Organized by Lidewij Edelkoort, a trend forecaster and design guru, the exhibition -- an expanded version of one that she curated for the 21--21 Design Sight museum in Tokyo last year -- includes the work of more than 60 established and up-and-coming contemporary designers from around the world, including Pieke Bergmans, Nacho Carbonell and Atelier van Lieshout (whose Family Lamp is shown here). Ms. Edelkoort's concept for the exhibition, which sounds a lot like her trend forecasts, foresees ''a break with a materialistic mentality'' and a return to ''modest earthbound and recomposed matter,'' envisioning ''a Fred Flintstone of tomorrow.'' PILAR VILADAS

For decades Logan Square, on the northwest side of Chicago, has been on the brink of gentrification by urbanites drawn to its broad boulevards lined with grand, turn-of-the-20th-century mansions and two-flats built by well-to-do immigrants. By midcentury, the neighborhood had declined owing to suburban flight, and many houses were chopped up into apartments. But the neighborhood has been revived in recent years as restaurants, coffee shops and bars have opened, encouraged by city loans and grants for small-business development. An affordable alternative to the neighboring and now pricey districts of Bucktown and Wicker Park, Logan Square is a magnet for creative types running everything from hip hair salons (Wilco's Jeff Tweedy gets his locks trimmed at Sparrow salon) to an international film series. ELAINE GLUSAC
