To the Sports Editor: Re ''Pitcher Spurns $12 Million, to Keep Self-Respect,'' Jan. 27: In the baseball world where players ask for and get exorbitant salaries, it was refreshing to read that Gil Meche retired rather than stay on with the Kansas City Royals in a lesser capacity and collect $12 million.

BARZELAY--Muriel E.,died at home in Southampton, New York on January 26 at the age of 91, having chosen not to be treated for an advanced cancer that was diagnosed in November. She is survived by her son Douglas, of New York, and by her sister Elenore Freedman of Manchester, NH and her brother Dr. Robert Stein of Atlanta. A graduate of Radcliffe College, she was active in the reform political movement in Syracuse beginning in the 1950s and during the 1960s served as a Vice Chair of the New York State Democratic Party. While she maintained her interest in politics throughout her life, spent many happy hours tending her garden and also pursued a wide range of intellectual and artistic interests, family was the true center of her life. For 67 years she shared a devoted and loving partnership with her husband, Professor Martin E. Barzelay, until his death in 2009. She will be remembered not only for her strength of character and uncompromising intellect, but for also for her unceasing kindness and thoughtfulness. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY. A commemoration of her life will be held on Saturday, February 5 at 3pm at Parrish Memorial Hall, Southampton.

A CAMEO appearance on ''Gossip Girl,'' which featured one of his paintings as part of the décor, led the artist Richard Phillips to the subject of his latest solo show. ''Most Wanted,'' at White Cube in London, features 10 larger-than-life oil paintings of celebrities against luxury label backdrops. ''I was hanging out on set, and it was incredible how these young actors were shaping news,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''They would take something from Page Six that was written about the show and then read it into the script. It was what the new shape of Pop Art can be: this reflexive mirror of culture.'' Mr. Phillips began musing over the idea of capturing that star power on canvas, and the result is a Pop pantheon that includes Chace Crawford and Taylor Momsen (above from left), as well as Dakota Fanning, Justin Timberlake, Kristen Stewart, Miley Cyrus, Robert Pattinson, Taylor Swift, Leonardo DiCaprio and Zac Efron (above right). In a Warholian nod, all the portraits are outlined in ''halos'' inspired by Richard Bernstein's Interview magazine cover art. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

HOENIG--Dr. Theodore "Ted" R. passed away at home in Sarasota, Florida at age 90. Ted enjoyed a full and productive life. He attended Cornell University and NYU College of Dentistry before serving in World War II as a Captain and dentist in the Army. Practicing dentistry in Harrison, NY, Ted was active in public service and elected President of the Harrison Board of Education. Ted loved travel, skiing, tennis, bridge, and the New York Giants! He was also an avid reader with a great sense of humor. Ted was happily married to "the love of his life," Lola Hoenig, for 67 years. He is survived by his three children, Bruce Hoenig, Karen Hoenig Rigamonti and Ellen Hoenig Carlson, two sons in laws, and seven grandchildren. Contributions can be made to "The Edward Hoenig Scholarship" at the Weill Cornell Medical College (www.weill.cornell.edu/ways-to-give or 1300 York Ave-Box 123, New York, NY 10065).

It has been a complicated career for Jason Williams, the point guard known to some as ''White Chocolate,'' who has morphed from troubled youngster in Sacramento, to reborn star in Memphis, to key championship cog in Miami to struggling veteran in Orlando. Williams has been a lightning rod for controversy since before he entered the N.B.A., having been thrown off the University of Florida basketball team following repeated suspensions.

As a student and a teacher of language, I appreciate curses and other vulgarities: they can add color and emphasis to our vernacular. But like all stylistic flourishes, the audience has to be taken into consideration. So here's the current quandary. The distinction between where it is and is not appropriate to curse - and I am not just talking about calling upon the wrath of God here, but of the full canon of vulgarities and obscenities - has nearly vanished. There are apparently no rules. No curse-free zones (except maybe church, and one can only hope that is the case). People curse without consideration.
International AFGHANS TO STOP RECRUITING

DICKINSON--Eleanor H.,died Saturday, January 8, 2011 at the Grand Islander Nursing Center in Middletown, RI where she had lived for two years. She was 91 years old. She was born in Philadelphia, on March 12, 1919, the daughter of Philip B. Hoge and Dorothy Anderson Hoge. She was pre-deceased by her sister, Langley H. Kenzie, and by her husband, Dwight Dickinson. She is survived by her sister, Phyllis Hoge of Albuquerque, New Mexico, and by her two sons, Spencer Dickinson and his wife Avery of Wakefield, RI and Philip Dickinson of Middletown, RI and by many nieces, nephews, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. She grew up in Elizabeth, New Jersey, where she graduated from the Vail Deane School and attended Centenary Junior College and the Newark School of Fine and Industrial Arts. Her husband, Ambassador Dwight Dickinson, served in the Navy during World War II and went on to a career with the State Department. Together they travelled widely and lived in many parts of the world, retiring to Jamestown, RI in 1974. She was a lover of art and an accomplished artist, developing new media and styles, inspired by the places she visited. She lived a long and remarkable life, was much loved, and will be sadly missed. An interment and memorial service will be held at Arlington in the spring.
LERNER--Holly, passed away peacefully on January 27. Beloved wife of Alan for 38 years. Cherished mother of Melanie and Carrie. Loved by many friends and family. She will be greatly missed.

NOTO--Robert M.,92, on January 11. Beloved Uncle. Caring friend to many. Loving surrogate father and grandfather. Proud WWII veteran. Quintessential New Yorker - The Times, W. 69th, Hells Kitchen. Owned "Noto" first on W. 43rd, then on W. 72nd and after many years opened the company, "Gargoyles." Terrific storyteller, always ending with a laugh. Loved the arts, from sculpture to ballet. A sweet, charming man with a generous spirit. Last of the Noto boys. Donations can be made to the VNS-NY Hospice Care. A celebration of his life will take place Spring 2011.

KRASNER--Peggie (Guzman) Resident of New York, NY, Fisher Island FL, and Los Angeles, CA, 79, died January 27, 2011 in Burbank, CA. Mrs. Krasner was born January 19, 1932 to Ethelyn and Mike Householter in Madison, Kansas. Peggie lived in New York City and was the proprietor of Rubicon Boutique on Madison Ave. for two decades. Peggie's love of design and natural sense of relaxed elegance garnered her much acclaim amongst the fashion community, but most importantly to her, the love and patronage of her large and devoted clientele. In her later years, Peggie worked with charities including amFAR & HRC and loved to travel, garden, and spend time with her devoted companion, Diego; a long-haired Chihuahua. Peggie is survived by her two sons, Cortes K. Alexander of Los Angeles, CA and Michael Loya of East Hampton, NY, as well as her loving sister, Joyce Starkey and her niece, Robin Starkey-McAlister. Additionally, Peggie is survived by her devoted ex-husband, Donald Krasner, of Fisher Island, FL. A private memorial will be held. Forest Lawn MemorialParks & Mortuaries.

An article on Jan. 16 about Belgian breweries and beer bars misspelled the surname of a founder of the De La Senne brewery in Brussels. He is Yvan De Baets, not De Bates. The article also misstated the time the train takes between Brussels and Bruges; it is generally one hour, not two.

FREEDMAN--Edy. Our deepest condolences to our dear colleague, mentor and friend Sol Freedman and his family on the loss of his wife and partner. Agins, Siegel, Reiner & Bouklas, LLP

The New York region's two largest airports, already choked with crowds and delays, may need to be radically reconfigured so they can make way for vitally needed additional runways that would help accommodate a projected increase of almost 50 million air travelers per year within two or three decades, according to a new study. The study, from the Regional Plan Association, calls for as much as $15 billion to be spent at Kennedy and Newark Liberty International Airports. At Newark, all three terminals would have to be at least partially razed, then rebuilt; at Kennedy, part of Jamaica Bay might have to be filled to create space for one or more new runways.

DRESSNER--Karen. On behalf of the students, parents, alumnae, faculty, and staff of the Nightingale-Bamford School, we mourn the death of one of our most talented and inspiring faculty members, Karen Dressner. A Lower School science teacher at Nightingale since 1988, she was a source of humor, wisdom, and, above all, vitality. With an ever-present smile, Ms. Dressner connected with everyone in the schoolhouse. She will remain in our hearts and memories always, and her legacy can be seen in the hundreds of Nightingale girls and women who share her passion for science and the natural world. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Sunday, January 30, at Nightingale, 20 East 92nd Street. Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School Nina Joukowsky Koprulu, President, Board of Trustees

PEEK--Mottell Davis, age 82, died on January 27th. He resided in Somers, New York. He worked in the financial services industry for over 50 years and was an investment advisor for Wells Fargo Advisors until the time of his death. He was born in Long Beach, California, and graduated from the University of Southern California in 1951. Mott is survived by his wife, Dr. Georgia Hooper-Peek, his daughters Dr. Amanda Wellford (Hal) and Abigail Waddell (Bill) his son Cameron Peek and five grandchildren. He was a volunteer throughout his life, having served causes including wildlife conservation, service organizations and the Presbyterian Church. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 5th at 11am at the First Presbyterian Church, 31 Bedford Road #
Film Stephen Holden

GARNER--Jay. Broadway veteran, Jay Garner, died on January 21, 2011 in New York City. Cause of death was respiratory failure due to pneumonia. He was 82. Born James H. Garner, Jr. in Sewanee, TN and a graduate of the Univ. of Tennessee, he made his Broadway debut in 1969 (as Jay Garner) in "Red, White and Maddox". Other Broadway roles include Ben Franklin in "1776," the Governor in "Best Little Whorehouse in Texas," Dindon in "La Cage aux Folles," Sir John in "Me and My Girl," and Horace Vandergelder in "Hello, Dolly!" with Carol Channing in 1995. Notable TV and film roles include Admiral Asimov in "Buck Rogers in the 25th Century," Jason Defarge, the drunk food critic in "Three's Company," and the tap-dancing banker in "Pennies from Heaven" with Steve Martin. Garner, an only child, left no survivors. Donations in his name can be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. No funeral service is planned.

GANTZ--Emanuel. Beloved husband of Pat for 62 years. Devoted father to Karen (Eric), Kim (Sanford), Kathy (Lary) and JoAnn (Bobby). Adoring grandfather to Rebecca, Benjamin, Ross, Austin, and Ariel. Mr. Gantz, known as Manny, was born on September 3, 1917 on the Lower East Side of New York City. The family moved to Port Chester where Manny's father, Joseph Gantz, started Empire Brushes. Manny was responsible for the first battery powered toothbrushes, hair brushes, and hand-vacs. He was President of Gant Brushes until he retired at 90 years old. Manny graduated from Port Chester High School, the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School, class of 1941. He proudly served as an officer in the US Army during World War II and was stationed in Eritrea with the Signal Corps. He was the only member of Old Oaks Country Club to start as a caddy and later become a member. Manny served as president of the American-Israel Chamber of Commerce, sponsored scholarships for Ethiopian Jews at the University of Samaria in Ariel, Israel, established the Philip and Emanuel Gantz Kindergarten in Jerusalem. His lifetime commitment to Israel was exemplified by his passionate involvement in helping to create the Israel Air Force Center in Herzilya, Israel. Donations may be made to Israel Air Force Center, Herzilya, Israel; Scholarship Fund for Ethiopian students at the University of Samaria, Ariel, Israel; and the Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

''I was making a crazy amount of money for not even pitching. Honestly, I didn't feel like I deserved it.'' Gil Meche, an injured pitcher for the Kansas City Royals who gave up his $12 million guaranteed contract for 2011 and retired -- a very rare move. ''The greatest tragedy would be to accept the refrain that no one could have seen this coming and thus nothing could have been done.''

CHESS--Muriel R.,died peacefully on January 11, 2011. A doyenne of the interior design community, she was the editor-in-chief of Professional Office Design and The Designer Magazine, winning an award for editorial excellence from the American Society of Interior Designers. She was Director of Corporate Communications for Swanke Hayden Connell Architects, on the board of directors of the International Facility Management Association, and a force in both the New York Metro Chapter of the American Society of Interior Designers and The Decorators Club. She was instrumental in founding Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS (DIFFA) and served on its first board of directors. For more than thirty years, she was a professional interior designer, serving residential and professional clients. She is survived by her children Caron, Daniel, and Nathan. For details about the celebration of Muriel's life, please contact her children at murielchess@gmail.com. Donations in her memory may be made to the doctors and staff who gave our mother tremendous joy by saving Daniel's life: Columbia University - Liver Transplant Unit, c/o CUMC Development Office, 630 W. 168th St, Box 48, New York, NY 10032.

STESSIN--Herbert. 88, of New York, died January 22, 2011, beloved brother of Belle Hammerschlag Trattler, husband of the late Nancy Stessin, stepfather of David Dundee and his wife Betty, cherished uncle of Stephanie Bernheim and Paul Hammerschlag, MD, great uncle of Erica Bernheim, Claudia Bernheim, Zoe Hammerschlag, Grey and Linus Raphaely, stepgrandfather of Owen and Sara Dundee. As an esteemed member of the New York musical community, he was an adored and respected teacher of generations of piano students, many of whom are celebrated artists and teachers. He studied piano with Clarence Adler, Jose Iturbi, and Sascha Gorodnitzki. After graduating from CCNY, he served in WWII, concertizing for the American troops and then working for Intelligence, interrogating war prisoners. He made his Carnegie Hall debut in 1950, and performed nationwide with James De La Fuente under Columbia Artist Management. His illustrious long-term teaching career at the Julliard School of Music included chairmanship of the Piano Department. He was a faculty member at the Aspen Music Festival (1983-2007) and at the Nagano Festival. He led master classes at Harvard, in Japan, Jerusalem, and was named Distinguished Teacher by a White House Commission of Presidential Scholars in 1995. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Herbert Stessin, to The Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023 or The Aspen Music Festival and School. His sparkling wit and generous spirit will be missed. A memorial is being planned.
In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began. The ''time on the market'' is from the most recent listing to the sales agreement. MANHATTAN
The Mortgages column on Jan. 9, about borrowers' extending rate lock-in agreements, misidentified the party who can impose extension fees. It is the lender, not the broker.

An article last Sunday about a scandal involving Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy gave an outdated name for the Italian justice agency. Since 1999, it has been the Ministry of Justice -- not the Ministry of Grace and Justice, its former name, which remains inscribed on the facade of its headquarters in Rome.

O.K., I'm a little slow; I admit I didn't grasp the point of all the drum-beating this week in Women's Wear Daily. I've been in Paris covering shows. But this morning all was illuminated when I went to wwd.com and saw the headline ''Michelle Obama Puts Kara Ross on World Stage.'' The article stated that Ms. Ross, a jewelry designer, had been ''called up to the major leagues'' by the ''prime placement'' of earrings on Mrs. Obama, most recently at the State of the Union speech. I can assure you that Ms. Ross and Rachel Roy, the designer of Mrs. Obama's white dress for the speech, would not have received so much attention before Women's Wear decided to conduct the equivalent of a witch hunt. The paper, with help from Oscar de la Renta and the Council of Fashion Designers of America, is trying to shame Mrs. Obama for her sin of wearing fashion by a non-American designer to the state dinner for China on Jan. 19. I mean, of course, the red Alexander McQueen.
BOHAN--Joseph P. Jr.,of Larchmont, NY on January 28. Visitation at Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday 10am at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont.

DRISCOLL--Barrie Keohane. Born, the Bronx, 1935, to Bart and Josephine (nee Keohane) Driscoll. Retired partner of Coopers & Lybrand, graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School(1953), Manhattan College (1957) and Fordham Law School (1962). Survived by his wife of 45 years, Marion (nee Gyves) Driscoll, sister Maureen D. Donovan, and daughters, Christine (Paul) Hogan and Marie (James) Spoto, and seven grandchildren: James Barrie, Charlotte, Bridget, Maeve and Lorelei Hogan, and Barry and James Spoto. He was a good and loving family man, a loyal friend, a sorely disappointed NY Giants fan, and a "Friendly Son of St. Patrick" in the finest sense and tradition of that organization. Funeral on Monday, January 31, at 9:30am from St. Anthony's RC Church, Hawthorne, NJ. Viewing Sunday, January 30th, at Browning, Forshay Funeral Home, Hawthorne, NJ from to 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

David Pearlman, an itinerant philosopher, adventurer and environmentalist widely known as Poppa Neutrino, who founded his own church, crossed the Atlantic on a raft made from scrap and invented a theoretically unstoppable football strategy, died on Sunday in New Orleans. He was 77. He had no fixed abode but had spent the last two years in Burlington, Vt., building and testing a new raft on Lake Champlain that he planned to sail around the globe.
BASS--Rudi, 96, died with his wife and family at his bedside in his home in Manhattan, NY, USA, on January 6, 2011.

SALAZAR--Barbara Hardy, died January 27, 2011 of cerebrovascular disease. Born November 27, 1923 Barbara Stress Hardy, Watertown, NY; later known as Barbara Sloane Hardy. Daughter of Harold Jay Hardy (18881992) and Lydia Stress (18871961). Attended St. Lawrence College; graduated from Wells College magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa 1944. Worked in publishing in New York (Putnam, Fawcett), Evanston, IL (Rand McNally), and Ithaca (Cornell U Press). Married to Oscar Rene Salazar (19231999) from 1955 to 1973. Spent her last five years in Berkeley and Oakland, CA, cared for by her devoted son, Wayne Hardy Salazar, and by his friend and ex-partner, Michael Ehrenzweig. She is survived also by a son, Gary Andrew Salazar of Hamilton, OH, and by two grandchildren, Natalie and Nolan Salazar. Barbara's remains are to be cremated and scattered at sea.

An article on Jan. 16 about eight particularly distinctive hotels around the world opening this year misspelled the surname of the French designer who was responsible for the interiors of the Hôtel Americano in Chelsea. He is Arnaud Montigny, not Martigny.

CURLEY--Dorothy Ann (nee Galvin), died January 26. "Dotsy" grew up in Forest Hills and Point Lookout, NY. She graduated from Mary Louis Academy and received nursing training at St. Vincent's. Dotsy had a knack for gardening, was known for her funny stories, and had the determined spirit of a true New Yorker. She especially loved sitting on the beach with family and friends. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband, Peter J. Curley, sister, Ginger, and parents. Survivors include brothers, Gerald (Pat), Brian (Kay), John (Jane); children, Eileen (Brad), Peter (Lisa), Anne (Steve), Claire (Mason); and six grandchildren. Wake at Murphy Funeral Home, 1102 W. Broad St., Falls Church, VA, February 1 from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral Mass, February 2, 10am, St. James Catholic Church, 905 Park Ave., Falls Church, VA. Interment private.
McKINLEY--Selma Anderson. Dearest Momma, you live in my heart - always remembered, always beloved.

An article last Sunday about efforts by CMT to bring situation comedies to its prime-time schedule misspelled the surname of the country singer who starred in the TV show ''Reba.'' She is Reba McEntire, not McIntyre. The article also included outdated information for the network's premiere of Pauly Shore's comedy-reality show, ''Meet the In-Laws.'' After the section had gone to press, CMT announced that it would not start on Jan. 28, as planned. The network did not give a new date.

KATES--Mary Maier, died at the age of 97 on January 22, 2011 in Sharon, CT in the company of her daughter Elizabeth Kates Burns of Marfa, TX. Mary Maier known as "Molly" to her family and friends was born on July 2, 1913 in Seneca Falls, NY. Her parents were the Honorable William J. Maier who was Comptroller of the State of New York and Grace Yawger Maier. She graduated from Wellesley College in 1934 where she established her lifelong interests in golf, tennis, art and French language and literature. In 1941 she married Rev. Frederick Ward Kates and strongly supported him in his national ministry throughout their marriage. She lived for over twenty years in Millbrook, NY where she was a member of Grace Episcopal Church. She lived a long full life. She is also survived by daughters-in-law Margaret H. Kates and Jane D. Kates and son-in-law Joshua A. Burns; grandchildren Dr. Laura W. Kates, Thomas W. Kates, Jr., Anne K. Field, William D. Kates and Caitlin Y. Burns; and three great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her husband and sister Grace Yawger Maier II and sons William W. Kates and Thomas W. Kates. Funeral services were held on January 27, 2011 at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kent, CT followed by burial in Silver Creek, NY. Services by Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

A review on Dec. 26 about ''Poser: My Life in Twenty-Three Yoga Poses,'' a memoir by Claire Dederer, included a misattributed quotation. While Nietzsche was not one to shy away from home decorating tropes (''I cannot stand this motley wallpaper style,'' he wrote of George Sand in ''Twilight of the Idols''), he is not the author of the aphorism ''Family love is messy, clinging, and of an annoying and repetitive pattern, like bad wallpaper'' -- that was another great philosopher, P. J. O'Rourke.
APPLEBAUM--Stanley, 86, died January 27, 2011. Beloved husband of Elaine; loving father of Laurie, Bruce and Brett and grandfather of eleven. Funeral: January 30, 11:30am, Sinai Chapel, Queens.

The Corner Office interview last Sunday featured Jeremy Allaire, chairman and chief executive of Brightcove, an online video platform for Web sites. After the column was published, editors learned that The New York Times Company owns a stake of less than 5 percent in Brightcove. Though the existence of the investment would not have affected the decision to publish the interview, it is the policy of The Times to include such information.

The Sports of The Times column on Dec. 12, about Mo Cassara, Hofstra's first-year men's basketball coach, misidentified the first captain of the team coached by Cassara's father at St. Lawrence University. The captain was Gary Reynolds -- not Wayne Morgan, a later captain who is now on Cassara's coaching staff at Hofstra. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail on Dec. 13; this correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow up on the complaint.

The five most-viewed stories on nytimes.com/sports for Jan. 22 to 28. 1. ROYALS PITCHER RETIRES, TOSSING AWAY $12 MILLION ''Once I started to realize I wasn't earning my money, I felt bad,'' said Gil Meche, who has an aching right shoulder. (Published Jan. 26)

SANDERS--Audrey (nee Goldston), at home on January 22, 2011. Born November 25, 1929. Loving daughter of Isaac and Rebecca (nee Freedman) Goldston, devoted sister of the late Howard Lee Goldston, beloved wife of the late Milton L. Sanders, adoring mother of Judith EllenSanders, Jane Sanders Markson, and Grace (nee Betty-Ann) Sanders, loving mother-in-law of Michael Rudenko, William Markson, and TrishBoyles, and dear Nana of Jonathan, Rebecca, Elizabeth, and Ezra. Audrey earned her Ph.D. in Psychology at 57 inspiring all with her gentleness and insights. A talented pianist with a flair for cooking, she remembered every detail of her life and every joke she ever heard delighting us for hours in the retelling. Audrey could fix anything, be it bicycles or broken hearts, and taught everyone she knew to live, love, and laugh heartily. She will be so greatly missed.

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. January 30, 2009. Two years. An extraordinary mother, wife, sister and daughter. Sorely missed, needed and adored by Zachary (3), Aleksander (5) and Diana (7), John, Shauna and Barbara. She is our song.

SCHWARTZ--Marvin D. Survived by his wife Betty, his four children Steven, Ellen, Phillip and Nancy, their spouses and five grandchildren. He originated the weekly "Antiques" column at The New York Times and authored The New York Times Book of Antiques as well as many other books on decorative arts. He was Curator of Decorative Arts at the Brooklyn Museum and later worked as a consultant and lecturer for the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

KERN--Beatrice Rubenfeld Died peacefully at the age of 91 in San Francisco on January 19th. The daughter of A.H. "Harry" Rubenfeld, and Victoria Charter Rubenfeld, she grew up in Mount Vernon, NY, and was graduated from the Calhoun School and Marjorie Webster Junior College. In 1941, she married Irving Kern, and until his death on January 7, their life-long romance and marriage lasted nearly 70 years. Mr. Kern was the former president and CEO of Dellwood Foods in Yonkers, NY, known for its premium milk and dairy products in the New York area under the slogan, "From Dellwood With Love." Bea Kern loved tennis, the arts, golf, sailing, and world travel. She was also an accomplished bridge player. She was a passionate volunteer with Planned Parenthood in San Diego, where she and her husband lived for 17 years. They moved to San Francisco in 2006. She is survived by three sons - John, Arthur, and Robert - her granddaughter, Erin Kern, her niece Judy Kleinberger and an extended family, who will greatly miss her adventurous spirit and love of life. Donations can be made to University of California at San Francisco Home Health Care, c the UCSF Foundation, Box 0248, San Francisco, CA 94143-0248. There will be a private Memorial Service in the New York area for the family this spring.

THE snow blanketing the Parade Grounds at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx lends the landscape a tone of pastoral tranquillity, even if generations of high school runners know better. To them, the scene is more like a battlefield temporarily stilled by nature. The park's cross-country course is legendary -- a grueling stretch of wide flats and twisting trails that has tested up-and-coming high school and college runners for nearly a century.

The knuckleballer R.A. Dickey was the best thing that happened to the Mets in 2011, emerging from a career on the fringe to go 11-9 with a 2.84 earned run average. He hustled in the field and on the bases, hit a robust .255 and impressed just about everyone around the team with his curiosity (a locker full of books), vocabulary and simple willingness to answer any and all questions.

If you asked poverty experts to name the single most significant new concept in the field in the last few decades, chances are they would say microcredit.  Microcredit is the lending of very small amounts of money to very poor people to help them invest in things that have the potential to bring income later on - a loan of $50 to buy a sewing machine to make clothes, for instance, or piglets to raise and sell.  It reaches nearly 100 million clients in more than 100 countries.

Mark Blumenthal of the Huffington Post links toward a different survey of Egyptian public opinion, this one by the pew Global Attitudes Project, which tells a completely different story. In contrast to the BBC study that we linked to this morning, which found relatively favorable attitudes toward the United States, the Pew poll finds that just 17 percent of Egyptians have a favorable view of the U.S. against 82 percent unfavorable. It also shows, again in contrast to the BBC study, that views of the United States declined somewhat between 2009 and 2010.

LOS ANGELES- The reputation of the Screen Actors Guild parties is that they're loose and uninhibited affairs, actors having been known to enjoy a celebration or several hundred after the SAG Awards. The traditional first stop is the People magazine afterparty, held in a tent adjacent to the Shrine Auditorium, where the award ceremony takes place. With the mix of TV and movie stars, it had the feel of a high-gloss reunion, with both a band and a D.J., and buffets for starving performers, who mostly went around congratulating each other and admitting their fandom. (It is the season of back-patting, after all.)

I didn't realize how lucky I was, more than a year ago, when I simply trotted over to my family doctor's office and got vaccinated against shingles. Having seen too many friends, younger and older, suffering with this painful disease, I considered immunization one of the benefits of turning 60, the age at which the vaccine is recommended. Happily, I didn't have to wait: My doctor had a supply on hand, and my insurance paid for the shot.

Back when I first tried to explain the logic of focusing on core inflation rather than headline inflation, I emphasized the distinction between goods whose prices fluctuate all the time and those whose prices are revised only occasionally; it's the latter category that is subject to inflation inertia, and therefore where you have to worry that inflation or deflation can get baked into the economy, and become hard to undo.
Cranberry juice is a popular home remedy for treating and preventing bladder infections. But exactly how and why it seems to help remains a scientific mystery, explains Dr. Abigail Zuger.

Our knowledge of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes troupe -- not the versions after his death in 1929 -- comes from texts, sketches, photographs and of course dances handed down over the years. But no film of a performance by the original company was thought to exist. Now a curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, where an exhibition on the company closed this month, has announced the discovery of less than a minute of performance footage on the Web site of the production house British Pathé.

FORWARD OPERATING BASE ANDAR, Afghanistan - This month Tyler Hicks and I have been working alongside the soldiers of Task Force Iron, an infantry battalion from the 101st Airborne Division that soon will complete a one-year tour in Afghanistan. We're busy editing photographs and wrapping up reporting on some of the operations we observed alongside American soldiers and Afghan police and intelligence officers, and will have at least two stories for the newspaper soon. As we work, we want to pause to share a fresh look at some of the Taliban's weapons, based on the battalion's recent captures from slain Taliban fighters or caches, as a means to understanding more fully how the Taliban fights.

LOS ANGELES- The Bagger spent the weekend at various award shows, convening with celebrities and other beautiful people, commiserating about having to be at awards shows. Tough gig, we know. But before we get to the scene on the dance floor with Justin Timberlake and Amanda Seyfried at a Dewar's-fueled Screen Actors Guild after-party, let us catch you up on the nontelevised happenings at the Directors Guild awards. The group allows all its best feature film nominees to give a speech before the winner is revealed, which is part of why the event -- dinner and the ceremony -- was nearly six hours long. (See, it is worth commiserating.) But there were moments of mirth, like Colin Firth and Helena Bonham Carter's introduction of Tom Hooper, the director of "The King's Speech" (and the evening's ultimate winner). Mr. Firth talked about being nervous performing in front of Mr. Hooper, who kept looking down at his shoes; when he finally looked up, Mr. Firth said he knew he'd nailed the part. Ms. Bonham Carter was even more honest.

DRISCOLL--Barrie Keohane. Born, the Bronx, 1935, to Bart and Josephine (nee Keohane) Driscoll. Retired partner of Coopers & Lybrand, graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School(1953), Manhattan College (1957) and Fordham Law School (1962). Survived by his wife of 45 years, Marion (nee Gyves) Driscoll, sister Maureen D. Donovan, and daughters, Christine (Paul) Hogan and Marie (James) Spoto, and seven grandchildren: James Barrie, Charlotte, Bridget, Maeve and Lorelei Hogan, and Barry and James Spoto. He was a good and loving family man, a loyal friend, a sorely disappointed NY Giants fan, and a "Friendly Son of St. Patrick" in the finest sense and tradition of that organization. Funeral on Monday, January 31, at 9:30am from St. Anthony's RC Church, Hawthorne, NJ. Viewing Sunday, January 30th, at Browning, Forshay Funeral Home, Hawthorne, NJ from to 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

LOS ANGELES -- ''The King's Speech'' collected an impressive 12 Oscar nominations last week. It might have stopped short of a dozen without help from a British entrepreneur who has planted his business at the tricky intersection of film and music. In an unconventional deal that may promise a revival in film music, the Cutting Edge Group, based in London, and its chief executive, Philip Moross, effectively bought the musical portion of ''The King's Speech'' months ago.

Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court visited the Capitol last week to lecture representatives about the Constitution, at the invitation of Representative Michele Bachmann, the Minnesota Republican and Tea Party leader. Some people may be interested in seeing what the founders themselves had to say, and thanks to digital technology, an increasing number of original documents can be found online. The University of Virginia Press, financed by the National Historical Publications and Records Commission is in the process of putting the published papers of Washington, Jefferson, John Adams, James Madison, Alexander Hamilton and Benjamin Franklin on a free Web site that is scheduled to be ready in June 2012. It will include private letters, military strategies, meeting notes, journals and other documents.

''The State of the Union surprised me,'' Representative Paul Ryan says. Instead of urgency, the Wisconsin Republican explained in an interview, President Obama offered boilerplate on deficit reduction. Mr. Ryan's response to Mr. Obama's annual address was plenty urgent, warning that a Greece-style fiscal calamity was ''around the corner.'' Yet the earnest new chairman of the House Budget Committee did not lay out any clearer path to solvency than the president did.

In the mythology of comic books, Superman is the survivor of a dying alien planet who is sent to earth to become its protector. For his new Superman movie, the director Zack Snyder did not have to search quite as far to cast his title character, but in the tradition of previous installments of the franchise, he has settled on a relative unknown to take up the mantle of the Man of Steel. Henry Cavill, a British actor whose credits include the Showtime series ''The Tudors,'' the 2007 fantasy film ''Stardust'' and the coming adventure ''Immortals,'' will play Superman and his secret identity, Clark Kent, in a film that Mr. Snyder is directing for Warner Brothers, the studio said on Sunday. In a statement, Mr. Snyder, whose previous films include the comic-book adaptations ''300'' and ''Watchmen,'' said, ''In the pantheon of superheroes, Superman is the most recognized and revered character of all time, and I am honored to be a part of his return to the big screen.'' He added that Mr. Cavill was ''the perfect choice to don the cape and S shield.''

The cellphone is beginning to have the kind of impact on industry that has been seen with only a few products, like the car or big kitchen appliances. The ripple effect showed up this week in a number of corporate earnings reports. Corning said on Tuesday that its quarterly profit surged 41 percent, in part because of rising sales of its unusually strong Gorilla Glass, which is used in smartphone displays. Gorilla Glass, which is used in roughly 200 million mobile devices, produced about $250 million in revenue for Corning in 2010. James B. Flaws, the company's chief financial officer, told analysts that Gorilla Glass could generate $1 billion in revenue this year.
VILAKAZI--Derick Malinga July 18, 1947 - January 31, 2010 Always in our thoughts and prayers. We love you and miss you beyond measure. Your children, family, and friends.

An art review on Thursday about Master Drawings New York 2011, and a picture caption with it, misspelled the given name of a 16th-century artist who drew a picture that was on display at the Alexander Gallery on Madison Avenue. He was Anthoni Bays, not Anthony. The picture caption also referred incorrectly to the drawing. The art dealer Monroe Warshaw found it in Paris, not in a museum in the Czech Republic. (It is a study for a painting in a museum there.) And a photograph of the painting, not of the drawing, was on display at the Alexander Gallery.

FRANKL--Seymour (Sy). Age 97, died peacefully on January 29th, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Frankl. He is survived by his daughters Karen and Dana (Teitler), granddaughters Katie and Beth, and great-granddaughter Sarah. Contributions may be made to Clal-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership or to The American Heart Association.

When the PBS newsmagazine ''Need to Know'' started last May it had big shoes to fill, replacing ''Bill Moyers Journal'' and ''Now on PBS.'' But even as angry e-mails from disappointed viewers have subsided, the producers acknowledge that the show remains a work in progress, and PBS says it has not decided whether to renew it. In a memo in December to public television programmers, Stephen Segaller, vice president for content at WNET.org, which produces the show, and Shelley Lewis, the executive producer, said of the feedback from fellow PBS stations: ''Some of the reaction has been negative, which is never pleasant, but is always useful.''

9 P.M. (Lifetime) TAKEN FROM ME: THE TIFFANY RUBIN STORY (2011) In this adaptation of a true story, Taraji P. Henson, who received an Oscar nomination for her role in ''The Curious Case of Benjamin Button,'' portrays Tiffany Rubin, a mother from Queens who traveled halfway around the world in 2008 to rescue her 7-year-old son, Kobe Lee (Drew Davis, above with Ms. Henson), after he was abducted by his biological father and taken to Seoul, South Korea. Beverly Todd plays Ms. Rubin's mother, who urged her daughter to seek the counsel of Mark Miller (Terry O'Quinn) and the nonprofit American Association for Lost Children. In ''Beyond the Headlines: The Tiffany Rubin Story,'' at 11, Ms. Rubin, her son, Mr. Miller and others recount the details of the mission. 6:30 P.M. (ABC) WORLD NEWS WITH DIANE SAWYER In the weeklong series ''Families on the Brink: What to Do About Mom & Dad?'' Ms. Sawyer explores issues that accompany caring for the aging. Panelists include Martha Stewart, who teamed up with the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan to open the Martha Stewart Center for Living; Dr. Neil Resnick, director of the Institute on Aging at the University of Pittsburgh; Dr. Marie A. Bernard, deputy director of the National Institute on Aging; and Virginia Morris, the author of ''How to Care for Aging Parents.''

FIRESTONE--Mark. With great sadness, I announce the death of my husband, Mark Firestone. He succumbed after a lengthy struggle to cancer. He was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1923 and always cherished his heritage. He attended school in Switzerland, received his baccalaureate at the French Licee and after the war he continued his education at Rutgers University and finally his MBA at NYU. He was a gentleman of the Old School, learned and a linguist of nine languages and a lover of music and art. He experienced the Holocaust first hand as well as the landing at Normendy as a U.S. Soldier. He was a most loving father to his two special children, Rennie and Cathy as well my most devoted husband of 63 years. Family was everything to him. Mark with his father co-founded the Export Firm, The M. Firestone Company in 1946.

Today we are proud of Egyptians. We have restored our rights, restored our freedom, and what we have begun cannot be reversed. MOHAMED ELBARADEI, a Nobel laureate and diplomat, speaking to protesters in Cairo. [A1]

LOS ANGELES- Tom Hooper, the director of ''The King's Speech,'' picked up the top prize at the Directors Guild of America awards on Saturday night, a surprise victory that scrambled the prognostications of the Oscar experts. The win came at the expense of another front-runner, David Fincher, the director of ''The Social Network,'' and followed a similar upset at the Producers Guild of America awards when the British period drama took the top honor. (David O. Russell (''The Fighter''), Darren Aronofsky (''Black Swan'') and Christopher Nolan (''Inception'') were the other nominees last night.) ''Thank you D.G.A., this is really, truly the hugest honor of my life,'' Mr. Hooper said at the Directors Guild ceremony, held in a Hollywood ballroom. Coupled with the Producers Guild honor, the win advances the chances for ''The King's Speech'' to fare well at the Oscars, where it was already heavily favored to win best actor for Colin Firth.

Bernd Eichinger, a German screenwriter and producer who made films in Germany and Hollywood, including the children's fairy tale ''The NeverEnding Story,'' the ''Resident Evil'' series derived from video games, and ''Downfall,'' a movie about the last days of the Third Reich that raised hackles for humanizing Adolf Hitler, died in Los Angeles on Monday. He was 61. The cause was a heart attack, Constantin Film, the Munich company with which he had been affiliated since the late 1970s, said in a statement.

KATZ--Walter. We are saddened to announce the death of Walter Katz, beloved husband of the late Gilda Katz (nee Ingram); father of Joe Katz and Dorrie Berkowitz and their spouses Jody Katz and Hal Berkowitz; grandfather of Taylor Berkowitz and Danny Katz; adored brother-in-law and uncle; true friend. Wally was a WWII Navy vet, DJ (known as Dave Walters), Emmy-award-winning film editor, educator at NYU and the New School, and a dedicated and tireless volunteer. He loved jazz, sports, and laughter. "Songs and snappy patter for every occasion!" Donations may be made to: travelersaid.org or nomrf.org (New Orleans Musicians Relief Fund).

LEVINE--Lawrence F. Larry has been a major part of the life of the Lorber family for more than 35 years. His visits with us to Fisher Island, during the winter months and Southampton in the summer will be forever missed. Breakfast without him will never be the same. We will always remember him. He was a man never to be forgotten. The Lorber Family

CNBC may not have known it, but last week, the financial news network ran one of the greatest Phish shows in recent memory. The band itself was nowhere to be seen. But Dan Greenhaus, chief economic strategist at Miller Tabak & Company and an occasional commentator on CNBC, gave fans of the jam band Phish a thrill when he appeared on ''The Kudlow Report'' on Jan. 24 to discuss the effect that global inflation might have on the American economy.

LEVINE--Lawrence F.,65, on January 29th, after a long battle with leukemia. He is survived by his former wife Marlene and sons; Geoffrey and Andrew. Larry was a man of great strength and passion which helped him live his life up to the last moment, with his family and friends by his side. Services will be held at 10am Monday, January 31st, at The Star of David Memorial Chapel 1236 Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY.

GARFINKEL--Rubin, on January 30, 2011. A remarkable and beloved humanitarian. She leaves behind her loving and devoted husband Milic Stojkovic, her children Leslie and Robert Cory, and her brother Norman Blumen. She was a dancer, she loved the dance, she performed and she taught others. A memorial will be planned at a later date. For condolences and information please contact: 914 636-7767.

Steven Romalewski stood at the intersection of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and West 181st Street in the Bronx the other day and peered at an old church across the street. In the cold, his right thumb slid across the screen of his black Palm Pre phone. ''I want to see if that church is landmarked,'' he said, humming as the device generated a list of landmarks nearby.

An article on Thursday about a book by the author Barnaby Conrad, ''The Second Life of John Wilkes Booth,'' based on the conceit that Booth escaped capture after assassinating Abraham Lincoln and embarked on a secret life on the American frontier, misstated the given name of Lincoln's secretary of war, who Mr. Conrad believes was behind the assassination. He was Edwin M. Stanton, not Edward.

More people are spending more time on Twitter.com every month. According to Experian, the average visitor to Twitter spent 1 hour, 51 minutes on the site in November 2009, a figure which rose 40 percent to 2 hours, 12 minutes in November 2010. Even though people spend more time on Twitter, their sessions are getting shorter: the average time for a single session fell from 15.1 to 13.1 minutes on a typical November day. The shorter visits may reflect Twitter fatigue for some users: even though usage is up for visitors ages 18 to 24, it has dropped for those 35 to 54.

DRANOVE--Joel K.,on January 29, 2011, age 62. Survived by his wife Carol, sons Alex and Zachary, daughter Zoe, and brothers Paul and David. A long-time resident of South Orange, Mr. Dranove was a noted criminal defense attorney with offices in New York City. Among his successes was his multi-year effort on behalf of Robert Calvin Boyette, who was freed after being wrongfully convicted of a horrific crime. An engaged parent, he served on education-related committees for the Township of South Orange and the School District of South Orange and Maplewood. Donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation (www.lustgarten.org).

A new business in the Flatiron district of Manhattan called General Assembly is not a university, but its founders hope it will seem like one. The 20,000-square-foot space offers desks, Internet access, classes and other services for entrepreneurs. ''We wanted to recreate the feeling of a college campus, '' said Adam Pritzker, one of the creators of the space. ''Something that was outside the structure of an institution but had the same academic tendencies.''

COWING--Evianne Muller. Peacefully at home on January 29. Economist, Banker and Realtor. Cherished mother of Grayson; loving wife of Chas. Survived by her parents Evie and Skip Muller. Services at 2pm Tuesday, February first, Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Cancer Center at Weill Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

MATTHEWS--William O'Connell, died peacefully at his home in Bronxville, NY on January 27, 2011. He was also a resident of Osterville, MA, and Palm Beach, FL. Bill was devoted to his faith and family. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years, Janet (Ross), two adoring children, Jennifer Matthews Frost of Bronxville, and her two children, Elizabeth M. Frost and Gerard G. Frost, III, and son William O. Matthews, Jr., and his wife Angela of Pacific Palisades, CA and their three sons, William O'Connell Matthews, III, Tristen V. Matthews, and Trevor C. Matthews. He is also survived by his sister Mary J. Matthews of Manhattan and several nieces and nephews. William is a direct descendant of Daniel O'Connell, the famed Irish Patriot and writer who served with distinction in the British House of Commons and for whom the O'Connell Bridge in Dublin is named. Born in Boston, Mr. Matthews joined the U.S. Navy, finished submarine school and served on the USS Spinax SS489. Upon completion of Naval service, he attended Boston College from which he graduated in 1955. Beginning his long and productive career in the investment business, Mr. Matthews joined Kidder, Peabody in Boston and later moved to Paine Webber before moving to New York where he held positions of increasing responsibility. He completed his distinguished career in 1998, retiring as a General Partner and Managing Director at SG Cowen & Company. Long a supporter of Boston College, Mr. Matthews donated a Student Lounge and a Computer Lab to graduate business school now called the Carroll School of Management. In addition, he was a major benefactor of the Irish Studies Program. Mr. Matthews was also generous with his time as a member of the Knights of Malta, and the Boston College Wall Street Council, which provides a wide range of scholarships. He was a long time member of the friendly Sons of St. Patrick as well as the Rotary Club of Bronxville. He was a long time member of the Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville; and the Oyster Harbors Club in Osterville and The Beach Club in Centerville, MA. In Palm Beach he was a benefactor of The Society of Four Arts, and also a member of The Beach Club and the Breakers Ocean Golf Club. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, 4 to 8pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's church, Bronxville, on Thursday February 3rd at 10am. A private burial will be held in Boston, MA. A memorial service is being planned in Osterville in the summer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, N.Y. 10707. www.jansenhospice.org

ABELES--Ilse F.,nee Echter, age 90, on January 27, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Hans Abeles, loving mother of Naomi (Jeffrey) Kraft and Terry Abeles, devoted grandmother to Marissa Kraft and Monika (Michael) Jaffe. Born in Mannheim, Germany she resided in Illinois and previously Yonkers, NY. A Memorial Service will be at held Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY on February 6 at 1pm.

BARZELAY--Muriel E.,died at home in Southampton, New York on January 26 at the age of 91, having chosen not to be treated for an advanced cancer that was diagnosed in November. She is survived by her son Douglas, of New York, and by her sister Elenore Freedman of Manchester, NH and her brother Dr. Robert Stein of Atlanta. A graduate of Radcliffe College, she was active in the reform political movement in Syracuse beginning in the 1950s and during the 1960s served as a Vice Chair of the New York State Democratic Party. While she maintained her interest in politics throughout her life, spent many happy hours tending her garden and also pursued a wide range of intellectual and artistic interests, family was the true center of her life. For 67 years she shared a devoted and loving partnership with her husband, Professor Martin E. Barzelay, until his death in 2009. She will be remembered not only for her strength of character and uncompromising intellect, but for also for her unceasing kindness and thoughtfulness. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY. A commemoration of her life will be held on Saturday, February 5 at 3pm at Parrish Memorial Hall, Southampton.
GREAVES--Jemima K. January 31, 1995. Passing years have not erased remembrance. Son Reynold and Family

JONES--Marian Page 98, devoted wife of Lendsey H. Jones, passed away on January 22, 2011, after a long illness. Beloved daughter of the late Howard W. Page and Carrie Poindexter of Washington, DC, via Richmond, VA. Cherished sister of the late Carrie Lewis of Washington, DC, and sister of the late Howard Page, Jr., and James Page also of Washington, DC. The aunt of Lola Colyar and Joyce Walker, and aunt of Howard Page, II, and James Page, Jr. Marian was a graduate of Virginia Union University of Richmond, VA. She received her Masters from the University of Michigan. She also did post graduate work at New York University. After graduation, she worked at several colleges including Virginia Union University and Morgan College in Baltimore, MD. She took leave of teaching and entered the entertainment world where she performed in both the United States and Canada. She later entered The New York School System where she retired as an Assistant Principal. She loved the theater where she put on plays both for the school and on and off Broadway. She was also very active in many other endeavors including the Barristers' Wives of New York and the N.B.A. Viewing will be held at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave. (141st Street), New York, Tuesday, February 1, 2011 from 4-8pm. Funeral Services will be held at the funeral home on Wednesday, February 2, 2011 at 10am.

BABBITT--Milton. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of our dear colleague, Milton Babbitt, a member of the composition faculty from 1971-2008. A person of encyclopedic knowledge, extraordianary wit, and profound artistic integrity, he guided generations of young composers and brought us all to a new understanding of the art of music. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and his many friends and colleagues. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost & Dean

A three-week excursion to India isn't exactly the standard for a holiday vacation. Yet Yuvi Alpert, one half of Ruby Kobo - a fine jewelry line specializing in "luxe bohemian" pieces (e.g., diamond-encrusted hamsas and antler tips) - spent his break roaming through the Rajasthan and Kerala districts, hitting two birds with one precious stone. Equipped with recommendations from his friend and fellow jeweler Waris Ahluwalia (of House of Waris), who has an office in Jaipur, Alpert turned a trip originally meant for business into one of eating, dancing and arts-and-craftsing. "We got to meet the actual artisans who are carefully handcrafting our next pieces out of tulsi wood, which was really great," Alpert says. "But one of the highlights of the trip was attending an extravagant, five-part Indian wedding. You don't really go to one of those too often - the food, the beautiful traditional costumes, the huge families. It was insane. The energy of the country is really inspiring." Alpert gives The Moment a glimpse into his adventures with a brief photo diary.

But in the hands of Camilla Morton, fairy tales are taking a very fashionable twist. "It all started when I was trying to explain my job to my godson," Morton says. "And, I realized when you watch a couture show come together - the drama, the glamour - you literally see magic." For "Christian Lacroix and the Tale of Sleeping Beauty," the first of what will be a series of fantasy designer biographies (Manolo Blahnik and the tale of the elves is up next), Morton has spun the story of Beauty, a starry-eyed princess condemned to wearing bland sack dresses.

Fifty-two games down, 30 to go, the All-Star break behind us and the final third of the regular season looming ahead. This is the time when the hockey gets serious and you start checking the standings -- the right time to look at how the Rangers are doing, man by man. Their official N.H.L. record is 29-20-3, which really means they're 29-23, but that's still a quite-good .558 winning percentage. Coach John Tortorella's team just might be going places, especially now that they're starting to get their injured forwards back (Ryan Callahan and Vinny Prospal are the first, with Brandon Dubinsky and Eric Christensen soon to follow). Tortorella's emphasis on conditioning has paid off in strong third-period performances (the Rangers lead the league in comeback wins with seven, two more than anyone else), and he has mellowed somewhat from the volcanic-tempered coach of the previous season.

"I always carry my iPhone, keys, credit card and some gloss," says Nicole Colovos, the co-designer for Helmut Lang. She and her husband, Michael, are gearing up for the first collection of bags to hit the stores since they took over the label in 2006. "We developed all new hardware and looked at bones and bird claws for inspiration and used hints of military finishes," Michael says. Available this month, the bags come in tough washed creta leather and smooth napa and have a whole lot of zippers. Styles range from duffels and messengers to clutches and pouchettes - just the right complement to their edgy-yet-polished motorcycle-jacket-and-skinny-leather-pants aesthetic. The Syn, a spiraling half-clutch/half-shoulder bag made from Perch skin, blends Michael's past as a commercial fisherman (straps have fisherman knots and braids) and Nicole's penchant for utilitarian dressing. "We wanted to create something sculptural, in an interesting fabrication, yet keep it functional," Nicole says. We couldn't ask for more. Except maybe a shoe collection. Hint, hint.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Sony NGP, a new hand-held device to be introduced by year's end, described one of its features incorrectly. It will have a 5-inch OLED screen, not an LED screen. (OLED, for organic light-emitting diode, uses organic compounds that emit light in response to an electric current.)

MAHON--Myra. The Board of Overseers, faculty and staff of Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the loss of our dear friend Myra Mahon. Myra, alongside her husband, Arthur, was a steadfast supporter of Weill Cornell and its mission for more than 20 years. A passionate advocate for patient education and women's health, she served as co-chair of our Women's Health Symposium Executive Steering Committee, co-chair of the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award Dinner and a member of the Executive Committee of the NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center's Lying-In Hospital. In 2007, the Medical College's Patient Resource Center was named in her honor, and a painting of her likeness in the Weill Greenberg Center will forever enshrine her memory. Generous, kind and committed to others, Myra was adored by everyone she knew. Our deepest condolences to her husband, Arthur, and their children Maura, Madonna, Arthur and Nancy. Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

ARNER--Leonard, oboist, of Fremont California, formerly of Leonia, New Jersey, on January 27, 2011 at age 87 after a long illness. Member of first graduating class of High School of Music and Art, attended The Juilliard School, graduated from Teachers College, Columbia University. Founding member, Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society. Former principal oboist, Buffalo Philharmonic, National Symphony Orchestra, St. Louis Symphony, Bell Telephone Hour, Symphony of the Air, New York City Opera Orchestra, Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra; also performed at Casals, Spoleto, Aspen, Marlboro festivals, and New School chamber music concerts with Alexander Schneider. Founder and director, Amadeus Ensemble. Taught at Queens College and Montclair State College School of Music. A rapier wit and consummate musical artist. Survived by wife Leah, daughter Jessica, son-in-law Eli Abbe, and his beloved grandchildren, Daniel and Rebecca Abbe. Contact family via Roller, Hapgood & Tinney, Palo Alto, CA, rht@rollerhapgoodtinney.com. Donations may be made to LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts and The Juilliard School.

SPORTS An article on Saturday previewing the Australian Open men's final between Andy Murray of Britain and Novak Djokovic of Serbia referred incorrectly to the significance of a victory by Murray. Had he won (he lost in straight sets), he would have been the first British man to win a Grand Slam title since Fred Perry, in 1936 -- not the first British player. (Several women have won Grand Slam titles since Perry -- most recently Virginia Wade at Wimbledon, in 1977.)

9 P.M. (National Geographic) HARD TIME A new season begins with ''The Hustle,'' which explores the underground prison economy -- an illegal system of barter and trade -- inside the Ross Correctional Institution in Chillicothe, Ohio. There, inmates have concocted a variety of money-making strategies to buy items like potato chips and brand-name shampoo at the commissary. Some work as tailors or tattoo artists to earn extra money; others act as lawyers for fellow inmates. (Above, David Applegate, an inmate, displays his tattoos.) The currency of choice: instant coffee. ''Prison City,'' a second episode at 10, interviews inmates at Ross who are using their sentences to prepare for life on the outside. Then there is David Stonestreet, who was sentenced as a teenager to 20 years to life for complicity to aggravated murder. Mr. Stonestreet, who has no hope of parole, has acknowledged his homosexuality and transformed into an alter ego, Twiggy. 8 P.M. (13) PIONEERS OF TELEVISION From ''Dragnet'' and ''The Untouchables'' to ''Mannix'' and ''Mission: Impossible,'' this episode plumbs the underworlds of crime dramas and some of the groundbreakers behind them. The list includes Jack Webb, Desi Arnaz, Bruce Geller, Bill Cosby, Angie Dickinson, Stefanie Powers (above, in ''The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.''), Barbara Bain, Martin Landau, James Garner and Peter Falk.

MAHON--Myra Ellen. Myra Ellen Mahon (nee Murphy) passed peacefully at home in Delray Beach, Florida, on Saturday, January 29, 2011, embraced and enveloped by the love and caring presence of her dear and cherished husband of 54 years, Arthur J. Mahon, and her four beloved children, Maura, Donna, Arthur and Nancy. Myra was also the dear Nana to her two grandchildren, Christopher and Emelia, and a wonderful mother-in-law to Susan who were holding her hand in spirit when she passed. Myra's date of passing was the Feast Day of Saint Thomas Aquinas, a day that her husband Arthur treasures and holds close to his heart, because on the day when he first met his beautiful, seventeen year-old wife-to-be at a Manhattan College dance, she told him she was reading the teachings of Saint Thomas Aquinas. Born in New York City on April 15, 1937 to James H. Murphy, from County Clare, and Mary Murphy (nee Caroon) from Westmeath, Ireland, Myra was always proud of, and true to, her roots in the Bronx and Ireland. She is predeceased by her parents, her deeply loved sister, Clare, and sisters-in-law, Mary Therese and Delia Rose. Her baby sister, Nula, who Myra loved dearly, survives her. Myra is also survived by her nieces, Maria O'Leary and Diane Slote, to whom she became a surrogate mother after their mothers' deaths, and by twenty other wonderful nieces and nephews from the Neil Mahon, Fitzpatrick, Burris, Thanhauser, and Slote families who were blessed to spend many weekends, Christmases, Thanksgivings, ski trips and also summers in Madison and Candlewood Lake, Connecticut, with their beautiful, generous, wise, funny and slightly irreverent Aunt Myra. A kid from Woodycrest Avenue in the Highbridge section of the Bronx, Myra lived from childhood with enormous intelligence, passion, elegance, conviction and concern for the underdog and the underserved. When the family moved to Queens, she attended St. Agnes High School in College Point. Married at the age of 20 to her love, Arthur, she returned to college as a young mother of four and graduated from Marymount, Tarrytown, summa cum laude as the valedictorian of her class, going on to earn her Masters in Social Work with high honors from Fordham University. Myra initiated her business career as a social worker at the United Way of Tristate in New York City, rising rapidly to Executive Vice President overseeing corporate partnerships and giving. She went on to become the Development Director of the Archdiocese of New York where she was fueled by her passion for raising funds for children to attend inner-city Catholic primary schools like the one she attended, Sacred Heart. An extraordinary team builder, mentor and leader, Myra took great joy and pride in the many people she worked alongside of, and she forever cherished their shared accomplishments and victories. Myra also lent her enormous energy and passion for social justice as a Member of the Board of Directors of a legion of wonderful organizations that embodied her unending commitment to giving all people the opportunity to live full, dignified and joyful lives. Those organizations included Marymount College, Women In Need, New York Foundation, Calvary Hospital and Hospice, New York State Parks and Recreation Commission, Museum of the City of New York and the Healthcare Chaplaincy. Myra took great joy serving for many years as the Co-Chair of the Women's Health Symposium at Weill Cornell Medical Center with her very dear friend and fellow New Yorker, Joan Weill. Myra was surprised five years ago when her loving husband, Arthur, told her that the second floor of the Weill Cornell Medical College's new building under construction at 1305 York Avenue in New York City would contain a resource center and it would be named in her honor. She was so pleased that the Myra Mahon Patient Resource Center included reading rooms and a library to help patients and families learn about and manage their illnesses. Upon its completion, Myra personally dedicated the Center "To those who serve unseen." Myra's immediate family and her personal assistant, Joan Hanebury, whom Myra loved dearly, attended a private memorial mass on Monday, January 31, 2011, at Holy Name of Jesus Church, Palm Beach, Florida, to honor and bless her memory. How appropriate and meaningful it is that Monday was the feast day of St. John Bosco, who dedicated his life to the education of poor children. There will be a mass celebrating Myra's life and all of her many loves, joys and accomplishments at Saint Patrick's Cathedral in New York City in the Spring. Donations in Myra's memory can be made to the Inner City Scholarship Fund of the Archdiocese of New York (Ms. Helen Lowe (212)371-1011, ext. 3325) for the Myra Mahon Fund for students at the Sacred Heart School in the Bronx, or to the Weill Cornell Medical College (Mr. Larry Schafer (212)746-4070) for the support of the Myra Mahon Patient Resource Center. Myra blessed the many people she loved with her warm spirit, endless wisdom, grace and intuitive gift for understanding and helping them. She leaves us with the memory of her sharing her favorite Irish prayer, "May the road rise up to meet you. May the wind always be at your back. May the sun shine warm upon your face, and rain fall soft upon your fields. And until we meet again, may God hold you in the hollow of His hand."

SCHAEFER--Clifford E. Schaefer, co-founder of Flying Cranes Antiques, Ltd., internationally recognized New York City firm for rare Meiji art, passed away on Thursday, January 20, 2011 at Weill Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. Always optimistic and courageous, Cliff had survived nine surgeries through the years, but this last one was impossible for survival, but one he underwent with his usual display of courage and hope. After graduating from Ohio State University in the 1950s, Cliff joined the Marines like his father before him. Initially a lieutenant, he became an intelligence officer soon after, serving in Alexandria and Camp LeJeune, NC. After a few years, following his stint in the Marines, he opened a busy office-machine business in Manhattan, his clients among the largest corporations in the city. During this time, he studied law during the evenings at Brooklyn Law and exhausted, he would joke, often missed his stop on the train during his late ride home. In the 1970s, when he and his wife, Jean, decided that country air would be a desired reprieve from the pace of city life, they rented a small cottage near Litchfield, CT. In order to furnish their new retreat, the country auction became a Saturday night ritual. Soon, all things Japanese became a specific lure and the country auction expanded to venues nationally and finally abroad. Collecting became a passion, the first interests, Japanese Hiradoware and cloisonne. Cliff's passion became an obsession and led eventually to the establishment of Flying Cranes Antiques. He and his wife opened their first gallery at The Manhattan Art & Antiques Center in New York City in 1985, followed by additional galleries in the same venue. It didn't take long for discriminating collectors, museums and royalty to become regular guests at the galleries. The obsession became total joy and encouraged the couple to travel and eventually to spend weekends at their new compound on a pristine lake in the mountains. Being addict collectors, soon Japanese landscaping, replete with koi pond, waterfall, rare shrubs, trees and rocks became the weekend focus, providing much pleasure from living among this Japanese-like extension of their life's work. A highly regarded London based Meiji art colleague described Cliff as, "An Immense character in the Japanese world and a wonderful promoter of the subject we both hold dear. His enthusiasm was entirely natural, as was his eye for the finest pieces in our field." Cliff will be remembered by all who knew him as a kind and generous man a devoted husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and the warmest friend. He had a lust for living, which he relished and lived to the fullest. So great was his zeal for collecting that during his last stay in hospital, an agent brought an item for him to see (before going to surgery) and his daughter photographed him handling the piece, which with excitement, he purchased right then and there. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about the downgrading of Japan's long-term sovereign debt by Standard & Poor's misstated the proportion of United States debt that is held by foreign investors. As in Japan, a majority of American debt is held domestically; it is not the case that most American debt is held by foreigners. (The Treasury estimates that foreigners own 47 percent of the outstanding Treasury debt not held by other American government agencies, like Federal Reserve and the Social Security Administration. If that debt to other government agencies is included, foreigners own 31 percent of the total.)

MAHON--Myra. The Women's Health Symposium Executive Steering Committee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Myra Mahon. She inspired all of us with her steadfast commitment to women's health, patient education and medicine, as well as her concern for the needs of patients and their families. Alongside her husband, Arthur Mahon, she established a legacy of charitable giving and was a tireless supporter of Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital. Her dedication to the advancement of women's health led her to serve as co-chair of the Women's Health Symposium Executive Steering Committee and co-chair of the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award Dinner, positions she held for more than a decade. Under her leadership, the annual Symposium educated hundreds of women about important health care issues and encouraged them to become their own health care advocates. We will miss our friend Myra -- her sound guidance, her beautiful smile, and most of all, her extraordinary compassion and kindness. Her passing leaves an emptiness in all of our hearts. Her outstanding contributions and enormous generosity will never be forgotten. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Mahon family, including her husband, Arthur, and her children Maura, Madonna, Arthur and Nancy. Joan Weill, Co-Chair The Women's Health Symposium Executive Steering Committee NewYork-Presbyerian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center

The new year has barely begun, but two big-event music festivals are already hits. Last week the Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., with Arcade Fire, Kanye West, Kings of Leon and the Strokes, sold out less than a week after going on sale. And by Monday all of the three-day passes for I'll Be Your Mirror, the new event in Asbury Park, N.J., presented by the people behind the All Tomorrow's Parties concerts, had sold out, three days after they went on sale. The two events are on very different scales. Coachella, which runs from April 15 to 17, sells tickets only for its full three-day run, and in the past its attendance has been in the neighborhood of 70,000 people per day. I'll Be Your Mirror, from Sept. 30 to Oct. 2, can hold a little more than 5,000 people in its two main theaters, and in addition to the 1,500 or so weekend passes that went on sale last week, single-day tickets are also available. (But they're said to be going fast too, particularly for the second day, featuring the British band Portishead; the opening night has a highly anticipated show by Jeff Mangum of the group Neutral Milk Hotel that is only open to people with full weekend passes.)

Manhattan Theater Club has added ''The Extinction Method,'' a new play by Daniel Goldfarb about two couples who live in adjacent Brooklyn apartments, to its season. Sam Buntrock, who received a Tony nomination for his revival of ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' will direct the production, which begins previews on May 10 and opens on May 25 at New York City Center - Stage I. Mr. Goldfarb is a regular at New York's nonprofit theaters. Manhattan Theater Club put on his ''Sarah, Sarah'' in 2004; his most recent play, ''The Retributionists,'' was done at Playwrights Horizons in 2009. He also co-wrote the book for Martin Short's Broadway musical ''Fame Becomes Me.''

GARFINKEL--Rubin. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourn the loss of Life Trustee Rubin Garfinkel. Mr. Garfinkel was a benefactor of LIJ Medical Center since its early days, and became a trustee of the hospital in 1960. His generosity over many decades helped fund numerous growth and development initiatives, enabling LIJ to become an outstanding health resource for the community. The Shirley & Rubin Garfinkel Patient Care Wing at LIJ is a testament to Mr. Garfinkel's dedication to ensuring that patients receive the best medical care possible. In addition, his support of continuing medical education enabled physicians to take advantage of learning opportunities without having to sacrifice time spent with patients. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Shirley. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chairman, North Shore-LIJ Health System

WASHINGTON - When David N. Miller joined the Treasury Department during the height of the financial crisis, the government's bailout programs weren't expected to break even, let alone turn a profit. But last week, the Treasury Department's sale of its warrants in Citigroup, the last of the government's stake in the firm, fetched $312.2 million, highlighting what has been a steady and, so far, profitable unwinding of taxpayers' holdings in financial institutions.

FIRESTONE--Mark. With great sadness, I announce the death of my husband, Mark Firestone. He succumbed after a lengthy struggle to cancer. He was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1923 and always cherished his heritage. He attended school in Switzerland, received his baccalaureate at the French Licee and after the war he continued his education at Rutgers University and finally his MBA at NYU. He was a gentleman of the Old School, learned and a linguist of nine languages and a lover of music and art. He experienced the Holocaust first hand as well as the landing at Normendy as a U.S. Soldier. He was a most loving father to his two special children, Rennie and Cathy as well my most devoted husband of 63 years. Family was everything to him. Mark with his father co-founded the Export Firm, The M. Firestone Company in 1946.

NOLAN--Charles, died peacefully at home January 30, at 53, with dignity and style. Born in Brooklyn and raised on Long Island, Charles was a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology and a member of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. He began his career working with Frank Tignino at Jerry Silverman, then with Bill Haire, and then Blassport among others...went on to design the Ellen Tracy collection and expose it to the international press...rejuvenated a bankrupt Anne Klein...left to join Howard Dean's campaign...and then launched his own line, which debuted in six full windows on Fifth Avenue at Saks. His particular passion was his own shop, in the Meatpacking District, on Gansevoort Street. His other passion: wonderful women. (The famous "kiss" at the 2000 Convention? Tipper was wearing Charles Nolan. Elaine Stritch at the Carlyle and on 30 Rock? Charles Nolan). He once successfully costumed Arianna Huffington on the fly as Queen Elizabeth, for a Renaissance Weekend skit, using only hotel tablecloths and a roll of tinfoil. Charles is survived by his father, Philip; his sisters Elizabeth, Joyce, Carola and Virginia; his brothers Philip, David, Kenneth, and Edward; his beloved nieces and nephews; his partner, Andrew Tobias; and his work, archived at charlesnolan.com. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday, February 1 from 6pm to 9pm, funeral service at Blessed Sacrament 11am Wednesday, February 2, 152 West 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Women in Need, 115 W. 31 St. New York City 10001.
