American Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall The American Symphony Or- chestra is known for its advocacy of neglected music, and on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, it presented what it said was the United States premiere of a century-old opera, Alberic Mag- nard's elegant, moving ''Beren- ice.'' Based on Racine's play about the Roman emperor Titus, who under public pressure sends away his beloved Berenice, the queen of Judea, to free himself for marriage to a native-born Roman, the opera is a little like ''Dido and Aeneas'' meets ''Madama Butter- fly.'' Magnard was an ardent Wag- nerian, and the slow-burning pas- sions and vivid orchestral colors of ''Berenice'' can resemble a lighter-textured, harmonically calmer ''Tristan und Isolde.'' In the wake of innovative works like Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' (1902) and Strauss's ''Salome'' (1905), ''Berenice,'' first per- formed in 1911, must have seemed tame, and it nearly vanished from the repertory. But it is involving, with Titus's indecision and Berenice's self-sacrificing dignity set to eloquent music that reflects the agonized but restrained emo- tions of Racinian style. The baritone Brian Mulligan was a vibrantly youthful Titus, and the bass Gregory Reinhart was imposing as his adviser Mucien. But Leon Botstein, the orchestra's music director, con- ducted rigidly, too rarely allowing Magnard's atmospheric score to breathe. And in the end, the opera de- pends most on a charismatic mez- zo-soprano in the title role, un- leashing rich floods of tone across a wide vocal and emotional range. While this Berenice, Michaela Martens was a sympathetic pres- ence, her voice tended to vanish and she never really commanded the stage. Still, even in an inconsistent performance, ''Berenice'' made an impression: an opera both self- consciously classical and unex- pectedly fresh. ZACHARY WOOLFE Ecstatic Music Festival Merkin Concert Hall As part of the Kaufman Cen- ter's Ecstatic Music Festival, the vibrant new-music orchestra Alarm Will Sound joined forces on Sunday afternoon with Face the Music, an ensemble of teenagers studying at the center's Special Music School. Face the Music, di- rected by Jennifer Undercofler, has given stunning performances in recent years, most notably a lively account of Terry Riley's ''In C'' as part of Make Music New York in 2009. This time, it began with two de- lightfully idiosyncratic post-Mini- malist works by Tristan Perich: ''Qsqsqsqsqsqsqsqqqqqqqqqqqq'' -- combining the tinkly timbres of toy pianos with Mr. Perich's bright-edged electronic sound -- and ''Interface,'' melding elec- tronics and a string quartet into something that sounds halfway between a harmonium and bag- pipes. Alarm Will Sound offered a quick overview of its current fas- cinations. Mostly that meant ar- rangements of electronica, includ- ing Preshish Moments's ''Why Do Birds,'' a parody of an old Car- penters recording, and Aphex Twin's percussion-and-brass- dominated ''Omgyjya Switch 7.'' Stefan Freund contributed ''kinda asleep,'' a sparkly ar- rangement from Matt Marks's ''Little Death: Vol. 1'' (both com- posers are players in the ensem- ble), but Alarm's most striking of- fering was Gavin Chuck's omi- nous orchestration of two move- ments (''Killshot'' and ''O God Protect Me'') from Ben Frost's ''By the Throat'' album. Together, Alarm Will Sound and instrumentalists and singers from Face the Music closed the concert with Steve Reich's ''Tehil- lim,'' in an occasionally muddy but generally spirited, often hard- driven performance conducted byAlan Pierson. ALLAN KOZINN

LOS ANGELES- There were no surprises in the movie categories at the Screen Actors Guild awards, which on Sunday night bestowed prizes on all the expected hopefuls: Melissa Leo and Christian Bale as best supporting actors in ''The Fighter;'' Natalie Portman as best actress for ''Black Swan;'' and Colin Firth as best actor for ''The King's Speech.'' That movie also picked up the group's version of best picture, the best ensemble prize. The Oscar chances for that British drama have improved in the last week, as it earned key honors from other industry groups, including the Directors Guild of America and the Producers Guild of America. (The winners of the Writers Guild of America, one of the last major Oscar indicators, will be announced in the next week.)

Our knowledge of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes troupe -- not the versions after his death in 1929 -- comes from texts, sketches, photographs and of course dances handed down over the years. But no film of a performance by the original company was thought to exist. Now a curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, where an exhibition on the company closed this month, has announced the discovery of less than a minute of performance footage on the Web site of the production house British Pathe. The site calls the clip ''Festival of Narcissus'' and describes ''one female dancer (representing Narcissus?) w/chorus of female dancers.'' Nowhere does it mention the Ballets Russes.
An article on Thursday about small-business incubators misidentified the North Carolina city in which one such incubator, Joystick Labs, is based. It is Durham, not Raleigh.

BURCH--Elliott, 86 of Portsmouth, RI and formerly of Garden City, NY died peacefully on January 29. Devoted and loving husband of the late Phyllis Hammond Burch and proud father of his daughter Jehanne Burch of Middletown, RI and three sons, Daniel and his wife Patricia of Manhasset, NY, and Richard and his wife Margaret of Charlotte, NC and the late William E. Burch of Garden City, NY. Elliott loved his four grandchildren Kathryn, Mackenzie, Charlotte and Olivia. Elliott trained thoroughbred race horses for over 30 years and was inducted into the National Thoroughbred Racing Horse Hall of Fame in 1980. He guided three horses Sword Dancer '59, Arts and letters '69 and Fort Marcy '70 to Horse of the Year honors and trained over sixty different stakes winners, winning three Belmont Stakes, and the Travers, Suburban, Woodward and Whitney four times each, and the Jockey Club Gold Cup twice. Graded Stakes winners also included Bowl of Flowers, Key to the Mint, Summer Guest, One on the Isle and Run the Gantlet. His father, Preston M. Burch, and grandfather, William P. Burch, were early inductees into the Hall of Fame. After serving in the Army Signal Corp. in WWII, Elliott began his career as a writer covering horse racing in Lexington, KY, he then joined his father in New York at Belmont Park to train thoroughbreds. He moved to Newport in 1988 and then to Middletown and finally Portsmouth, all on Aquidneck Island where he enjoyed living for the last 22 years. Friends and family are invited to calling hours on Thursday February 3 from 5-7 pm at the O'Neill-Hayes funeral home, 465 Spring Street, Newport. A Memorial Service will be held at the United Congregational Church, 524 Valley Road, Middletown on Saturday February 12 at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Newport Hospital or the National Museum of Racing in Saratoga Springs, NY at: www.racingmuseum.org.

Rakowich, left, the chief executive, and the AMB Property Corporation agreed to merge on Monday in a deal that would create a real estate company with a total market value of $24 billion. NATIONAL An article on Jan. 22 about a potential shortage of drugs used in executions referred incorrectly to Oregon's law governing the drug pentobarbital. It may be used in physician-assisted suicide -- not in euthanasia, which is illegal in Oregon.

WASHINGTON -- In his State of the Union address, President Obama proposed giving the nuclear construction business a type of help it has never had, a role in a quota for clean energy. But recent setbacks in a hoped-for ''nuclear renaissance'' raise questions about how much of a role nuclear power can play. Of four reactor projects identified by the Energy Department in 2009 as the most likely candidates for federal loan guarantees, only two are moving forward. At a third, in Calvert Cliffs, Md., there has been no public sign of progress since the lead partner withdrew in October and the other partner said it would seek a replacement.

Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Google's location-based social network. The musician who first took the stage of the Apollo Theater in Harlem as Little Stevie Wonder at age 12 in 1962 and then went on to some very big things will receive an  honor from the theater later this year. The Apollo is to announce on Wednesday that it will induct Mr. Wonder - he's just Stevie now, thank you very much - into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame. Mr. Wonder, the best-selling pop and soul artist whose albums include "Talking Book," "Innervisions" and "Songs in the Key of Life," was a child performer on Berry Gordy's Motown Revue when he made his Apollo debut, and returned several times to the theater for performances including its "Save the Apollo" concert in the 1980s and a series of solo shows in 2005, the theater's press representatives said. Other artists already named to the theater's Hall of Fame include Michael Jackson, Aretha Franklin, Quincy Jones, Smokey Robinson and Ella Fitzgerald. Mr. Wonder is to be officially inducted on June 13 at the Apollo's annual spring gala.
